His address at the last Convocation, in sounding a note of warning as regards the financial outlook of the University, appealed to local beneficence and patriotism for the endowment of Chairs in the University, and it is to be hoped that a fitting response will be forthcoming to an appeal so frank and convincing. Several endowments were acknowledged by my predecessor last year. Three more endowments call for notice, one by Rao Bahadur M.C. Rangaiengar, one by the Bhabha Memorial Fund Committee, and the third by the now defunct Mysore Branch of the National Indian Association received through Rao Bahadur M.C. Rangaiengar. The University is deeply grateful to the donors for their valued contributions.

It gives me great pleasure now to address a few words to the students assembled at this Convocation. You who have been called by your Alma Mater to receive her benedictions, to my first greeting to you is in the words of the poet "My heart is at your festival." I congratulate you on your personal triumphs and success. I congratulate you still more because you live in stirring times. It has been your lot to live through the greatest War in History, through a world-cataclysm which has changed the face of things on this globe for all time. "One hour of crowded glorious life is worth an age without a name." The great War has been even more fatal to all half-truths and makebelieves, to patched-up virtues and soft glossings, than any of the great Religions of Mankind. And young as you are, the Psychology of War and of the after-math of War, has profoundly affected the perspective of youth. The "vision splendid" in you has assumed a sober colouring from man's mortality, and your ears have heard the song of the Fates, above the roar and tumult of the world!

For many of you, for most of you, questions of personal happiness and unhappiness are beside the mark to-day. With your motherland in a devastating conflagration, in the throes of a mighty convulsion which has broken up her peaceful and ordered progress, you are burning with a passion for you know not what. a passion of selfimmolation in some glorious cause. Nothing external has happened to you, but of a sudden you feel that the world has changed its face! there suddenly start up around you enveloping mists and dazzling glories, angelic choirs and dreadful silences. You, young men, are those of whom it was foretold: your young men shall dream dreams. They are those who live in Messianic times, for whom the faroff divine event comes and stands greeting at the door. That event and those times do not bring glad tidings. Most often, they are times of tribulation and of darkness, but a divine madness fills them. I read signs of that enthusiasm in your hungry eyes. I will not summon you to the bar of Reason, and arraign your Hope of visionariness and your Love of blindness. Love is apt to be blind,﻿ and Hope is always enchanted. But I call you, children of Bharatavarsha, to a larger Hope, and a diviner Love. That Hope shall make you free as the Truth alone can make you free, and that Love shall be Wisdom.

But first let me speak to you of the other love, which possesses with something of a demoniac possession: the love of your country, the love of Freedom. What is your country? What is your Freedom?

I will answer for you. Your country is Bharata, but Bharata is not, has never been, confined within territorial bounds. Brahma is the true country of the Spirit: that has been India's claim through the ages! And Brahmavarta, Aryavarta, Bharatavarsha, Jumbudvipa,in extending circles, the country of the Spirit has ever moved forward: it has had territorial embodiments, but no territorial limits. The visible country is but a symbol of the cosmos, the visible History is but a moment in Eternity. You cannot be true to your country if your vision should be so blurred as to barter the cosmic and the eternal for a place in or out of the British Empire, or, for that matter, for the dominion of the Earth. You belong to &tradition and a race that carried with it the original home, Brahma or Brahmavarta, in its march, its migrations, its settlements. Do not sell that birthright for a mess of pottage. Claim the entire world as your own. Wherever the Atman reveals itself you have your country and countrymen; wherever the Atman is dishonoured, you are ousted and dishonoureda Correct therefore your country's true standpoint. Political,﻿ national, territorial organizations and delimitations, the historic passion and patriotism, are all very real, and must be accepted as a working arrangement, but not unto blindness and obsession, unto hate or fury, unto the self-alienation of the Spirit. India, this Greater India, which has no bounds or confines, calls to you as your patria eterna. May this Sanatana Bharata, your Eternal country, represent through you, her sons, in the Leagues and Councils of the World, the idea of this extra-territorial nationality, this extra-territorial sovereignty, which the creed of Buddha, the Enlightened and the Enlightener, first preached to the world: A Buddhist Sloka given by Aryadeva, the itinerant Buddhist preacher, to the masses exhorts the sovereigns of the world to follow the Code of Dharma without territorial limits, a Code of Laws which places the good of other States and peoples in the same category with that of their own. See that you are not betrayed into any obsession of hate which makes you unfit to be Servants of this Greater India, in whose name you must go forth to the nations of the world. It is a name which unites,- for the follower of the Prophet will recognize herein the advent of his Islam, the Peace of God, and the follower of the Son of Man the advent of the promised Kingdom of God.

Unites! For it is the one great law of Personality in the individual as in the group or mass: Each can realize himself only by helping others to realize themselves. And this law implies the converse each can help others to realize themselves, only if he seeks to realize himself. Each in all, and all in each! For it is the Great Being, Universal Humanity, or as others would have it, the Great God, who is being accomplished and fulfilled in every man, woman and child, individually as well as collectively. Doing or suffering, enjoying or enjoyed, we are His hands and His feet, His eyes and His mouths. The weakness of one is the weakness of all, the strength of one is the strength of all. Victory is mine, saith the Lord; defeat is inine, saith His Consort of the Infinite Compassion!

And seek not the lesser Freedom, but first the Greater Freedom which embraces all lesser privileges and franchises. Be free of the Commonwealth, not merely of the Federation of the British Empire or of the WorldFederation when it comes, but also of this your true country, the Country of the Spirit. Remember you are citizens of no mean city, not of Benares, not of Delhi, not of Rome, those eternal cities of the East or the West that come on the tidal waves of History and are borne away by that tide, but of the Eternal City that sits enthroned in the Brahman above the uproar and the tumult of Man in his generations!﻿

Address delivered at the Convocation of the University of Mysore on 4th October by Munir-ul-Talim H.J. Bhabha, M.A.

MAY IT PLEASE YOUR HIGHNESS, MEMBERS OF THE SENATE, LADIES AND GENTLEMEN,

I esteem it a great honour and privilege to be invited from my seclusion to deliver an address before this Convocation. The higher the honour the greater is my diffidence to appear before you after the eminent educationists who have given excellent addresses on previous occasions. I fear I was somewhat hasty when I accepted the invitation from a sense of duty to obey His Highness the Chancellor's wish which was to me a command rather than from any exaggerated feeling of self-esteem. I have put together a few thoughts that have struck me from a distance, for the expression of which I beseech your kind indulgence.

When shortly after my retirement from the Educational Department, over which I had the honour to preside for a period of twenty years, it was decided to estalish the University of Mysore, I heard the news with feelings of great gratification. That the department which had been built up with strenuous exertion for a long series of years was to be crowned by a University naturally filled my﻿ heart with joy and pride. The wisdom of having a University of our own which had long been looked forward to cannot be doubted. The Colleges which had been affiliated to a distant Univesity naturally would benefit the most by the establishment of a local University of which they would be integral parts, and in the management of which they > would have a leading part. The curricula and schemes of examinations instead of being super-imposed by a distant and sometimes unsympathetic body would be arranged to their own satisfaction by the local Professors on well-thought outlines. It is a great thing for a people to have a Teaching University of their own in direct sympathy with their wants and aspirations, so that they may have the kind of education they esteem most advantageous to their interests. No system of education can flourish so well as that which satisfies the needs and wishes of the people. Such a Teaching University does away with the disadvantages of external examinations and brings students and professors into intimate connection, so that cramming of the worst kind is effectively discouraged and real progress and scholarly knowledge are encouraged, while at the same time physical education and the training of character are attended to with great care. The University of Mysore, though it cannot strike out any great departures from the beaten track of older Universities, will be free to encourage the study of Kannada, Sanskrit and Persian in a satisfactory way, to foster the growth and publication of a modern Kannada literature without﻿ which the education of a whole people cannot proceed, to promote the study of such new objects and provide such practical training as may satisfy the aspirations of the people and suit their economic and social needs, to form sehemes of its economic and social needs, to form schemes of its own of female education and oriental learning, and to arouse patriotic love within the hearts of the people for a system of education which is under their own control. There is further no agency so powerful as a local University for extra-mural instruction, for not merely organizing what are called Extension Lectures but regular schemes for adult education for giving instruction up to the level of University standards to people whom circumstances have not permitted to acquire higher education but who have the desire and ability to profit by it. These are no small advantages, and that they are now available to the people of this State presages a bright educational future for them.

The Mysore State has always been distinguished for its earnestness and liberality in promoting education. No Native State or Provincial Government in India has been able to spare such a large proportion of its revenues for education as the Mysore State. This is hardly a place for giving comparative statistics, but your Educational Department can easily prove that the proportion of total revenues spent on Education in Mysore is the highest of any province in India, though it may be much lower than in the advanced countries of Europe and America, and in Japan. In an advanced State like Mysore a University﻿ was bound to come, and though some publicists may be tempted to be critical and look askance at the commencement, when in a short time it has proved its great usefulness, it will disarm all criticism and ungenerous comments.

One of the principal advantages of having a Teaching University of our own is to have a full-time Vice-Chancellor who watches over the instruction and discipline of the students, their physical welfare, their corporate life and intimate connection with their Professors. I may be excused however if I refer, for a moment, to a possible danger, though it should be very unlikely, of the sense of responsibility of the Heads and Professors of Colleges getting weakened for the maintenance of discipline and the training of character. The authorities of a college should be solely and wholly responsible for the internal discipline of a college, and the bonds between the Professors and pupils should in no case get weakened. It is the personality of the teacher that, exercises the most potent influence over the character and manners as well as the intellect of the pupil. It would be a misfortune if this influence became less for any reason.

It is often asked what is a University and what are its functions. Cardinal Newman in his eloquent language gives a definition which can bear repetition:

"If I were asked to describe as briefly and popularly as I could what a University was, I should draw my answer from its ancient designation of a Studium Generale, or 'School of Universal Learning'. This description implies﻿ the assemblage of strangers from all parts in one spot from all parts; else, how will you find professors and students · for every department of knowledge? and in one spot; else, how can there by any school at all? Accordingly, in its simple and rudimental form, it is a school of knowledge of every kind, consisting of teachers and learners from every quarter. Many things are requisite to complete and satisfy the idea embodied in this description; but such as this a University seems to be in its essence, a place for the communication and circulation of thought, by means of personal intercourse, through a wide extent of country.... A University is the place to which a thousand schools make contributions; in which the intellect may safely range and speculate, sure to find its equal in some antagonist activity, and its judge in the tribunal of truth. It is a place where inquiry is pushed forward, and discoveries verified and perfected, and rashness rendered innocuous, and error exposed, by the collision of mind with mind, and knowledge with knowledge. It is the place where the Professor becomes eloquent, and is a missionary and a preacher, displaying his science in its most complete and most winning form, pouring it forth with the zeal of enthusiasm, and lighting up his own love of it in the breasts of his hearers. It is the place where the catechist makes good the ground as he goes, treading in the truth day by day into the ready memory, and wedging and tightening it into the expanding reason. It is a place which wins the admiration of the young by its celebrity, kindles the﻿ affections of the middle-aged by its beauty, and rivets the fidelity of the old by its associations. It is a seat of wisdom, a light of the world, a minister of the faith, an Alma Mater of the rising generation. It is this and a great deal more and demands a somewhat better head and hand than mine to describe it well."

Although in the above definition a University is defined as Studium Generale, that is, a School of Universal Learning, it does not follow that every University should teach every subject. The expanse of knowledge is so wide, the number of sciences and their sub-divisions is so large that it is impossible for any University in the world to attempt to teach them all, and the resources of no State would suffice to maintain such a University. For a new University like Mysore, which is not endowed but is maintained wholly by the State, it is safest to limit its functions at first to an irreducible minimum of subjects. We must have Languages and their Literatures; in our case English, Sanskrit, Persian, Kannada, other Vernaculars and French; we must have History, both Ancient and Modern, Philosophy, Mathematics, and Physics and Chemistry. We have already in addition to this irreducible minimum of subjects Economics, Commerce, Engineering and the natural sciences of Geology and Botany.

It is no doubt, a disadvantage that the departments of Science and the Humanities in the Mysore University are placed at a great distance from one another and constant intercourse between students of both departments is not﻿ possible. There is no advantage so great in a University as the constant interchange of thought between students of Science and Engineering on the one hand and those of Literature, Philosophy and History on the other. A means of lessening this disadvantage is to bring about friendly meetings in rival contests of games, debates, lectures, and social gatherings. A social week in Bangalore and another in Mysore in different parts of the year for the students of both sections would combine pleasure with instruction. Such interchange of ideas removes narrowmindedness, broadens the intellectual outlook, and produces a real world of culture and liberal learning.

Everywhere the addition of new subjects to the programme of studies depends on various circumstances, on geographical position, on a donor appearing with a handsome endowment, on an eminent teacher rising in our midst to whom students flock in large numbers and who can lead them on to advanced studies and research. As for endowments India is essentially a poor country, and we have hardly any Rockfellers or Carnegies among us. The Calcutta University is the only University in India which has been fortunate enough under the enthusiastic advocacy of Sir Asutosh Mookerjee to obtain large endowments from leaders of the bar and from Zemindars of Bangal. Even Bombay with its merchant princes has not shown yet anything more than a long list of scholarships and prizes as Mysore has already begun to show. But scholarships and prizes are not endowments for chairs, laboratories and﻿ libraries. Until the endowments come the expansion of the University has to wait, unless the State can, without injury to other interests, spare more funds and can take up the additional burden. But when they come sooner or later as they are bound to do in the case of Universities admittedly doing good work, the choice of new subjects will depend upon various circumstances, geographical, economical and social. In the case, however, of subjects like mining and metallurgy it would perhaps be more advantageous to found scholarships to enable selected students eto go to well-equipped European Universities of established reputation in the teaching of mining and metallurgy like Birmingham, Manchester, Sheffield, or to America than to have costly technological departments of our own. Agriculture and the sugar industry which are of great importance to the country should claim the first attention and also suitable subjects of applied chemistry like the chemistry of fats and oils, lac industry, of dyes, gums, resins and varnishes, etc. With the Indian Institute of Science close at hand which is handsomely aided by the Mysore State, important help can always be obtained in technological subjects from that Institute which is being re-organized at present on improved lines.

Before the further addition of other faculties and subjects to be taught by the University is discussed, it is to be hoped that the question of having honours courses separate from those of the ordinary degree in Arts and Science will be taken up in eamest. I believe it has﻿ been to some extent already discussed. But unless a clear distinction is made between the courses for an ordinary degree and those for an honours degree, the student of exceptional talents will not be distinguished from another of average abilities, nor can the former be encouraged to do his best without such differentiation. Such a want of opportunity to excel given to students of excellent abilities is so much loss to the University and the country. The Madras University has set a most admirable example by providing honours courses which may be followed in Mysore. Moreover, research work and training in the methods of research are the most important functions of a University which are best carried out when there are honours courses.

Though the number of faculties and subjects may perforce have to be limited in a young University, what is perhaps the most important aspect of University education must not be undervalued or forgotten. University teaching especially in a unitary University like Mysore exercises a most powerful influence on the character and manners of the students. It is the character-forming influence of University education which is perhaps its most valuable part. A student may not on leaving the University find lucrative work which will rapidly advance his material interests, but his help and company will be sought after as of one who can always be relied upon, whose character is unimpeachable, whose lofty aims, self-sacrifice and readiness to help his neighbours and hatred of all meanness distinguish him from his less fortunate brethern. A residential and﻿ unitary University gives such scope to high-minded professors and tutors for the exercise of elevating influence on their pupils' character and manners as cannot be found in any other educational institution. These influences exercised in an unobtrusive way leave a stamp on the mind and manners of young men which lasts a life-time. It is in the University that young men have an opportunity of learning industrious and persevering habits, and that intense love of work which ensures their success in life. It is in the University that they receive those humanizing influences which broaden their outlook on life, and give such an insight into human nature as renders them worthy leaders of men in future. The material result of University education at the commencement of life may be small, but their moral elevation is their best reward. I am glad to say that the educated Mysorean is already making a good name for himself in other parts of the country. Respectful, obedient and of gentle manners he has by this keen sense of duty and devotion to work already won golden opionions wherever he has found work..

There is no doubt that our educated men have often long to wait for adequate recognition of their merits from a material point of view in a poor country like India. The number of careers open to the best products of University education in India compared to those open to similar men in more advanced countries are, it must be admitted, very few, and cause anxiety to them and their parents who at great sacrifice have given them higher education. Until﻿ the economic state of the country improves by the development of trade and industries, the opportunities of fairly remunerative employment will, I fear, remain limited. The University cannot increase these opportunities. It can only help to a limited extent by shaping its courses of instruction so that they may suit the nature of employment in trade and industry. While a highly educated Englishman can find a career in the Church or the Army or in the higher administrative branches of the public service both at home and abroad, Indian youths have no similar openings. The higher grades of Engineering, Medical and Civil Services are in British India mostly filled by Englishmen. In an enlightened Native State like Mysore, however, the higher grades of service are happily open to Indians of high education, but the number of well-paid posts is necessarily limited in the State. The only careers usually open to an ordinary graduate are the lower grades of the Civil and Administrative services, at the bar, and in the Judicial, Public Works, Medical and Educational Departments, and in other kinds of work which require literary ability and high character.

In industrial concerns there is a popular prejudice, which is often justified by facts, that a highly educated man is unpractical and not suitable for employment. Want of manual training in the education received at school is often his misfortune. A natural or inherited dislike of practical work which requires the ready use of hands is a great hindrance to admission to the avenues of industry, Unless such a man begins his career on the lowest rung﻿ of the ladder, he gets no chance of rising in industrial pursuits. But when once he has established his footing he can rise rapidly by his intelligence, ability and character above a number of ill-educated competitors. It is false pride often to refuse to make a modest beginning. Most young men have to learn that though they may be trained in theoretical science, in all industries requiring practical skill they have to commence work low down in a factory The scientific training gives him an advantage over uneducated workmen, and he understands the reason of every process and can use his resourcefulness in time of need, he rapidly proves his superiority and may rise in a short time to the highest controlling post from very modest beginnings. This is a lesson in life which most of our educated men ambitious of a practical career have yet to learn.

Distinguished students in Europe and America on completing their courses of higher engineering studies at a University find it necessary to pay high premia of two to three hundred pounds a year for two or three years in order to apprentice themselves in great engineering or manufacturing works to acquire practical experience, and in such works they commence in the lowest grade and rise step by step through all the stages of work. It is such men that achieve success in their profession. During this apprenticeship they are subjected to severe discipline and have to obey the orders of their superiors implicitly although these orders may have the appearance of being﻿ inconsistent with the theoretical teaching they have had at College. They also learn how to handle labour as they rise to positions of responsibility, in which they have to control the actions of other workmen, and at the same 2 time they acquire tact in dealing with their associates as well as their superiors. A man who is always at variance with his colleagues cannot be chosen by his superiors to fill positions of trust and responsibility. It will thus be seen how essential practical training is and how a successful industrialist should acquire all these practical e qualifications after completing his theoretical course. It is true that great Engineering Works are few in number in India and earnest students may have to go to Europe or America for such apprenticeship. But the best use should be made of the existing works in India.

What is true of engineering students is also true of scientific students who are eager to rise in industrial pursuits. And the same thing is imutatis mutandis true of the literary scholars turned out by the University. They have to commence life in these days of keen competition in humble positions in the hope of future advancement unless they are blessed with meanse which make them independent. The struggle in life is growing on every side and in a poor country like India it is at its worst.

I refer to the difficulties of finding a ready career immediately after completing a course of University education, even in the case of those who have gone through a highly scientific training, not with any idea of discouraging the﻿ students but only as a warning against possible disappointment, and to invite attention to remedies or rather palliative measures under the existing circumstances. There is nowhere in India such eager desire to obtain the highest education obtainable as there is among the people of Mysore, because the intellectual classes have no other avenue to success in life except through higher education. Mysore being an inland Province has hardly any commerce, all its trade being an exchange of its raw products with neighbouring parts for what is necessary to supply its limited wants. Industries have not been developed and the country on the whole is poor, and its, wants are few. Under such circumstances higher education is the only resort of ambitious young men. The lure of higher education attracts all men that possess some ability, and consequently there is a tremendous rush of students knocking at the door of the University for admission. The numbers of students in the Maharaja's College and the Central College which were 275 and 313 in 1916-17 have risen in five years to 518 and 359 respectively, the admission into the science classes of the Central College being necessarily restricted on account of the limited accommodation for practical work in the laboratories. The strength of the Engineering College which was 45 in 1917-18 has increased in the short space of four years to 156 in 1921-22. The Entrance Examination of the Mysore University was held for the first time in 1917 when the number of candidates was 244 of whom 120 were declared to have passed. The corresponding figures in 1921 were 1,029 and 287. If the increase proceeds at the present rate, it will soon become impossible to give admission to even half the number seeking it. It might be of use to inquire what remedies or palliatives can be found for the present state of things. One way would be to add to the number of Faculties by adding Medicine and Law as soon as may be convenient. The Medical Colleges of other parts of India are already unable to admit Mysorean students as all their available accommodation s. required for local men. How far funds would be available for such expansion of the work of the University is a question for the administrative authorities of the State to solve. In considering the answer to this question it will have to be borne in mind that all departments of education, University, High, Middle and Primary, should proceed with equal step, no one department being favoured at the cost of the others. Another and perhaps more effective remedy would be to turn the present Collegiate High Schools into Intermediate Colleges by adding one more year to the course of study in the Collegiate Schools. The Intermediate Colleges would be formed of four classes, the present fifth and sixth forms and two College classes. The Entrance Examination would mark the completion of the Intermediate College course, while the S.S.L.C. Ex-, amination would mark the completion of the course ending with the sixth form. When the Intermediate Colleges are formed it should be possible to start alternative classes from the fifth form upwards, three periods in the morning being devoted to such cultural subjects as are necessary for all pupils, and the whole afternoon being devoted in the case of some pupils to academical subjects and in the case of others to special or vocational subjects and workshop practice, which would fit the pupils •for practical work and a career in life without having to proceed to the University. Such alternative subjects might be various, and should include agriculture the chief industry of India, mechanical and civil engineering in their lower branches, training for a lower teacher's diploma than the B.T. Degree, domestic science for girls, commercial training, training for telegraphists and for police duty, etc. The number of vocational subjects may be increased from time to time as need is felt. As many of the vocational courses of the Intermediate Colleges may be co-ordinated with higher University teaching as possible, to encourage a few select lads to proceed to the University if they are deserving. Such co-ordination would be easy to make when there are Colleges of University status teaching the same subjects. Thus the Intermediate Colleges would provide education for a large number of young men who have not the abilities or the means of proceeding to the University but prefer to go into active life from the Intermediate College or High School. Along with the formation and expansion of Technical Instruction with graded institutions from Taluk and District schools to a Technological Institute, in which whole-time instruction is given in technical subjects with workshop practice, may be instituted. To work out schemes of this kind will require time, experience and a heavy outlay. Yet it is worth while by offering alternative courses to boys of average abilities to check the present rush to the University and reserve University Education for young men of the highest capacities and for those who desire high education in cultural subjects, and have independent means and leisure.

Similarly for women a graded scheme in subjects of domestic science from middle schools upwards to the University can be arranged. Your learned Vice-Chancellor referred to this subject in his address last year. It would be wrong to consider that subjects of domestic science are not worthy of taking a place in University education. When it is considered that women's chief function in life is that of maker of the home and man's chief happiness is found in a well-ordered home, any teaching which fits a woman to be a model wife and mother would be welcomed by Indian women who are unsurpassed in dovotion to their duties. The humbler duties of cookery and laundry work may be taught in middle schools for girls by practical lessons while subjects like 'hygiene, home-nursing and economics, etc., may be taught in Girls' High Schools. In the University a higher course worthy of it can be arranged for women in select portions of applied chemistry, sanitary science, applied hygiene. bacteriology, general biology, and physics with practical demonstrations and experiments, in economics of the household, in general and child psychology and ethics. There is quite enough of cultural and scientific﻿ training for women in a course like this to make it equal to an advanced course for men. A department for the education of women built up gradually from below is what is wanted for giving an impetus and right direction to women's education in Mysore. When the Maharani's College was started forty years ago by a few enthusiasts there were hardly two or three good middle schools for girls in the Province. Its establishment was evidently much too premature.

Graduates of the Mysore University of 1922, I congratulate you on your success in the University examinations and hope and trust that it will be a precursor of equally great success in life. You have received an education, which is second to none obtainable in India, by the enlightened liberality of His Highness the Maharaja. You have given proofs of your industry and more than average abilities by passing your examinations. The culture and the training of character you have received will make you useful and enlightened subjects of His Highness, and I hope you will make worthy use of your opportunities in a way that will reflect credit on your University. You have taken a solemn obligation to-day to uphold and advance social order and the well-being of your fellow-men. This is a comprehensive obligation. Your first duty is to be hearty and firm in your loyalty to your' Maharaja and the State that have done so much for your enlightenment, culture and happiness. If the spirit of unrest that has spread to a considerable extent in other parts of India find entrance into the State,﻿ it will be your duty to fight against it and prevent it from contaminating the ingenuous minds of the people of this Province. And further it is your duty to preach and implant in the minds of all Mysoreans loyalty to the suzerain power under whose protection and by whose generous guidance and help the State that has educated you has flourished But you have sworn also to uphold and advance social order and well-being of your fellow-men. By your education you will be centres of light wherever fortune may place you. You have knowledge, your judgement has been cultivated, and you are able to decide what is right from what is wrong, what is proper from what is improper. You have also under the humanising influences of the University leamt to sympathize with your less fortunate brethern, to understand their weaknesses and deficiencies and appreciate their just hopes and aspirations. It will be your duty to guide them by your wisdom, and help them by your knowledge to fulfil their righteous aspirations. You will see around you a vast amount of ignorance, prejudice and blind adherence to long-established usage which may have had a justification in ages long gone by, but which cannot suit the presnt enlightened times. It will be your duty with your wider knowledge and keener judgement to lead he blind and the ignorant into the right path and persuade them to adopt reforms that would increase their happiness. You should make the cause of popular education your own, and give your personal help in spreading Primary education among children and especially in helping the cause of adult education among the people around you. On local and municipal boards your active work will be required. By your generous sympathies and help you can bring enlightenment into many dark nooks, and happiness into the lives of your unfortunate fellow-men. For these unselfish services the State that has educated you has claims upon you, and you will increase your own happiness by performing them. Your joy and satisfaction in helping others will make you happier. In whatever you do always entertain high motives, suppress ungenerous and mean feelings, and be always ready to render service to others, while not neglecting your own interests or those of the people nearest you. I wish you all success and prosperity in your future life.

May this University flourish for ever.﻿

Address delivered at the Convocation of the University of Mysore on 24th October, 1923 by Sir P.S. Sivaswamy Aiyar, K.C.S.I., C.I.E.

YOUR HIGHNESS, MR. VICE-CHANCELLOR, LADIES AND GENTLEMEN,

When the gracious wish of His Highness the Maharaja was conveyed to me that I should deliver the customary address on this occasion, I felt it to be my duty to comply with the request of a prince whom I have had the honour and privilege of knowing for several years and for whom I cherish feelings of high esteem and admiration as the enlightened ruler of a model State and for his virtues alike in public and private life. While I am deeply sensible of the honour conferred by the Maharaja's choice, I am even more sensible of its onerous character and of the difficulties of the task. The topics covered by a Convocation address are more or less hackneyed and it is hardly possible to discover any topics which have not already been dwelt upon in this University or in the sister Universities of India. The rule of your University which requires an address suitable to the occasion is somewhat different in its terms from the rule of the Madras University which prescribes that the address should exhort the graduates to conduct themselves suitably unto the position to which they have attained by their respective degrees. I have﻿ no qualifications or experience as an educational expert. My only claim to a hearing is my connection with the Madras University for a period of twenty years and a year's connection with the Hindu University of Benares and the interest which I have naturally taken in university affairs. I shall therefore avail myself of the latitude of your rule and claim your indulgence in the observations I am about to make.

At the time when the Government of Mysore decided to sever the affiliation of its colleges to the University of Madras and found a university of its own, I happened to be the Vice-Chancellor of the Madras University. There were doubts and misgivings in some quarters as to the preparedness of Mysore for an independent university of its own, but I never entertained any such doubts or misgivings myself and was optimistic about its success. Apart from the question as to the suitability of the affiliating type of university and apart from the question whether the Madras University had changed its character at all even in respect of the colleges situate within the metropolitan area, I had long entertained the conviction that a single university for the whole of the area comprised within the jurisdiction of the Madras University was too unwieldy for the purposes of the examining type and too inadequate for the purposes of the teaching type. Judging with reference to the area of Southern India, the strength of its population and the languages spoken by it and considering the provision for university education in Western countries, there could﻿ be no question as to the desirability, nay the necessity, of having several universities in place of one. The only limitations upon the creation of new universities, whether of a regional type or of a more comprehensive character, are those imposed by finance, or the available supply of cultured men to participate in and carry on the administration of the university. While difficulties of this character form insuperable impediments to the creation of new universities in the Madras Presidency, there was no reason to apprehend that they would constitute a serious obstacle to a university located in the headquarters of the premier Indian State in Southern India. The example of Mysore and the policy of the new Madras University Act have set the Travancore Government seriously thinking of the formation of a university to subserve the needs of the Kerala region. There is reason to hope that the University of Travancore may also come into existence in the near future.

The reasons for the multiplication of universities are the extension of educational facilities and the adaptation of the character of education to the varying requirements and ideals of different regions. In bringing the University of Mysore into existence it was the intention of your Government not to reproduce the pattern of the University of Madras to which the colleges were affiliated but to start a residential and teaching university with special features of its own. The payment of greater attention to the vernaculars, the promotion of the corporate life of the university, the institution of extension lectures and of a Publication Bureau were﻿ intended to be some of the new features of your university. The reduction of the university course by a year and the corresponding extension of the high school course by a year was one of the important features of this university. In introducing this change this university anticipated in some measure one of the important recommendations of the Calcutta University Commission. One of the main defects noticed by the. Sadler Commission in the system of high school education in India was that the course of instruction provided in the secondary schools was an inadequate foundation for the university and that the Intermediate classes of the colleges were making an inefficient attempt to supplement the instruction provided by the secondary schools. They recommended that this duty of supplementing the instruction furnished by the secondary schools should be transferred to Intermediate colleges and that the length of the ordinary degree course of the university should be reduced to three years. In providing for a year's course in your collegiate high schools as a preparation for entrance to the university the object evidently has been to maintain the length of the period required for the university degree at four years from the completion of the secondary school course. Judging from our experience of the secondary schools and Arts colleges in Madras, the recommendation of the Sadler Commission appeared to me to be thoroughly justified, even though it increased the length of the period required for﻿ an ordinary degree to five years. In view of the unsatisfactory nature of the training afforded by our secondary schools and in view also of the fact that the Intermediate course is a preparation and a starting point for several professional courses, the course of two years at an Intermediate college or institution would appear none too long for the purpose it is intended to fulfil. The experience of Mysore with regard to the working and results of the collegiate school course must be of considerable value and interest to the educational authorities in the Madras Presidency and other parts of British India. In regard to the other objects set forth as the special features of the University, I presume that they are being attained in gradually increasing measure. There is evidence of original work being done both in the Science Department and in the Department of Kannada Literature and the activities of the Publication Bureau seem to have been maintained, notwithstanding the restriction imposed by temporary financial stringency. The number of students on the rolls of university colleges during the last year is said to have been a little over a thousand. The deficiency in the strength of the colleges as compared with those in Madras need not cause any dissatisfaction, as it permits of greater attention to individual students and closer personal intimacy between the teaching staff and the students. The success of the university is not to be judged by the numbers of its students or merely by the results of the public examinations. Quality, not quantity, should be the aim of all genuine university work.﻿

The facile task of suggesting new lines of activity and new developments is superfluous in the case of a university under the guidance of a distinguished and versatile scholar like your Vice-Chancellor who is thoroughly familiar with the requirements and ideals of modem universities. The task would also be otiose, as all ambitious schemes are stranded on the shoals of finance. Many things might be suggested in the way of opening new professional colleges, new departments of the Arts and Science Faculties, art schools, art galleries and museums, providing facilities for research work in various departments, popularizing knowledge by courses of extension lectures and publishing original works and translations. But. all such schemes are severely limited by financial considerations and I have no doubt that the Government of this state would only be too glad to initiate new lines of work if they were in a position to provide more funds. The expenditure on university education by the Government of Mysore in proportion to its finances is perhaps too low. There are no theoretical limits to the expenditure of money on university education. The authorities of the University of Liverpool with their annual income and expenditure of over £230,000 complain of inadequacy of funds. The University of Chicago spends over 3 million dollars a year and the Harvard University which spends more than 5 million dollars per annum would like to spend much more. Before starting work on new fields it would be rather desirable to consolidate the work already undertaken in the different branches of learning﻿ in which university education is now provided and see that the institutions now in existence discharge their functions as efficiently as possible. It is only six years since the University was started, but short as the period may be, there is no ground for dissatisfaction with the work so far accomplished. Our opinion as to the progress in education made in this country must necessarily be determined by the ideals we entertain as to the purpose of education. I doubt whether there has been really any serious difference of opinion on this point among the people or between the Government and the people. The ideals of a course of university education must be to train the mind, character and physique of the students, so that they may develop their faculties to the fullest extent, to impart culture and breadth of outlook, to inculcate patriotism and the duties of citizenship, to enable them to raise the level of national efficiency and national welfare and to contribute to the advancement of knowledge. These ideals may or may not have been realized by our universities. The methods pursued may have been faulty and the objects may have been but very imperfectly attained. The political ferment in India has directed men's attention to the question of education among others and the desire for national education has often taken curious shapes and led to a movement for a boycott of schools and colleges maintained or supported by the Government. There can be no doubt that the movement has been inspired rather by a destructive spirit than by any sound conception of the aims and methods of education.

﻿

education is so large that it cannot possibly be solved except by the use of State funds. There need be no qualms of conscience about resort to institutions maintained or supported by the State when the funds are raised by taxation from the people themselves. As put by a recent nationalist writer on this subject, "Is it the language which is the medium of instruction which makes it national or the agency through which it is imparted or the agency which controls and regulates it or the books which are taught or the standards and ideals which underlie it?" If the level of national efficiency and well-being is to be raised, India cannot afford to cut herself adrift from the currents of modern thought and modern science and knowledge and the only sane course for her is to follow the example of the most powerful nation in the East and to learn and assimilate all that is good and worth knowing in the culture and civilization of the West. In the words of the writer already referred to, "It will be folly and madness to try to discourage the study and dissemination of European languages, European literatures and European sciences in India." Nor can India afford to resort to womout methods of education which, whatever value they might have possessed in ancient times, are no longer suitable to the new conditions. There are many among our people who consider that our schools and colleges are too expensive institutions for a poor country and that a reversion to the methods of the ancient pathasalas is necessary. Far be it from me to deny the good features of the old system of instruction by the guru to the chelas in his own house or in the village. But let us see what the old method involved. Taking, for instance, the life laid down by Apastambha for a student, it was a life of more than Spartan severity, of asceticism and aloofness from the world. The mind of the student was looked upon as a wayward thing to be crushed by an iron discipline and drilled into conformity rather than as a tender plant requiring the most genial surroundings and influences for its nurture and growth. The psychological problems of the juvenile mind were unknown and the theory of education was that knowledge should be poured into the mind to be retained and reproduced when necessary. As a preparation for the world and the struggles of life, and its temptations and dangers, as a means of cultivating initiative, resourcefulness and a spirit of enterprise, as an instrument of education in the amenities of social life and the knowledge of human nature, the system was bound to fail. The value of the moral discipline it imparted was discounted by the fact that it was adapted not to the ordinary surroundings of society in which the student would have to play a part in after-life but a highly artificial surroundings of a monastic character. The classical story of Rishyasringa who succumbed to temptation at the first contact with the world of realities is an excellent illustration of the liability to a breakdown of the moral discipline enforced by the old system. Can there be any doubt that the English public school produces a much more virile character, with habits of self-reliance and independence﻿ or that it instils the spirit of patriotism, or promotes a love of sports and athletics and a spirit of adventure and of courage, or equips the students with a considerable knowledge of human nature and society. The Gurukula at Kangri is perhaps the only institution which is modelled upon the old system of guru and chela and which also seeks to impart some of the elements of Western knowledge. But to the extent that it enforces monastic ideals, it must be held that the training given by the institution is illadapted to modern conditions of life. That some of the objects aimed at by the Gurukula system are worthy of praise cannot be denied. I am aware that the Gurukula at Kangri has elicited tributes of appreciation from various quarters, European and Indian, as an attempt to preserve what is good in the ancient methods of education. The spirit of reverence and devotion to the teacher, the vow of chastity, the love of simplicity and the habit of selfcontrol are traits worthy of admiration, but we must not suppose that these virtues cannot be adquired in schools conducted according to Western methods or acquired at too heavy a price. Even taking the ancient ideals of education at their best, it may fairly be said that their tendency on the whole was the promotion of respect for authority rather than the encouragement of intellectual freedom. We know that in the field of metaphysical speculation no country in the world has produced more independent and fearless thinkers than India. We know also that even in the case of the Vedas, the infallibility of which is an article﻿ of creed in the orthodox world, they have been eviscerated by interpretation by the Mimamsakas on the one hand and by the Vedantins on the other, till we have only a shell of formal ritualism and a nucleus of a Parabrahma left behind. Generalization has its dangers but very genera statement must be understood subject to qualification. There can be no doubt in the mind of an impartial investigator, that the inculcation of submission to authority is a characteristic of the national system of education in India. In fact, it is one of the precepts to be observed by a pupil that he should not contradict his teacher.

The sphere of education is not the only one in which there is a conflict between the ideals of the old world and those of the modern. In many an other department of our social and intellectual life there is a similar conflict of ideals between the East and the West. Conflicts of this character between old and new ideals, between authority and freedom, between religion and science are not peculiar to this country. They have been experienced in the West also and they have been or are being solved in some way satisfactory or otherwise. The peculiarity about the conflict of ideals in the mind of the educated Indian of the present day is that it is not a case of collision between ideas of the same or similar national origin, but a collision between the indigenous culture of the land and the foreien culture of the West. Patriotic, historical and evolutional considerations enter the arena and affect the issue. The complete adoption of the Western ideal looks like treachery to one's own country and disloyalty to the spirit of the nation and of the past. On the other hand, a stolid adherence to old ideals and a refusal to assimilate what is best in the culture of the West is a handicap in the struggle for existence. Some adjustment is obviously necessary between the old and the new ideas if we are to adapt ourselves to the changed conditions of the world and maintain our national individuality. Not merely is such adjustment necessary in the interests of our national progress, but it is equally required in the interests of individual happiness and peace of mind. Even among the educated classes, there are some who give no thought to the claims of these divergent ideals, who are assailed by no doubts as to the wisdom of the past and who fail to realize the demands of the present. A spirit of placid conservatism is the attitude of one section of our countrymen. A contemptuous disregard for the past and an unqualified admiration for the whole and every item of Western civilization is the attitude of another section. Yet another section leads a life of double personality, leading two parallel lives without feeling the necessity for any logical coherence of beliefs. It was remarked of a certain class of persons by Herbert Spencer that when they entered their oratory they closed the door of their laboratory and when they entered their laboratory they closed the door of their oratory. There are, however, large numbers of us who feel the force of the impact between the old and new ideas and the only solution which is practicable is for each one of us to attempt a synthesis to the best of our lights between the divergent ideals, to follow a policy of eclecticism and pick up whatever is best in the culture of the East and of the West and is best calculated to improve the efficiency of the nation and the happiness of its citizens. In illustration of my remarks, I may be permitted to refer to a few such cases of divergence between the old and the new ideals. Let us take, for instance, the ideals of marriage in ancient India at their best and the relations between the husband and the wife. Marriages were settled for the bridegroom: and the bride and the choice of the parties themselves counted for little or nothing. Exceptions were no doubt allowed in the case of the Kshatriyas who were permitted to contract a marriage in the Gandharva form, but the ordinary rule was for the parents to choose and for the children to accept the decision. This practice has continued to the present day and the objectionable features have assumed much larger dimensions. With the growing practice of postponing the age of marriage both on account of the difficulty of securing bridegrooms and the growing desire to give some education to girls, it is obvious that the wishes of the parties themselves to a marriage must be allowed a very much larger share in the transaction, even if they are not allowed to become the decisive factor. Take again the duties of the wife to the husband as laid down in our epics and in the Dharma Shastras. The husband, was the lord and master, if not also a God to his wife and even a wife like Sita was said to have followed her﻿ husband as his shadow. However flattering and acceptable the ideal may be to the majority of the male sex, is it likely to be acceptable to the educated woman anxious to secure opportunities for self-realization and development, who cannot blind herself 'to the faults and the defects of her husband and is unable to detect any presence of the divine element in him and recognizes perhaps all too painfully that he is a mere man with perhaps more than his share of the faults of his sex? Is not the ideal of a partnership on equal terms more consistent with the dignity of woman, more conducive to mutual esteem and good-will and domestic happiness and more likely to be in accord with the changing conditions of the future?

Let us turn again to the question of filial obedience. No nobler picture of filial obedience has ever been conceived than that of Rama who undertook an exile to the forest for a term of fourteen years to enable his old father to redeem a thoughtless promise made to a young wife. As a Hindu myself I feel fascinated by the picture and feel that no true Hindu can resist the appeal of this charming picture. I know also that our literature loves to teach Dharma by the use of hyperbolic stories; but is it an ideal which is practicable at the present time, or can it be laid down that it is the duty of a son to obey every unreasonable wish of his father, provided it is not sinful? We have another illustration of an extreme case in the story of Parasurama who beheaded his mother at the instance of his father, because she had admired the passing form﻿ of a Gandharva. Let us take again the old ideal of a Hindu joint family with the mutual obligations of the members to support each other and the training it afforded in habits of altruism and its comparative disregard of the rights of the female members of the family. To some, it may appear as a satisfactory compromise between extreme individualism and the communistic principle. On the other hand, is not the Dayabhaga system of law which abolishes survivorship a more satisfactory scheme and is it not better adapted to modern conditions? Turning to the political sphere, is not the theory of the divine right of the sovereign which is laid down in our Dharma Shastra and which has been asserted or recognized in other countries as well, an outworn fiction which can no longer serve any purpose in advanced countries?

Passing from the question of the double personality in the mental sphere of the educated Hindu, let us cast a glance at the double life led by many an Indian inside his home and outside. There is a want of accord between the ideas and beliefs of the educated Indian and those of his womenfolk. Inside his house he leads a life of conformity to traditional practices and observances which have lost their meaning for him but still retain a hold on the women. He acquiesces with an air partly of amusement and partly of resignation, in their forms of worship, in their religious ceremonies and in their methods of nursing and bringing up children. He lacks the pleasures of intellectual companionship, but he sometimes feels that his women﻿ are the sanctuary of his religion and that they make up by their faith and devotion for his own want of religion, or of conformity. He has a vague fear that the idyllic atmosphere of his home may be disturbed by female education, but however charming it may be, it is rather an atmosphere of racial childhood. There is no other way to get rid of this double life than by the education of women, not necessarily on identical lines with that for men (except, of course, for those who intend to follow the learned professions), but on lines more appropriate to the sphere of their duties and functions at home and in society. The alteration required in the higher educational courses for women will, I hope, engage the early attention of this University if it has not already done so. The defects in the existing system of education have all been pointed out in the Report of the Calcutta University Commission, a mine of educational experience and wisdom and and the suggestions for improvement which it contains are practically applicable to the universities of Southeren Indian quite as much as to Calcutta.

One of the important functions of a university is the advancement of knowledge by the encouragement of original research. The only university which has so far provided facilties for research is the University of Calcutta. Thanks to the energy, zeal and far-sighted and broadminded patriotism of Sir Asutosh Mukherji, the University of Calcutta has made provision for an elaborate scheme of post-graduate studies in a variety of subjects and the University College of Science has won a name for itself in the scientific world by the contributions of its professors and advanced students who are all Indians. In Mysore you possess the inestimable advantage of the best-equipped institute of science in the whole of India and graduates of Mysore who have got an aptitude for research can avail themselves of the facilities of the Indian Institute of Science. The addition of new departments to this Institute cannot be beyond the resources of the authorities now co-operating in its mainteance and it may perhaps be a satisfactory and less expensive alternative to the university undertaking the encouragement of scientific research entirely on its own account. Whether there are any administrative or other obstacles to such a course, I do not know. Let us hope that the Iron Works at Bhadravati will prove a successful venture and create a demand for experts in mining and metallurgy and that the increased prosperity of the finances of Mysore will enable the Government to establish technical colleges in mining and metallurgy as well as other subjects of a regional character.

Attached to the University of Madras, training corps have been formed both in Madras and in Trichinopoly as part of the scheme of the Indian Territorial Force. The advisability of forming a similar university training corps in Bangalore and Mysore may well be considered by the Government, more especially as the presence of a large military force in Bangalore, with its complement of officers should facilitate the necessary arrangements for instruction and training.﻿

Of those who have taken your degrees to-day, some will probably think of prosecuting further studies of a specialized character, either with a view to acquiring professional knowledge or with a view to the attainment of a higher standard of knowledge in subjects already studied by you. Others will probably be obliged to think of some career and earn their living. Some of you, at any rate, may have discovered your special aptitudes and directed your studies accordingly and I hope you will all succeed in the careers to which you may be called. But whatever may be your special callings, you will have to discharge your duties as citizens of the State. Opportunities for participation in public life are daily expanding, whether in the sphere of local or central government, both in Mysore and in British India. The Constitutional Reforms which have been foreshadowed by His Highness' Government will open more largely the avenues of political life. The satisfactory discharge of your duties to the State requires the formation of sound opinion on public questions and the proper guidance of public opinion. Constitutional advances in the direction of popular government require and pre-suppose the education of public opinion. The average elector in any country and still more in India is seldom sufficiently educated to form his own independent opinion on matters of public concern without assistance from those who are better qualified. If he is literate, he takes his opinions from the newspapers which fall into his hands. If he is illiterate, he has to depend upon the speeches of politicians which are open﻿ to his literate brethren also and upon second-hand accounts of the contents of newspapers. Opinions are largely swayed by the impressions received from these sources and by class or party interests. The responsibility of guiding public opinion which rests upon politicians and journalists can be adequately discharged only, if they make an honest and impartial endeavour to arrive at correct conclusions and in the interests of the country at large. Careful study of the question or policy at issue in all its bearings and the dispassionate examination of the arguments on one side and the other, and an honest attempt to understand the views of those who differ from you are the necessary preliminaries to a balanced judgement. The cultivation of a judicial frame of mind is essential to the formation of correct opinion, though it may disqualify you to some extent for partisanship. It may be urged that cultivation of the virtue of sobriety of judgement may result in loss of driving power and render a man unfit for participation in party struggles whether as a leader or as a follower. The party system is an unavoidable and essential feature of the system of parliamentary government and it may also at times prove necessary as a preparation for the development of the parliamentary system. But even in this view the formation of sound opinions is not a superfluity, which can be dispensed with. The interests of the State will be better served, if opinions are carefully formed and compromises are subsequently adopted in so far as they may be necessary for the reconcilement of divergent interests﻿ or for carrying through measures of great importance. This is not the place or the time to go into any detailed discussion of the ethics of the party system, the exigencies of parliamentary government, or the extent to which an honest politician may agree to a compromise. Conceding that a certain degree of narrowness of vision is necessary to make a successful party politician, which do you consider should give more satisfaction, the consciouness of having endeavoured to serve the country or to serve the party?

Another piece of advice which I may give you is the necessity in political or other spheres of public life of division of labour and concentration of your attention and efforts upon particular subjects. If you are a member of a political body, it will not be possible for you to acquire a mastery of all the subjects that may engage the: attention of that body. If you are a public worker in the sphere of social welfare, it will not be possible for you to take equally active part in all social movements. While you may be ready to help many causes with your vote or your purse, you can acquire a close familiarity only with some of them. Division of labour is the essential condition of success in many spheres besides, the economic.

Turning to the general public life of the country, one cannot help noticing with regret the signs of discord between rival creeds and communities and the bitterness of animosity which has been aroused in different parts of the country. The unity which was supposed to have been brought about between the Hindus and the Mussalmans﻿ three or four years ago rested upon the artificial foundation of a common hatred of British rule. A real rapprochment between the two great communities can only be achieved by an understanding and appreciation of each other's views and wishes and a spirit of mutual compromise and mutual reassurance. It is a remarkable and gratifying circumstance that violent disputes between rival creeds are of comparatively rare occurrence in the territories of the Indian princes. The causes of this happy state of affairs deserve study. Inter-communal differences unfortunately flourish even in your Province and it will be the duty of the educated classes to find ways and means of composing or reducing these differences as far as possible. In the Report on Constitutional Reforms in Mysore a device has been suggested in the method of representation of the interests of minorities with the object of attaining this end. Should this experiment be sanctioned the working of it will be watched with interest in British India and its results may prove of value to us. Your political problems are not exactly of the same character as those in British India. While there must be several common features, you must not lose sight of one fundamental difference between the conditions here and those in British India. The ruler and the subjects belong to the same race here and your progress will not be retarded by external influences having their origin in vested interests or in any want of insight and sympathy.

Graduates of the University of Mysore, the degrees conferred upon you to-day are a recognition of your successful﻿ completion of a course of liberal education, but they do not mark the close of your education. This is a process which you have to carry on through life on the foundations laid here. Your Alma Mater is still very young, but is none the less entitled to your affection and reverence. The life you will lead, the ideals you entertain, the service you render to your fellow-citizens and to the State will help to form traditions, which will bring credit to your University and will be cherished by your successors. In return for the benefits you have received from the University you owe her an obligation to advance the cause of learning and education. Do not allow your bread-winning pursuits on of your activities or to absorb all your time and thoughts. Let your ideals be a pure and unsullied life with noble aims and a wise harmony of plan, an unabating ardour for knowledge, the cultivation of varied intellectual interests and the uplift of your country Disappointments there may be in the attainment of the objects we set before ourselves in life, but the consciousness of having striven for high ideals must bring a compensating measure of happiness. No higher ideal of culture, accomplishments, chivalry or service to the country has been conceived than that embodied by the first of Aryan poets in his pictures of Sri Rama. It is a most beautiful conception to my mind of perfect character or divinity as embodied in humanity. I have referred to Valmiki because I am more familiar with his work. But such ideals have their counterparts in other great religions also. Go forth into the world with the most cordial wishes of the University for your future welfare. May the Almighty shower His choicest blessings on you all and may the University of Mysore steadily expand its mission and its influence and take root in the affections of the people.﻿

Address delivered at the Convocation of the University of Mysore by Dr. Annie Besant,D.L., on 29th October,1924

MAY IT PLEASE YOUR HIGHNESS : YOUR HIGHNESS, LADIES AND GENTLEMEN,

It is impossible for me to stand here to deliver the Convocation Address before the Chancellor and the University of Mysore, the first University founded in our own time by an Indian Ruler for the benefit of his people, without remembering that in the past of India the greatest and wisest of her monarchs found in the promotion of learning their noblest and most beneficent achievement, and saw in the foundation of a university the most enduring memorial of their thrones. Learning in India has ever been regarded as greater than wealth and rank, the fillet of wisdom as more worthy of reverence than the jewelled diadem of kings.

Who does not remember how the famous Madura Sangam, as highest honour, tied round the head of a greatly learned man a fillet-like the laurel crown of Greece-placed him on a platform supported on poles, borne on the shoulders of men of learning, sometimes a king among them, and carried him in procession along the royal roads? In these days in which Indian women are recovering their ancient position, it may be worth while to note that not only do we come across the names of learned women, but that, as Professor S. Krishnaswami Aiyangar tells us:

A ruler of Tanjore, poet, musician, warrior and administrator, did extraordinary honour to a lady of the Court by name Ramachandramba, who composed an epic on the achievements of her patron, Raghunatha Nayaka of Tanjore. It appears she was a poetess of extraordinary powers, who could compose with equal facility in eight languages, and was accorded the honour of Kanakaratna Abhisheka (bath in gold and gems). She was, by assent of the Court, made to occupy the position of the "Emperor of learning," Kavita Sarvabhauma. *

That such honour was no ephemeral thing in India we may see if we recall the scene in the Royal University of Vikramasila, ten centuries later (founded by King Dharmapala of Gauda). When the University had gathered together to lend their Principal to Tibet, to bring about a revival of Buddhism there, the Tibetan envoy describes the waiting, and is eager to see the Sage, and he enquires whether one venerable Lama after another is not he. The Raja came "and took an exalted seat," but no monk rose to greet him. "When all the seats were filled up, there came Jovo Atisa, the Venerable of venerables, in all his glory, at whose sight the eyes felt no satiety."**

Thoroughly do I believe the maxim, spoken by Professor Sidgwick to his University undergraduates: "If you would know what England can do, you must know what England has done in the past." To you I would say: "If you would know what India can do, you must know what India has done in the past." You have here, in the shaping, a young University, to bę moulded by Indian Ruler and Indian men of learning into what shape they will. Will you, I venture to ask you, make it only a copy, an imitation of Western Universities, or will you lift your eyes to the universities born on the Indian soil, breathing the Indian air, nourished by Indian traditions, and then set an example so inspiring that every great Indian State shall follow the example that you set, the example of the Ashramas and Sangams of the Hindu, the Viharas of the Buddhist. the Madrasahs of the Muslims?

Even in such a record as The Encylopaedia Britannica, may be found an acknowledgment of the value of indigenous education in India, though not recording the splendour of its achievements. After mentioning the fact that "the existing system of education in India is mainly dependent upon the Government, being directly organized by the State, at least in its higher departments," the writer proceeds:

At no period of its history has India been an altogether unenlightned country. The origin of the Deva-Nagari alphabet is lost in antiquity, though that is generally admitted not to be of indigenous invention. Inscriptions on stone and copper, the palmleaf records of the temples, and, in later days, the widespread manufacture of paper, all alike indicate not only the general knowledge, but also the common use of the art of writing. From the earliest times the caste of Brahmanas has preserved,﻿ by oral tradition as well as in manuscripts, a literature unrivalled alike in its antiquity and in the intellectual-subtlety of its contents. The Muhammadan invaders introduced the profession of the historian, which reached a high degree of excellence, even as compared with contemporary Europe. Through all changes of Government vernacular instruction in its simplest form has always been given, at least to the children of respectable classes, in every large village. On the one hand, the Toles, or seminaries for teaching Sanskrit philosophy at Benares and Nadiya, recall the schools of Athens and Alexandria; on the other, the importance attached to instruction in accounts reminds us of the picture which Herace has left of a Roman education. Even at the present day, knowledge of reading and writing is, owing to the teaching of Buddhist monks, as widely diffused throughout Burzaa as it is in some countries of Europe. English efforts to stimulate education have ever been most successful, when based upon the existing indigenous institutions.*

This is too much forgotten. Therefore, I ask you to wander with me for a short space in the forests of the Ashramas, the exquisite gardens of the Viharas, and let us see whether they do not present something that we may learn to utilize. We may consider the higher education in Ancient, Middle and Modern India, the Vaidic, the Buddhistic and the Muslim periods.

Dr. Rabindranath Tagore has, in his Tapovana, striking passage on learning in Ancient India:

A most wonderful thing that we notice in India is, that here the forest, not the town, is the fountain head of all its civilization.

Wherever, in India, its earliest and most wonderful manifestations are noticed, we find that men have not come into such close contact as to be rolled or fused into a compact mass. There, trees and plante, rivers and lakes, had ample opportunity to live in close relationship with men.

In these forests, though there was human society, "there was enough of open space, of dloofness; there was no jostling. Still, this aloofness did not produce inertness in the Indian mind; rather it rendered it all the brighter. It is the forest, that has nurtured the two great Ancient Ages of India, the Vaidic and the Budhistic.

As did the Vaidic Rishis, Lord Buddha also showered His teaching in many woods > of India. The royal palace had no room for Him, it is the forest that took Him into its lap. The current of civilization that flowed from its forests inundated the whole of India.*

The Hindu Age

It may be pointed out that the supreme literature of India, the Upanishads and the Brahma Sutras, are said to have been taught by sages and studied by reverent pupils, in these forest depths. For that supreme literature cannot be understood in its deepest meanings except with the aid of meditation and the discipline of the Raja Yoga. A teacher would give an aphorism, say, to his pupil, and send him away to meditate on it, and to bring back the result to him, when he had reached a definite understanding thereof.
