I see before me deployed the youthful mind at the end of a golden quinquennium of glowing hopes and generous enthusiasms. Youth must speak to Youth, like Deep calling unto Deep! Youth must be its own Guide for the future which belongs to Youth, in the﻿ light of its own lamps. Be ye lamps unto yourselves', as the Buddha enjoins, the Lamps which are your own

The first of your Lamps is the Lamp of subjectivity, freedom from the tyranny, the iron grip, of the hard facts and realities of life. Youth dares to be free. The iron has not yet entered into its soul.

The second Lamp of Youth is its romance, its exalted sensibility, its bursting freshness and variety. The flame of life burns intense, white and pure, on the altar of youth.

Its third Lamp is its creativeness, its power of conjuring up a world of its own. Youth's alchemy transmutes the basest metal into its own gold.

Its fourth Pradipa is its invincible optimism, its perennial spring of joy and song, of hope and adventure. Youth, like a thing of beauty, is a joy for ever. Youth has climbed Everest, has traversed Darkest Africa and reached the Poles, dived into the bottomless sea, and has glimpsed the secrets of the moon and the stars.

And the fifth Lamp of Pañchapradipa Youth is its sense of immortality, of an inextinguishable, irrepressible life. A thing of Palpitating life, what should it know of death?

May I also end this exhortation to my youthful audience by reminding them of the following meaningful lines of Shelley, the Poet of Youth?

" I slept and dreamt that Life is beauty;
I woke and saw that Life is duty.”﻿

Youth lays the foundation of its future in its Brahmacharya based on the Triple Vow of Chastity, Poverty, and Labour : Vow of Purity in body, mind, and speech , Vow of Poverty in abstention from luxuries; and Vow of Labour in menial service to the Guru-Kula and the Student-Brotherhood, taking charge of its house-hold economy, and even begging for its maintenance.

Every educated Indian must next be the torchbearer of India's Learning and Culture as so aptly symbolised in our National Flag on which the figure of the wheel is the Dharma Chukri, the kingdom of Righteousness, Rūmarujya, as Gandhiji would say, the Rule of Right which was inaugurated by the great Buddha by his first discourse delivered at Sarnath, known as Dharma-Chakra-PravartanaSatra. The Dharma-Chakra is a secular State in the sense that it does not stand for any particular Dharma or religion of its own but for the Dharma that is universal, the principles of Morality which are acceptable and applicable to entire mankind. The Dharma-Chakra thus points to the moral foundations of the so-called secular State.

Let me now conclude with the pregnant words addressed by the teacher to his parting pupils, as stated in the Taittiriya Upanishad:

Practise ye Truth, Duty, Study and Teaching ! Don't giv: in to lethargy, but exert ye for your own welfare and prosperity! Revere ye as thy God thy Father and Mother, "Preceptor, and also thy Guest as a symbol of humanity : Practise ye charity in a spirit of esteem. Give according to your means in all﻿ humility, and in a spirit of friendship: And offer ye to thy Alma Mater suitable gifts in return for what you owe Her:

सत्यं वद । धर्मं चर। स्वाध्यायान्न प्रमदितव्यम् । प्रवचनान्न प्रमदितव्यम् । आचार्याय प्रियं धनमाहृत्य . . . .

सत्यान्न प्रमदितव्यम् । स्वाध्याय-प्रवचनाभ्यां न प्रमदितव्यम् । कुशलाद्भूत्यै न प्रमदितव्यम् । मातृदेवो भव । पितृदेवो भव । आचार्यदेवो भव । अतिथिदेवो भव। श्रद्धया देयम् । श्रिया देयम् । ह्रिया देयम् । भिया देयम् । संविदा देयम् ।

Lay to heart also the Message of Lord Buddha wishing godspeed to his disciples : Go ye forth, ye monks, on your daily rounds, ministering to the welfare of the people, promoting their good and Happiness dedicating yourselves to the service of God and Man.

चरथ भिक्खवे चारिकम् ।
बहुजनहिताय बहुजन सुखाय
अत्थाय हिताय सुखाय
देवमनुस्सानम् ।(विनय पिटक–महावग्ग)

Let our young hopefuls be inspired by the message of that master-mind, Max Muller, on the abiding value of India's Culture :-

“If I were to look over the whole world to find out the country most richly endowed with all the wealth, power and beauty that Nature can bestow in some parts a very paradise on earth---I should point to India. If I were asked under what sky the human mind has most fully developed some of its choicest gifts, has most﻿ deeply pondered on the greatest problems of life, and has found solutions of some of them, which well deserve the attention even of those who have studied Plato and Kant--I should point to India. And if I were to ask myself from what literature we, here in Europe, we who have been nurtured almost exclusively on the thoughts of Greeks and Romans, and of one Semitic race, the Jewish, may draw that corrective which is most wanted in order to make our inner life more perfect, more comprehensive, more universal, in fact more truly human, a life, not for this life only, but a transfigured and eternal life again I should point to India.”

Let us recapture this potent heritage of Indian Thought and Life by which we may overcome the menace of this Atomic Age. Scientists have discovered means by which life itself may be wiped off the surface of this planet. They have for the time being released the tremendous destructive power inherent in Matter, which can only be controlled now by the power of the Spirit for which India has stood through the ages. The Spirit of Man is his only hope in this Cosmic Dance of Death, It alone stands between us and a lifeless globe, and will yet enable Man to master Matter and solve this central, universal problem of saving the race from extinction.

This dangerous international situation has been graphically described by President Eisenhower as presenting two Atomic Colossi who are doomed﻿ malevolently to eye each other indefinitely across a trembling world." Will mankind be condemned to begin all over again the age-old struggle upward from savagery toward decency, right and justice?

Summary of the Address delivered in Kannada at the
Mysore University Convocation on 10th December
1956 by Shri R. R. Diwakar, Governor of Bihar.

YOUR HIGHNESS, MR. VICE-CHANCELLOR, MEMBERS
OF THE SENATE, AND MY DEAR GRADUATES,

I AM grateful to the authorities of this famed 1 University for having done me the honour of inviting me to deliver the Convocation Address of this year. Well-known scholars and savants. have preceded me year after year in delivering Convocation Addresses to the new graduates. In that galaxy I could have no place except by the great goodwill you have shown towards me. I do not possess any of their qualifications to perform this august function. But I am sure that you will credit me with a sincerity which inspires me to say a few words on this occasion.

This is an occasion of varied significance to many people. Though this is a recurring routine ritual in the life of a University, it gives us an opportunity to take stock of what has been accomplished so far. The assessment of the educational progress we aave made, the statistics of passes and failures, the relief felt by parents and guardians that their wards have crossed one main hurdle of life, the anticipation that the youth turned out of the University will have acquired the strength and discipline necessary to face the battle of life, the eager expectation that the﻿ swelling of the number of graduates will redound to the credit of the society of which they are a partthese and a few more are the assessments and anticipations with which the minds of the people are naturally occupied on an occasion like this.

The object of such a special function as the convocation is similar to our celebrating on a special day the birthdays of our great prophets. On that occasion we seek to focus the thoughts of people on the messages that each of them conveyed to mankind. The object of a convocation is just to impress the alumni of a University with the importance of the task that awaits them and with the way in which they have to conduct themselves in life as befits educated men. The convocation is a ritual and a sacrament, a samskara to use a Sanskrit expression. It serves a purpose similar to that of a sacrament, namely, to leave a permanent impress on an impressionable mind which inay stand it in good stead as time rolls on. The human mind grows on what it feeds on. Human culture is the result of these samskaras and the cumulative impressions they produce by which we are inured into a pattern of culture. Every man is born as a young animal. He becomes human and civilized by the transmission and diffusion of culture. We are what our culture has made us. The convocation is a sacrament in the progress of our life. And like the sacraments of yore this also has an appositeness and importance which should not be lost sight of.

The name convocation' is outlandish and is a gift to us by the English people who ruled over us.﻿But the institution is as old as India's ancient civilization. The Taittiriva Upanishad gives a beautiful picture of a convocation held three thousand years ago--an impressive ceremony leaving a lasting impression on the mind of youth embarking on the householder's life. There is no new or old then about this matter. The convocation is a stage in life's journey and is a state of being at which one has arrived after trouble and travail. This is a gala day for those candidates who have been lucky enough to participate directly in this ritual. I will not be far wrong if I say that they are the real actors of the drama that is being enacted here. I heartily congratulate them on this joyous occasion and wish them a happy future. The convocation marks a moment of crisis when one steps out into the wider world from the threshold of a University. This is the time when one embarks on the adventure of putting to the test all that one has learnt from books and teachers on the touchstone of life's realities. This is a moment when one steps down from academic serenity to a world which demands practical efficiency, from the internal world of contemplation to the external field of action. It would be very proper at this time to bestow some thought on the several issues that will face us at this juncture.

Fortunately we are citizens of no mean republice India has had a great cultural heritage and a continuous unbroken cultural tradition. It is timehonoured and ancient. But if antiquity had been its only virtue it would not have survived so long nor﻿ would we have admired it so much. It seems to have thriven on a hidden secret surprising vitality, an inexplicable resourcefulness, creative and dynamic in its upsurge. Whatever we may say of other ancient civilizations, so far as India is concerned, the witness of a past is unnecessary to testify to its present life and vitality. India today has been uttering eternal values in a new voice, expressing ancient truths in a new idiom and acting also in a way refreshingly new in the modern world. In the words of Will Durant, India has been teaching in return for conquest, arrogance and spoliation” the “ tolerance and gentleness of the mature mind, the quiet content of the unacquisitive soul, the calm of the understanding spirit and a unifying, pacifying love for all living things.” The spiritual achievement of Sri Ramakrishna Paramahamsa, the fertilizing currents of thought and spiritual discipline of Sri Aurobindo, the philosophy of Satyagraha of Mahatma Gandhi, the Bhoodan Yajna of Vinobaji, the popularity of Nehru's Pancha Seela in the international world are a few of the recent illustrations of India's perennial and beneficent vitality. India can still be the holy land and a land of heroes.

We, the people of Karnataka, have no doubt developed certain distinctive cultural features of our own. We have our own language, literature, art and ways of life. We have had a long history of our own and an individuality of our own. There is no gainsaying this fact. But we should not forget for a single moment that we are parts of a greater unit called India. When we speak of Karnataka culture﻿ what we really mean is Indian culture as it has manifested and developed in the region called Karnataka. We cannot conceive of a Karnataka culture apart and antithetical to Indian culture. At the same time what we call Indian culture is nothing apart from the regional cultures of Kannada, Andhra, Tamil, Marathi, Gujarati and so on. India is one organism and these are its limbs that derive their sustenance from it. We must not forget that the culture of India has many strands in it. We may better liken it to a confluence in which many streams mingle and tumble sweetly together enfolding each the other. In this confluence of several streams there has emerged a fundamental cultural unity from Kashmir to Kanyakumari. Historically, politically, economically and socially. our interests as a people are welded together. If in the face of this ineradicable fact we begin to fan the flames of animosity based on doubtful ethnological fictions like Arya, Anarya, Dravida, Naga, Sindhu and so on, we are in for trouble and inviting home the passing devil. There is nothing more ludicrous and unscientific at present than to seek to determine as to what proportion of our blood and sinews are Aryan and what Non-Aryan.

Apart from these we have ideologies which stress the individual at the expense of society and those that stress society at the expense of the individual. This is based on a vicious dualism. The individual's well-being is wrapped up with the well-being of the whole society. The individual and society stand in﻿ indiscerptible relation. The attempts to pit the individual against society and society against the individual are misconceived and dangerous in the extreme. The individual without society is a fish out of water and society without the individual is an empty abstraction. Therefore when we speak of individual well-being we mean social well-being and vice versa.

But what is meant by the well-being of the individual or society? People are likely to hold different views as to what constitutes well-being. Is it to be measured in terms of material comfort or moral welfare? Buddha spoke of both. Material comfort at the expense of moral welfare spells disaster. Equally so the neglect of material prosperity in the name of spiritual well-being. We must aim at both, Abhyudaya and Nishreyas, material prosperity and spiritual welfare. The good must be made pleasant and the pleasant must be made good. The pleasant divorced from the good poisons the well-springs of life whereas the good divorced from the pleasant dries up the fountain of life. It is this same truth that is expressed by the Upanishads in its doctrine of the Koshas. Harmony at all levels of our being is the keynote of human perfection. It is only then that life becomes full and fructifying. Man's individual existence must be the result of an integration of the physical, the biological, the psychological and the spiritual. It is only when we attain this balance of our being that we can be said to have achieved life's purpose. When this balance becomes upset for some reason or the other, life becomes a gamble and a waste. The wreckage of it becomes disgusting. Our life must therefore be hitched to a star without our being content to be a clod of earth, the star of perfection, freedom, happiness and immortality. How far have all our endeavours in the several fields of life's activity helped us in this onward march is a vital question we have to put to ourselves.

Life is an experiment. We must approach it in the spirit of an experimenter following the method of trial and error. We must consolidate and register the progress that we have made at every step. Life is both a science and an art. We have in us the potentialities of being bondsmen or free. It is only when we have become masters of ourselves that we can call ourselves really free. Let us gauge our present-day achievements in the light of this ideal of self-mastery or emancipation of the human spirit from all obstacles that hamper its upward striving.

We have now in our possession the knowledge of atomic energy. We are fully aware of its terrific nature. But unfortunately we lack the inner restraint or refinement which is absolutely necessary to keep it in leash. Man is threatened with self-destruction by the very Frankenstein he has himself raised. He has been finding it difficult to bottle up the genie. It is a paralysing fear that has overtaken many who argue for our going back to an age of primitive simplicity when we knew no science of this type. But this is a symptom of weakness. The solution does not lie in escapism. "We must face the situation with all the strength of our souls. We﻿ must learn to control ourselves and control these energies and use them for constructive purposes. This is already within the range of practical possibility. It behoves our scientifically trained alumni to bend all their energies to humanize the knowledge and agencies of science and harness them to the moral and spiritual elevation of mankind. This shall be the social function of science

We are today a free nation. Ample opportunities are gradually unfolding themselves to which we must gear our intellectual and technical abilities. We have now been given the privilege of being the architects of our own destiny without the interference of others. Now is not the time for our dissipating our energies in-unseemly squabbles arising out of sectarian, communal, provincial and linguistic prejudices. At least let the coming generation steer clear of these devitalizing elements. Let them be inspired by a loftier national spirit without succumbing to these petty fissiparous tendencies. Let them be inspired by a radiant vision of the future India, an India, united, pure, strong and free. There is no task more glorious than to build it up from now. To be alive now to do this is bliss. If we lose this vision, we perish. Freedom then becomes a curse instead of a blessing.

We have given to ourselves a democratic constitution. We cannot go back on that. Democracy is the most difficult form of Government to practise. It can be successful only when we develop a sense of duty, an attitude of equality, a spirit of toleration and sweet persuasiveness. Democracy is based on﻿ the principle of persuasion and not coercion. We must realize.as at no time before how very responsible we are to grow now. We must endeavour to make democracy work in its true spirit and not be content with maintaining its external forms. We must not get deluded that we have the substance of democracy when we are only having its forms. The consciousness of duties must take precedence over the consciousness of rights.

We have learnt many things from the west-many arts by which we could intellectually improve. Literacy, Cheap books, Newspapers, Cinema all belong to this group. But the necessary sense of discrimination of what is good and bad in them has still not become our asset. The other day the Central Assembly passed a law banning terror films. Unless We develop in the people a sense of discrimination and proper appraisal of what is really good or bad in these exotic products, more harm than good is done by them. In this respect also the new graduates must establish a healthy example for others to follow.

Let us now for a moment cast a glance at ourselves in Karnataka. We had so far been parcelled out into several shreds but now with the emergence of the new State of Mysore on the ist of November 1956 we have become united. This is a great event in our history and this has filled our people's minds with fresh hopes and aspirations for the future. Legally, politically and geographically we have now become one. But this by itself will not suffice. Our hearts and minds must unite. Without any mental reservations we must come together and pull﻿ ourselves together. Let the one United Karnataka So govern herself that she shall bring fame and glory to the India which is our common motherland.

The architects of India's future destiny are these young men and young women whom I witness before me. I see in each one of them tremendous potentialities. May their lives shine forth like a steady, pure flame shedding illumination on all around them. Let them hold in iheir hands undimmed the torch of freedom and purity and march on in bold strides joining the procession of Humanity towards its divinely appointed destiny.﻿

YOUR HIGHNESS THE CHANCELLOR, Mr. VICE
CHANCELLOR, FELLOWS AND GRADUATES OF THE MYSORE UNIVERSITY,

IT is a privilege and an honour to participate in this function of the year, and I am most grateful to the Chancellor and the Members of the University for inviting me to it. It was with no little concern and diffidence that I accepted your kind invitation. I was doubtful then, and more so now, about my adequacy, in substance and eloquence, to present a Convocation Address worthy of this great institution. And this feeling is sharpened when I think of the distinguished men who have addressed in the past Convocations of this University. All the same, it is always most stimulating and encouraging to meet a gathering of young students, teachers and scholars engaged in the pursuit of knowledge and discovery, and all that it implies. The cultivation and exploration of knowledge, if it is to lead to results of real value, has to be a continuing process, vigorous, courageous and relentless. We are assembled here because we share in common our dedication, to the best of our strength and ability, to knowledge and truth. We recognise that education-and it is a process which must continue throughout life and not end abruptly on graduation-is an integral and vital element of a worthwhile and purposeful life.

To the young men and women who have received their degreestoday I offer my warm felicitations. I wish them a happy and fruitful life, and express the﻿ confident hope that they will make a worthy contribution towards the progress and prosperity and security of our great country.

Today's Challenge :

We live in unusual times, and this is true in more than one way. The thought which is uppermost in our minds today is of the challenge, unprovoked and sinister, to our security and freedom. That a great country with which we have been at peace for centuries, should have suddenly invaded our land and, confronted us with naked force, casting aside all pretence of civilised behaviour, is not only a crime against us but a crime against humanity and decent behaviour. What we should do to make freedom endure? That is the most important question which faces us. In the stirring and noble words of our Prime Minister:

“Every generation has to fight anew the battle for freedom. Otherwise we grow soft and forget the basic values of life and freedom and tend to lose their essence. My generation had the inestimable privilege of serving under Gandhiji in the struggle for our freedom.

Now a chance comes to all of us and, more especially, to the young to test their mettle and their patriotism. Already the wonderful response of the people of the country has shown our basic strength. Let this not be frittered away in petty things. Let this challenge be considered an opportunity and be met with strength, dignity, discipline and fortitude, so that out of this trial new and better India might be fashioned by the efforts and sacrifices of her children.

There are many ways of serving this cause, and many more will be pointed out to us from time to time. Meanwhile, I should like all our University students to join the National Cadet Corps or the N. C. C. Rifles to get some elementary training. It may be necessary to have higher training later on. Let us live a life of some austerity and save as much as we can, so that our savings might help in increasing the nation's effort.

Let us continue our education and training and prepare for the time when more is required of us.”

Problems facing Universities :

In the modern world, characterized by its increasing dependence on science and technology the universities hold a unique place. Their role and influence in determining the pace of progress (material, cultural and even spritual) can be, and in most cases is, both powerful and profound. Perhaps, there is no other institution or agency which in this respect is of comparable importance. It is the mission of universities to provide society with good and competent men and women trained in arts, science and technology, medicine, agriculture and other professions; and who, above all, are imbued with a sense of altruism, openmindedness and dedication. “A university stands for humanism, for tolerance, for reason, for the adventure﻿ ideas and for the search for truth. It stands for the onward march of the human race towards even higher objectives. If the universities discharge their duties adequately, then it is well with the nation and the people.”

It is common knowledge that in education many of the fundamental problems with which we are concerned also face most countries, including the more advanced ones. Almost everywhere there is a marked increase in student enrolment to meet the requirements of expanding economy and other national needs; there is an acute shonage of teachers partly because of the increasing drift to industry and other avenues of public and private employment, and the shortage is further accentuated because of rising student numbers; there is much serious concern that in many places there is too much teaching' but relatively too little of 'good teaching and far too little of good research; there is the problem of specialization and insulation, and its relation to inter-disciplinary communication and the needs of liberal education; there is too much fragmentation and compartmentalization of knowledge, and not only are there wide gulfs separating humanities, science and technology, but the bridges are far too few and even these are often unused; and there is the important and pressing problem of collaboration and mobility of staff between universities, national laboratories, industry and also Government scientific departments. There is also the complex and far-reaching problem of university autonomy, of relative freedom from Government control and outside interference, of freedom﻿ from internal strife and bigotry, and this can take many different and ugly forms.

Raise quality and reduce wastage :

In a sense the central problem facing us, which is basic to everything else in the field of higher education (in fact, all education), is to raise quality and 'reduce wastage, particularly that resulting from large-scale failures, of the order of fifty percent, at examinations. To progress in this direction is most important that we take urgent and energetic steps to raise the quality and strength of the teaching staff, to make available good books at reasonable prices within the easy reach of our students, and to provide reading-seats’in libraries and day-students homes' for a substantial proportion of our students. And in whatever we do, the student must always be at the centre of our attention.

“The quality of a university is always in direct proportion to the quality of its teachers." To attract and retain in the teaching profession men of outstanding ability and character reasonable salaries are important, but by no means everything. Opportunities of professional advancement, possibility of migration from college to university, and between universities, recognition by society of the value and importance of the teaching profession, would go a long way ip attracting to the profession reasonable proportion of men and women of high intellectual ability and character. Generally, it should be made possible for a teacher to carry with him his provident﻿ fund, leave and other benefits in moving from one university or college to another.

University is a Society dedicated to learning :

A university is, above all, a society of students and teachers dedicated to the pursuit of learning, accumulation of knowledge, its transmission to succeeding generations and exploration of new knowledge. A good teacher is a continuing student.' A university combines education and discovery, teaching and research. In this combination lies its peculiar strength. The experience of over a century beginning first with the German Universities has conclusively demonstrated that teaching and research flourish best in combination and they both wither in isolation. The best of either is achieved in an environment where both are cultivated.

As we all recognize it is of the utmost importance to ensure that the highest standards are observed in the recruitment of teaching staff. Appointments should be made on the basis of academic merit and suitability, uninfluenced by considerations of caste, regionalism and other extraneous factors. At one of its recent meetings, the University Grants Commission after carefully considering the matter observed that “appointments of teachers in the Universities should be governed by their suitability for the work to be done by them (that is on the basis of academic achievement, personality and character), and no consideration should be given to factors such as caste, creed and place of birth.”

Every possible encouragement should be given to﻿ young men of ability to join the teaching profession. If a person has outstanding work to his credit, young age should be no disqualification for appointment to University Chairs. In fact, other things being equal, it is in the interest of university education that young men still in the most creative period of their life be appointed to high academic posts.

Feed-back process :

Education provides a good illustration of the "feed-back’ process. If things are so organised that every year an appreciable number of our best young men join as teachers in our schools and colleges we shall have continually escalating improvement in education. On the contrary, if we plough back into our schools and colleges young men with less than average ability, then standards would rapidly (exponentially) go down as years roll by. The key to a continuous improvement of standards is to feedback into the teaching profession every year a reasonable proportion of the best young men turned out by the universities.

Student admissions :

It is hardly necessary to say that in universities and colleges admission of students should be on the basis of merit--and this may not be narrowly interpreted in the sense of percentage of marks secured at examinations--uninfluenced by considerations not in keeping with the essential character and ethos of a university. Apart from other things, this is necessary if we are to make the best use of our very limited﻿ facilities and resources for higher education. As the National Integration Council has observed : “Admissions to the universities should not be denied on considerations of place of birth, residence, caste or creed (except in so far as any reservations have been provided under the Constitution).”

Academic Standards are international:

In the field of university education, specially at the postgraduate level and research, we must aim at the highest international standards. Nothing less is or can be worthwhile. There are no, and can be no, local or regional standards as academic standards by their very nature are international. International standards in scholarship and research are not easy to achieve, but even in underdeveloped countries one sometimes comes across buildings and equipment which compares with the best anywhere. This is only a reflection of the simple fact that whereas in the first case we have to spend thought, in the second case it is primarily a question of spending money. Money is relatively much easier to spend than thought, specially when it is someone else's money.

Knowledge, as has been aptly said, is an international commodity.' The universities share a common stock of knowledge and a common attitude towards its cultivation and progress. They share in and contribute towards creating a common brotherhood of learning and scholarship. This is a thing of special value and significance in the "age of the atom" and ballistic missiles.﻿

The Unprecedented peril:

The mention of atomic age immediately calls to our minds the unprecedented peril, both in depth and extent, which faces mankind today in the shape of a possible misuse, deliberate or accidental, of nuclear knowledge. Indeed, nothing less than civilisation and human survival are at stake. If this simple fact is not as widely apparent and forcefully realised as it ought to be, it is largely because there has not been enough serious and sustained effort to inform us about it. As Professor Le Gros Clark observed in his Presidential Address to the British Association last year (1961): “For, let us not deceive ourselves, the frightening question is now beginning to present itself whether the civilisation which mankind has slowly and laboriously built up over a period of many thousands of years. can avoid disastrous dissolution as the result of uncontrollable (or, at any rate, uncontrolled) struggles for political power or economic, superiority, and, indeed, whether the human species can avoid at least partial extinction by the misapplication of its own ingenuity.”

The two big power-blocks possess nuclear weapons totalling many thousands of megatons (TNT equivalent) in constant readiness for immediate deployment, within hours to minutes, largely against city-targets and population centres. (At the present level of nuclear stalemate military targets' are hard or difficult to locate, and for that reason less 'paying' than city targets.) This balance of terror' with hideous weapons of colossal mass-destruction hanging over﻿ mankind creates a state which is too precarious and too unstable to exclude the possibility--in fact, much more than mere possibility, of the occurrence of some unpredictable spontaneous event' or accidental happening, a sort of political Brownian motion, escalating into a full-scale nuclear war. Given enough time, say ten years, but some think this is too long, the situation is almost certain to explode. It is hardly necessary to stress this point with the Cuban crisis still fresh in men's minds. The crisis in this case was resolved happily because of exceptional courage, statesmanship, and mankind's good fortune.

It is an interesting and significant thing that statistical analysis, carried out by L. F. Richardson, of the distribution of wars through history seems to fit in with the laws of chance (Poisson distribution):Chance and not wills of men seem to govern the incidence of wars.

Knowledge and Wisdom :

The balance of terror has to be replaced by common-links of co-operation and common endeavour in the pursuit of high ideals and goals. The present unfortunate and tragic situation is essentially a reflection of the widening gap between rapidly expanding scientific and technical knowledge on the one hand and 'political wisdom', statesmanship and ethical values on the other. Science and spirituality or atom' and non-violence are not in balance. It is this imbalance which mankind must seek to redress.

The universities could make and ought to make a definite contribution in correcting the imbalance﻿ between science, technology and the humanities. They also have a role, no doubt very modest but nonetheless significant, in helping to bridge the gap between knowledge and wisdom. What the universities can do towards these great ends will be in direct proportion to their being and becoming, in pursuit of their true ideals, places where freedom to enquire boldly and readiness to doubt courageously, where knowledge and understanding and true humility go together and grow from more to more, and where the highest standards of scholarship, integrity and conduct expected and respected and cultivated.

ADDRESS BY SRI PRAKASA
on Saturday, 5th Dec. 1964 FELLOW STUDENTS,

GRATEFUL as I am for the great honour that your esteemed Vice-Chancellor has done me in inviting me to address your Convocation this year, I must confess to a feeling of deep embarrassment as I stand before you in fulfilment of his wishes. I am close upon 75 years of age, and feel completely out of date. I realise only too well that the world is always for the young, and never for the old. If kindly death does not remove the aging ones in good time, the survivors must cheerfully withdraw themselves from the scene, and hand over charge to the young, of the affairs of life in all sincerity. By their persisting to take active part in the world's work when they become senile both in mind and body as I certainly feel I am, they can only make a nuisance of themselves without doing any good to anybody. As the wise, all understanding sheikh sa-adi has very rightly enjoined : " Bas kun azan pesh ki goyand bas”-“Say unto yourself 'stop' before others perernptorily tell you that they have had enough of you." I should like, therefore, to apologise for my appearence before you; and I have no doubt you will readily pardon me when you know that I am really not responsible for it. I tried very hard to avoid encumbering you with my presence, but your Vice-Chancellor would not take a 'no', and insisted on making elaborate arrangements to transport me from my home in Banaras, now called Varanasi; and so here I am.

Standing before you, I cannot help recalling an old association of my family with your fair State. I cannot say whether my mention of it will amuse you or, in fact, irritate you. A remote ancestor of mine, seventh in direct ascent from me, Sah Manohar Das by name, was actually present as the com nissariat agent, banker and mint-master of the old East India Company, at the battle of Seringapatam -in 1799. He did, I fear, drag from there a fairly large fortune to his home in distant Kashi, and whence I too have come. At a time when there is a great deal of talk at least in the neighbouring State of Madras, of the exploitation of the South by the North, perhaps this incident may give them a. convenient handle to press further their accusations. Old incidents, however, amuse me personally a great deal, and I should like to express my gratitude to you for having helped this ancestor of mine to leave sufficient for his family to enable them to live in fair comfort for seven generations after him.

You need, however, not be angry any more for the fortune is now spent; and with the enormous growth in the number of his descendants through the generations, high prices and heavy taxation, we despite your generosity in the past, are as badly off as any others can be in the land in the conditions of today. I may aiso perhaps be allowed to add that at that time, politically speaking, the inhabitants of Kashi Khand and those of Mysore, did not really regard themselves as citizens of the same﻿ country; and my ancestors, I fear, did not realise with the complications that the presence of the British had caused, that Hyder and Tipu were great patriots, heroes and statesmen, as later students of history have rightly proved them to be. My mind also sadly lingers on the tragic death, in October 1956 at Bangalore, of my dearly loved younger son Tapovardhan at the early age of 32, because of which I had always thankfully declined every invitation kindly extended to me to come to the State since then, till I was compelled to overcome my feelings and be with you here today.

Setting aside these personal notes, for striking which you will please excuse me, I should like to complain again here as I have often done on similar occasions before at other places, against this system of our universities having an address delivered by an outsider at their Convocation time, particularly at the end of lengthy ceremonials after which everybody is anxious to go out to stretch his legs having received ihe degree for which he had primarily come. The number of universities in the country has been multiplying very rapidly, and so also the number of Convocation addresses. I myself must have delivered these at 15 different places during the last 12 years or so, and I really do not know what new things to say as the problems continue to remain the same that they were when freedom was ushered in the land seventeen years ago. I fear I can only repeat what I have said many times before.﻿

To start with, the one thing that I am bound once more to press on the authorities of any university, as I have done several times earlier, is that they should always invite an old student of their own to address their convocations. I should also prefer such a person to be called who may not be regarded as having been what is called successful in life in the material sense, for then he would be able to give the best advice possible to the young graduates that are issuing out of his University, and tell them what to expect in the outside world, and how best to face the struggles of life with their unavoidable disappointments and frustrations. The so-called successful person is inclined to indulge in homilies and platitudes, and rather airily say that others can do as well as he has done if they would only have the necessary guts, which is patently incorrect for no one person can succeed unless heaps of others fail. Though it does happen that, thanks to Swaraj and my association with the Indian National Congress, I have held some socalled high offices, I have really myself not been a successful man in the ordinary sense of the word ; and if this ancestor of mine to whom I have referred above, had not left something for me at your expense, I do not know where I would have been. Thus I may say in all humility, that perhaps I am better placed than many others who have preceded me or may follow me on this platform, while speaking to you today.﻿

The wise British scientist and philosopher of the nineteenth century, Herbert Spencer, has very rightly said that the purpose of education is to enable the individual to make himself most useful to himself, his family and his society; and I have no doubt that today as you are about to issue out from the portals of your University where you have enjoyed a more or less sheltered existence, your minds must be troubled as to what life holds for you, for you would now be thrown entirely on your own resources, and would come face to face with difficulties and dangers of all sorts. You will meet situations suchas you may perhaps not have imagined possible. You must be earnestly and anxiously thinking of how you are to find occupation that would be both congenial and gainful to enable you to rare a happy and healthy family; how you are to live in accordance with standards that you think right and proper for yourselves; how you are to obtain comfort and happiness, and how to inspire confidence and respect in your fellow men.

You will see large numbers of our educated persons living unhappy lives, unable to find a proper niche in the economic edifice of society, and feeling that the education they had received, has been of no value to them, and that the trouble they had undergone in its pursuit and the sacrifices their parents had made for them, have been totally wasted. This unfortunate phenomenon with all its bitterness and sorrow, which is really quite wide﻿ spread, is due, to my mind, to the fact that a more or less uniform type of education has been given to us all, which has fitted us only for a very few professions-and that too such as had been newly introduced by the British in the land. These were already over-crowded; and with the demand of education becoming greater and greater as is but right in the setting of Swaraj, the over-crowding has become only the greater, because new avenues for employment have not been found, and what is worse, only these have come to be regarded as respectable and honourable, and others among whom are many of the older ones, have been relegated to the category of disreputable ones, beneath the dignity of the educated person to adopt and unworthy of the education he has received. It is but natural that the educated person should look for recognisedly respectable and honourable professions, with the result that many important lines of activity have been suffering badly owing to the neglect of them by those who should really have known better.

Permit me to pause for a moment and to draw a distinction, if I may, between 'literacy' and ' education'. The two are very often inclined to be mixed up, but they really can be very different from each other. An illiterate man can be a really educated person, and a literate one, totally uneducated.

Literacy 'simply means the skill to read and write, while education' means the capacity to do a piece﻿ of work properly and well. To take illustrations from the life of your own State, I am not one of those who think that the illiterate person who tames your wild elephants and boldly faces the tigers and snakes of your forests, or the illiterates who produce your marvellous works in ivory or sandalwood, are uneducated. Many of your educated persons would be unable to handle ivory and sandalwood, and would keep at a very safe distance from elephants, tigers or snakes. As Governor of various States in the country, I was called upon to make presents that were carefully chosen by the various Chief Ministers, to be given to visiting dignitaries from abroad. Curiously enough, I did not find even one article among them that was the product of an educated person so-called.

Mysore works of ivory and sandalwood were among the most popular of these presents, and they are all the handiwork of the illiterate. From my own home towni of Varanasi, came the lovely brocades, and from Kashmir came shawls and carpets. These delighted the eyes of the foreigners who received them with unconcealed admiration ; but they were all products of the skilful fingers of the illiterate. The tragedy is that those who actually produce them, are not brought forward to present them as they ought to be, but the presents are made by public functionaries who have no idea as to how they are created. Literacy is necessary and must be made universal ; but when those who﻿ are called educated, feel very superior to the illiterates though they cannot do what these can do, they should not forget that our country is more famous abroad for the creations of the illiterate than those of the highly educated. I do not say all this to minimise the importance of the education that is given to us at our schools, colleges and universities. What I do want to stress is that we ought to have a wholesome respect for the objects produced and the work done by the illiterate; and that if we are really educated, we should not crowd. the few so-called respectable and honourable learned professions that the educated have so far adopted for themselves, but they should really be enabled by their education, to improve upon the work that the illiterates are doing today. We are also to honour the work and the worker, and not neglect them as we have been doing. Wandering through a village one morning, I stood watching with awe and amazement, the potter at his wheel turning out most useful household utensils from the lump of clay that he had put on a whirling wheel, with the help of his bare and extra-ordinarily skilful fingers. As I stood there wonder-struck, the potter turned to me and said: “This too is art, but who cares? Nobody recognises either us or our work." I felt humiliated for though a university, without proper appreciation of values, had made me a Bachelor of Arts, the university of life had made this man a true artist, and he was certainly very much more useful to society than I could pretend to be.﻿

I have no doubt in my mind that the realisation of this fact should make us see to it that the illiterate artist is made literate without losing his art, and that adequate material return is made to him and a proper social position given to him for the services he renders to his fellow men. If only our educated persons will not spurn the professions that are regarded as humble and unworthy of them, and would so work them that they produce better stuff than the so-called illiterates do today, they would certainly justify their education. To take just one illustration: If the educated agriculturist with the help of his knowledge would produce one hundred maunds of wheat and rice where his illiterate ancestor produced only twenty, we would solve our food problem in a trice. Let it not be forgotten that in the setting of Swaraj, we have given ourselves the status of a Sovereign Democratic Republic. By 'Sovereign' we mean that we are the masters of our own destiny, and that no one has any right to interfere with us in any way. By Republic' we mean that no one is entitled to any public office merely because he is the child of his parents. These words are easily understood, and do not really apply to the ordinary man and woman so far as his or her daily life is concerned.

The important word in the formula is democratic. It concerns us all, and is a significant fact in our day-to-day existance. Democracy, envisages an approximate equality of all citizens by giving an﻿ equal vote to everybody. It thus places an enormous amount of responsibility on us all, for we are ourselves responsible for everything that is happening. It is no use complaining against what the rulers may do because we have ourselves chosen them. If we have voted wrongly at elections, whatever the reasons we may be able to give for it, we must hold ourselves answerable for the results. Democracy has some very important ingredients which all of us must scd ilously and constantly remember. As all men are mortal, democracy does not regard anyone as indispensable, and feels that there will always be available in every society at any given time, proper persons in adequate numbers to perform the many tasks that the world requires. Democracy has prescribed the method of elections for the ferreting out of such people from odd corners as might be necessary. Thus the citizen with a vote becomes a very important person, and he has to exercise the privilege given to him, with the utmost care and caution. Democracy requires all matters to be discussed on a high intellectual level, when passion and prejudice have to be cast aside ; when emotions have to be kept under control; when everyone has to be given credit for good intentions and conclusions reached after careful discussion. Democracy also always respects majority; and when a majority decision is taken, it is regarded to be in the interest of the minority as much as of the majority itself, and should be cheerfully accepted. While the﻿ minority concedes victory to the majority, it is the bounden duty of the majority to see that no injustice of any sort is done to the minority, whether it is communal or linguistic. It is not enough for the majority to say that it is doing the right thing by the minority: it is only when the minority says so that the verdict can be accepted.

Then Democracy also puts a seal of finality on decisions so taken, so that we might not go round and round the same thing, and keep constantly upsetting what has once been decided because it does not happen to suit the convenience of this person or that. Thus the spirit of democracy comes in the picture all the time, and applies to every individual in the home, in the social circle, in the economic sphere and in public life. We see around us that though we call ourselves a democratic people, we do not posses the essential qualities that can make us true democrats. That is what is causing most of the confusion in the land, against which we complain: indiscipline not only in educational institutions but also in legislatures themselves; corruption in many forms not only on the humble levels of life but even on the highest ; development of personality cults; and insecurity of life and property. A democracy is not pining for great men. In fact, it is always suspicious of tall poppies. It requires a high average of ordinary citizenship. If we are to make our democracy successful, we are not eternally to pray for some﻿ unique personalities to descend mysteriously from the skies to look after us, we have to look after us ourselves. The great thing in democracy is that it ensures permanency. Whoever may come or whoever may go, a democratic society goes on for ever. We in our country have seen endless changes of kings and kingdoms, and boundaries of States. We have suffered grievously from foreign conquests and internal turmoil. We do not want to repeat the sad pages of our history. That is why we have declared ourselves a democratic people. We have to be. worthy of our ideals, and we can be so only if we are all good citizens. If the country looks to the graduates of its universities, to show the way by precept and example-more by example than even by precept there is nothing to be wondered at.

My great appeal, therefore, to the young graduates, would be to make themselves into good citizens. How can we be that? First of all, a good citizen must chose his work in life in good time, and then adhere to it through good report or evil, through success or failure. As the Bhagavad Gita says:

*Yogasthah kuru karmani sangam tyaktva,
Dhananjaya,

Siddhyasiddhyoh samo bhutva,
samatvam yoga uchyate.

(Perform action, O Dhanan-jaya, dwelling in union with the divine, renouncing attachments, and balanced evenly in success and failure ; equilibrium is called Yoga.)

We are all very often prone to give up our work at the least set-back, feeling disheartened and discouraged. That is how so many of us are not able to do anything in life. A good citizen labours hard to learn all the details of his calling, and applies himself assiduously to the task needed for the same. We are all inclined to be very lazy, and a good citizen cannot afford to be lazy. He has his hours of relaxation and recreation as he must have, but above everything, he is a very hardworking person. Then a good citizen is a very responsible person. I fear we very greatly lack this quality in our country. We very readily make promises of all sorts in small and big matters, which we have no intention of fulfilling. If today we witness such wide-spread dislocation in our social and economic life, it is due entirely to no one being able to trust anyone else or be sure that the person who says he would do a thing, would actually do it. The one great characteristic that I found in our late Prime Minister Shri Jawaharlal Nehru, through almost half a century of close association with him as a colleague in public and a friend in private life, was his great sense of responsibility. Whether it was a small matter or big, when he undertook to do 'something, he always did it. Everybody could﻿ depend upon him for fulfilling what he had undertaken. This need not necessarily be a quality of a person who is great. In our own spheres, we can all be equally responsible. Our country will be a much better place to live in if only we were that.

A good citizen is also a generous person. He does 'not keep his knowledge a close secret with himself. He shares it with others, so that there may be progress all round all the time. Our people have been very averse to parting with their knowledge, because of which so many of our arts and sciences have died, and each generation had to. re-discover what had already been discovered before. All progress, therefore, has been at a stand-still; and while others who originaily learnt arts and sciences from us. have very greatly advanced and progressed in them, we remain where we were many centuries back, and have now to learn from those whom we had taught. Then a good citizen has to be proud of his work. We are not so. We are always thinking that we deserved to have something more congenial and suitable than we have, and that we could have done other people's work better than they do that themselves. We thus spoil both ourselves and our work. To quote the Bhagavad Gita again,

*Shreyan swadharmo vigunah paradharmat swanushthitat,

Swadharme nidhanam shreyah, paradharmo bhayavahah.

(Better one's own duty, though destitute of merit, than the duty of another weli discharged. Better death in the discharge of one's own duty; the duty of another is full of danger.)

A person who works hard so that he may do his work well; who is responsible so that all who deal with him, can depend upon him ; who is generous so that he hands over his work to future generations to improve; and who is proud of his work so that he feels happy in what he is doing and does it well, is a true citizen, and he alone can be a true democrat. If we want to make our democracy a success, we must all be such citizens.

And whatever we learn or do not learn, let us make sure that we learn three things without fail. Above everything, we must learn patriotism. This must be sedulousiy, consistently, persistently taught to us at every stage of our life, training and education, for let there be no mistaking, we sadly lack this cardinal virtue. That accounts for all the endless squabbles we have over caste and creed, over language and region, and we really never take the right decisions because we do not go the right way. We are not prepared to keep our country above everything, and hence we miserably fail in most of the things we seem to do, not only in the larger matter of the solution of the food problem or the eradication of corruption, but even when the simplest tests are applied to us as we go about in · the concerns of our ordinary daily life. We have﻿ also to learn to perform our simple social and civic duties properly. We do not know what we owe to our neighbours. We do not know the art of carrying sticks and umbrellas in the public streets without hurting others, or looking right and left before we cross a road so as not to endanger ourselves and others. We throw orange and banana peels carelessly in public places, on which people slip and hurt themselves. We are supremely.indifferent to keeping our surroundings clean and sanitary. We do not look after our depressed and handicapped brethien, and are really cruel to animals. We must be taught the social sense so that every one may be assured that someone will come to his rescue when in need, and that no one will put unnecessary risks in the path of others directly or indirectly. .

And then we must all learn good manners. Good manners are like oil that keep the machine of human relationship running smoothly, harmoniously and successfully. So many of us seem to think that politeness is sycophancy, and rudeness isindependence. With such ideas, we cannot go very far, orf man is a social animal. He cannot live alone. He must know how to conduct himself if he is to function properly in the society in which his life is cast. The ancients have very rightly enjoined:

*Shruyatam dharma sarvaswam, shrutva chaiva vadharvatam ;

Atmanah pratikulani paresham na samacharet.

(Listen unto the very quintessence of all Dharma and religion, all righteousness and spirituality; and having so listened, thou shalt lay it securely to thy beart. Whatever thou findest unpleasant and unpalatable in the conduct of others towards thyself, thou shouldst know that the same is unpleasant and uopalatable in thy conduct towards others.)

A patriotic person with a strong sense of duty by his subordinates and his fellow creatures, and blessed with courteous demeanour, is a good citizen. He is also thus a good democrat; and so we must all be if we are to prove worthy of the Freedom we have attained, the political status we have given unto ourselves, and the legacy we have inherited from ages past. Remember we have to make our own very special contribution to world thought and world endeavour. We cannot be satisfied with being a mere copy, of any other country, whether America or Russia.

Graduates of the year, the tasks before you are indeed great. At the present moment, we are at the cross-roads of history, and the future entirely depends on how we condnct ourselves today, I pray that you may be able to raise happy and healthy homes for yourselves, that would give peace and rest to heart and head alike. May you find congenial and profitable occupations to ensure the fulfilment of your legitime te ambitions, and a proper place for yourselves among your fellow men.. May you succeed in whatever you undertake May your contacts with your Univessity ever remain close and cordial. May your alma mater be always sustained and surrounded by your love and service, and may she ever be proud of her sons and daughters who as good citizens of the land, are ever striving in their own lives and wherever they might function, so that its Unity may be consolidated and its Liberty kept inviolate for all time to come.﻿

CONVOCATION ADDRESS
BY
DR. ZAKIR HUSAIN
15th December, 1966﻿﻿

Mr. Chancellor, Mr. Vice-Chancellor, Ladies and Gentlemen,

I am grateful to you for the honour done to me in asking me to address the Convocation of your University. I do not wish to have more than a just share of this honour, and sometimes I feel that I hava exhausted the small store of knowledge that I possess and must decline invitations to address convocations that are generously, perhaps all too generously and insistently, extended to me. But I have had the privilege of knowing Dr. Shrimali, the distinguished Vice-Chancellor of this University, for a long time and have too high an opinion of him to abide by any self-denying decision I may have taken in this matter. I am aware also of the history and the cultural traditions of Mysore. This is the State that offered the most effective, because the most intelligent opposition to the East India Company, the State which attempted to make resistance to inperialism an international issue, to train armies on modern lines and to provide them with the best available weapons. It is the State which first sponsored a scientific study of military organisation and modern strategy and tactics, published and available even now in book form. It is also the State whose craftsmen have been recognised as masters of detailed ornamentation, craftsmen for whom ivory and sandalwood and stone were equally pliant material, whose hands never failed them and whose eyes were never confused by the most complicated patterns. It was impossible, therefore, for me to resist the temptation to visit﻿ Mysore once again to pay my homage to the values which your Staie represents.

But what I should say to you is quite another matter, Here I come up against the multitude of problems facing uş today, which are as baffling for me as for many of you. You must have heard it said that we are passing throug a very critical period. The people who say so perhaps mean different things and it is not comforting, at least intellectually, to find the same terms used repeatedly for different things, and sometimes also, no doubt, only because repetition involves no mental effort, I do not know of any period in the history of any country which could not, in some sense, be called critical We might also, when we look back at these two decades of our history fifty or a hundred years hence, find that the apxiety and the premonitions of disaster which we now feel were not quite justified. But we do need clarity of thought and consistency between belief and practice, between the ends we have in view and the means we adopt to achieve them.

We need to make a clear distinction between State and Government. Loyalty to the State is unconditional. Loyalty to the Government is conditional on our belief that it is acting justly and in the interests of the State. But it is the Government that acts as the agent of the State, and not individuals and their opinions. Opposition to the Government in' a democracy must, therefore, be inspired and guided by a deeper loyalty to the interests of the State than may be apparent﻿ from the decisions or the actions of the Government. Law and order, for instance, is the interest of the State, not of the Government and if a complete breakdown of law and order takes place, it is not a defeat of the Government but a form of dissolution of the State. Citizens who take it upon themselves to oppose a democratic Government, must evince, in their actions, a higher regard for disciplined conduct and ordered living as an interest of the State than the Government they happen to oppose, they must be more thoughtful, far-sighted and consistent than those who happen to be holding the reins of Government. Democratic opposition ceases to be truly democratic if it becomes a kind of bull-baiting. It shou'd not consist in the adoption of the quickest and easiest means of provoking the Government to take violent action, so that retaliation and further provocation can be disguised as a demand for justice. Those of us who have the interest of the State at heart must seriously consider whether there is or is not a tendercy among us to confuse the Government with the State, and all unconsciously to give opposition to the Government a character and a form which is damaging to the interest of the State.

Another distinction, not quite easy to appreciate but still one that it is essential to make, is the distinction between Government as such and the party in power which operates the machinery of Government. I trust that you will not mistake my meaning. . All that I wish to say is that in a democracy which wishes to ensure its survival conflicts of opinion and﻿ clashes of interest should not undermine the very idea of Government or the concept of obedience. We must develop the instinct of knowing when to stop and where to stop. Headstrong action, taken in anger or spite, breeds hysteria, and people who are not aware of the dangers of hysterical behaviour cannot serve as proper guardians of a democratic system.

We must cultivate the babit of consequent thinking. If anything goes wrong, we must seek the real reasons, and not look for the most convenient targets. If Mysore appears to be cleaner than other towns, it is not only because the city fathers are most conscious of their duties; it is due also to the habits of the people. And if we find cities that are not clean, we can be sure that it is because the inhabitants do nothing to co. operate with the city authorities in maintaining proper standards of cleanliness, We hear vehement complaints of corruption. This is a phenomenon that calls for serious thinking and not vociferous indignation. We must analyse its causes objectively. If such an analysis reveals that there is a fairly large number of citizens who do not scruple to disregard the standards of honesty in public life, we must not pass hasty judgment on some other party alone. Perhaps if we turned our attention from the sensational cases that are written or whispered about in public to those that are hardly noticed because corruption is not a term we might apply to them, it will be possible to build up a strong sentiment in favour of﻿ honest dealing. We would not then be like fishermen who make nets to catch the biggest fish only and who find their nets broken through or carried away by their intended prey as the only reward of their ingenuity and labour.

The habit of consequent thinking would stimulate us also to consider the ultimate results of whatever we do to assert our right to the freedom of civic self-expression. While we criticised, we would also search our hearts to make sure that we balance our criticism with an equal willingness to cooperate in the maintenance of high standards in our civic life. While we agitated, we would consider what harvest we shall ultimately reap from agitations that are ends in themselves and transform basically reasonable demands into obsessions. I do not believe there are many among us who would prefer disintegrated living to the necessary restraints of a democratic way of life. There should, therefore, also be many among us who realise the risks of a too inconsiderate exercise of the rights we possess, and who do all in their power to give proper direction to sentiments and energies that can become destructive if they get out of control.

It is to the universities that we look for guidance in scientific and constructive methods of thought. I have myself spoken frequently in an idealistic vein about the role of universities and the duties of intellectual leadership which they must fulfil. Circumstances now make it urgent for us to give concrete forms to whatever idealism we claim for ourselves, as the university campus in the begining more and more reflects certain unpleasant aspects of the conditions outside. If we ever thought that we could reflect and decide at leisure, it is obvious that we cannot do so now. We have to act and act rightly and effectively. Not only youth but the country as a whole is filled with expectation. We have to press into the present moment what we believed could be done conveniently in a deeade or perhaps in the whole period of a teacher's service. And whatever we do now will be of much account and likely to provide a greater momentum for progress than similar actions might have done ten years ago or might do a year hence.

It is necessary, I know, that we keep eyes on universities abroad and the systems they follow, but in fact each of our universities must find the solutions of its problems within the conditions that govern its working. There are universities in the world whose administration is in the hands of the state ; there are universities in whose working the state would deem it a sacrilege to interfere. Both represent workable systems, and one could say that academic freedom is not less evident in the one than it is in the other. There are universities in which the Rector or Vice-Chancellor is a mere figure-head, where a professor enjoys a higher status and would refuse to waste his time performing the ceremonial duties of a figurehead. There are universities in which the Vice-Chancellor possesses full academic and executive authority and is judged﻿ by the effectiveness with which he exercises this authority There are universities in which the government makes all the appointments and universities where all appointments are made by the university authorities. There are universities which look like cooperative associations of teachers and students and are proud of the amenities and prospects they offer, and there are universities which expect students to be mature enough to look after themselves, to select their courses of study, to choose their teachers and to hunt for books by themselves. We have in our own country universities following widely different patterns. The value of any system seems to depend not on theoretical merits but on the merits of those entrusted with its working, and if we bear this constantly in mind there is no reason why any defects that there might be in a system should not be neutralised or overcome.

I am aware, of course, of the difficulties in which the universities have been placed for no fault of their own. There is overcrowding, and I can imagine earnest teachers feeling exasperated at the size of their classes. The process of change in the medium of instruction would in itself have bred a host of problems, but we have now in the multitude of students a relatively small number only of those who are mentally mature enough for university education. There is an acute shortage of books and necessary equipment. An atmosphere of depression is created because the existing opportunities of employment are obviously far too inadequate for those who have found﻿ admission to the universities. On the other hand the government, because of the overriding needs of development and defence, cannot fulfil the demands of education which it acknowledges to be just, and we have to be content with what it can give. The provision of employment is in a sense one of the functions of our State, but that responsibility cannot be unlimited. What, then, are we to do?'

I have been deliberately brief and hasty in the enumeration of our diffculties. There is no advantage, it seems to me, in being elaborate and eloquent in such enumeration. It would be helpful, in the first place, if we habituated ourselves to seeing our difficulties in the context of our whole national life. They will then appear to be not an infliction but a challenge, and we shall realise that our problems are not our own only, but the problems of the whole nation. It is not only in education but in almost every sphere of activity that we find ourselves handicapped by lack of resources. Ours is a populous country, the vast majority of whose inhabitants have suffered from centuries of neglect, and we have now decided to give them the attention and the opportunities which they deserve. We should be proud of this decision and deem it an honour to assist in its fulfilment. Those working in the sphere of education have certain basic requirements which must be met to enable them to perform their functions. But they need also to cultivate that spirit which is not intimidated by lack of material aid and support, which discovers an opportunity in every﻿ difficulty and stimulates us to march forward with greater determination because of the many obstacles that have to be surmounted.

One of the causes of the frustration many of us feel is that we overlook, if we do not mentally reject the fact that India is a poor country, and that our efforts are directed towards moving out of poverty and not at attaining any degree of affluence. We must make adequate provision for advanced teaching and research in science and technology - that is something which undoubtedly depends on resources. But the problem is different for the vast mass of those who obtain university education. Here what we need is intensity of concern with teaching and learning, spontaneous and self-directing cooperation between teachers and students in the communication and acquistion of knowledge, and a continuous and unsparing assessment. The universities must not examine their students only, they must examine themselves, and must not wait for others to tell them where they fail. The university administration should not be a bureaucracy but a cooperative democracy always discovering new means and methods of integration, and assisting individuals in the accomplishment of their academic aims; the measure of the persons in charge, whatever the charge they hold, must be their own intellectual and academic prestige, or their ability to enable others to devote themselves with singlemindedness to the advancement of knowledge. We shall then have a different atmosphere, the university will﻿ become a closely knit community, its administrative and organisational affairs will be settled in brief and purposeful discussions and merit will not have to canvass for the recognition due to it.

In this integrated university community, the students and their interests will form an organic element of the whole. Their participation in political and social movements will not create discord but be in harmony with the aims and functions of the university. You will agree that till the attainment of independence it would have been tragic if students remained concerned only about their personal interests and careers and indifferent to the cause of national freedom. After independence it became obligatory on every student to concern himself as exclusively as possible with the development of his own particular aptitudes so as to acquire the greatest competence for serving the nation in his special field. It remained his duty, as a citizen-to-be, to keep himself informed of what was being done in the various spheres of national life, so that he could discover what his own preferences were and also find a place for himself where he was likely to be most useful; even the prospective politician should have looked for opportunities to train himself in organisation and persuasive oratory in constructive enterprises within the campus. Unfortunately, the mental adjustment necessary after independence was left to chance or undertaken in a haphazard way. Students were asked to interest themselves in welfare activities of some kind, or they were﻿ just barangued. Mostly they were left themselves. The earnest students--and let us never forget them when we talk about students-the earnest students did what was necessary and proper. The others suffered from lack of guidance within the campus and the absence of those pressures which, in a competitive society, make a man thoughtful in spite of himself. That may be regarded generally as the cause of what is now called 'students' unrest'. But would this or any other diagnosis of the causes of unrest in the least justify the forms which the unrest has taken? Would it entitle the students to assume the character of a social class, organising itself for self-assertion? And can this self-assertion include demands for the lowering of standards and the relaxation of academic discipline?

I have posed these questions, but I am convinced in my own mind that we do not need to press for the answers. The unfortunate occurrences of recent months are a passing phase, and have been more the product of political tensions outside the university campuses than of discord within them. But the students, like the university authorities, must remember the circumstances under which he people as a whole are living: That they will one day take the place of their elders, as leaders and followers, as persons engaged in the manifold occupations of our political, social and economic life is an obvious physical fact, not an excuse for the demand of special treatment. On the other hand, the fact that students are students no reason to make them suffer from neglect. That transport services should﻿ be so regulated as to meet the needs of passengers, even if thay happen to be students, that buildings should be clean and kept in good repair, that food should be hygienically prepared and nutritious, that public servants should show proper attention and courtesy are generally admitted obligations, and something is seriously wrong if an agitation of any kind is neaessary to remedy laxity or indifference in the fulfilment of these obligations.

I would like in the end to remind you, my young friends, that the suavival of democracy ia India depends on the means we adopt to attain ovr objectives. You will not find anything perfect and many things vary imperfect indeed, in your country, as in any other. It is your duty, as citizens, to strive to improve, to the best of your ability, whatever needs to be improved. But you must be scrupulous and circumspect in the means you choose for the performance of your duties. And you must, above all, try to understand. To fix the blame and call for punishment is seldom, if ever, an effeciive means of removing ills. Human nature and human habits of thought and behaviour cannot be easily changed, and those who desire change must also be those who excel in patience and perseverance. Above all, you must remember that setting a good example is abcut the greatest act of public service, even though its influence is not swift or obvious. It is not necessary for each of you to aim at great things; great things can be achieved, as it were without effort, where all are anxious to set an example in doing the small things. We shall not find leaders of supernatural capacity to bear the responsibility of this vast country of ours; that can be borne only by each of us showing that his shoulders are strong, his mind keen and clear, and his heart filled with patience, goodwill and hope.﻿
