ADDRESS BY Pdt. H.N. KUNZRU
on Saturday, 18th Jan. 1969

I AM grateful to the Mysore University for having done me the honour of asking me to address its Convocation this year. This is a great. responsibility but I have accepted it in a spirit of humility: I felt because of my deep interest in education and in our youth who will, in course of time, inherit the country, that I should take this opportunity of stressing the importance of education in shaping the lives of our young men and building up the strength of the country.

I warmly congratulate the successful candidates. I hope that they will be able to find opportunities of using their talents for their own good and that of the country.

The future of our.country depends on various factors but on none more than on education. In the recent debates in the French National Assembly on the reform of the universities, the Education Minister emphasized the importance of education by saying “The university is not a part of the nation. It is the nation itself.” What we are at any time is a reflection of the prevalent educational system. Political progress, economic development, social advance, the security of the country, all depend on the quantity and quality of education.

Judged from this standpoint, there is a chasm between higher education as it is and what it should be. Excluding those in the Intermediate classes, the number of students receiving higher education in 1967-68 was about 20 lakhs. The number is not large in comparison with the population of the country. But the position with regard to the educational equipment of the freshmen and the efficiency of teaching is far from satisfactory. In 1965–66, taking both the annual and the supplementary examinations into account, the percentage of the successful candidates was 54.5 in the B.A. examination (Pass & Hons.), 51.3 in the B.Sc. examination and 55.6 in the B.Com. examination. These figures show that about half the candidates failed in these examinations. The percentage of failures is disquietingly high. It is a serious reflection both c. the teachers and on the students.

Our anxiety increases when we consider the standard of attainment of the graduates as shown by the divisions in which the successful students were placed. In the annual examination held in 1966, out of the 58,500 B.A.'s while only about 700 or 1.2 per cent passed in the 1st division, as many as 42,000 or 71.7 per cent passed in the 3rd division. For the B.Com. examination the corresponding figures were roughly 11,900, 251 (2.1 per cent) and 8240 (69.5 per cent). The results of the B.Sc. examination were distinctly better. Broadly speaking out of the 32,000 candidates who passed, as many as 4,400 or 13.7 per cent obtained the 1st division and only 13,600 or 42.4 per cent passed in the 3rd division. I should not, however,﻿ be understood to mean that we should be satisfied with the attainments of our science graduates.

Owing to the low standard of education in India, our first degrees in Arts, Commerce and Science suffer in comparison with similar degrees in the educationally advanced countries. : “ What is really comparable ", says the Education Commission, "is our second degrees in Arts, Commerce and Science and the first degrees in agriculture, engineering and medicine with the first degrees given by Universities in the educationally advanced countries.”

It should be noted that the enrolment in the Arts and Commerce faculties is much greater than in the Science faculty. In 1967-68 the enrolment in the first two faculties was 11.35 lakhs while that in the Science faculty was only 7.36 lakhs or about 40 per cent of the enrolment in all the three faculties. The Education Commission has justly said, “At present there is an over-production of graduates in arts and commerce..... and consequently, there is a growing incidence of unemployment among them.”

It is clear from the facts cited above that a large percentage of the students who are admitted to the universities are ill-equipped to profit by higher education. It is no kindness to them to let them waste two or three precious years of their lives in the pursuit of an unattainable objec﻿tive. It is difficult to differ from the Education Commission when it says, “ A stage has, however, now been reached in the process of expansion when the policy of selective admissions will have to be extended to all sectors and institutions of higher education ... There is no escape but to link broadly the total enrolments in higher education to man-power needs and bridge the gap between these enrolments and the demand for higher education by adopting a policy of selective admissions.” The higher education of those who are unable to get admission to a college should be provided for through evening classes and correspondence courses as is done in countries like the U.S.A., the U.K., the U.S.S.R. and Japan. These courses should include courses in science and technology.

The low standard of education in the universities is largely due to the deplorable condition of secondary education. After the completion of his secondary education, the successful student is fit neither to pursue his studies in a university nor to join a higher grade technical institution. For all practical purposes, secondary schools are the weakest link in the educational chain. Their radical improvement is imperatively called for in the interests both of the students and of the - country. The Education Commission has recommended the establishment of a National Board of School Education to bring this about. As the﻿ Board will be advisory and will have no power to assist selected schools financially to raise themselves to the required level, in my opinion it will fail in its purpose. In spite of the theoretical objections of the Commission, I think that the Board should be allowed, with the consent of the States concerned, to give carefully chosen schools financial assistance over and above what they receive from their governments, to enable them to reach the highest standard fixed by it so that in 20 or 25 years about 25 per cent of the Secondary Schools may be comparable to those in the advanced countries

But even without waiting for the improvement of secondary education, it is practicable to raise the standard of university education in the arts faculty. While on the science side a student has to work for five or six hours every day, on the arts side, generally speaking, he is required to work for three hours only. The educational value of the first arts degree is thus lower than that of the corresponding science degree which too, as pointed out by the Education Commission, is none too high. In fairness to the arts students, their education should receive much greater attention in future and steps should be taken to raise the standard of attainment for the arts degree to the level of that required for science degree. Independent study, tutorial work and seminars are the means by which this objective can be﻿ realized. To change the present system will require considerable effort and expenditure but we owe it to the country to do the best we can for our students on whom its future depends. As I have already said, education is the key to progress in every direction, and it should be regarded as the most important factor contributing to the building of the nation. The money and effort required for its modernisation and development should, therefore, be regarded as an invaluable investment.

There has been considerable discontent among the students for many years, manifesting itself in demonstrations and strikes which have frequently taken ugly forms. These have often been the · result of educational weaknesses. Increases in tuition or examination fees, which hit hard the increasing number of students from lower and middļe class rural families, unsatisfactory living conditions, difficult examination papers, want of contact between students and teachers, inadequate preparation of the students for higher education have all led to prolonged interruptions in their studies. Again, whenever a student is expelled for misbehaviour, the demand is put forward for the cancellation of the expulsion order and it is followed by a strike and rowdyism. In some universities students have also demanded the enrolment of as many students as seek admission. Factions among teachers also﻿ create difficulties for the universities. The teacher politicians are found from time to time to be involved in the strikes. Strikes backed by teachers are more prolonged and have more serious consequences than those led only by students. The strikes are sometimes politically oriented. In Northern India at least, political parties are believed to have been involved in the strikes and, in some universities, they have their cells among the students. They may not incite them to strike but when a strike has begun, their support to their groups lends political colour to the strike and the students become merely pawns on their chessboard.

The students have genuine grievances, but the expression of their dissatisfaction, I regret to say, often takes highly undesirable forms. The absence of any system or method followed by the students has been noticed with great regret by some observers of the Indian educational scene. For instance, Prof. Shils of the United States, who has sympathetically studied the student movement in India, has said in Higher Education and Student Politics in India, “The hostile energy is there, the inflammability is there but the energy is primitive. It is not transfigured or disciplined by calculating intelligence or by a comprehensive vision, whether it be doctrinaire or idealistic, utopian or realistic.”

The acadamic deficiencies which create discontent among the students have been referred to in﻿ its report by the Education Commission. They are, according to it," the mechanical and unsatisfactory nature of many curricular programmes ; the totally inadequate facilities for teaching and learning in the large bulk of institutions ; poor student teacher contact--many a student goes through the entire undergraduate course without exchanging a word with his teachers; the inefficiency and lack of scholarship on the part of many teachers and their failure to interest themselves in the students' problems...the prevalence of what has come to be known as teacher politics in some colleges and universities....” It goes on to say that “ the conditions of public life and the falling standards of discipline among the adults and a weakening of their civic consciousness and integrity" have also had an undesirable impact on the students. The removal of the educational deficiencies is urgently necessary to inspire the students with respect for their colleges and universities and their teachers. It is only teachers with a reputation for scholarship that can have the moral authority to give young people the moral guidance that is sadly lacking today. But improvement in this respect is bound to take time. The rapid expansion of higher education, like that of secondary education, has led to the establishment of inefficient educational institutions and the employment of inefficient teachers. I know that there are good and devoted teachers too in our universities and﻿ colleges, but there must be more of them. To attract more talented men to the teaching profession and to create contentment among the teachers it is necessáry, among other things, to pay them the salaries recommended by the Education Commission..

Generally speaking, the participants in student revolts are those who are studying the liberal arts. The science and technology students who value the education they receive and understand the vital bearing of success in their studies on their future, have neither the time nor the inclination to take part in or encourage strikes and demonstrations. If the standard of education in the humanities is raised, as pointed out above, the arts students are likely to be as mindful of their studies and as sober as the science students are. .

In addition to this imperative reform, deserving students should be helped to receive higher education. In the more important western countries, like the U.S.A., Great Britain, France and Germany, the educational policy is that no able boy or girl should be prevented by lack of means from following an advanced course of study. In Great Britain about 90 per cent of the university students are aided from public or private funds. In France and Germany the percentage of students receiving Government stipends is 67 and 55 respectively. In India also scholarships should be liberally given. A beginning may be made in﻿ accordance with the recommendations of the Education Commission. In the award of these scholarships the claims of poor but bright students should receive special attention.

The measures suggested above in the interest of the students and the country should, in the natural course, reduce the frequency of violent outbursts but it will be too much to hope that they will be a cure for the present student indiscipline. We need not take a tragic view of the ebullition of feeling and rowdyism among the students. A wellknown proverb says, " Anyone under twenty who is not a radical does not have a heart; anyone over forty who still is one does not have a head." Young men will be young men, but we cannot make light of the resort to violence by striking students, which has taken the form of destruction of university property, burning of buses and cars and cinema houses, attackes on post offices and railway stations and, sometimes, manhandling of teachers and university officers. Recently in a northern university a student was stabbed on the campus and another student was thrown off the roof of a two-storey hostel. Severe notice should be taken of such conduct. The students should not be allowed to feel that they are a privileged class and that they are not amenable to the law which is applicable to the rest of the community.

The cure for this malady depends on the courage and understanding of the students themselves,﻿ They are assuredly friends of democracy whose existence depends upon the appreciation of its ethies by the younger generation. They should, therefore, respect the democratic process where their own interests are concerned. The large majority of students who realize the value of knowledge at the present time and want to carry out their studies have so far given in to an organised and determined minority whose actions have unfortunately received widespread publicity. It is their duty to resist the attempts of the minority which wants to disrupt their studies. Their failure to do so will result in the developnient of institutionalised terrorism or lead to prolonged discontinuance of studies in the colleges and universities.

Widespread student revolts in other countries, particularly in Europe and the United States, have sometimes been referred to almost as a justification for the unrest among Indian students. But violence déserves condemnation wherever it may manifest itself, and well-known educationists have, as a matter of fact, condemned it at least in some of the important western countries. It has also been said that the revolt is due to the dissatisfaction of the youth with the ideas of the older generation. I should welcome the rejection of old ideas, for absence of adjustment to changing circumstances would lead to stagnation and decay, if I discerned any new ideas that might be expected to take the place of the old. But, for all its﻿ seeming radicalism, the student movement in India does not appear to be actuated by any large social or political purpose, as it was during the struggle for national freedom: it is now linked to no ideology.

The language question has a vital bearing on higher education and the unity of the country. It is admitted on all hands that theoretically the mother tongue should be the medium of instruction. But the regional languages unfortunately are underdeveloped. There is hardly any literature in any of them, not merely on science and technology but on such subjects as history, politics, economics and sociology. The Central and State authorities and the educationists will have to work together for a long time to make them capable of expressing modern ideas, and become fit. vehicles of modern knowledge. In the interest of education, there should be a phased transition from English to the regional languages as media of instruction.

This question should also be considered in relation to national integration. It will be readily agreed that the inter-state migration of students and teachers is highly desirable from the point of view both of education and of national unity. This will, however, not be possible if the regional languages are the sole media of education in universities. If this is done, the Central universities which are at present regarded as all﻿ India universities will be so only in name in future. No student in one state will be able to benefit by the scholarship of an able teacher in any other state unless he learns the language in which instruction is given in the university to which the teacher belongs. The teachers also will be prevented by the linguistic barrier from seeking employment, delivering lectures or taking part in examinations in other universities. The principal task of education should be to make our young men and women feel that they are Indians first and anything else afterwards; but prematurely making the regional languages the media of instruction in universities will actually make them parochial and give the first place in their thoughts to their states. I have no doubt that is important universities whose facilities are taken advantage of by persons in different parts of the country, there should be room in future also for teachers and students coming from states other than those in which they are situated. It is necessary for this that provision should also be made for teaching in a language which educated men all over the country can easily understand, which is English. This will lead to extra expenditure, but for a very good purpose. As the purpose is national, the central government should, if necessary, bear a part of the expenditure.

Hindi aspires to replace English as the common language of the intelligentsia. I have every hope﻿ that it will be able to realise its ambition if its advocates act with moderation and remove the impression among the non-Hindi speaking people that they are linguistic imperialists trying to force their language on them. But it is obvious that Hindi will take a fairly long time to establish itself as the medium of communication between educated men throughout the country.

English is a help to us at present in maintaining the unity of India and is an important language of international communication. It also provides us with a window on the world. It enables us to keep in touch with new developments in science. technology and the humanities. Its knowledge is, therefore, indispensable to the progress of the country and arrangements for teaching it should be greatly improved. Learning it properly should not be regarded as a hardship. In many countries, boys and girls are required to have a good knowledge of at least one internationally recognised language. The State governments are doing a great injustice to our boys and girls and prejudicing their future by neglecting this important question. They must bear no small part of the responsibility for the present acute discontent among the students because of the poor education which they receive in the secondary schools.

Notwithstanding what has happened, I have faith in our young men and women, who will provide the country with its future leaders. They﻿ are full of idealism and enthusiasm. If they have the right kind of leadership, they can bring about a transformation of the educational system and be a powerful instrument for imparting a new moral vitality to our hidebound society. I lay special stress on this because this is Gandhiji's birth centenary year. He wrote in Young India in 1931, “I shall work for an India in which the poorest shall feel that it is their country in whose making they have an effective voice; an India in which there shall be no high class and low class; an India in which all communities shall live in perfect harmony"; and in his constructive programme he emphasized the necessity of our working wholeheartedly for Hindu-Muslim unity and the removal of the disgrace of untouchability from our society. We should add the uplift of the tribal people to these items. I ask our young people to strive in accordance with their circumstances to bring into existence, the India of Gandhiji's dreams. Let them pledge themselves like the spartan youths to pass on the country to the coming generation better and happier than it is. They can have no greater happiness than the happiness of knowing that through their efforts others are happy.﻿

ADDRESS BY D.C. PAVATE 12th Dec. 1970
ಕುಲಾಧಿಪತಿಗಳಾದ ಶ್ರೀ ಧರ್ಮವೀರರೆ, ಕುಲಪತಿಗಳಾದ ಪ್ರೊ. ಜವರೇಗೌಡರೆ, ಮಹಿಳೆಯರೆ, ಮಹನೀಯರೆ, ವಿವಿಧ ಪರೀಕ್ಷೆಗಳಲ್ಲಿ ಉತ್ತೀರ್ಣರಾಗಿರುವ ವಿದ್ಯಾರ್ಥಿ-ವಿದ್ಯಾರ್ಥಿನಿಯರೆ :

ನನ್ನನ್ನು ಇಲ್ಲಿಗೆ ಈ ಘಟಕೋತ್ಸವಕ್ಕೆ ಆಮಂತ್ರಿಸಿದುದಕ್ಕಾಗಿ ಮೊಟ್ಟ ಮೊದಲು, ಮೈಸೂರು ವಿಶ್ವವಿದ್ಯಾನಿಲಯದ ಅಧಿಕಾರಿವರ್ಗಕ್ಕೆ ನಾನು ನನ್ನ ಹೃತ್ಪೂರ್ವಕ ಕೃತಜ್ಞತೆಯನ್ನು ಸಲ್ಲಿಸುತ್ತೇನೆ. ಈ ವಿಶ್ವವಿದ್ಯಾ ನಿಲಯದ ವಿದ್ಯಾರ್ಥಿ ನಾನಾಗಿದ್ದರೆ ಒಳ್ಳೆಯದಾಗುತ್ತಿತ್ತೆಂದು ನನಗೆ ಅನಿಸು ತದೆ. ಅದು ಸಾಧ್ಯವಾಗಲಿಲ್ಲ. ಆದಾಗ್ಯೂ ನಾನು ಈ ವಿಶ್ವವಿದ್ಯಾನಿಲಯದ ಪದವೀಧರನಿದ್ದೇನೆ. ಕೆಲವು ವರ್ಷಗಳ ಹಿಂದೆ ಮೈಸೂರು ವಿಶ್ವವಿದ್ಯಾ ನಿಲಯ ನನಗೆ ಗೌರವ ಡಿ. ಎಸ್ಸಿ. ಪದವಿಯನ್ನಿತ್ತಿತು, ಅಂತೇ ನಾನು ಈಗ ನಿಮ್ಮವರಲ್ಲಿ ಒಬ್ಬ. ಆದರೆ ಮೈಸೂರು ವಿಶ್ವವಿದ್ಯಾನಿಲಯದ ಬಗ್ಗೆ ನನಗೆ ಚಿಕ್ಕಂದಿನಿಂದ ಅಪಾರ ಗೌರವವಿದ್ದಿತು. ನಾನು ವಿದ್ಯಾರ್ಥಿ ಯಾಗಿದ್ದಾಗಿನಿಂದಲೂ ಈ ಭಾವನೆ ನನ್ನಲ್ಲಿ ಮನೆಮಾಡಿಕೊಂಡಿತ್ತು. ಇದಕ್ಕೆ ಕಾರಣವೆಂದರೆ, ಮೈಸೂರು ವಿಶ್ವವಿದ್ಯಾನಿಲಯವು ಕನ್ನಡ ಸಾಹಿತ್ಯ-ಸಂಸ್ಕೃತಿಗಳನ್ನು ಸಂರಕ್ಷಿಸುವ ಭದ್ರ ಕೋಟೆಯಾಗಿತ್ತು. .

ಉತ್ತರ ಕರ್ನಾಟಕದಲ್ಲಿ ಆಗ ಈ ಸೌಕರ್ಯಗಳಿರಲಿಲ್ಲ. ವಿದ್ಯಾರ್ಥಿ. ಯಾಗಿದ್ದಾಗ ನಾನೂ ಕನ್ನಡ ಕವಿಯಾಗಬೇಕೆಂಬ ಮಹತ್ವಾಕಾಂಕ್ಷೆ ಯನ್ನು ತಾಳಿದ್ದೆ. ಆದರೆ ಈ ಆಕಾಂಕ್ಷೆಗೆ ನೀರೆರೆಯುವವರಾರೂ ಆಗ ಇರಲಿಲ್ಲ. ನನ್ನ ಕವಿತೆಗಳನ್ನು ನೋಡಿದ ಮಹನೀಯರು, ನಾನು ಇನ್ನೂ ಚಿಕ್ಕವನೆಂದೂ, ಕವನಗಳನ್ನು ಬರೆಯುವ ಮೊದಲು ಕನ್ನಡದಲ್ಲಿಯ ಮಹಾ ಕಾವ್ಯಗಳನ್ನು ಆಳವಾಗಿ ಅಭ್ಯಸಿಸಬೇಕೆಂದೂ ಉಪದೇಶಿಸಿದರು. ಮುಂದೆ ನಾನು ಕವಿತೆಗಳನ್ನು ಬರೆಯುವುದನ್ನು ಬಿಟ್ಟಿ ನಲ್ಲದೆ, ಕನ್ನಡ ಗ್ರಂಥಗಳ ನೋದುವುದನ್ನೂ ಕೈಬಿಟ್ಟೆ, ನನ್ನ ಕನ್ನಡ ಸಾಹಿತ್ಯ ಸಾಧನೆಗೆ ಅಷ್ಟಕ್ಕೇ ಇತಿಶ್ರೀಯಾಯಿತು. ಉತ್ತರ ಕರ್ನಾಟಕದಲ್ಲಿ ಆಗ ಕನ್ನಡದ ಅಭ್ಯಾಸ ಒಂದು ತುದಿಗೆ ಬರಿ ಪ್ರಾಥಮಿಕ ಶಾಲೆ ಇಲ್ಲವೆ ಇನ್ನೊಂದು ತುದಿಗೆ ಎಂ. ಎ. ಡಿಗ್ರಿ ವರ್ಗಗಳಿಗೆ ಮಾತ್ರ ಸೀಮಿತವಾಗಿತ್ತು. ನಡುವಣ ಹಂತದಲ್ಲಿ ಅದರ ಗಂಧವಿರಲಿಲ್ಲ. ಹೀಗಾಗಿ ಮುಂಬಯಿ ವಿಶ್ವವಿದ್ಯಾಲಯದ ಪದವಿ ಪಡೆಯಲು ವಷ್ಟರಲ್ಲಿ ಕನ್ನಡದ ಅಭ್ಯಾಸದ ಬಗ್ಗೆ ನನ್ನ ಉತ್ಸಾಹ ಸಂಪೂರ್ಣವಾಗಿ ಕುಂದಿಹೋಗಿತ್ತು,

ಆದರೆ ಮೈಸೂರು ವಿಶ್ವವಿದ್ಯಾನಿಲಯದಲ್ಲಿ ಕನ್ನಡದ ದೀಪ ಎಂದಿ ನಿಂದಲೂ ದೇದೀಪ್ಯಮಾನವಾಗಿದೆ. ೧೯೧೬ನೇ ಇಸ್ವಿಯಲ್ಲಿ ದಿವಂಗತ﻿ ಭಾರತರತ್ನ ಎಂ. ವಿಶ್ವೇಶ್ವರಯ್ಯನವರ ದೂರದರ್ಶಿತ್ವದಿಂದ ಪ್ರಾರಂಭವಾಗಿ, ತನ್ನದೇ ಆದ ವಿದ್ವತ್ತು-ಸಂಶೋಧನಗಳ ಪರಂಪರೆಯನ್ನು ಮೈಸೂರು ವಿಶ್ವವಿದ್ಯಾನಿಲಯ ಬೆಳೆಯಿಸಿಕೊಂಡಿತು. ಉಳಿದ ವಿಶ್ವವಿದ್ಯಾನಿಲಯಗಳ ಕಣ್ಣು ಕುಕ್ಕುವಂತೆ, ಪ್ರತಿಭಾವಂತ ಪ್ರಾಧ್ಯಾಪಕರ ಸೇವೆಯನ್ನು ದೊರಕಿಸಿ ಕೊಂಡು ಉತ್ತಮ ಸ್ಥಾನವನ್ನು ಗಳಿಸಿತು. ಶ್ರೇಷ್ಠ ವಿಜ್ಞಾನಿಗಳನ್ನೂ, . ಅರ್ಥಶಾಸ್ತ್ರಜ್ಞರನ್ನೂ , ತತ್ವಜ್ಞಾನಿಗಳನ್ನೂ, ಸಾಹಿತಿಗಳನ್ನೂ ತರಬೇತು ಗೊಳಿಸಿತು. ಕನ್ನಡದ ಆಧುನಿಕೀಕರಣವನ್ನು ಸಾಧಿಸಿ ಅದನ್ನು ಕೊನೆಯ ಹಂತದವರೆಗೆ ಶಿಕ್ಷಣದ ಮಾಧ್ಯಮವನ್ನಾಗಿ ಮಾಡಿತು. ಇಂದಿನ ಭಾರತದ ಶ್ರೇಷ್ಠ ಕವಿಗಳಲ್ಲೊಬ್ಬರಾದ ಕುವೆಂಪುರವರು ಇಲ್ಲಿಯೇ ವಿದ್ಯಾರ್ಥಿಯಾಗಿ ಬೆಳೆದು ಪ್ರಾಧ್ಯಾಪಕ-ಕುಲಪತಿಗಳಾಗಿ ಅಮೋಘ ಸೇವೆ ಸಲ್ಲಿಸಿದರು. ಕನ್ನಡ ನಾಡಿನಲ್ಲೆಲ್ಲ ಅವರ ಹೆಸರು ಮನೆಮಾತಾಗಿದೆ. ಅವರ ನೇತೃತ್ವದಲ್ಲಿ ನಡೆದ ಕನ್ನಡ ಇಲಾಖೆಯೇ ನಿಮ್ಮ ಇಂದಿನ ಕುಲಪತಿಗಳಾದ ಪ್ರೊಫೆಸರ್‌ ಜವರೇಗೌಡರವರನ್ನು ಮೈಸೂರು ವಿಶ್ವವಿದ್ಯಾನಿಲಯಕ್ಕೆ ಒದಗಿಸಿಕೊಟ್ಟಿದೆ. ಅವರೂ ಖ್ಯಾತ ಸಾಹಿತಿಗಳು, ಕನ್ನಡದ ಜ್ಞಾನಕೋಶವನ್ನು ಜನತೆಗೆ ಒದಗಿ ಸುವದರಲ್ಲಿ ಅವರು ಪರಿಶ್ರಮವಹಿಸಿರುವದಲ್ಲದೆ, ಕನ್ನಡ ನಾಡಿನ ಎಲ್ಲ ಭಾಗಗಳ ಸಾಹಿತಿಗಳಿಗೆ ಅವರು ಪ್ರೋತ್ಸಾಹವನ್ನು ನೀಡಿದ್ದಾರೆ. ಮೊನ್ನೆ ಮೊನ್ನೆ ಅವರು ರಷ್ಯಾ ದೇಶದ ಪ್ರವಾಸವನ್ನು ಕೈಕೊಂಡಾಗ, ಕೀವ್ ವಿಶ್ವ ವಿದ್ಯಾನಿಲಯ ಅವರಿಗೆ ಲೆನಿನ್ ಪಾರಿತೋಷಕವನ್ನು ಕೊಟ್ಟು ಸತ್ಕರಿಸಿ ಕನ್ನಡ ಜನತೆಯನ್ನು ಗೌರವಿಸಿತು. ಇದಕ್ಕಾಗಿ ನಾನು ಅವರನ್ನು ಹೃತ್ ಪೂರ್ವಕವಾಗಿ ಅಭಿನಂದಿಸುತ್ತೇನೆ.

ಇಂತಹ ಸಂದರ್ಭದಲ್ಲಿ ಈ ಘಟಿಕೋತ್ಸವದಲ್ಲಿ ಭಾಗವಹಿಸುವದೆಂದರೆ ಯಾವ ಕನ್ನಡಿಗನ ಮೈ ಪುಲಕಿತವಾಗಲಿಕ್ಕಿಲ್ಲ ?

ನಮ್ಮ ದೇಶದಲ್ಲಿ ಪ್ರಜಾಪ್ರಭುತ್ವವು ಭದ್ರವಾಗಬೇಕಾಗಿದೆ. ಸಾಮಾ ಜಿಕ ವಿಕಾಸಕ್ಕೆ ತುಂಬ ಆಸ್ಪದ ಕೊಡಬೇಕಾಗಿದೆ. ಭಾರತೀಯರು ತಮ್ಮ ದೇಶದ ಸ್ವಾತಂತ್ರವನ್ನೂ , ಪ್ರಜಾಪ್ರಭುತ್ವವನ್ನೂ ಒಂದು ಅಮೂಲ್ಯ ಸಾಧನವನ್ನಾಗಿ ಉಪಯೋಗಿಸಿಕೊಂಡು ತಮ್ಮ ರಾಷ್ಟ್ರದ ಸಾಂಸತ್ತಿಕ ಸ್ಥಿತಿಯನ್ನು ಸುಧಾರಿಸುವದಲ್ಲದೆ, ಜನಸಾಮಾನ್ಯರ ಕಲ್ಯಾಣ ವನ್ನು ಸಾಧಿಸಬೇಕಾಗಿದೆ. ಆರ್ಥಿಕ ಸಂಪತ್ತಿನೊಡನೆ ಬೌದ್ದಿಕ ಸಂಪತ್ತನ್ನೂ, ಹೃದಯ ಸಂಪತ್ತನ್ನೂ ಸಂವರ್ಧಿಸಬೇಕಾಗಿದೆ. ಈ ಮಹತ್ ಕಾರ್ಯದಲ್ಲಿ ಹೊಸ ಪೀಳಿಗೆಯ ಹೊಸ ಉತ್ಸಾಹದ ತರುಣರು ವಹಿಸಬೇಕಾದ ಪಾತ್ರ ವಿಶಿಷ್ಟವಾಗಿದೆ. ಅದನ್ನು ಕುರಿತು ಒಂದೆರಡು ಮಾತನ್ನು ಹೇಳಲಿಚ್ಛಿಸುತೇನೆ. ﻿

ಬೇರೊಂದು ಆರ್ಥಿಕ ಸಾಮಾಜಿಕ ಪರಿಸ್ಥಿತಿಯಲ್ಲಿ ಬೆಳೆದ ನನ್ನ ತಲೆ ಮಾರಿನವರಿಗೆ ಹೊಸ ಪೀಳಿಗೆಯ ಆಶೋತ್ತರಗಳನ್ನು ಸರಿಯಾಗಿ ತಿಳಿದು ಕೊಳ್ಳುವದು ಸ್ವಲ್ಪ ಕಠಿಣವಾಗಿದೆ. ಕಳೆದ ತಿಂಗಳು, ಉತ್ತರ ಹಿಂದೂ ಸ್ವಾನದ ಪ್ರವಾಸವನ್ನು ಕೈಕೊಂಡ ಮೈಸೂರು ವಿಶ್ವವಿದ್ಯಾನಿಲಯದ ಕೆಲವು ವಿದ್ಯಾರ್ಥಿಗಳು ಪಂಜಾಬ ರಾಜಭವನಕ್ಕೂ ಬಂದು ನನ್ನನ್ನು ಕಂಡಿದ್ದರು. ಅಲ್ಲೋಪಹಾರದ ಸಂದರ್ಭದಲ್ಲಿ ಮಾತುಕತೆ ನಡೆದಾಗ, “ ವಿದ್ಯಾರ್ಥಿಗಳು ರಾಜಕಾರಣದಲ್ಲಿ ಭಾಗವಹಿಸುವದನ್ನು ಕುರಿತು ತಮ್ಮ ಅಭಿಪ್ರಾಯವೇನು ? ” ಎಂದು ಅವರಲ್ಲೊಬ್ಬರು ನನ್ನನ್ನು ಕೇಳಿದರು. ಉತ್ತರ ಹಿಂದೂಸ್ತಾನದಲ್ಲಿ ನಡೆದ ಸಂಗತಿಗಳು ನನ್ನ ಜ್ಞಾಪಕಕ್ಕೆ ಬಂದವು. ಕಾಲೇಜಿನ ಕ್ಷೇತ್ರದಲ್ಲಿ ವಸತಿಗೃಹ ಇಲ್ಲವೆ ಜಮ್ಖಾನಾ ಚುನಾವಣೆಗಳಲ್ಲಿ, ಅಥವಾ ಕಾಲೇಜ ಯೂನಿಯನ್ನಿನಲ್ಲಿ ಭಾಗವಹಿಸುವದನ್ನು ನೀವು ರಾಜ ಕಾರಣವೆಂದು ತಿಳಿಯುವದಾದರೆ ಅದರಲ್ಲಿ ಅನುಚಿತವಾದುದೇನೂ ಇಲ್ಲ ವೆಂದು ನಾನು ಹೇಳಿದೆ. ಆದರೆ ವಿಧಾನಸಭೆ ಇಲ್ಲವೆ ಲೋಕಸಭೆಯ ಚುನಾವಣೆಗೆ ಹುರಿಯಾಳಾಗಿ ನಿಲ್ಲುವದಾಗಲಿ, ಇಲ್ಲವೆ ತಮಗೆ ತಾತ್ಕಾಲಿಕ ಸಂಬಂಧವಿಲ್ಲದ ವ್ಯವಹಾರದಲ್ಲಿ ವಿದ್ಯಾರ್ಥಿದೆಶೆಯಲ್ಲಿದ್ದಾಗಲೂ ಅಗ್ರ ಪಾತ್ರವಹಿಸುವದೆಂದರೆ ವಿದ್ಯಾರ್ಥಿಗಳು ತಮ್ಮ ಆಯುಷ್ಯವನ್ನು ಹಾಳು ಮಾಡಿಕೊಂಡಂತಾಗುವುದೆಂದು ನನ್ನ ಅಭಿಪ್ರಾಯವಾಗಿತ್ತು, ಅಭ್ಯಾಸದ ಬಗ್ಗೆ ಶ್ರದ್ಧೆ, ನಿಷ್ಠೆ ವಿದ್ಯಾರ್ಥಿಗಳಲ್ಲಿರುವದೂ ಅತ್ಯಾವಶ್ಯಕ. ಇಲ್ಲದಿದ್ದರೆ ಅವರನ್ನು ವಿದ್ಯಾರ್ಜನೆಗಾಗಿ ಕಳಿಸಿದ ಹಿರಿಯರ ಹಣವನ್ನೂ ವಿದ್ಯಾರ್ಥಿಗಳು ಹಾಳುಮಾಡಿದಂತಾಗುತ್ತದೆಂಬುದು ನನ್ನ ಖಂಡಿತ ಅಭಿಪ್ರಾಯವೆಂದೂ ಹೇಳಿದೆನು. ಆದರೆ ನನ್ನ ಅಭಿಪ್ರಾಯ ಆ ವಿದ್ಯಾರ್ಥಿ ಮಿತ್ರರಿಗೆ ಎಷ್ಟರ ಮಟ್ಟಿಗೆ ರುಚಿಸಿತೋ ನನಗೆ ಗೊತ್ತಿಲ್ಲ. ಆದರೆ ಇದು ಎಲ್ಲರೂ ಕಲೆತು ವಿಚಾರಮಾಡುವ ವಿಷಯವಾಗಿದೆ. ವಿದ್ಯಾಸಂಪಾದನೆಯ ಅನಂತರ ನಿಮ್ಮ ಇಡಿ ಆಯುಷ್ಯವನ್ನೇ ರಾಜಕಾರಣದಲ್ಲಿ ತೊಡಗಿಸಬಹುದು. ಆದರೆ ಶಾರೀರಿಕ, ಮಾನಸಿಕ ಮತ್ತು ನೈತಿಕ ವಿಕಾಸದ ಕಾಲದಲ್ಲಿ ರಾಜಕಾರಣದ ಮೋಹ ವಿದ್ಯಾರ್ಥಿಗಳಿಗೇಕೆಂಬುದು ನನಗೆ ತಿಳಿಯುವಂತಿಲ್ಲ.

ಜಗತ್ತಿನ ಎಲ್ಲ ಭಾಗಗಳಲ್ಲಿಯ ವಿಶ್ವವಿದ್ಯಾನಿಲಯಗಳಲ್ಲಿ ಹೊಸ ವಿಚಾರಗಳ ಗಾಳಿಯೊಂದು ಈಗ ಬೀಸುತ್ತಿದೆ. ವಿದ್ಯಾರ್ಥಿಗಳು ಏನೆಲ್ಲ ಪ್ರಶ್ನೆ ಗಳನ್ನೂ ಇಂದು ಕೇಳುತ್ತಿದ್ದಾರೆ. ಅವರ ವಿಚಾರಗಳನ್ನು ನಾವು ಅತ್ಯಂತ ಸಹಾನುಭೂತಿಯಿಂದ ಕೇಳಿಕೊಳ್ಳಬೇಕು. ರಾಷ್ಟ್ರೀಯ ಹಿತ ಮೂಲಗಳಿಗೆ ಅವು ಪೋಷಕವಾಗಿದ್ದರೆ ಮತ್ತು ಅವರ ವ್ಯಕ್ತಿತ್ವದ﻿ ಸಂವರ್ಧನೆಗೆ ಅನುಕೂಲವಾಗಿದ್ದರೆ, ಅವರ ಸೂಚನೆಗಳನ್ನು ಅವಶ್ಯವಾಗಿ ಸ್ವೀಕರಿಸಬೇಕು.

ವಿದ್ಯಾಸಂಸ್ಥೆಗಳಲ್ಲಿಯೂ ಸಂಶೋಧನಾಲಯಗಳಲ್ಲಿಯೂ ನಡೆಯುವ ಕಾರ್ಯವಹತಿ, ಹಿಂದೆಂದೂ ಇಲ್ಲದಂತೆ, ಸಮಕಾಲೀನ ಜಗತ್ತಿನ ರೂಪ ರೇಷೆಗಳನ್ನು ಇಂದು ನಿಶ್ಚಿತಗೊಳಿಸುತ್ತಿದೆ. ಅಂತೆಯೇ ವಿದ್ಯಾರ್ಥಿಗಳು ಉತ್ತಮ ಶಿಕ್ಷಕರೊಡನೆ ನಿಕಟ ಸಂಪರ್ಕವನ್ನಿಟ್ಟುಕೊಳ್ಳುವದು ಇಂದು ಅವಶ್ಯವಾಗಿದೆ. ಈ ರೀತಿ ಮಾತ್ರ ಒಂದು ಉತ್ತಮ ಸಾಂಸ್ಕೃತಿಕ ಸಂಪ್ರದಾಯವನ್ನು ನಾವು ಬೆಳೆಯಿಸಿಕೊಂಡು ಬರಬಹುದು. ಈ ಸಂದರ್ಭದಲ್ಲಿ ರಷ್ಯಾ ದೇಶದಲ್ಲಿ ಮಾಡುವಂತೆ ನಮ್ಮ ದೇಶದಲ್ಲಿಯೂ ಸಹ ಪ್ರತಿಭಾವಂತ ವಿದ್ಯಾರ್ಥಿಗಳನ್ನಾರಿಸಿ ಅವರಿಗೆ ಸೇರುವ ವಿಶಿಷ್ಟ ತರಬೇತಿಯನ್ನು ಕೊಡುವದು ಈಗ ಉತ್ತಮ ವಿಧಾನವೆಂದು ನನಗೆ ತೋರುತ್ತಿದೆ. ನಿಮ್ಮ ಕುಲಪತಿಗಳು ಇದೀಗ ರಷ್ಯಾ ದೇಶದ ಪ್ರವಾಸ ವನ್ನು ಮುಗಿಸಿಕೊಂಡು ಬಂದಿದ್ದಾರೆ. ಅಲ್ಲಿಯ ಮಾಸ್ಕೋ, ಲೆನಿನ್‌ಗ್ರಾಡ ಮುಂತಾದ ಮೇರಗತಿಯ ವಿಶ್ವವಿದ್ಯಾನಿಲಯಗಳಲ್ಲಿ, ಎರಡು ವರ್ಷಗಳ ಪ್ರಿಯೂನಿವರ್ಸಿಟಿ ಶಿಕ್ಷಣವನ್ನು ಪ್ರತಿಭಾವಂತ ವಿದ್ಯಾರ್ಥಿಗಳಿಗೋಸ್ಕರ ಏರ್ಪಡಿಸಿರುವದನ್ನು ಅವರು ನೋಡಿರಬಹುದು. ಅಲ್ಲಿ ಭೌತಶಾಸ್ತ್ರ ಮತ್ತು ಗಣಿತಶಾಸ್ತ್ರಗಳನ್ನು ಆಧುನಿಕ ರೀತಿಯಲ್ಲಿ ಕಲಿಸುತ್ತಾರೆ. ಮುಂದೆ ವಿಶ್ವ ವಿದ್ಯಾನಿಲಯದಲ್ಲಿಯೂ ಅವರವರು ಆಯ್ಕೆ ಮಾಡಿದ ವಿಷಯಗಳಲ್ಲಿಯೇ ಅವರಿಗೆ ತರಬೇತಿ ಕೊಡಲಾಗುತ್ತದೆ. ರಷ್ಯನ್ ಎಂಜಿನಿಯರ್‌ಗಳು ಹಾಗೂ ವಿಜ್ಞಾನಿಗಳು ಶ್ರೇಷ್ಠ ಮಟ್ಟವನ್ನು ಮುಟ್ಟಿರುವ ರಹಸ್ಯ ಇಲ್ಲಿದೆ. ನಮ್ಮ ದೇಶದಲ್ಲಿಯೂ ವೈಜ್ಞಾನಿಕ ವಿಷಯಗಳಲ್ಲದೆ, ಇನ್ನಿತರ ವಿಷಯಗಳಲ್ಲಿಯೂ ಈ ಕ್ರಮವನ್ನು ನಾವು ಅನುಸರಿಸಬಹುದು. ಎಲ್ಲ ವಿದ್ಯಾರ್ಥಿಗಳನ್ನು ಒಂದೇ ಪಡಿಯಚ್ಚಿನಲ್ಲಿ ಹಾಕಿ ತೆಗೆಯುವದೆಂದರೆ ದೇಶಕ್ಕೆ ಅಪಾಯವಾಗು ತದೆ. ಇಂಥ ಉತ್ತಮ ಶ್ರೇಣಿಯ ವಿದ್ಯಾರ್ಥಿಗಳು ಯೋಗ್ಯ ಶಿಕ್ಷಣವನ್ನು ಪಡೆದು ಮುಂದೆ ಉತ್ತಮ ಪ್ರಾಧ್ಯಾಪಕ, ಸಂಶೋಧಕ ಇಲ್ಲವೆ ಆಡಳಿತ ಗಾರರಾಗಿ ದೇಶಸೇವೆಯನ್ನು ಸಲ್ಲಿಸಲಿಕ್ಕೆ ಸಮರ್ಥರಾಗುತ್ತಾರೆ. ರಷ್ಯ ದಂತಹ ಸಮತಾವಾದಿ ದೇಶದಲ್ಲಿಯೂ ಕೂಡ ಆಯ್ದ ಪ್ರತಿಭಾವಂತ ವಿದ್ಯಾ ರ್ಥಿಗಳಿಗೋಸ್ಕರವೆಂದೇ ವಿಶೇಷ ಶಿಕ್ಷಣ ತರಗತಿಗಳನ್ನು ಏರ್ಪಡಿಸುತ್ತಾರೆ. ಇಂತಹ ಶಿಕ್ಷಣಗಳನ್ನು ಮಾನವಿಕ ವಿಷಯಗಳಲ್ಲಿಯೂ ಏರ್ಪಡಿಸಿದರೆ ಮೈಸೂರು ರಾಜ್ಯದ ವಿದ್ಯಾರ್ಥಿಗಳು ಐ. ಎ. ಎಸ್., ಐ. ಪಿ ಎಸ್. ಮುಂತಾದ ಪರೀಕ್ಷೆಗಳಲ್ಲಿ ಹೆಚ್ಚು ಪ್ರಮಾಣದಲ್ಲಿ ಉತ್ತೀರ್ಣರಾಗಬಹುದು. ಈ ಪರೀಕ್ಷೆಗಳಿಗೆ ಬೇಕಾದ ಮುಖ್ಯ ವಿಷಯಗಳು ಇಂಗ್ಲಿಷ್, ಇತಿಹಾಸ,﻿ ಅರ್ಥಶಾಸ್ತ್ರ, ರಾಜನೀತಿ ಮುಂತಾದವುಗಳು. .ಮೈಸೂರು ರಾಜ್ಯದ ವಿದ್ಯಾರ್ಥಿಗಳು ಈ ಪರೀಕ್ಷೆಗಳಲ್ಲಿ ಸಾಕಷ್ಟು ಸಂಖ್ಯೆಯಲ್ಲಿ ಉತ್ತೀರ್ಣ ರಾಗುತ್ತಿಲ್ಲ. ಎಲ್ಲ ವಿದ್ಯಾರ್ಥಿಗಳಿಗೂ ಈ ಪರೀಕ್ಷೆಗಳ ಮಹತ್ವ ತಿಳಿಯುವಂತೆ ಮೈಸೂರು ರಾಜ್ಯದಲ್ಲಿಯ ವಿಶ್ವವಿದ್ಯಾನಿಲಯಗಳು ಪ್ರಯತ್ನಿ ಸಬೇಕಾಗಿದೆ. ಅಲ್ಲದೆ ಇಂಗ್ಲಿಷ್, ರಷ್ಯನ್ ಮೊದಲಾದ ಪರಭಾಷೆಗಳಲ್ಲಿ ಪರಿಣತ ಶಿಕ್ಷಣ ಹೆಚ್ಚಾಗಿ ದೊರೆಯುವಂತೆ ಶ್ರಮಿಸಬೇಕಾಗಿದೆ. ಒಂದು ವಿಶ್ವವಿದ್ಯಾನಿಲಯದ ಸ್ಥಾನಮಾನ ಅದರ ಇಲಾಖೆಗಳಲ್ಲಿ ನಡೆಯುವ ಸಂಶೋಧನ ಕಾರ್ಯ ದಿಂದಲೂ, ಹಾಗೂ ರಾಷ್ಟ್ರೀಯ ಮಟ್ಟದ ಪರೀಕ್ಷೆಗಳಲ್ಲಿ ವಿದ್ಯಾರ್ಥಿಗಳು ಪಡೆಯುವ ಯಶಸ್ಸಿನಿಂದಲೂ ನಿರ್ಣಯಿತವಾಗುತ್ತದೆ.

ಕನ್ನಡ ಈಗ ದಿನದಿನಕ್ಕೆ ತನ್ನ ಸ್ಥಾನಮಾನಗಳನ್ನು ಕಂಡುಕೊಳ್ಳು ತಿರುವದು ನಮ್ಮೆಲ್ಲರಿಗೂ ಸಂತೋಷಪ್ರದವಾದ ಮಾತಾಗಿದೆ. ದೇಶದ ಅತ್ಯಂತ ಪ್ರಾಚೀನ ಹಾಗೂ ಉಜ್ವಲ ಭಾಷೆಗಳಲ್ಲಿ ಕನ್ನಡಕ್ಕೆ ಗಣ್ಯ ಸ್ಥಾನವಿದೆ. ಅದು ನಮ್ಮ ಉಸಿರಾಗಿದೆ.

ಕನ್ನಡಿಗರು ಸದಾ ಭಾರತೀಯ ಪ್ರಜ್ಞೆಯನ್ನು ಸಹ ಸರಾಗವಾಗಿ ಬೆಳೆಸಿಕೊಂಡು ಬಂದಿದ್ದಾರೆ. ಕನ್ನಡ ನಾಡು ಸಾವಿರ ವರ್ಷಗಳಿಂದ ಭಾರತೀಯ ಪುನರುಜ್ಜಿವನದಲ್ಲಿ ಕಾಲಕಾಲಕ್ಕೆ ಭಾಗವಹಿಸಿದೆ. ಈ ರಾಷ್ಟ್ರೀಯ ಪಾತ್ರವನ್ನು ನಾವು ಪೋಷಿಸಿಕೊಂಡು ಮುಂದುವರಿಯು ಬೇಕಾಗಿದೆ. ಇದಕ್ಕಾಗಿ ದಿಕ್ಕು ದಿಕ್ಕಿನಿಂದ ಬಂದ ಜ್ಞಾನಭಂಡಾರವನ್ನು ಅರಗಿಸಿಕೊಳ್ಳದೆ ಉಪಾಯವಿಲ್ಲ. ಎಲ್ಲ ಜ್ಞಾನಕ್ಷೇತ್ರಗಳಲ್ಲಿಯೂ ನಾವು ಮುನ್ನುಗ್ಗಬೇಕು. ದೇಶವನ್ನೂ , ಜಗತ್ತನ್ನೂ ಕನ್ನಡ-ನಾಲಕ ನಾವು ತಿಳಿದುಕೊಂಡಿರಬೇಕು.

ಇದು ವಿಜ್ಞಾನ ಹಾಗೂ ಯಂತ್ರಶಿಲ್ಪದ ಯುಗವಾಗಿದೆ. ಜನತೆಯ ಬಡತನವನ್ನು ಹೊಡೆದೋಡಿಸಲು ಹಾಗೂ ಜೀವನದ ಮಟ್ಟವನ್ನು ಸುಧಾರಿ ಸಲು ವಿಜ್ಞಾನ ಯಂತ್ರಶಿಲ್ಪಗಳು ನಿರ್ಣಾಯಕ ಸಾಧನಾಂಶಗಳಾಗಿವೆ. ಎಲ್ಲ ಕುಶಾಗ್ರ ಬುದ್ಧಿಯ ವಿದ್ಯಾರ್ಥಿಗಳಿಗೆ ಸ್ವಲ್ಪ ವಿವರವಾಗಿ ವಿಜ್ಞಾನ, ಯಂತ್ರಶಿಲ್ಪ ಶಾಸ್ತ್ರಗಳನ್ನು ಅಭ್ಯಸಿಸುವ ಸುಸಂಧಿ ದೊರೆಯುವಂತೆ ನಾವು ಅಭ್ಯಾಸಕ್ರಮದಲ್ಲಿ ಏರ್ಪಾಟು ಮಾಡಬೇಕಾಗಿದೆ. ಸೈದ್ಧಾಂತಿಕ ಹಾಗೂ ವ್ಯಾವಹಾರಿಕ ವಿಜ್ಞಾನ ಕ್ಷೇತ್ರಗಳಲ್ಲಿ ಪ್ರಗತಿ ಎಷ್ಟು ವೇಗವಾಗಿ ಜರುಗುತ್ತಿದೆಯೆಂದರೆ ಒಂದು ಒಳ್ಳೆಯ ಸಂಶೋಧನಾತ್ಮಕ ಲೇಖನ ಬೆಳಕನ್ನು ಕಂಡ ದಿನವೇ ಹಳೆಯದಾಗಿ ಹೋಗುತ್ತದೆ. ಜ್ಞಾನ ಪ್ರಪಂಚ ದಲ್ಲಿಯ ಈ ಸ್ಫೋಟದ ಪರಿಣಾಮವಾಗಿ ಲೋಕದಲ್ಲೆಲ್ಲ ಶಿಕ್ಷಣ ಕ್ಷೇತ್ರದಲ್ಲಿ ಅದ್ಭುತ ಕಾ೦ತಿಯಾಗಿದೆ. ಈ ಆಧುನಿಕ ಸಂಶೋಧನೆಗಳ ಕೂಡ ಹೆಜ್ಜೆ﻿ಹಿಡಬೇಕಾದರೆ ನಮ್ಮ ವಿಶ್ವವಿದ್ಯಾನಿಲಯಗಳು ಯುರೋಪಿನ ಬೇರೆಬೇರೆ ಭಾಷೆಗಳ ಅಭ್ಯಾಸಕ್ಕಾಗಿ ಸಾಕಷ್ಟು ವ್ಯವಸ್ಥೆ ಮಾಡಿಕೊಳ್ಳದೆ ಬೇರೆ ದಾರಿಯಿಲ್ಲ. ಯಾವುದೋ ಓಬಿರಾಯನ ಕಾಲದ ಅಭ್ಯಾಸಕ್ರಮ ಹಾಗೂ ಅದಕ್ಕೂ ಹಳೆಯದಾದ ಪಠ್ಯಪುಸ್ತಕಗಳನ್ನೋದಿ ಶಿಕ್ಷಕರೂ, ವಿದ್ಯಾರ್ಥಿಗಳೂ ಇನ್ನೂ ತೃಪ್ತರಾಗಿರುವದು ನಮ್ಮ ದುರ್ದೈವವಾಗಿದೆ. ಆಧುನಿಕ ಪ್ರಗತಿ ಪ್ರೇರಣೆಗಳನ್ನು ಅರಗಿಸಿಕೊಳ್ಳುವ ಮನಸ್ಸಿದ್ದರೆ ಈ ಹಳೆಯ ಅಭ್ಯಾಸ ಕ್ರಮಗಳನ್ನೂ , ಪಠ್ಯಪುಸ್ತಕಗಳನ್ನೂ ಬಿಟ್ಟುಕೊಡಬೇಕಾಗುತ್ತದೆ. ಅವು ಗಳಲ್ಲೆಲ್ಲ ಸಂಪೂರ್ಣ ಮಾರ್ಪಾಟಾಗಬೇಕು. ವಿಶ್ವವಿದ್ಯಾನಿಲಯ ಧನ ಸಹಾಯ ಆಯೋಗದವರು ಈ ದಾರಿಯಲ್ಲಿ ಶಕ್ತಿ ಮೀರಿ ಪ್ರಯತ್ನಿ ಸುತಿದ್ದಾರೆ.

ನಮ್ಮ ದೇಶದ ಮುಂದೆ ನಿಂತಿದ್ದ ಅನೇಕ ಆರ್ಥಿಕ ಸಮಸ್ಯೆಗಳಲ್ಲಿ ಪದವೀಧರರ ನಿರುದ್ಯೋಗ ಸಮಸ್ಯೆಯ ನಿವಾರಣೆ ತ್ವರಿತವಾಗಿ ಆಗ ಬೇಕಾಗಿದೆ, ಎಂಜಿನಿಯರಿಂಗ್ ಪದವೀಧರರ ವಿಷಯವಂತೂ ಅತಿ ತುರ್ತಿನ ಪ್ರಶ್ನೆಯಾಗಿದೆ. ಈ ನಿರುದ್ಯೋಗ ಪ್ರಶ್ನೆ ಬರೀ ತಾತೂರ್ತಿಕ ಪರಿಸ್ಥಿತಿ ಯಿಂದ ಉಂಟಾದುದೆಂಬುದು ನಿಜ. ಹೀಗಿದ್ದರೂ ಇದಕ್ಕೆ ತಾತ್ಕಾಲಿಕ ಮುಕ್ತಾಯ ಅತ್ಯಗತ್ಯ. ೬೦,೦೦೦ ಎಂಜಿನಿಯರಿಂಗ್ ಪದವೀಧರರಿಗಾಗಿ ಉದ್ಯೋಗ ದೊರೆಯುವಂತೆ ಪುಟ್ಟ ಕೈಗಾರಿಕೆಗಳಲ್ಲಿ ಅವರ ಸೇರ್ಪಡೆ ಯಾಗುವುದಕ್ಕೋಸ್ಕರ ಕೇಂದ್ರ ಸರಕಾರವು ಧನಸಹಾಯಮಾಡುವ ದೆಂದು ಘೋಷಿಸಿದೆ. ವಿವಿಧ ರಾಜ್ಯಗಳ ಔದ್ಯೋಗಿಕ ಇಲಾಖೆಗಳು ಅವರಿಗೆ ಬೇಕಾದ ಸಹಾಯವನ್ನು ಒದಗಿಸುವ ಭರವಸೆಯನ್ನಿತ್ತಿವೆ. ನಮ್ಮ ತರುಣ ಎಂಜಿನಿಯರಿಂಗ್ ಪದವೀಧರರು ಈ ಸೌಕರ್ಯಗಳನ್ನು ಉಪಯೋಗಿಸಿ ಕೊಳ್ಳುವರೆಂದು ನಾನು ಆಶಿಸುತ್ತೇನೆ, ಖಾಸಗಿ ಕಂಪನಿಗಳು ಈ ಪದವೀ ಧರರನ್ನು ಬರಮಾಡಿಕೊಂಡು, ಅವರಿಗೆ ಆ ಕ್ಷೇತ್ರದ ಆಡಳಿತ-ವ್ಯವಹಾರ ವನ್ನು ತಿಳಿಯುವ ಅನುಕೂಲ ಮಾಡಿಕೊಟ್ಟರೆ ಮಾತ್ರ ಈ ಯೋಜನೆ ಯಶಸ್ವಿಯಾಗಬಹುದು. ಇಂತಹ ಉಮೇದುವಾರರು ಮುಂದೆ ಪ್ರಸಿದ್ದ ಔದ್ಯೋಗಿಕ ಕಂಪನಿಗಳ ಮಾಲೀಕರಾಗಬಹುದು, ಇಲ್ಲವೆ ಸಂಶೋಧಕ ರಾಗಬಹುದು. ಕಮಾರರಾಗಿ ಪ್ರಾರಂಭಿಸಿದ ಹಲವಾರು ಜನರು, ಮುಂದೆ ತಾಂತ್ರಿಕ ಸಲಕರಣೆಗಳ ಪ್ರಸಿದ್ಧ ಉತ್ಪಾದಕರಾದ ಉದಾಹರಣೆಗಳನ್ನು ನಾವು ಕಂಡಿದ್ದೇವೆ. ಮುಖ್ಯವಾಗಿ ಪದವೀಧರರು ಮೈ ಮುರಿದು 'ದುಡಿ ಯುವದು ಕೀಳಲ್ಲವೆಂಬುದನ್ನು ಮನಗಂಡಿರಬೇಕಾಗುತ್ತದೆ. ತಮ್ಮ ತಾಂತ್ರಿಕ ವಿದ್ಯೆಯ ಮೂಲಕ ಜನತೆಗೆ ತಮ್ಮ ಸೇವೆಯನ್ನು ಸಲ್ಲಿಸುವ ಹವಣಿಕೆ ಅವರಲ್ಲಿರಬೇಕಾಗುತ್ತದೆ.﻿

ವಿಶ್ವವಿದ್ಯಾನಿಲಯಗಳೆಂದರೆ ಬರಿ ಬುದ್ದಿ ಜೀವಿಗಳ ಸೊತ್ತಲ್ಲ. ಇಂದು ಸಾರ್ವಭೌಮ ಸ್ಥಾನದಲ್ಲಿರುವ ಜನಸಾಮಾನ್ಯನ ಸಂಸ್ಕೃತಿ ವರ್ಧನೆ ಗಾಗಿಯೂ ಅವು ದುಡಿಯಬೇಕಾಗಿದೆ. ಜನಸಾಮಾನ್ಯರಿಗೆ ಅವರ ಸಾರ್ವ ಜನಿಕ ಜವಾಬ್ದಾರಿಗಳ ಅರಿವಾಗುವಂತೆ, ವಿಶ್ವವಿದ್ಯಾಲಯಗಳು ಸಂಸ್ಕೃತಿ ಪ್ರಚಾರ ಕ್ರಮಗಳನ್ನು ಏರ್ಪಡಿಸಬೇಕಾಗಿದೆ, ಒಕ್ಕಲತನ, ತೋಟಗಾರಿಕೆ ಮೊದಲಾದ ಉದ್ಯೋಗಗಳ ಆಧುನಿಕೀಕರಣ ಮನೆಮನೆಗೂ ಮುಟ್ಟುವಂತೆ ಮಾಡುವ ವಿದ್ಯಾಭ್ಯವಸ್ಥೆ ಅತ್ಯಾವಶ್ಯಕವಾಗಿದೆ. ಪ್ರಜಾಪ್ರಭುತ್ವದ ನೈಜ ತಿರುಳು ಸಹ ಎಲ್ಲರಿಗೂ ಮನದಟ್ಟಾಗಬೇಕಾಗಿದೆ. ಹೊಂದಿಕೊಳ್ಳುವ ಮನೋವೃತ್ತಿ ಬೆಳೆಯುವಂತೆ ಮತ್ತು ಜನಸಾಮಾನ್ಯರಿಗೆ ಲಭಿಸಿರುವ ಅಧಿಕಾರದ ಸದ್ವಿನಿಯೋಗವಾಗುವಂತೆ ನಮ್ಮ ವಿಶ್ವವಿದ್ಯಾನಿಲಯಗಳು ಹೆಚ್ಚು ಹೆಚ್ಚಾಗಿ ಹವಣಿಸಬೇಕಾಗಿದೆ.

ಯಶಸ್ವಿಯಾದ ಸುಸಂಸ್ಕೃತ ಜೀವನ ಸಾರ್ವಜನಿಕ ಸೇವೆಯಲ್ಲಿ ಸಾರ್ಥಕವಾಗಬೇಕಾದರೆ ಮುಖ್ಯವಾಗಿ ಬೇಕಾದ ಸಾಧನೆಗಳೆಂದರೆ ಕಾಲು, ಇವುಗಳಲ್ಲಿ ಶೀಲಸಂವರ್ಧನೆ ಮುಖ್ಯವಾದುದು. ಶೀಲವಿಲ್ಲದ ವ್ಯಕ್ತಿ ಕೀಲಿಲ್ಲದ * ಗಾಲಿಯಿದ್ದಂತೆ. ಎರಡನೆಯದಾಗಿ, ತೀಕ್ಷವಾದ ಬುದ್ದಿ ಬೇಕು, ಒಳಿತು-ಕೆಡಕು, ಉಚಿತ-ಅನುಚಿತ ಇವೇ ಮೊದಲಾದ ದ್ವಂದ್ವಗಳ ವಿಂಗಡಣೆ ತೀಕ್ಷ ಬುದ್ದಿಯಿಲ್ಲದೆ ಸಾಧ್ಯವಿಲ್ಲ. ಮೂರನೆಯ ದಾಗಿ, ಎಲ್ಲರ ಕ್ಷೇಮವನ್ನು ಅಪೇಕ್ಷಿಸುವ-ಎರಡನೆಯವರ ದುಃಖವನ್ನು ಕಡಿಮೆಯಾಗಿಸಲು ಶ್ರಮಿಸುವ ಅಂತಃಕರಣ ಬೇಕು, ಈ ಹೃದಯ ಔದಾರ್ಯವಿಲ್ಲದೆ ನಾಡಿನ ಪ್ರಗತಿಯನ್ನು ನಾವು ಸಾಧಿಸಲಾರೆವು. ಕೊನೆಯದಾಗಿ, ಆತ್ಮವಿಶ್ವಾಸ ಹಾಗು ದೈವನಿಷ್ಠೆ ಬೇಕು. ಇವಿಲ್ಲದಿದ್ದರೆ ಯಾವ ಮಹತ್ಕಾರ್ಯವೂ ಸಾಧ್ಯವಾಗಲಾರದು.

ಈಗ ಹೊಸ ಪದವೀಧರರನ್ನುದ್ದೇಶಿಸಿ ನಾಲ್ಕು ಮಾತುಗಳನ್ನು ಹೇಳ ಅಚ್ಛಿಸುತ್ತೇನೆ. ವಿಶ್ವವಿದ್ಯಾನಿಲಯದ ವಿವಿಧ ಪರೀಕ್ಷೆಗಳಲ್ಲಿ ಉತ್ತೀರ್ಣ ರಾಗಿ ಪದವಿಗಳನ್ನು ಪಡೆದ ನಿಮ್ಮನ್ನು ನಾನು ಮೊದಲು ಹೃತ್ಪೂರ್ವಕ ನಾಗಿ ಅಭಿನಂದಿಸ ಬಯಸುತ್ತೇನೆ. ಮೂರು-ನಾಲ್ಕು ವರ್ಷ ನೀವು ಪಟ್ಟಿ ಪರಿಶ್ರಮಕ್ಕೆ ನಿಮ್ಮ ಯಶಸ್ಸು ಈಗ ಕಿರೀಟವಿಟ್ಟದೆ. ದೀರ್ಘಕಾಲ ಸರಿ ಶ್ರಮಿಸಿ ನಿಮ್ಮ ಗುರಿಯನ್ನು ಮುಟ್ಟಿದ್ದೀರಿ. ಈ ಯಶಸ್ಸು ನಿಮಗೆ ದೊರೆಯಲೆಂದು ನಿಮ್ಮ ಪಾಲಕರು ಇಲ್ಲವೆ ತಂದೆತಾಯಿಯವರು ಸ್ವಂತದ ಸುಖವನ್ನು ಕೆಲವು ಮಟ್ಟಿಗೆ ತ್ಯಾಗಮಾಡಿದ್ದಾರೆ. ನೀವು ಅನೇಕ ತೊಂದರೆ ಗಳನ್ನು ಸಹಿಸಿ ನೀವು ಹಿಡಿದ ಕಾರ್ಯವನ್ನು ಕೊನೆಗಾಣಿಸಿದ್ದೀರಿ. ಒಂದು ಧೈಯವನ್ನು ಎದುರಿಗಿರಿಸಿಕೊಂಡು ಒಮ್ಮನಸ್ಸಿನಿಂದ ಅದರ ಸಫಲತೆಗಾಗಿ﻿ ಕೆಲವು ವರ್ಷ ಅವಿಶ್ರಾಂತವಾಗಿ ಶ್ರಮಿಸಲು ಏಕಭಾವದ ನಿಷ್ಠೆ ಬೇಕಾಗು ತದೆ. ನಿಮ್ಮ ಪ್ರಾಧ್ಯಾಪಕರಿಂದ ದೊರೆತ ಸಹಾಯ ಹಾಗೂ ಮಾರ್ಗ ದರ್ಶನವಲ್ಲದೆ, ನಿಮ್ಮ ನಿಸರ್ಗಸಿದ್ಧ ಬುದ್ದಿವಂತಿಕೆಯಿಂದ ದೊರೆತ ಯಶಸ್ಸಿ ನಿಂದ ನೀವು ಸಂತೋಷಗೊಂಡಿರುವದು ಯಥೋಚಿತವಾಗಿದೆ. ನಿಮ್ಮ ವಿದ್ಯಾಮಾತೆಯಾದ ವಿಶ್ವವಿದ್ಯಾನಿಲಯವನ್ನು ಕುರಿತ ಸವಿನೆನಪುಗಳು ನಿಮ್ಮಲ್ಲಿ ಯಾವಾಗಲೂ ಕೊನರುತ್ತಿರಲೆಂದು ನಾನು ಆಶಿಸುತ್ತೇನೆ.' ವಿದ್ಯಾರ್ಜನೆಯ ಜೀವನ ಕ್ರಮ ಮುಗಿದು ಪ್ರಪಂಚದ ಭವ್ಯದ್ಯಾರಈಗ ನಿಮ್ಮೆದುರು ತೆರೆದಿದೆ. ಒಂದು ಜೀವನವೃತ್ತಿಯನ್ನು ಅವಲಂಬಿಸಿ ನೀವಿನ್ನು ವ್ಯವಹಾರ ಕ್ಷೇತ್ರದಲ್ಲಿ ಕಾಲಿಡುವಿರಿ. ಆ ವೃತ್ತಿ ಔದ್ಯೋಗಿಕವಲಯ ದಲ್ಲಿರಬಹುದು, ನೌಕರಿಯಾಗಬಹುದು, ಇಲ್ಲವೆ ಈಗ ಎಲ್ಲಕ್ಕಿಂತ ಹೆಚ್ಚು ಲಾಭಕರವಾದ ಕೃಷಿಕ್ಷೇತ್ರವಾಗಬಹುದು. ನಾನು ಹೇಳುವುದಿಷ್ಟೆ : ಕ್ಷೇತ್ರ ಯಾವುದೇ ಇರಲಿ, ಕ್ಷೇತ್ರಜ್ಞರಾದ ನೀವು ಅಂತಃಕರಣಪೂರ್ವಕವಾಗಿ ದುಡಿಯಿರಿ; ಪ್ರಾಮಾಣಿಕವಾಗಿ ಬಾಳಿರಿ, ಒಂದು ಉಜ್ವಲ ಪ್ರಾಚೀನ ಪರಂ ಪರೆಯ ಔರಸರು ನೀವಾಗಿದ್ದೀರಿ, ವಿಜಯನಗರದ ಹಿರಿಯ ಹಿನ್ನೆಲೆ ನಮಗಿದೆ. ಸಾವಿರ ವರ್ಷಗಳ ಹಿಂದೆ ಬಿಹಾರ-ಬಂಗಾಳ ರಾಜ್ಯಗಳ ಮೇಲೆ ಪ್ರಭುತ್ವ ನಡೆಯಿಸಿ, ತನ್ನ ನಿಪುಣ ಆಡಳಿತ ಹಾಗೂ ನ್ಯಾಯಬದ್ದಿಗಾಗಿ ಕನ್ನಡಿಗರು ಕೀರ್ತಿವಂತರಾಗಿದ್ದರು. ಇಂದಿಗೂ ಅಲ್ಲಿಯ ಜನ ಈ ಕನ್ನಡ ರಾಜವಂಶಗಳನ್ನು ಕೃತಜ್ಞತೆಯಿಂದ ನೆನೆಸುತ್ತಾರೆ. ಗಳಿಸಬಹುದಾದ ಕುಬೇರನ ಸಂಪತ್ತಿಗಿಂತ, ಪಡೆದ ಒಳ್ಳೆಯ ಹೆಸರು ಹೆಚ್ಚು ಅವಮೌಲ್ಯ ವಾದುದು. ಆ ಯಶಸ್ಸು ನಿಮ್ಮದಾಗಲಿ !﻿

ADDRESS BY S.S. RAY
on Sunday, 16th Jan. 1972 MR. CHANCELLOR, MR. VICE-CHANCELLOR, LADIES AND
GENTLEMEN AND GRADUATES OF THE YEAR :

A t the outset, I wish to express my heartfelt thanks to the authorities of the University of Mysore for inviting me here today to deliver the convocation address. I am very glad to have the opportunity of being here amidst the graduates and the distinguished academicians of the University of Mysore which, for over fifty years, has rendered signal service to the cause of higher education. I hope that in the years to come, it will be given to the University of Mysore to face with increasing success, the problemis and challenges of changing India and to demonstrate by example how education can instil in its recipients a true sense of the values which will help them to build a new society. We have in our country, through the days of the distant past built up value systems which in no way are irreconcilable with the science and technology of the present day. The key to the rapprochement between inherited values and modern science is education, which can impart on the one hand the essence of our tradition and through it, on the other, provide the recipient with the power to utilise for general social good the advantages of science and technology. The spiritual and literary history of Mysore offers a fit background against which this rapprochement can be achieved. The soil of Karnataka has repeatedly in the course of its history, shown itself capable of harmonising the old with the new. It has within its compass captured and represented the genius for synthesis which has characterised Indian philosophic thought and﻿ tradition through the ages. It was on this soil that different systems of philosophy converged and divergent strands of thought were inter-related and unified into a conceptual whole. It is on this soil again that we see functioning today one of the leading Indian Institutes of Science.' A more ideal background for adventurous thinking and for grappling with the perplexing problems which education poses today would be hard to find.

Our preoccupations with such problems were recently interrupted, as you are all aware, by a grave national crisis caused by aggression on our borders, threatening the very security of our country. As a result of the gallant performance of our fighting forces on the battlefields and the single-minded resolve of the nation to defend the safety and integrity of our land, we care through the ordeal successfully and with a supreme manifestation of our moral force and material valour, we were able once again to hoist the flag of freedom. The unity and solidarity which the entire country displayed during its hour of peril represented the values for which this country stands and qur institutions of higher learning can contribute a great deal to ensure that this spirit is kept alive in times of peace as well. It is the least that we could do by way of homage to our valiant armed forces, as it is for the preservation of these very alues that they have so heroically fought in the theatres of war. The united resolve of our people and the spirit of determined action which were in such abundant evidence during our hour of trial should hearten us all and make us aware of our potential. It is this approach that should﻿ underlie our attempts towards national reconstruction which includes the restructuring of education.

There is no doubt that much outstanding work has been done by universities like yours, our Institutes of Technology and other seats of higher learning, particularly in the realm of post-graduate education and research and it is everyone's wish that this should continue in an ever-increasing measure and that the highest standards should be aimed at and achieved. But it is inevitable that from time to time changes should take place to keep pace with current developments and to recognise the new facets of old problems. One of the many differences between the past and the present is the altered relationship between the teacher and the taught. This altered relationship has been accentuated by the present day explosion of knowledge and the early obsolescence of this knowledge and its swift replacement by more up-to-date knowledge, all of which has all but obliterated the distinction between the teacher and the student, as it obtained in an earlier day. Such a situation calls for modified approaches in the technique of teaching and the evaluation of the students' work. Translated into material terms, this would mean a new type of teacher education and reforms in the pattern of examination. There is also a need for standardisation in the quality of education imparted by various universities. Where universities were few, diverse approaches and standards led to variety which was desirable, whereas with the large number of universities mushrooming today, there is need for standardisation in order to ensure the quality of education imparted. This does not﻿ mean mere uniformity, but a level of effort which will help to preserve the essentials of learning and ensure the goals of higher education. The role of the institutions of higher education should always be to maintain high standards and to make sure that their graduates would actually benefit by what they have learnt during their study in their portals.

This task is of such magnitude that it is time that we paused to consider whether we should not relieve our universities and other institutions of higher education of the responsibilities arising from the rest of the problems relating to higher education, problems which are not their direct concern. To saddle the universities with such additional responsibilities is to hamper their efforts in their specific areas of work. It is time we thought of establishing a separate machinery to handle these problems.

What I have in mind is collegiate education which has to fulfil the demands of an increasing number of pupils drawn from all classes and strata, of society for such education. Without a doubt, we should provide equality of access to all types of education including education at the highest level for anyone who has the aptitude for it and has the desire to pursue it. But let us consider the kind of collegiate education to which we are giving them access. Is it a meaningful opportunity or is it just driving the increasing number of aspirants into a purposeless pursuit of a robot-like routine ending with the award of a degree? The principle of equality of opportunity is by no means carried out by the mass scale conferment of degrees. It is carried out only when it implies the﻿ opportunity for the attainment of quality in one's educational endeavour. This calls for a restructuring of our education at all levels. We have to introduce a pattern of education which suits the actual requirements of the individual and the society. We should put into operation a process of manpower planning and organise such educational programmes as will support this planning and provide the necessary manpower. Vocationalisation of education at the secondary level has to be more energetically pursued than at present and insistence on the part of employers on the possession of a degree as a pre-condition to any type of employment must be done away with. Such measures will pave the way for job-oriented education.

The question of costs naturally arises and in this connection a point has been advanced whether it is necessary for the Government to subsidise university education for everyone. It is a pertinent point in a welfare State where the leisured classes can afford to pay for their liberal and general education which would meet their aesthetic and social needs. In such a situation, Government subsidies should be earmarked for those who cannot afford to pay their way although they are eminently fitted and equipped to receive the benefits of higher education. In an egalitarian society, pledged to ensure social justice, we have to go further by detecting talent among the financially ill-favoured from the school level onwards and granting them scholarships on a liberal scale in order to enable them to reach the highest peaks of educational excellence.

It is not as if these questions have not received﻿ any thought or consideration in our country. Several Committees and Commissions have gone into them and made recommendations and published their reports. The Government and the University Grants Commission are also keenly aware of the problems which perplex us and had an investigation carried out last year under the chairmanship of Dr. Gajendragadkar on the subject. What is now required is the will and the determination among all those concerned with the administration of higher education to implement with expedition and despatch at least some of the reforms which are indicated.

The avidity and enthusiasm we have displayed through the years in reflecting on our educational situation and analysing it from all angles and suggesting passible solutions, certainly wholesome as it is, should now be transferred in full measure to the realm ' of action. We have just recently proved to the world that we are not a nation which merely beats the air. In the most vital sphere of our national life, the defence of our country against external aggression, we have shown our mettle and demonstrated that we are capable of resolute action in a just cause. Let us then at this moment resolve to bend our energies to action in all those fields where such action is required and in the process transform our educational scene. Institutions of higher learning and all those engaged in educational reform, practising teachers, research workers and educational administrators can strive to make the educational process meaningful and purposive. This should lead to the creation of a background which will facilitate the involvement and﻿ participation of the student community in all aspects of institutional life. It should make them feel that it is a joy to be an integral part of the growth and progress of these institutions. The personal example of the teachers can draw the students in a stimulating partnership with them and the sense of purpose and fulfilment that this will generate will stem the incursion of politics into our seats of learning, a feature which all right-thinking men abhor. When the educational community knows clearly what it is about and what colleges and universities stand for, and are deeply involved in their academic pre-occupations, it should be impossible for political elements from any quarter, which seek to sow the seeds of disaffection, to make any headway. This would leave the student community free to partake of the fruits of academic life and develop a sense of responsibility. There will then be the chance for them to discern that to be young is not to be all-knowing, but a passing phase in which maturity is to be gained.

If higher education is to develop along these lines in India, it is essential that the various States and the Centre should work together to implement the measures suggested by various Committees and Commissions. Naturally, the first step is for each institution to reform itself, not forgetting in the process that it is one amongst the many institutions of higher learning. In order to serve the educational needs of the country effectively, all the institutions, while pursuing their individual destinies, should together form a national pattern, eliminating waste.

Finally, I wish to congratulate all the graduates assembled here on the successful completion of their studies and wish them all possible opportunities for further self-development and service to the country. I would plead with them that they should enter upon their next stage of life with confidence in themselves and faith in the country whose tasks and challenges will soon devolve on them with the assurance that the country will not fail them.﻿

ADDRESS BY S. NURUL HASAN on Saturday, 13th Jan.
Mr. Chancellor, Mr. Pro-Chancellor,
Mr. Vice-Chancellor, Distinguished Guests and Graduates of the year,

I am grateful to the authorities of the Mysore University and especially to its Vice-Chancellor, Professor Javare Gowda, for having invited me to participate in this function. I deem it a privilege and an honour to do so, specially when I think of the distinguished men who, in the past, have addressed your convocations. I have, therefore, accepted this invitation in a spirit of humility and especially because it is always a stimulating and pleasant experience for me to be in the midst of students and teachers engaged in the pursuit of knowledge and excellence and all that it implies.

I have always been keenly interested in the development of this University. It has symbolised the aspirations of the people of Mysore to make their contribution to the promotion of learning and enlightenment. Several distinguished ViceChancellors have guided its affairs among whom I might specially refer to my predecessor in office Dr. K. L. Shrimali. The efforts of a distinguished band of teachers and students have also materially helped in making the University what it now is. I am also happy that the Uni vetsity is now presided over by Professor Javare Gowda who is an eminent scholar and a great﻿ educationist. I am sure that under his far-sighted leadership the University will rise to further heights.

To the young men and women who have been awarded degrees and distinctions today, I offer my warm felicitations. I wish them a happy New Year and a prosperous and fruitful life. The hallmark of higher education is a liberal mind which abhors all narrow parochial trends; and it is only the liberal minds developed in higher education that can help to create the secular, democratic and socialist society which is our national objective. I, therefore, look upon the young men and women who come out of our university system to wage a relentless war against the retrograde forces of chauvinism, regionalism, casteism or linguism which are now raising their ugly heads in several parts of the country and threatening our national unity, strength and progress. I am sure that the graduates of this University will play their proper role in this war against these retrograde forces, side by side with the graduates of ather universities, and prove themselves worthy of this great institution.

II

There is universal agreement on the important role which higher education plays in national development. It is the one major instrument through which a nation continually strives to preserve, disseminate and extend knowledge, to train the high level manpower needed for leadership in all walks of life, to understand the problems of existence in all their complexity and to devise appropriate solutions for them, and generally, to help the people to improve the quality of their life in all its aspects. It is also a major instrument of social transformation and developing countries like ours have to rely heavily on education to create the new society of our dreams. Faith in the universities or higher education is, therefore, merely an expression of our faith in the future of our country. Perhaps the best expression of this faith can be found in the noble words of Jawaharlal Nehru who, addressing a Convocation of my Alma Mater, the University of Allahabad, said: "A University stands for humanism, for tolerance, for reason, for the adventure of ideas and for the search of truth. It stands for the onward march of the human race towards even higher objectives. If the universities discharge their duties adequately, then, it is well with the nation and the people".

What is causing serious anxiety to all of us at the present moment is the fact that, for a complexity and a variety of reasons, the universities are not in a position to discharge their duties adequately. Some of the difficulties are internal to the system (i.e., outmoded curricula, nonproduction of high quality teaching and learning materials, or inappropriate methods of teaching and evaluation) and a determined effort on the part of the teachers and students can overcome them. But several other difficulties are outside﻿ the system. These, for instance, include inadequacy of resources, non-availability of adequate employment opportunities and the disastrous results of unhealthy political and other pressures exerted upon the system. These cannot be solved unless the society as a whole, and its leadership of all categories, recognise the significance of higher education to national development, learn to exercise restraint and create that atmosphere and those necessary conditions which alone can help a university system to function satisfactorily: I am, therefore, convinced that the present serious crisis in our system of higher education can only be resolved if all of us - Government, political parties, leaders of all walks of social life, teachers and students-join hands together and make a wellplanned and concerted effort to improve higher education. This alone will enable the universities to function satisfactorily and thereby, in the words of Jawaharlal Nehru I have just quoted, lead to the progress of the people and the nation.

III

It is obviously not possible, in the short time at my disposal today, to deal with all the major problems of higher education which we will have to make a concerted effort to solve in the next few years. I shall, however, deal, in some detail, with one of them, namely, the problem of numbers.

One of the outstanding features of our system of higher education which began a little more than﻿ a century ago, is the tremendous expansion it has achieved. In 1857, when the Universities of Bombay, Calcutta and Madras were established, there were only 27 colleges of all types, and in the first Matriculation Examinations conducted by these universities, only 219 students passed. By 1947, universities increased to 19, the colleges to 636 and their enrolments to 256,000. Great as this expansion was, it has been far surpassed in the last 25 years. We now have about a hundred institutions of university status, about 3,600 colleges of all types and an enrolment of over 30 lakhs. What is even more staggering is the indiction that, at the present rate of expansion, we will have about 5,000 colleges and nearly 60 lakhs students in higher education by the end of the current decade.

This expansion of higher education has both positive and negative aspects. It has certainly had several beneficial results. In the pre-independence period, it awakened national consciousness and strengthened the struggle for freedom. In the post-independence period, it has given us the political leadership to run the world's largest democracy and the scientific and technical leadership to modernize our industry, and to create a green revolution in agriculture. All along these years, it has enabled the less privileged social groups to throw up a new leadership and by accelerating social mobility, has strengthened egalitarian trends. On the other hand, it has also led to the dilution of standards in a majority of﻿ institutions of higher education and created a large and growing group of the educated unemployed, who threaten to disorganise national life. It is, therefore, necessary for us to understand the different dimensions of this problem in their complexity and to take appropriate measures for their solution.

Let me first of all make it clear that even with this expansion, I cannot regard India as an over-educated country. If our national goals are to be realised and the right to education enshrined in the Constitution has to become a reality, we need, not less, but much more of higher education. Unfortunately, our policies in this field are subject to three major constraints. The first is the shortage of good quality teachers who alone can enable us to maintain adequate standards. The second is the lack of financial resources which prevents us from expanding full-time institutions of higher education beyond a certain optimum number. It also limits the total amount of subsidy we can provide for higher education; we may give a small subsidy to a large number of students or a larger subsidy to a small number of students. But we do not just have the resources to give a large subsidy to an unlimited number of students. The third major constraint is that of the comparatively limited employment opportunities that are being thrown up by the rate at which the economy is expanding at present. Even with the best that we can hope to do in this field, the economy may not grow at more than 6 or 7 per cent﻿ per annum while the output of graduates is increasing at 11 to 13 percent per annum. It is therefore not possible for the economy to absorb the output of this system of higher education whose relationship to productivity is rather tenuous. It therefore becomes obvious that, in spite of all theoretical argument to the contrary, we will have to regulate the expansion of the system of higher education within manageable proportions and relate it more realistically to the manpower needs of economy and social development or the employment opportunities that are being generated from time to time.

IV

How is this regulation of the expansion of higher education to be attempted in practice. This is one of the most important questions to which we have to address ourselves. Obviously, a complex situation. We shall therefore have to develop several programmes for this purpose.

My first suggestion is that a major remedy for this problem lies, not in higher education itself, but in secondary education which has three major defects. It is generally a single continuous stage. Under such a system, a student enters it at so young an age that any kind of direct or indirect selective procedure is ruled out; and once in, he has no option but to continue to the end. Its duration is too short so that a student who completes the secondary school is generally about 16 or 17 and therefore not eligible for appointment nor mature﻿ enough to profit adequately by university studies. What is even worse, it has an undiversified and non-vocationalized character so that, instead of preparing a majority of students for different walks of life, it fits the average student for entrance to a college and almost unfits him for everything else. It is because of all these major weaknesses of the system of secondary education that a secondary school leaver finds himself unwanted everywhere, and it is they which compel him to make education, not a preparation for work, but a substitute for it and to seek asylum in a college. An engineer who is concerned with serious floods in the plains takes the first step in its defence by putting up dams, not in the plains, but higher up in tne mountain regions where the floods originate. Similarly, we must try to control the flood of numbers in higher education by putting appropriate dams at the stage of secondary education itself. We must first lengthen the duration of secondary education in such a way. that the entire period of school education covers 12 years and a secondary school graduate is about 18 years of age and mature enough for employment or entrance to a university course of studies. Further, we will have to put a break in the school system at the end of Class X or about the age of 16 when a student would be sufficiently grown up to make an intelligent decision about his future career. Thirdly, we will have to diversify and vocationalize the higher secondary stage so that secondary education becomes terminal 'for a﻿ majority of students and prepares them for different and useful careers in life. This is why the Radhakrishnan Commission and the Kothari Commission recommended the adoption of the 10+2+3 pattern. This programme deserves, to be given high priority in the Fifth Five Year Plan.

Another suggestion which I would like to make in this context relates to the modification of the existing recruitment and wage policies. At present, all worthwhile jobs have become willynilly the preserve of persons who have received higher education and the differential of wages between those who have received secondary and higher education is so large that private investment in higher education becomes very profitable even from the economic point of view, not to say anything of its social and cultural advantages. A deliberate attempt will have to be made to turn the tables. It has been suggested that recruitment to all services in the public sector should be at the end of the school stage of 12 years, and that the persons selected should be given such further education as is necessary for them at State expense, through a liberal programme of scholarships. The army chooses its personnel at the end of the secondary stage and with good results. The engineering and medical professions also do the same with equally good results. There is no reason why the same principle should not be extended to all other public services. I would, therefore, suggest that this pro﻿blem which can only be tackled on a national basis by a co-ordinated effort of the Central and State Governments, should receive our earnest consideration. Obviously, so radical a reform of the recruitment policies will have to be followed up with several others which will radically alter the promotional policies, inter-service transfers and 1 several other allied issues. But all this will be extremely worthwhile; and once the appropriate decisions can be taken, we will be able to reduce the rush of students to universities who generally go there in the vain hope of being able to net a good job in the public sector.

V

In the university stage itself, I would like to emphasise that we must make every effort to see that proper standards are maintained and that what we call 'higher education' does effectively indicate its contents as the label on a bottle of standard medicine. When I use the expression 'maintenance of standards', I do mean, not only the intellect, but a good deal besides. I do feel very strongly that standards in higher education must imply liberalizing of the mind to rise above narrow panochial considerations, developments of a rational and scientific temper, inculcation of basic human values, strengthening of national integration, awakening a sense of social responsibility and social awareness and building up of habits of self-study and promoting problem-solving﻿ ability. If these standards are to be maintained, we will have to plan the location of colleges very carefully, ensure that every institution of higher education will have a faculty and enrolment of a critical size and the necessary facilities and teachers of the right quality.

Unfortunately, al good deal of expansion that is now taking place in higher education is at the cost of, quality. The location of colleges is unplanned and haphazard; most of the new colleges to be established are small, uneconomic and nonviable academic units; even the minimum facilities required are often not provided and the qualifications prescribed for teachers are often diluted. These are the wrong methods of expansion and they do more harm than good. We must now adopt a new policy under which we will try to achieve the maximum expansion possible in a planned manner and consistently with the maintenance of standards. Perhaps a major restraint in the present situation is the limited number of competent teachers available and the lack of monetary and material resources. If due heed is paid to this restraint and standards in higher education are not allowed to fall below the minimum prescribed, there would be an automatic limitation on the number of institutions which will be providing full-time instruction and their enrolments. This is a limitation which we must willingly accept because it can be ignored only at great national peril.

As the uncontrolled expansion at the univer﻿sity stage takes place mostly through private colleges, it has also been suggested tha our policy towards private enterprise should be reviewed. At present, the initiative for opening new institutions is mostly left to private enterprise, and once it starts new colleges in any implanned or haphazard manner, the State is called upon, sooner rather than later, to assist it with subsidy from the public exchequer. It has therefore been suggested that the State should now come forward and take initiative in establishing new colleges and that these should be established only in under-developed areas or for the under-privileged sections of the community, for both of which private enterprise does not generally cater. Some have also suggested that no grant-in-aid should be given to any private college established after 1st April, 1974, when the Fifth Five Year Plan will begin. Others have suggested that no private college should be allowed to be established in the Fifth Five Year Plan unless it is able to bear a fairly substantial portion of its total cost, thereby reducing the subsidy from the public exchequer. I have not taken a view on this as yet. But I do feel that these suggestions need to be seriously examined by all concerned. What is equally important, measures which deny or reduce subsidies from public exchequer to new institutions of higher education will have to be extended over the years; in a planned and a phased manner, even to existing instituttons as well.﻿

The two measures indicated above, in whatever form they are adopted, will certainly lead to some regulation of the expansion of facilities for full-time higher education. One result of this restriction may be that the weaker and poorer sections of the community get squeezed out of full-time institutions which may come to be monopolized, almost exclusively, by the better off sections of the community. This would indeed be a calamity; and if this result' were inevitable, I would even prefer the present policy of open door access in spite of all its weaknesses. But fortunately, this is not so. In spite of the overall contraction in the size of full-time enrolments in higher education, it is still possible to increase the access of the weaker sections of the community to higher education. This can be secured, as I have stated earlier, by establishing Government institutions in under-developed areas or for the benefit of under-privileged social groups. In addition, steps may be taken to reserve, in all institutions of higher education providing fulltime instruction, an adequate number of seats for the Scheduled Castes, Scheduled Tribes and other weaker sections of the community defined on the basis of appropriate socio-economic criteria. Moreover, fee grants, hostels and scholarships should also be made available to students coming from under-privileged social groups on a liberal scale so that their interests are not adversely affected by the restrictions on the opening of new institutions and the denial (or reduction) of subsidy to new institutions.﻿

I would also like to compensate the limitations placed on the expansion of full-time instruction, to some extent, by increasing informal types of higher education so that it becomes available to all who seek it and qualify themselves for it. From this point of view, I would recommend a large expansion of programmes of part-time education, correspondence courses, or self-study. I would prefer to have one National Open University having jurisdiction over the entire country so that any student, even in the remotest corner of the country, can have access to its instruction and degrees, if he so desires, at a minimal cost which would be within his reach and without affecting his capacity to earn and help himself and his family. This should be supplemented by the development of a programme of correspondence courses in at least one university in every State. In addition, private study should receive the most liberal emphasis and it should be open to' all' individuals to appear at all Board and University examinations as private candidates. All colleges should function as academic centres and throw open their facilities to students studying on a part-time or self-study basis, and such academic centres could even be established in good secondary schools.

VI

To sum up, I visualize, over the few years, a programme of regulating the expansion of higher education, in a planned manner so that﻿ the products of the university system can be quickly absorbed in the economy. This will need a major effort of reform at the secondary stage to increase its duration, to adopt the 10+2+3 pattern and to vocationalize the higher secondary stage. It will also imply reduction of wage differentials that now operate between the secondary and college graduates and a radical re-orientation of the recruitment policies in the public sector to select all the persons required at the end of the secondary stage. Coming to the university stage itself, this will imply a limitation on the number of places available in institutions providing fulltime instruction, mainly on account of lack of resources and the necessity of maintaining adequate standards. It will also imply a change of policy towards the priyate sector and assumption of a larger initiative by the State in the establishment of new institutions. In order that these measures should not adversely affect the interests of the under-developed or under-privileged sections of the community, it will be necessary to reserve seats for them in institutions for fulltime instruction and to provide scholarships and fee grants on a liberal scale. Above all, programmes of part-time education or self-study will have to be greatly expanded to ensure that higher education is available to all who seek it and qualify themselves for it. I do believe that a satisfactory programme for the development of higher education in the Fifth Five Year Plan can be developed on these broad principles. This is a task to which the universities and State Governments have now to address themselves.﻿

ADDRESS BY Dr. GEORGE JACOB on Sunday, 20th Jan. 1974
MR. CHANCELLOR, MR. PRO-CHANCELLOR, MR. VICE
CHANCELLOR, LADIES AND GENTLEMEN, AND GRADUATES OF THE YEAR:

I am very happy to be with you today to participate in the Amual Convocation of your University and to address the graduates who are passing out this year. Mysore University is the sixth oldest University in this country and, next to Banaras Hindu University, is the oldest university established in India during the 20th century. Under the old dispensation when we had a British India and Indian States, Mysore University was the first university to be established in an Indian State. So this university can legitimately look back with pride and satisfaction to the long period of useful and creative work that it has rendered. But today, university education in this country is at the cross-roads. Questions are being asked in many quarters whether universities are serving the purpose for which they were set up. This question needs consideration, first, by teachers in colleges and universities, and next, by those who administer colleges and universities.

The Central Advisory Board of Education has recommended an educational system of 10 years of school followed by 2 years of post-high school training followed by a 3-year degree course (10+2+3). The University Grants Commission﻿ will be considering this at the next meeting of the Advisory Committee of Vice-Chancellors. The UGC and Universities are concerned with the last part of this scheme, namely 3 years for a degree course. Personally I endorse the 3 year degree course because I am of the view that to do any subject in depth and certain allied subjects also in sufficient depth, a period of 3 years is necessary. But the 12 years of training preceding this 3-year degree course is not primarily the concern of universities or the University Grants Commission. It is the concern of the secondary school or the higher secondary school system of education. But colleges and universities cannot afford to ignore what happens in schools and in higher secondary classes, because what can be done during the 3 years in the degree classes depends on the academic level of the students who are admitted to the first year of the degree class. Even today Delhi University admits to the degree classes students who have passed the Delhi Higher Secondary Examination, which is held after a course of 11 years. So the Delhi graduate who does a 3-year degree course actually puts in only 14 years, viz., 11 #-3. Yet the Delhi graduate compares very favourably with graduates of other universities in the country. This is because the Higher Secondary Examination of Delhi represents a high level of attainment. With one more year added to these eleven years of schooling, the Higher Secondary examination of Delhi can be raised to a still higher level of academic attainment. The standard of proficiency of a﻿ student admitted to the first year of a degree course will determine, to a large extent, what a college or university will be able to do during the 3 years of the degree course. I am emphasising this because universities and colleges do not generally concern themselves with the standard achieved by boys and girls at the secondary school stage. The leadership of the university should help secondary schools and high schools to step up their standards in the different subjects.

Of all the subjects taught at the school stage, the basic ones, having a vital connection with the standard to be achieved in university courses are the languages-English and Kannada for this region-and Mathematics. Take the example of the study of English as a language. What we have to attempt is to ensure that the student has a certain vocabulary of the English language at his command when he comes to the first year of the degree course. Anyone, who falls very much below this requirement of vocabulary, will not be able to cope with the work in a university or college if the medium of instruction is English. In the same way, in Mathematics it should be possible to measure the standard of achievement of a student by the time he finishes the secondary school. The degree courses should be built on this foundation of a sound standard of attainment on the part of the student who comes to the first year class.

This University uses both English and Kannada as the medium of instruction at the degree level in Arts, Science and Commerce, but at the postgraduate level it has only one medium of instruction, viz., English for all the three faculties. How do we ensure that students who have taken a B.A., B.Sc. or B.Com. degree with Kannada medium have sufficient proficiency in the English languge to be able to cope with the requirements of a post-graduate course in Arts, Science, or Commerce? The same principle should be applied to the transition from the school to the university. On academic grounds, for a considerably long time, students and teachers of Indian Universities will have to be proficient in two languages-English and the mother tongue. For national integration, facility in a third language, Hindi, is also needed. In the case of your university, students and teachers should have a very high degree of competence in Kannada and English. Sixty per cent of the world's scientific knowledge comes out through journals in English. So any student who wants to do advanced work in a science subject must have sufficient command of the English language to be able to refer to up-to-date journals. But at the same time, he has to communicate his knowledge to other people in his own language. As a matter of fact, a scholar who has mastered the latest discoveries through the English language will become more creative as he tries to communicate that knowledge through his own mother-tongue.

A second important question which concerns universities today is whether the syllabus followed in different fields is in the first place, up-to-date,﻿ and secondly whether it is related to the needs of the society around. The present pattern of a university prescribing a syllabus on the basis of which instruction is imparted to students in colleges has its serious limitations. The syllabus tends to get out-dated and the syllabus may not be related to the competence and experience of a teacher who teaches the subject. If, on the other hand, the prescribing of a syllabus becomes the responsibility of the teachers who will teach the subject and examine the students, there will be a vital correlation among prescribing the syllabus, teaching of the syllabus, and examining of the students. It is this concept which has been highlighted in the granting of autonomy to first-rate and reliable colleges in all the universities in this country. An autonomous college gets autonomy only in respect of its academic programmes. The teachers of the departments, assisted by a few outside experts, will prescribe the syllabus for a such a college. Teachers will teach the subject and will examine their own students. This will be a challenge to teachers because the teacher will have to maintain a standard of integrity and reliability which will not be questioned by his students.

This standard of integrity and reliability in our teachers is basic to any improvement in our higher education

As the University Education Commission Report (1948–49) says, "Moral and religious instruction does not mean moral improvement. What can﻿ be tested in an examination is acquaintance with theories. What we need is not the imparting of instruction, but the transmitting of vitality. We must civilise the human heart. Education of the emotions and discipline of the will are essential parts of a sound system of education”. Since instructing the intellect does not mean improving the heart, though thought has its own effects on life, how shall we build these values into the human mind ? If institutions are to impart moral vitality, they should have, as the University Education Commission Report (1948-49) further says, "simplicity and an atmosphere of consecration that permanently lives”. The greatest persuasion is exercised by personal examples. The personal examples of a team of dedicated and devoted teachers, carrying out their daily tasks, faithfully and earnestly, will have a great impact on their students and, in the ultimate analysis, will have a cleansing, and spiritualising effect on the college or department concerned. It is on the multiplicity of such teachers that the re-generation of our university education depends. As I said earlier, the concept of an autonomous college, with internal assessment by the teaching staff, will not be successful unless the autonomous college has a team of devoted and dedicated teachers of the highest integrity and reliability. So, integrity and reliability become essential requirements of a teacher in such an institution. Our university education has got into difficulty because these essential traits have been ignored, and we thought intellectual achieve﻿ment, without any moral commitment, could make a great teacher. A great teacher cannot be made that way. A great teacher must have intellectual competence of a very high order but, equally, he must have moral commitment and unimpeachable integrity.

In the case of Agricuitural Universities in India, it has been observed that the employment market favours the products of innovative instiutions with high standards of education. A college, with competent and dedicated teachers, if granted autonomy, will become an innovative institution, whose products will be in demand in the employment market.

Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, while addressing the graduates of Allahabad University in 1947, told them that universities in India stood for reason, humanism, tolerance, search for truth and adventure of ideas. And, he added, if our universities discharged their functions properly, all would be well with our country. In these two sentences Jawaharlal Nehru gave a brief, but, eloquent philosophy of education and the role of universities in Modern India. It is to enable our universities to discharge their functions effectively that the State recognises the autonomy of universities. The concept of autonomy implies, that there is discussion and even dissent. The junior teachers of a department should have the right to discuss and differ from the senior teachers of the same department. The student should have the right to discuss and, if necessary, differ﻿ from his teacher. But all discussion should be based on reason, humanism and tolerance, and with only one end in view, namely the search of truth. It is in this spirit of discussion and dissent that the university or the college becomes a centre of continuous growth.

An authoritarian system is not conducive to intellectual development. It does not help the development of the subordinate who cultivates an attitude of subordination, but, equally, it does not help the development of the person in authority because he can take decisions without a debate or discussion. The weakness of the authoritarian system is that it kills initiative amongst the vast majority of participants. The university system is particularly efficient in bringing together people specialised in many fields who are but able to judge the work of their peers. Actually in the university system, the evaluation is always by one's peers and not by one's superiors. In the academic council of a university, the distinguished scholars of one faculty can make a distinct contribution to the betterment of the course of studies pursued in another faculty. The great strength of the University Grants Commission is also based on this concept of evaluation by peers. Whenever an institution or'a department is to be evaluated, the University Grants Commission gets the services of scholars, from other institutions, who have specialised in these fields. So, these scholars go to these departments not as inspectors, but as peers, and in﻿ consultation with those who are working in the department, the work of the department is assessed This is the most creative way in which knowledge grows and new ideas get adopted.
