If a university. can bring into practice this basic advantage of the university system, and if its faculty can go out into the neighbourhood, tackle problems relating to the neighbourhood and take to the people of the area this attitude of assistance by one's peers, they will be able to do what is best for the community around as a joint enterprise. This is the best way to evolve a social system in which an individual citizen will realise his significance and consequently will have a significant part to play in the development of his country. It is important for us to remember that though there are national problems, there are no national solutions, and each area has to choose a programme and to find a solution most suited to its environment and needs. It is this involvement in the problems of the area around that has made our outstanding agricultural universities, leaders in the fieid of agriculture and animal husbandry in those regions. The general universities have not been able to have such an impact because of their lack of involvement in the problems of the area.

The development activities of the comprehensive area development programmes can be utilised to enable both teachers and students to bring their knowledge as well as devotion to the service of the people of the community. Earlier in this address, I expressed the view that autonomous colleges and﻿ departments will have the freedom to launch out into fields of innovation. I hope that by this means the syllabus will get updated in many colleges and departments and new means of communicating knowledge and assessing the same will be devised.

Our democratic institutions have survived, but if they have to continue to survive, we have to breathe a new life into them. Our universities have so far stumbled along. If they are to be dynamic centres of light and learning, we have to breathe a new life into them. To that challenging duty I call teachers and students of this University.﻿

ADDRESS BY DR. RAJA RAMANNA on Saturday, 21st Dec. 1974
Mr. Chancellor, Mr. Pro-Chancellor, Mr. ViceChancellor, Members of the Senate,
Ladies and Gentlemen:

I am deeply honoured that I have been invited to address you on the occasion of the Convocation of this great University. As you may know, this University conferred on me the distinction of the degree of Doctor of Science at the last convocation, an honour I cherish more than any other I have received. It is, therefore, with special pleasure I speak to you, particularly the younger members present here.

You have just imbibed most of what a university can impart to you and are now on the threshold of facing life in all its diversities and complexities. While it is hoped that what you have received is of value to guide you through life and give you discernment to gauge the events occurring around you, there are still, in spite of the education we have all received, many things that happen around us which leave us in a state of confusion and bewilderment. I refer here not to the problem of transition that our country is passing through from a backward, feudal, colonial status to a modern industrialised society, but to doubts assailing us on what was considered of permanent value to our civilisation itself. While some of it can be attributed to the impact of Western ideas on our incredibly rich Sanskritic origins, the major impact comes﻿ from the great advances science and technology has made during the last 50 years. I venture to express my views on some of these, particularly because of my close and long association with scientists and I trust we all believe that science has many new things to tell us yet. In my address, I propose to analyse how some of our traditional values have been forced to re-examination in the light of new developments and if a change is required, how then do we react to it, especially if we are to survive as an identifiable cultural force in the world. Our roots and contributions of the past have been so deep and rich in value that a complete replacement does not seem warranted, but a re-examination leading to suitable transformation is certainly necessary. Adapt or perish, that is and always has been the implacable law of life in the biological sense and this is true of our cultural moves too.

While all advances in science do not as yet support the existence of an Almighty God who guides our destinies, in any clear scientific terms, there is enough. scope to say that this is as yet an insettled question: We, however, realise that arguments based on Aristotalean logic and scientific reasoning, as we know it, do not require this assumption, but the discovery of Quantum Mechanics during the earlier part of this century was itself a rude shock to those who viewed the world as﻿ a purely mechanistic system. That the world is guided by newer laws than those, not obvious to the eye has become evident from the successes of the new mechanics. Determinism has given place to indeterminism at least in the atomic world and all laws are to be interpreted in a probabilistic manner. Mathematics itself which was considered as the paragon of rational thinking has begun to manifest inconsistencies and incompleteness in its very foundations. In spite of this living in a world in which the more mundane aspects of the advances of science and technology are having a profound effect on our lives, it is obvious we cannot ignore their influence on our spiritual lives.

In addition to the progress made in the exact and technological sciences, the recent advances made in the life sciences, particularly in understanding the structure and dynamics of the Cell, its co-operative behaviour and the laws that govern genetics, will certainly have a profound effect in determining the position of Man in the universe. Man's attempt to conquer space has certainly shown that at last in the solar system, his position is unique. No life recognisable as having the same qualities as the human species seems to exist in the rest of our solar system. However, it seems to be an impossibility to know of the immediate existence of life in the rest of our galaxy and the outer universe, as﻿ signalling to these outer worlds is itself restricted in time because of the finite velocity of our fastest signals, i.e., light. We may at best eventually get to know of what might have existed in these far off worlds several million years ago. It is strange that while in our laboratories we are now in a position to measure very accurately time intervals of very much less than a thousandth millionth of a second called a nano second, communication to outer space will always remain a very slow operation; certainly well beyond the finite span of human life.

Whatever be our philosophical ideas on the meaning of the word "existence", "physical existence" can be demonstrated with great confidence, be it in regions of 10-13 cms. or distances several million light years away. Such is the power of modern science. But, we. note that all physical measurements, however dependent on sophisticated instrumentation has to be evaluated finally by the brain. In the end it is human consciousness which decides ultimate reality. The true meaning of reality can therefore be understood only in the context of the working of the brain both in isolation and in the interaction of one with another, either through our sense organs, i.e., the eye, the ear etc., or even directly if this is possible.

The overall feeling one gets of our cul'ture and philosophy, and I make these statements fully knowing that I am no expert on﻿ the subject, is that great importance is placed on the individual self in the assessment of what

imate truth. The individual and his perception of the universe is given a pre-eminent position in all our ancient writings: I wish to bring to your attention an aspect of modern science where it is shown that collective behaviour of interacting units are more important than individual behaviour and it is the nature of this interaction between entities that plays a key role in our understanding of the universe.

You may be aware that in studying microscopic structures, one first identifies the individual building block or unit and then studies its individual and collective characteristics. In the case of physical matter, it is the atom which constitutes the unit. The structure of the atom determines its entire chemistry and the mutual interaction between atoms determines all observable physical properties of matter. The study of the properties of matter nowadays means the understanding of the complicated interaction between atoms. This approach has given rise to several new developments in modern technology and to name one such is the solid state device, the transistor. As you all know, this has revolutionised communication. The situation in the case of the atomic nucleus is even more complex than that of the atom. Here the constituent particles are protons and neutrons, the nature﻿ of whose mutual interactions is still not quite understood though we know that they give rise, under special circumstances to energy releases of unbelievable magnitude as for example, in a nuclear device or a reactor. It is now the general view of all physicists that in the study of elementary particles, the nature of the particles by themselves have no immediate significance, but the study of the interaction between them constitutes modern physics and represents the forefront of basic science. We note that as yet no consistent pattern has appeared in the understanding of elementary particles. It is almost like in a game of chess, for one who does not know the game where the actual entities are made of wood or ivory but the rules of the game make it mysterious.

The other microscopic region of study where the building blocks play a vital role in the understanding of the origin and purpose of life is the biological cell. While considerable progress has been made on the detailed structure of the cell and its molecular properties, we are far from understanding intercellular behaviour. Its behaviour is certainly amazing especially when we consider how the normal human system works where each cell acts according to a well organised co-operative system with respect to the other. It is even more amazing when something goes berserk as in the case of cancer. Here, you find some﻿ of the cells taking control of the situation to work against the general well being of the system and even the normal cells begin to take orders from the malignant ones to make the destruction quicker and more complete. It is not my intention to describe to you all the new advances made in understanding intercellular behaviour or the new information we have on the working of the brain and other biological phenomena, but to bring to your attention how even at the microscopic level the behaviour of systems have a certain likeness to the behaviour of an integrated system such as man: Man by himself in isolation is a fantastic structural unit. His power of thinking and putting into action his ideas are quite unbelievable, especially considering his size. One has merely to compare him with a small computer which does a very much lesser number of operations. In spite of this, man in isolation is not such an interesting object of study as man in interaction with other fellow human beings. If you can bear with me, I place such a great importance on this inter-man behaviour that I would like to associate its existence with the Supreme Brahman of the Vedas itself.

We sometimes come across similar to that of a diseased malignant cell, where one group of human beings try to destroy the other and therefore the entire community. Human society, very similar to repair mechanism of cells, in order to protect itself against﻿ such possibilities and introduce stability has evolved for itself various types of constraints to social behaviour. Grouping of sets of individuals is a common manifestation. At the moment, the criteria for grouping seems to be based on religion, profession and language. In our history, language has played an important part in the rise of our great culture. While it is something we should be so proud of, it has become a stumbling block to the integration of this great country of ours. We seem to concentrate on its narrower aspect and forget its greatness. For economic and other reasons, we have developed social systems to segregate ourselves into castes which in my opinion, whatever may be its value in the past, serves no purpose now. Everybody should be prepared to undertake any work from lofty and exalted philosophical reflection down to the most mental of tasks, and yet remain honoured members of the society.

In spite of the weakness of our society as exists, we have thrown up people of high quality to give the right leadership and at the right time. This is the main reason why I call our country great, but more often than is good for us, we produce people who merely elbow themselves into positions of power without any particular qualities of constructive leadership. Society therefore requires protective devices to contain and counteract the role of such people. Our system has in﻿ deed developed inherent feed backs to fight against those initiating malignant and retrograde processes, but we have to ask ourselves, are these repair processess good enough for our times. As I see it, the only corrective processes we have, is the maintenance of law and order through judiciaries, through Parliament etc. Is this sufficient ? Should it not be more through our innate sense of fair play and a regard and love for one another. It seems tragic to me that in recent times that the very definition of fair play and love for a fellow being has been distorted. Physical cruelty to the weak and disabled seems to be an accepted norm of our society. Coming as I do from an overcrowded city, the amount of cruelty shown to women and children makes me wonder whether we have any philosophy left at all.

Be that as it may, let us ask ourselves the question what is it that ensures that cruelty and callousness do not become an accepted part of our society. There is no doubt that in the past religion both in its elementary form and its highly sophisticated aspects provided a stronger base than legislation for sustaining a human society. The sophisticated aspect of religion relying on the spiritual identity of man can but influence only a few, but the elementary form of religion which provides some kind of a corrective feed back process does indeed influence a large number of people, but operates on a large component of irrational superstition. Can. we allow this to continue or should we replace it and if so by what? In my view, all superstitions and other manifestations of ignorance are evils and are motivated by selôshness. In my early years, I recall the cruelty meted out to widows in the name of Karma and Dharma. This is something that this country can never cleanse itself from. I ask you that whenever you are forced with a decision involving a challenge, da not be guided by superstition. Have courage to face up to your decision's and take full responsibility for it. If at the spur of the moment you feel unable to do this, get the help of progressive company around you, but do not revert to superstition.

I am not suggesting that you should not believe in the higher things that manifest themselves in the material world. In fact, I am a great believer in intuition and as things stand, intuition is the only way complicated problems can be approached. You will recall that in science, prediction is possible only if one has all the necessary information to solve a set of equations which describe the behaviour of a given system. Exact solutions are possible in simple cases. Perhaps, a computer can be used for the more complicated cases. In science, this is called the solution of a many body problems and presents itself in a formidable way in understanding the behaviour of﻿ a system of nucleons, system of atoms or a system of cells, each with its own degree of complexity. It is clearly impossible to use the present many body problem methods of science in predicting the behaviour of man. But this, however, does not mean that on some pseudo-scientific basis, one can claim to predict a man's future. If people are impressed by coincidences, by clever guess work, it may be that it satisfies their ego, their selfish wants, but certainly, there is no science behind this method of prediction. There are, of course the possibilities of the human brain intuitively responding to a set of circumstances, at least to determine which is the right path to take and which is not. In the exercises of one's intuition, the path must clearly be one which does not simply allow the self or individual to prosper but it must be for the benefit of the community without any differentiation towards opportunities. Unfortunately, we have to admit that the human species being what it is, all brains do not have the same characteristics, some have more discrimination, some have more intuition and many neither. But at no stage is there need for cruelty, callousness and destructive cynicism to enter because of these inherent difference.

In this short address, I have attempted perhaps in an imperfect fashion, to outline before you the mutuality of interactions in the atomic, sub-atomic, cellular and intra-cellular﻿ world in relation to the more integrated organismic and human levels and how these are inextricably interwoven into the tapestry of Indian culture and moves. It is essentially a personal view arising from my own experience and background.

Before I conclude, I would like to take the opportunity of wishing you all the best that Life has to offer you and you in turn will spare nothing on your part to help this great country of ours and promise not to do anything which will destroy its foundations. It deserves all the devotion you can give it. Nowhere in the world is there a country with such a glorious past and a promise of a great future in spite of all its diversities and discontinuities. It only requires young people like you to let it flower into real greatness.﻿

ADDRESS BY ERIC STOKES on Sunday, 6th Feb. 1977
Mr. VICE-CHANCELLOR, LADIES AND GENTLEMEN
AND GRADUATES OF THE YEAR

It is a particular privilege and distinction to be

asked to address this Convocation, especially as I appear among you as quite the newest of your graduates. In doing me these personal honours I would like to think that you are also acknowledging the connexion of Mysore University with the wider international academic community. A university, as its name implies, is a society that aspires to universal knowledge, and though set in a particular place belongs to the world of learning at large. Now whatever the undoubted gains that have accrued from the massive expansion of higher education throughout the world since 1945, an enhapcement of the open, universal, international character of universities has not been among them. The reasons are clear. Impelled by the forces clamouring for material development national governments have turned to the university as the chosen instrument for producing their most advanced echelons of trained man-power (under the Sex Anti-Discrimination Act in Britain we are now almost required to say—“people power"). But the profuse financial bounty that has been showered on university education, especially in the west, has steadily increased the dependence of the universities on the State, and their subordination to it.﻿

Even an ancient university like my own, with traditions of self-government going back to the thirteenth century, has found itself caught up in a tide that is cutting away the foundations on which its old independence was founded. The private financial endowments of Cambridge University and of the autonomous Colleges, though still substantial, represent a relatively minor part of their overall income. Dependence on State finance has inevitably meant indirect State influence in academic policy making, in the decisions on the number of staff and the subjects to be expanded or contracted.

Our students are largely supported by State maintenance awards; our tuition fees are paid by public authorities who must be consulted over any alteration of their amount. By the constraints of the system of block grants we have felt obliged to obey governmental behests and raise the fees charged to overseas students to nearly double that levied on ordinary students. Applicants from abroad have to satisfy stringent immigration requirements. Even overseas academic staff wishing to call at British universities on their way elsewhere often find the immigration formalities intimidating. Our private funds for inviting longer-staying academic visitors have been eroded by inflation, and overseas governments are known to look with a jealous eye on private exchanges as carrying with them the danger of foreign interference. University research has increasingly come under the aegis of﻿ semi-governmental national research councils, so that a British scholar wishing for funds to work abroad must first gain approval of his project from such a body. He has then to gain access to the country of his choice and in many parts of the world obtain approval of his project from the government of that country. For their part governments in seeking to promote closer relations with another country blithely sign cultural exchange agreements providing for the interchange of academic visits without any consultation with the academic community. Hence scholars came to be despatched more in the character of national representatives than as individuals pursuing their own line of inquiry and research.

I, therefore, point to a general world phenomenon when I state that the power of governments over the university world has increased and is increasing. It is not a condition for which any particular country or government is to blame, and there is an element of hypocrisy if we try to point an accusing finger. For the situation is one which we may deplore as scholars but which we have willed as citizens. It is the price we pay for the powerful drive of governments to improve our material lot, to allocate scarce resources, and to respond to our nationalist urges to control the entry and activity of foreigners in our countries. For these we have let go the nineteenth century world of minimal government, unfettered private initiative and enterprise, free international move﻿ment of persons, and a large measure of university autonomy. The university has not been a chosen victim. Every sphere of cultural life has been brought into the politico-governmental world, including international sport and even the Miss World Competition. Nevertheless we have a situation in which although universities and their international contacts have been multiplied in gross, they have been drawn into a steadily narrowing national setting and much of their old independence and power of initiative has been draihed away to strong national governments at the centre. In this sense their universality and open international character have been impaired. Does this matter? I think it does.

The proper function of learning is to bring the individual into communication with a mental world larger than the one he naturally inhabits. Its purpose is to release him from the narrow bonds of his immediate time and place and make him free- of a world of mental discourse that knows no boundaries of community, nation or race. In the field of the natural sciences the international or universal nature of learning is not open to question. Scientists have always been the most internationally minded members of the academic community and the least affected by pational prepossessions. To governments it is also abundantly plain that their scientists must be afforded the fullest and freest access to the international scientific community if their talents are to be most fully developed in the national﻿ interest. In the humanities the need for outside contact is much less obvious, since scholars in these disciplines are often concerned with some local facet of their own national cultures and communities. The humanities splinter much more naturally into localized compartments, so that while a science syllabus will be more or less common throughout much of the world a humanities syllabus will not. Moreover, the humanities appear to have no immediate cash value in terms of promoting economic development, and hence have been least favoured by governments with aid to overcome their localization by more frequent and abundant contact with the international academic community. Yet paradoxically these are in many ways the subjects that are most in need of opening a window on the wider universe, because although, like women seemingly weak and ineffectual on a superficial view, it is their hands that rock the cradle and rule the world. For in our general views and political persuasions we are all ultimately products of the conditioning we undergo from the men who handle words, whether' politicians, officials, administrators, teachers, journalists, or broadcasters. And the ideas they purvey are drawn from a general culture outside the special truths of natural science and technology. The humanities and in some measure the social sciences remain the most powerful source of this general culture which suffuses our newspapers and the spoken public word. Hence in the intellectual sphere the﻿ liberty of the mind and its ability to range across Frontiers is in the end of supreme importance, for in this sphere of general culture ignorance or what is worse, half knowledge, carries the most damaging consequences. In every country we are in constant danger of being shut into the narrow thought world of our particular national culture in its most introvert form. The danger to the British people of such insularity of mind has long been apparent, an insularity which can be defined, to transpose a phrase of the late G. M. Young, as "introspection within a closed circle of experience". I would have thought that India faced similar dangers though a different set of problems. Her vital need is to fashion a general culture which is modern though essentially Indian, and which couched in the language of universal communication-English-remains a natural, spontaneous, and creative expression of Indian life. Such a culture cannot be introspective; it must be outgoing. The function of a university anywhere is to foster an autonomous intellectual discipline by which men and women can view their immediate local and personal prejudices with some measure of detachment. Academics do not, of course, live up to this ideal in ordinary life. They are fallible human beings, concerned like the rest of mankind with promotion and pay, and swept at times by gusts of political love or hate. Yet even in their most impassioned and prejudiced moods they continue to recognize dimly the vital impor﻿tance of keeping the argument open, and they appeal even in the height of controversy to some objective standard of judgement springing from a wider overarching cultural framework. That objective standard may be for us no more sometimes than the hard view taken of us by the outside world.

If, therefore, the need to keep a window open on the wider world is peculiarly important in sustaining this larger cultural framework, then the position of the least favoured elements of the university community-the humanities-requires to be looked at with more discernment. Their need to keep open communication with the international academic community is in the end no less vital than for the scientist. I am impressed, for example, how few university teachers of the humanities whom I have met in India have effective opportunities to pay academic visits elsewhere, either in India or abroad.

There is a further issue. The influence of governments over universities has not merely elevated the latter's national stance at the expense of its international stance. It has also tended to weaken the springs of self-government, self-help, and self-initiative. The pattern of centrally guided research by national research councils threatens the springs of individual spontaneity which is the source of all creativity. Now it has always been one of the great traditions of true liberalism to oppose the dominant forces of the age, not to overthrow them but to prevent their﻿ excessive dominance. In Britain in the last century Matthew Arnold stood up to oppose the prevailing current which ran strong in favour of lais sez faire and the absence of all governmental interference. Today the pendulum has swung far the other way and the liberal needs to exercise bis strength in an opposite direction. Not because he is opposed to state power as such and wishes to displace it, but because he does not wish it to grow so powerful as to negate the ultimate end it is designed to secure, the spontaneity and capacity for initiative of the individual. This at least is one of our perennial concerns in university circles in Britain, and I suspect that it is not absent here.

Mr. Vice-Chancellor, these are ponderous remarks for what is by nature a happy occasion. Yet I thought it useful to show that British and Indian universities share problems that differ in degree rather than kind. From what I have learned of Mysore University they are not problems which press too heavily upon you; and you appear to have adopted your own vigorous remedies. I was delighted to read in the Diamond Jubilee Number of the Mysore University Gazette of the permanent and practical way the university had decided to commemorate its first sixty glorious years. It has renewed its appeal for the Golden Jubilee Foundation, begun in 1966, whose purpose is to use private gifts for the promotion of scholarship and research, for the founding of new chairs, and for the provision of equipment. I was interested,﻿ above all, in the proposals to institute visiting professorships and lectureships, to promote international understanding by staff exchanges, and to make travel grants and loans for promising teachers and researchers to study abroad.

Such a foundation meets all the objectives set out in my earlier reflections. Mysore University is strengthening the sources of local initiative, looking other than to Government for financial help, reaching out to the world beyond Mysore and bringing that world back to its doorstep From the record of the past sixty years it is evident-to use Othello's modest understatementthat you have done the State some service. In enlarţing the range of your external contacts you are not, I think, indulging the private interests of individuals. India can only benefit from increased contacts with the outside world. In Singapore and Malaysia last year I was-much struck by the absence of contact with Indian universities and the small extent to which India was studied in a region with which India has had close cultural and historical ties. Presumably if India is to pursue an informed foreign policy this isolation of her educated classes from so vital an area will have to be rapidly overcome, and I gather that institutes of South East Asian Studies are being set up or expanded in a number of Indian universities. The same absence of Indian academic contacts is also observable in Africa despite the fact of the common bond of an English language culture. Mysore University﻿ has not been backward in its international connections, although not perhaps with these particular areas. The record of academic visitors in all your major departments, and of the visits of your own academic staff overseas, demonstrates a lively and healthy concern to keep Mysore an 'open' university in the very broadest sense.

I would like Mr. Vice-Chancellor to feel that my presence here today is a token and pledge of the good-will which Cambridge and the British academic world bears towards your university. For myself, returning to Mysore is a source of great personal pleasure. One does not readily forget the place where one attained the age of majority or heard the awesome news of the dropping of the first atomic bomb. I was then merely a subaltern in an Indian mountain artillery regiment which formed part of 26th Indian Division as it lay poised at Vadigenhalli in August 1945, ready to spring forward for the assault on Malaya. The world has changed a great deal since that date and India with it, but the countryside of Karnataka still wears a smiling face and breathes the same balmy climate. Among the British there is a special affection for this land, an affection that ranges beyond the attractions of Ooty. Some of our greatest names are connected with it. Wellington, whose figure even now adoras our five-pound notes, was taught his sharpest lessons in military science by Tipu at Srirangapatnam. Lord Macaulay, whose complete letters are now being published by the﻿ Cambridge University Press, wrote some of his liveliest descriptive prose in relating the scenic beauties of Mysore when in 1834 he was carried up the ghats from Madras and made his way to Ootacamund to take his place in the GovernorGeneral's Council. A still more famous man, Winston Churchill, developed such an attachment to India when he was a young cavalry officer in these 'parts in the 1890's that as an old man in 1947 he could not bring himself to accept the necessity of severing the political tie between Britain and India, despite the almost unanimous voice of both British and Indian opinion.

It is, Sir, with these historic associations between us that I'thank you for asking me to address this Convocation today. May I offer the other new graduates the most cordial congratulations in the confident hope that they will go out into the world to swell the ranks of the university's ambassadors who are scattered far and wide in this country and beyond the seas. So long as the parent trunk of Mysore University is firmly rooted in Karnatak soil, every branch which it throws up into the outside world can only give it fresh nourishment and strength. Thus, long have you flourished. Long may you do so!﻿

ADDRESS BY ASHOK MITRA
on Saturday, 23rd Apr.1978

The University of Mysore has done me a great honour in inviting me to this august Convocation, I am a renegade from the world of learning; it is only your tolerance for an acknowledged maverick which justifies my presence here. This kindness overwhelms me.

The occasion demands that I should address a few words to the young scholars who have been formally conferred their degrees today. It is a proud day for them, but it is also a day which adds to their load of responsibility. The burden of this nation rests squarely on them. What is the import of this burden? How is the educational system as it obtains at present relevant to the apportionment, and sharing, of this burden ?

As I see it, there are three ways of looking at education. It is in the first place a public good to which all ought to have equal right and access. Like water, air and light, education too should be available on demand to the citizens of a free country. Education in this sense is a stock, a stock to draw upon, which allows the constituents of the community to improve their minds and raise the level of their awareness. One talks of adult suffrage and the right to vote for each citizen. But this right loses its significance if it is not accompanied by the much more primal right of education.

The second aspect of education is perhaps an extension of the first, but is equally relevant.﻿ Education is the imbibing of skill, skill that is needed if one wants to qualify for a profession or livelihood. Here again, the crucial element is that of stock-building, the garnering of an addi-. tional asset. In a free society, each citizen should normally have the right to choose the skill he intends to specialise in and to have as much opportunity as his neighbour for obtaining the training and education required for the development of that particular skill. True, there would be a problem of resource-constrain here ; formation of any skill is a function of certain investment activities and investments imply a draft on resources since the imparting of some skills is more resource-using than others; the question of a proper allocation of resources is bound to arise. The expectation would still seem reasonable that, in a country given to the observance of democratic norms, whatever resources are available should be so distributed as to ensure the equitable spread of skill-formation as between the different members of the community.

Unfortunately, in our country neither of these two aspects of education has been in command. Primary education, which should be a free public good, is yet to filter down to the millions and millions of the poorer households. In the countryside, those who either do not have any land or have only meagre morsels of it remain outside the pale of education; the State has been able to do little to redress the situation in the course of the past thirty years. Outside the rural sector, the situation is no less murky. By and large, the dispossessed are disinherited from the educational process too. The causality is of a multiple kind. A large number amongst those who are poor are unable to partake of the opportunity to educate themselves because they use their time scrounging for food ; education is a luxury. which they simply cannot afford. At the same time, the poor do not have the means with which to get themselves educated either ; poverty and illiteracy are heavily inter-correlated.

The situation is obviously much worse in the case of the upper layers of the educational process, leading to advanced skill formation of some genre or other. In the very high reaches of learning, the children of the poor are a near-negligible category. This gives rise to a phenomenon which is not just self-perpetuating; it is actually selfaggravating. Those who have the assets corner the opportunities for additional skill formation, enabling them to acquire more income and assets, which in turn leads to the possibility of their acquiring even more skills, while the poor are left out in the cold. It is still only through sheer accident os happenstance that children from poor families can, as late as even today, hope to obtain higher education, including scientific and technical education.

There is however a third aspect of education I wanted to talk about. Even amongst the fortunate few who succeed in breaking into the arena﻿ of higher education, a process of attrition begins to work. The rationale for acquiring additional skills is that, with these skills, one would succeed in earning a wage higher than one could have expected otherwise; in other words, skill-differentials are the key to wage-differentials. But it has not been happening that way at all in our country. Only a minor fraction of those who emerge out of our universities, technical schools and engineering and medical colleges have been able to secure an earning commensurate with their expectations. A substantial number have discovered to their awe and consternation that employment opportunities are shrinking with each day, and society has little use for their skills. In particular, developments in the country since the mid-1960's constitute a sombre story, with hundreds of thousands swelling the crowd of the socalled educated unemployed. This fact notwithstanding, we find, year in and year out, a continuous addition to the crowd seeking higher education. Education has suddenly become much like an indeterminate, interminable tunnel. Those who are reluctant to enter the labour market wait out in this tunnel. They are reluctant to emerge out of it, because at the end of it awaits uncertainty, uncertainty about jobs and earnings. Education is hence converted into an elongated process. Young men and women, willy nilly, remain students because, they apprehend, once they arrive at the terminus, only a nominal switch in their identity will take place: they will cease to be﻿ students, only to join the vast reserve army of the unemployed. It is a fate which they want to postpone; they therefore hang around within the portals of educational institutions, an undecided, hazy crowd for whom education is no longer a means for advancing their skills, but has become a vestibule which keeps them away from the fate of joblessness.

I am hardly exaggerating. Even as I face the young men and women who are passing out today, the overriding emotion I have is one of guilt and sadness. I wish I could have some extra words of cheer for them. But that would be an exercise in hypocrisy. The graduates of the University of Mysore -are, I have to assume, a representative cross-section of the graduates all over the country. Only a few amongst them can, at the present juncture, look forward to receiving in life the kind of reward which they would consider to be adequate quid pro quo for their education and skills. This is the reality.

It is this reality which reminds us that the national economy has been in a state of near atrophy for almost fifteen years now. There bas been growth, but only just about to take care of the rising population. There has been growth, but the expansion of industrial and commercial activities had been of a most modest order. There has been growth in agriculture too, but it has been highly selective and beyond a point, has not been shared by all sections of the community. We cannot ignore the stark fact of a certain lack﻿ of impulse in the different segments of the economy. There are exceptions to this story, but not of such moment as to obliterate its central message. Our graduates fail to obtain gainful employment, because the economy is languishing. Each year, our institutions produce hundreds of engineers, scientists and other technical people ; they produce graduates in commerce and economics ; they produce other graduates who are wonderfully proficient in the liberal arts; yet, a huge number from amongst them soon discover that the nation has little use for the additional skills they have accumulated. It is all a cry of sellers, sellers of skills, with but few buyers.

This is what reduces the educational system in the country to such a pitiful state. At the end of the tunnel there is only further darkness. There is an apparent inversion of roles; the tunnel, which allows our young ones to wait out, becomes a symbol of security; it is the end of it which is full of grim forebodings.

We are thus faced with a conundrum. At one end, education, which should be a public good and, at the same time, is a skill-augmenting asset, is currently the prerogative of a very limited proportion of the population, the nation's majority remaining beyond its pale; at the other end only a handful of even those who receive the bounty of this precious asset are assured of a secure future. Of those who pass out of the universities, a bare few are fortunate enough to receive conventional social acclaim;﻿ their skills are recognised inside the country, and occasionally outside. Some amongst them can even command an international clientele. They can, if they so choose, leave the country and enjoy a high life-style in richer lands; some so choose. Those who are left behind engage in a fierce competition amongst themselves to corner the severely restricted opportunities for comfortable existence that are available in this poor, near-stagnant country. Once the lucky ones have been sorted out, the rest join the vast non-descript crowd of the hapless and the mediocrities, who have little to look forward to and for whom opportunity is often denied for class-biased reasons.

At this point, I would like to append one or two humble comments which my young friends will not, I hope, take amiss. It is perhaps time to perceive that there is an organic link between the fact that a majority of the nation are denied educational opportunities and the other fact that a great number of those who do receive education nonetheless cannot fulfil their aspirations. Disenchantment awaits the latter, the realities of the economy hold them back. These realities are those of retarded economic growth, and the lack of expansion of industry and commerce, agriculture and crafts, science and technology. An intense kind of interdependence, characterises economic activities; once one specific activity is held back, others 'too are affected pari passu. Without appreciable economic expansion, employ﻿ment is adversely affected, and as employment opportunities peter out, income and demand for goods and services level off too; there is then a further recession in economic activities. It is a perfect empirical correlate of that worn-out expression, low-level equilibrium.

It could have been altogether otherwise, however. It can still be. If, instead of being burdened by a rate of illiteracy of around 70 per cent in the country, as a whole and much more in the countryside, we were able to spread the bounty of education more evenly across the population, a different situation would have emerged. Education-even elementary educationwould have led to an awakening of consciousness on the part of the poor. No greater capital asset than this awareness is conceivable. It would have made the poor realise the factors underlying the distance, social as well as economic, between them and the favoured ones. From this awareness would have come a certain cohesiveness within their fold, which could have strengthened their determination to demand an increased proportion of national assets and earnings. Education would have led to a sharpening of the hunger for land, the hunger for higher wages, the hunger for a larger share of the crop on the part of the share-croppers, for a larger share of the available irrigation facilities, of bank and co-operative loans, of pesticides, of seeds and diverse other amenities provided either directly by the State or under its auspices. This awareness would have﻿ led to a more even sharing of the nation's assets. Many other things would then have followed. The enlarged income of the poor would have led to an enlargement of the purchasing power across-the-board, which in turn would have led to a widening and deepening of the market. This would have resulted in the intensification of demand for farm products and industrial goods, for commercial and service activities, and for inputs of various sorts. The sum-total would have been a pulsating increase in the rate of economic growth, from which the entire nation would have benefited. The economy would have hummed, work and employment opportunities would have multiplied, scientific and research would have flourished, the texture of the horizon would have been transformed for our young people.

We thus have to begin, to re-tread the cliche, at the very beginning. If today even for the limited few, who are blessed by the advantage of advanced education, the future seems more or less uniformly bleak, the answer has to be sought in the other fact that educational opportunities have been confined to these few. If the younger generation are to be ensured a greater order of security, they would have to grapple with the problem on their own. I would plead with them to form a lobby, a lobby which will plead that educational opportunities are not kept cornered by a handful, but are spread out all over. It is in this generosity that. I feel, lie the class interests of those who are represented in this hall this morning.

And this campaign should mean bits and pieces of other things too. It is the advance of the poor which can contribute most effectively to economic growth and, therefore, to jobs and enhanced earnings for the hitherto privileged, including the graduates who are getting their degrees today. Attend to the poor and the under-privileged and the flood-gate of opportunities will be opened for you. This is not altruism, but enlightened self-interest. Education has given you added skills, use these skills to serve the cause of the poor. The poor do have but meagre resources, so adapt your skills in order that the poor can raise their productivity at relatively low investment. Use your skills for evolving a technology which suits the poor. Once the poor survive and advance, the rest of us in society would too. Education is for self-enlightenment; there can be no greater self-enlightenment than the realisation that the poor and the disinherited are very much a part of an integrated system to which we all belong. I hope my young friends agree; even if they do not, I hope they will agree to debate my proposition. A university education, after all, is for opening the doors and windows of the mind.

I thank you all.﻿

ADDRESS BY K. SHIVARAMA KARANTH
on Saturday, 21 Apr.1979

Mr. Chancellor, Mr. Vice-Chancellor, Graduates of the University, Ladies and Gentlemen.

My first duty is to thank this University for having committed an initial" blunder" in 1963 by conferring on me' a doctorate and now more so by requesting me to deliver today's Convocation address. This I do with humility and gratitude. Though I had at one time, enlisted myself as a student of the Madras University, my studentship lasted no longer than 7 months, thanks to Gandhiji who in 1922 goaded me to give it up in preference to a much larger job of serving the cause of Indian freedom. I am glad that I did so, for it taught me that India was bigger than myself and also the Madras University and during later years I discovered that this universe itself was too vast, for comprehension by the mind of any single individual, in a life time. Had I finished my University I would have become one like, any average graduate, who normally comes out of its portals, feeling relieved of the big bother of passing examinations. I would then have gone hunting after security of my own life, at the expense of everything else, this wonderful world had to offer me.

. This has given me a chance to interest myself in many things, that concern man, his past and present. Such an enterprise is﻿ vast. It is so baffling and intriguing as much as interesting and ever inspiring. My pursuit has shown me that an individual's life has a definite end, but the process of enquiry and learning has no end at all. As such I have read a little bit, about the activities of a few Universities, here and abroad. This was a sort of inference, which drew from the writings, of many scholars, who conducted pioneer studies, in varied branches of exact Sciences, Social Sciences and if I am permitted to coin a term, "inexact” or speculative Sciences.

I feel that a University which trains young people in order to fit themselves into a larger world, ought to create first of all a love for learning. It has to inspire the pupils for ardent carving out a vaster and deeper understanding of the place of man in this universe. No doubt I am suggesting a never ending task. You would terrify him by the enormity of the project for his action starts with the little place he lives on this earth; life and other problems prevailing here so that he can adjust himself to his surrounding in order to live harmoniously with multitudes of other species that made a home, here before man himself. I would be content with this pilot scheme before aspiring after still more distant things and questions.

Do we stimulate such hunger for knowledge and sponser such activities or research﻿ on unknown aspects of life and its problems about History and its implications about the beauties and the pleasures that life can offer us and about creative Arts ?

Acquainting oneself with things already known and then probing into the unknown is such a vast enterprise that would warrant ignoring a hundred failures to one bit of success.

Those of you who would agree with me with the above objectives will have to agree with me that these ambitions cannot be realised by medicore brains who have no zeal, no sense of wonder, no curiosity but are only satisfied with memorising facts and repeat them whenever asked to do so. Men who feel amply satisfied if given a prestigious place and a comfortable purse are not the ones that could handle such an adventure. They cannot draw or discover talent in themselves, or draw them out of their students. That is possible by men, who by themselves are thirsty after knowledge. They by their personality can infuse such a zeal, in students. They can by instinct spot out talent and encourage students in varried branches of knowledge so that they too become everinquisitive. To them further knowledge becomes their reward, in life. Society would provide them with all creative comforts. Such craze for knowledge does not end with a comfortable job. Even after retirement﻿ they will not seek comfort in Bhajan Parties, I know very well that such zealous persons are not to be found in large numbers. Universities to be Universities should go after such seekerst after knowledge if they have to be worth the name. It is only when such scholars inspire and guide the youngyou are bound to have a crop of intellectual enthusiasts-in every University. Their labour, research and achievements are bound to reflect on the intellectual prosperity of a nation. The nation benefits; and such benefits can pass beyond a country's borders

During the thirties, I read a book about the activities of Illinois University by Sudhindra Bose. A student who came there wanted to specialise, in the 'Culture of Crow-Indians'. The University had no chair for such a study. They could have said 'No' and asked him to choose some other course of study which they could offer. The Crow-Indians are a group original inhabitants of the United States of America. They still live there, and are treated as primitives of the land by the American colonisers. The Illinois University thought, it fit to create a special chair for studies on the Crow-Indian language and culture. All this for a single student. We would have thought it utter waste of public money thus betraying our narrow attitude towards knowledge. We would not﻿mind wasting money by creating a chair for the sake of persons whom we like, but not for subjects in general. Knowledge is knowledge to us if only it would help us to feed one's belly, but not the brain. Otherwise it is impossible to think of the place given to Sanskrit in our Universities. To us it is only a dead language. It was this and another dead language Pali, which store the best of the Indian cultural and intellectual tradition.

Both these languages reflected the intellectual life of our country, all our thought processes and our logic. Our religious teachings as well as philosophical attitudes were expressed through them. Every aspect of life and living had to face challenges from scholars of the age. Hence they were virile and not docile. It is not only the languages but also their contents that ought to receive due respect and attention by us. What we call Indian Culture is the product of so many challenging intellectual reflections and beliefs of the past.

We have been blindly accepting the choice of subjects of studies from the West. We imitate their curricula. So far as modren sciences are concerned this is a necessity but not so in everything. A number of subjects have to deal with problems of our own society and country. Unless our teachers become research-minded in all aspects, we can only be imitators, content with copying﻿ their curricula. After doing so, we begin to set a premium on memorising of texts. Examinations mean recapturing what one has memorised. Let it be any subject unless the mode of presentation of a subject depends on the arousal of interest, making the student to investigate, to think and then make the subject part of his accepted beliefs it is no education.

It needs a professor of a different kind to whom a discipline is a live issue. His own learning has not ended and during the entire period of his teaching career he is in touch with all researches that are going on about the subject. It is such a person who inakes his students alive to the problems of the world.

We have now reduced all this to-memorising facts, and teaching and learning of the same oriented to the demands of an examination paper.

What is the place of research in University education ? Research is a quest that you persue on your own. Is it enough if we spare a week--for it, in a whole year ? Our professors cease to be researchers any more. That pursuit ends with their Doctorate. I am not alleging that everyone is like that but many of them are surely.

Your University Grants Commission has been good enough to provide funds even to retiring professors so that they may﻿ engage themselves in research. What would happen if the U.G.C. call for a report ? Both active and retired professors are doing the jobs of tutors and no more. That is because the University is content to hand down to students only accumulated knowledge of the past. They have no further ambition. Research to us is not part of Collegiate education. Our Education is supposed to be job-oriented, without in the least bothering as to what those jobs are.

Ours is neither liberal education that makes one feel an elite or fits us well to particular jobs—the requirements of which we are not aware. Such omnibus education fails. in serving any social need.

Prestige and popularity of Universities depend much on the prestige and brilliance of its professors. The Princeton University invited Einstein to stay with it when his theory of relativity had no immediate use. Many scientific researches do not have utilitarian objectives. But Einstein's theory shook the world of Physics and Astronomy. His equation E = mc2 resulted in unimaginable profits to every nation that was prepared to receive it.

We seem to be practical minded people whose attitude towards knowledge has been equally practical. As such it is shorne of all glamour, all speculation and hence no further thirst for more of it.﻿

Our text books reveal our attitude. It is enough, if our students memorise only portions, that have been prescribed to each class.

To speak in a lighter vein, let me cite an example. There is the bothersome question " What is life ?". For us the answer could be " It is kicking about between birth and death”. We have reduced matters to bare essentials. Answers are to be either 'yes' or 'no'. Nothing lies in-between.

From the primary class to the highest collegiate one--we think drilling factual knowledge into the brains of the young constitutes education. But a genius here and a doubter elsewhere upsets us, by opening new windows and presenting new horizons and skies. He points out the nature of black holes and quasars. He reduces the atom to constitutent energy particles. All these begin to have their own repurcussions on Applied Sciences too. Have the Universities to keep abreast of such things or not? Should they leave this job to Pure Science Research Institutes and say that is none of our job?'

I am surprised at the vast multitude of young men -that flock to .our Universities.. Being an egalitarian race--we set no standards for admission. Our standards are simple ; made much more simple each year so that no seeker of the college degree is driven back. We have created an illusion in the minds of the young that a pass bestowed here will fit him into every walk of life. So, they come and come inspite of knowing that there are thousands unemployed all over the country. This number is ever increasing and in inverse ratio standards are falling

If providing jobs is our aim, we have to provide suitable technical education. This we are doing too. But many of our Technical Schools and Colleges-have to cater for the needs of Industries, that are in existence and many that may get established. Their needs dictate the terms for employment. These Industries have to face world competition and consumers' preferences for price and quality.

Imagine the fate of the U.S.A. a far advanced country, with capital and technology being challenged by post war Germany and Japan. Here again it is research into easier and newer ways in manufacture, that can make competition successful. Our students and graduates too will have to face it in life. Preparation for facing life in all spheres is the very concern of education.

Besides, education will have to provide the means and basis for emotional and intellectual needs of man. That may not bring salary or monetary gain. But it will bring pleasure and contentment and save﻿ man from destraction and despair. Will teaching a few bits from the classics serve this purpose ? Do arts really attract our students for their own sake ?

The time has come when our young men and women who flock into the Universities have to seriously think about their own future. During the time they spend in the Universities a few poor students are serious about it. Where the state provides for 66 per cent of them they feel happy, because they are much better off than their people at home.: They are not worried at all; they would like to continue here, if only you can keep them here. The prospects of white collar jobs are not plenty. Private trade or industry cannot pay as much as the Banks can. And the pupils who come out of the portalscannot think of any other job, that needs hard work.

During my short sojourn in the U.S.A., I saw many college students work in restaurants as servers; and as workers in road building. It would look impudent to suggest such things to our students.

Our leaders feel that the exodus of talented young men to U.S.A. or Canada is unpatriotic. But here we do not recognise. their worth. Those that have secured jobs did so by dint of hard work, showing the "Americans that to employ them would bring prosperity to their country. Shirkers of work﻿ don't have a place there. The more energetic you are, the better your pay scale and opportunity for enlarging your talents. Your contribution to the prosperity of the U.S.A. or Canada enables you to live there in comfort.

With us birth and influence may count in certain areas of employment. In fields, where the tax-ayer pays for all inefficiency, it can go on but never so in a private enterprise. It is an area subject to heavy competition.

At this stage, I must express my fear about the deterioration of human character among our youth. Young men normally are idealistic and sentimental in nature. It is assumed that in later life society forces them to be something different. If I am to believe-the various newspaper reports-of mass copying, threatening invigilators with dire consequences and various dubious and shameful ways adopted to pass examinations and obtain false marks cards, I feel sad about their future. Except our benign government agency no private institution may be willing to absorb such a dubious talent. The unscrupulous ways practised during student-hood, are bound to tempt him or her to shirk work and hoodwink his employers.

How long will our Universities tolerate such character--deterioration ? It is telling upon the attitudes of honest, diligent and﻿ intelligent students, who may be small in number and who have begun to grumble " if honesty and diligence have no value-what next ?"

Now I am nearing the end of my boring speech. Our Educators have failed the young. They failed them from the primary class onwards by making-learning distasteful. No education is possible without creating interest in the subjects taught. It was Rabindranath Tagore who when questioned by his father, on his return from England within 17 months of his stay-said 'Even English men have not made education interesting?

Children are prisoners, are drilled into mercilessly by teachers. They had to bear all that. Their own curiosity, age and interests were never heeded to.

Later as grown up young men they flock to colleges and revolt. They rebel for every cause, their own or the world's. You may ask me why we didn't do so, when we were studying in our colleges. Then the number who sought admissions were too few. Those who came-knew of their own poor circumstances and value of money. They strove hard because they believed that education would provide them with a livlihood.

Now with thousands flock into colleges, they do so because the state takes care of﻿ two thirds of the number. Requirements for admission are reduced to the minimum. They get in by right and not by worth. The 'anasakti yoga' you taught them upto their high school stage-gets an impetus. The final stage has come. 'Just say it is the modern age. Revolt of youth is a natural phenomena. Trying to curb it may bring horrible results.

Then Sir, please abdicate your place and leave all the responsibility of Teaching Curricula, Examinations, Assessment and Management to them-and seek retreat elsewhere.

To you, young graduates, whatever the circumstances that have shaped your life so far, once you step into, too wide world you have to fight your own battle. Parents of many of you cannot provide you any more. You cannot reduce your newly acquired standard of life also. If you set your goalas living like men, you have to be brave. Face life squarely as crores of people are doing in our country. Shirk not your responsibility. Accept any work or toil and fit yourself for the task. At no time make your friends or employers feel that you are not to be trusted.

I chose writing as my profession and carried on as best as I could. It failed to﻿ provide for me and my family, I felt insecure till I was almost Sixty years of age and I assure you I have no regrets and I have not made undue claims against my society.﻿

Address delivered at the Sixtieth Convocation
(Diamond Jubilee Convocation)
of the University of Mysore
on 17th January 1980
by Shri Neelam Sanjeeva Reddi,
President of India

I am happy to be here with such a distinguished gathering, and to participate in the Diamond Jubilee Convocation of the University of Mysore. More than six decades ago, men of vision foremost among whom were the then Maharaja of Mysore and Shri M. Visveswariah, laid the foundation of this great centre of learning in the already famous and well known city of Mysore. This city, reputed for its salubrious climate, beauty, cultural and scholastic traditions has nurtured the University of Mysore which is today a premier institution for higher education in the country. This University has contributed significantly to higher education and research not only in Karnataka, but in the country as well. This is a matter in which all who have been associated with this University may feel justifiably proud. One of my distinguished predecessors in office, Dr. Sarvapalli Radhakrishnan, was on the faculty of this University, and had made a valuable contribution to the growth and development of this University and to its high academic renown. Many distinguished﻿ scholars like the renowned poet and scholar, Dr. K.V. Puttappa, have burnished the image of this University and made it a heaven for those seeking knowledge. It is for you who are now in the University, as teachers and students, to derive inspiration from these traditions and work with devotion for making this institution worthy of the dreams of its founding fathers. I greet the young men and women who have won academic honours and distinction today. I congratulate them on the successful completion of their academic pursuits.

At the same time, I would like to remind you that today is not the end of your quest but only the beginning. The challenge of life lies ahead. There are innumerable problems for which you will have to seek appropriate solutions. The fundamental purpose of all education, and in particular higher education at the University level resolves itself ultimately to a search for such answers. By the very nature of things such a search never ceases. In conferring academic degrees on you today, this University has conferred on you the status of seekers after perfection and truth. The success you have achieved singles you out as men and women who have dedicated yourselves to use your intellectual gifts for the benefit of society at large and to provide initiatives to your fellowmen in this search for a better and brighter future. Your responsibilities in this regard are particularly onerous in a country like ours where the privilege of education and, particularly University education, is available to very few. It is my hope that you will not only uphold the ideals of this great séat of learning and dedicate yourselves to the service of our people, whose hope for the future focusses on you.

Education is the key to personal enlightenment and progress. It is also the instrument of national and world progress. We cannot offer our people a better life unless we give priority to their needs in this aspect of nation building activity and be selective in the design of the educational system so that it is in harmony with aspirations and needs of our people.

The compulsions of the modern social structure dynamic, competitive and ever-changing-calls for an imaginative and adaptable educational system. We stand committed to certain fundamental human values. Our educational system must reflect these national objectives and so orient itself that those goals may be achieved smoothly and with expedition. Education should not remain an insular intellectual exercise but must display its involvement in the enormous and variegated social and economic tasks which face us.

Our centres of learning should be free to think and to experiment with new thoughts and ideas; and to probe the unknown and the imponderable. At the same time, they should not forget their obligations to society which conveys such freedom of thought and expression. To me this is the essence of University autonomy and academic freedom.﻿

The future of our country and indeed that of mankind is in the hands of the millions of youngmen and women who are now serving their aprenticeship for life at Universities. This is at once a challenge and an opportunity. The youth of a nation are the trustees of posterity. They are a national asset of very great importance. As we plant a seed, 'and watch it germinate, grow up, flower and yield fruit, so must we watch tenderly over our young people as they take first steps forward in this march into the future. Youth has several valuable attributes. Let us channelise these into various forms of nation building activity and set before youth goals for them to achieve. We must encourage them to develop their personalities and be leaders in the glorious future which beckons to us all.

Today is a great and memorable occasion for all of you who have received degrees and diplomas. Alumni of this University have enriched the life of this ancient land in many ways. I am glad that the University of Mysore has decided to celebrate the Diamond Jubilee celebrations by building a Senate Hall.

As you step into the wide world, fortified with the knowledge and wisdom you have imbibed in your years at this University, I offer all of you my sincere good wishes and blessings and hope that your life ahead will be full and rewarding. May your lives always reflect the best in 'our national life and tradition.

Jai Hind.﻿

ADDRESS BY Y. NAYUDAMMA
on Saturday, 7th Feb.1981
Mr. Chancellor, Mr. Vice-Chancellor,
Graduates of the year, Ladies and Gentlemen

I am conscious of the honour, you have done me in inviting me to deliver this convocation Address. The honour is all the greater recognising the rich record of Mysore University as a seat of light, liberty and learning and service to society.

At the outset, allow me to offer the graduates of the year our hearty congratulations and all good wishes. Those that graduated are entering the real world that lies outside the University. You are out to seek and make a career as an academician, administrator or an entrepreneur.

You are like a ship ready to sail outward bound. Life is a voyage in the high seas. Your education and your degree is comparable to a set of charts. Your steering the ship is comparable to your skill to use this chart and knowledge. To seaworthy vessel, all oceans are open-If you have the skills and the chart, you can touch any port you. want-so in your life, with an ambition and plan, with adventurous spirit and skill, you can reach any high position.﻿

No University can train you for an unknown situation but it can prepare you to face challenges with competence, confidence and courage. This implies, a degree is not an end in itself but only the beginning of a continuous learning process. It is learning to learn.' Learning never ends. Continuous learning gives you a feeling of self realisation, a sense of creativeness, a sense of responsibility, a knowledge of purpose and a fellowship with the world. This is development-development of the person-of the individual personality, developing the inherent resourcefulness, creativity, innovative ability, problem solving capability and productive capacity. Development is self competence, self-confidence and self-reliance, to stand on one's own legs and live with a sense of values of human dignity and, to become an asset and not a liability to the society. Self-reliance is the core of development and development is dependent on education. Self-reliance and gainful employment give a person dignity, increased incomes, reduce imbalances and increase the purchasing power of people.

The aim of all development is the improvement of quality of life. Quality of life should include a satisfactory personal life, job satisfaction, a sense of community, a sense of social justice, a sense of belonging﻿ to one world with individual identity, equality and freedom.

Life is worth living: Worth depends on values and values decide quality of life. We are what we value. That which we value moves us into action. Values are basically attitudes and a manifestation of behaviour. Values determine our choices and choices face us to examine our values.

The focal value--that what society values most of the world today appears to be materialistic gain and conspicuous consumption, where 10% of the world consume 90% of the world's resources, resulting in depletion of resources, degradation of environment, domination and disparity, increasing inequity and inbuilt violence. indiscipline, indecision, inaction, corruption, craze for power and money have become a way of life. This value system must change and self-reliance should become the focal social value.

Development should be with a social purpose, that requires transformation of social values and attitudes. What we need is a fresh thinking of life and living and the basic contours of a new life style for the mass of people. Development is a transdisciplinary process requiring a transdisciplinary approach. Leaders in philosophy, politics, sciences, économics, social﻿ sciences and others must join hands to outline alternative futuristics, formulate new patterns of thought and conduct and inspire new endeavours. It is not enough to merely direct the people towards good; they have to be provided with necessary motives for realising it. Otherwise, it would be like lighting an oil lamp without putting oil into it (Simone Weil). Free thinking men can be pioneers of progress. They should think out new ideals and fit them into realities of life in such a way that they influence most effectively the circumstances of the time (Schweitzer).

As early as 1945, Gandhi wrote to Nehru " The real question according to you is how to bring about man's highest intellectual, economic, political and moral development. I agree. In this there should be an equal right and opportunity for all."

Education is a vital input for the conception of values; inculcating right rational scientific attitudes; imparting knowledge, skills and awareness, leading to self competence, confidence and self reliance and gainful employment. This then is the link between education, employment and development.

Education: Employment :

Educational facilities in the country have expanded considerably in the past three﻿ decades. The number of educated persons entering labour market is on the increase but the employment opportunities have been limited. Thus by the beginning of 1980 there is a backlog of 3.7 million unemployed and to it another 8.1 mn is likely to be added during 1980-85. Of the total 12 mn unemployed, 2/3 are metriculates and the other 1/3(i.e.) 4 mn are graduates and post-graduates.

This position is untenable. Special efforts are needed to correct this position. There are two obvious ways: (1) by reorientation of education and training, linking education with employment and (2) finding newer avenues for employment generation.

Linkages :

The Sixth Plan framework has called for concerted efforts to forge beneficial linkages between education, employment and development. This makes it necessary that the educational programs be related to emerging occupational patterns and also offer preemployment training as also continuing education for the already employed for their further improvement.

Such a program includes restructuring of under-graduate course to make them purposeful and also terminal for those who seek employment, (2) provision for vocational courses and (3) making research relevant to national needs. This requires sensitization of the academic community, to the problems of poverty, unemployment, environmental pollution ; accepting public service as a primary function ; Extension Service as the third dimension in addition to training and research; transdisciplinary task forces approach to tackle a task; and legitimizing the involvement of academicians in development problems such as Minimum Needs program and the Health for All schemes. Experience with integrated Child Development Service has shown the beneficial impact of associating medical colleges with field program.

At present most colleges have stereotyped, rigid curricula. They should be encouraged to have flexible curricula and also subject combinations which would improve employment opportunities and technical competence. eg. physics. mathematics and electronics or instrumentation or computer service : chemistry, biology and pharmacology or medical technology, etc. courses can be organised for careers in government services or in public enterprises, cooperative and small scale industry and in tertiary service sector like tourism and transport management. Such courses should simultaneously meet the employment needs of the educated and development needs of the country.﻿

Employment Generation :

The other avenues is greater employment generation. The Government has resorted to special employment programs from time. to time both at the state and national levels. *Some of these are programs for Half-aMillion jobs; Special Employment, for Educated unemployed; Self employment; Training of Engineers, Entrepreneural Development; Rural artisans/craftsmen, etc. The latest in the year 1979-80 are the National Scheme of Training of Rural Youth for self-employment for 0.2 mn youth every year; Honorarium or stipends to educated unemployed as done in Maharashtra, Karnataka, etc. Over Rs. 1,750 mn are spent on these various special programs. These programs aim at extension and improvement in the quality of education, experience, financial assistance, training in employment intensive and productive areas such as rural engineering services, door to door services like radio repairs ; agro service centres, extension of consumer co-operative stores ; design units for rural water supply, irrigation, floods and drought control, road and house building projects, district industries centres, etc.
