Most of the employment programs have training component either to orient the already trained people towards self-emplorment or to provide training in skills, manage﻿ment etc. required for self-employment. This only goes to prove probably the existing education does not prepare the student for 'any specific occupation or even group of occupations.

Strategy:

Reliefs, doles and stipends do not answer the unemployment problem. It would only aggrevate the tendency of dependence. The goal is self-reliance to make every person an asset and not a liability to the society. The answer is to mobilise, generate and utilise natural and human resources. To do this a resource inventory needs to be built indicating the country's strengths and making best use of them. Our strengths, to mention if only a few are-large trained and skilled manpower available at low cost; tropical climate a large country with a long coast line and rich traditional skills and experience. This gives us a clue. Greater employment may be generated in areas such as resource survey, generation and mobilisation, and setting up science, skill and resource based industries.

Proper planning can be done only with a proper natural and human resource inventory. After a remote sensing survey, an army of educated unemployed could be gainfully processed into service for an inch﻿ to inch ground survey including botanists, zoologists, geologists, geographers, social scientists, statisticians, economists etc. Based on such a survey, land use maps, water-soilcrop management maps could be prepared and utilised with benefit.

Taking advantage of tropical climate, resources may be generated in highly profitable areas like aromatic and medicinal plants ornamental plants like orchids, sericulture, mushrooms, economic and fast growing plants, biomass and algae for food or fuel; improved acquaculture for fish, prawns, muscles, setting up of model farms for breeding crocodiles, exotic and fur bearing animals etc. This would mean greater returns and additional employment.

Resource mobilisation includes better. care and collection of oil seeds, gums, résins, tannins and other forest produce generating empolyment specially in tribal and hilly areas. Similarly manpower may be utilised with proper refresher or reorientation courses of the educated unemployed to meet industry's needs. The paradox is on one side a large number is waiting for a job and the industry is short of suitable people in several fields like marine geology, ocean engineering, polymer technology.

Additional employment could be generated utilising the increased resources genera﻿ted and mobilized starting agro-forest, and animal based industries. For example, a phyto-chemical complex could be set up to extract perfumary components from lemon grass, citronella grass or jasmine and other flowers, oleoresins from ginger, turmeric cloves, chillies etc. bio-pesticides from pyrethrum flowers etc. fetching high returns and additional employment.

Agro-industries may be established with the concept of utilising every part of the plant from leaf to the root. Take for example cotton plant, cotton leaves yield vitamin C., Cotton stalk for particle board, lintels for nitrocellulose, cotton for textiles, cotton seeds for edible oil, fatty acids, resins and for edible protein and finally cotton seed cake for fodder or fertilizer. Similarly several industries could be started around paddy plant. Paddy straw can be used for growing mushrooms; for fodder, thatched roof and for making straw board ; paddy husk for particle board, activated carbon, silicon and for ash to be made into cement; rice bran for edible oil, fatty acids and the residue as animal fodder; and rice for food, starcheş, chemicals and wine. At least 5-6 industries may be set up centred around each plant. This would mean bringing industries to rural areas where the bulk raw material is; fetching better returns to﻿ farmers; more gainful employment and bringing city comforts to the village, instead of bringing the villager to the City slums. Similarly, the vast resources of the ocean are yet to be fully tapped.

One could also consider several science and skill based industries like solar and wind/ energy, electronics, chemicals; converting waste into wealth etc. We should be highly competitive as we have scientists in large numbers and they are paid much less as compared to advanced countries.

Modern methods of management and technology could be woven into traditional tapestry to improve quality and productivity. Centralised management and decentralised production of consumer goods based on wood, leather, paper, food etc. would mean greater employment, traditional experience, skills, patience and precision as shown in gem cutting could be well utilised in making modern electronic and other precision components. I would like to think that such a strategy outlined above is likely to succeed in employment generation.

Organisation :

To implement such ideas, suitable organisation and methodology have to be evolved. Planning at Block and District level with a natural and human resources survey may﻿ be the first step. In the Sixth Plan, there is a proposal to set up a District Development Centre and District Employment Generation Council. There is already a. District Industries Centre. The development Centre should link education, employment and development and co-ordinate the activities of various state agencies like, Small Industries Corporation, Agro-industries Corporation etc. at the district level. The district plans should include, employment impact statements and employment audit. In providing financial credits and examining the feasibility reports, employment impact should be a criteria. Credit may be made available through the proposed National Agricultural Bank for Rural Development Bank (NABRD) and other development banks to meet the needs of the educated unemployed. In preparing plans and programmes, local development banks, industrialists, administrators, people's representatives, students and teachers may be involved. Involvement, consensus, harmony working together should be the pattern of our planning to ensure better implementation. Colleges may play their role in promoting self-employment ventures by educated persons and build linkage with the development departments and industry.

Voluntary agencies such as Rotary﻿ Clubs may be involved in promoting such ventures.

Development banks should encourage setting up and engage industrial consultancy firms to prepare a portfolio of projects to be offered to the entrepreneurs at the block and district levels.

A well considered national policy may also be evolved for the export and import of talents getting Indian the right type of jobs abroad and making use of Indians abroad for starting trade and industries in India.

On the lines of Peace Corps, a National Resources Corps may be set up to undertake various national tasks like resources survey. generation, mobilisation and utilisation ; preparation and implementation of plans, programmes and projects, technology transfer, consultancy and extension services; popularisation of science and scientific attitudes; and for making self-reliance as a mass movement stressing competence, character integrity, quality and excellence. National Resources Corps would then bring about a quiet revolution and become an instrument of social change.

To-day, the nation faces a crisis of character, of courage, confidence and of purpose. Every crisis poses a challenge and every challenge an opportunity. Here is the opportunity for the educated youth to take﻿ up this challenge and change the course. I am sure you can do it. Only you can do it.

My faith in the youth is more than confirmed by the letter I received from an young lady as I write this Lecture and I quote. " Youth is not a time of life it is a state of mind—a temper of the will, a quality of imagination and a vigor of the emotions, a freshness of the deep spring of life. Youth means a temperamental predominance of courage over timidity; of the appetite for adventure over a life of ease. Nobody grows old by merely living a number of years. People grow old by deserting their ideals. Years may wrinkle the skin but to give up enthusiasm wrinkles the soul. Worry, doubt, self-distrust, fear and despair those are the long long years that bow the head and turns the growing spirit back to dust whether sixty or sixteen. There should be in every educated person-a love of wonder, the sweet amazement of stars and star. like things and thoughts; the undaunted challenge of events, the unfailing child like appetite for what comes next and the joy in the game of life.

"You are as young as your faith and as old as your doubt; as young as your selfconfidence and as old as your fears; as young as your hope and as old as your despair.﻿

"In the central place of your heart, there is a wireless station. So long as it receives messages of beauty, of hope, cheer, grandeur and courage and power from the earth, from people and from the infinite-so long you are young. When the wires are all down and the central places of your heart are covered with pessimism and ice of cynicism, then you have grown old indeed!”

Such is the connection between youth and growth. May you all grow self-reliant with hope, courage, competence, confidence and character !﻿

ADDRESS BY General K.V.K. RAO on Monday, 7th Dec. 1981
Mr Chancellor, Mr Vice Chancellor, Members
of the Senate, Ladies and Gentlemen,

1. I feel deeply honoured to have been. invited to deliver the Convocation Address to you, this year. I consider that this is something unique, as perhaps this is the first time that a soldier has been asked to do so. By this, I felt, that you have done the Armed Forces a great honour. My pleasure is all the greater, as an old and famous University such as yours, has asked me to undertake this task.

2. Having been an Instructor at the National Defence Academy, indeed a founding member of the Institution, and having been an Instructor at the Defence Services Staff College ; as also having received a large number of young officers and men every year in the various Formations that I commanded, I have all along been deeply interested in the development of youth, whom I consider to be the future hope of this country. I have always been convinced that this great potential of the country should be properly nurtured and exploited for the good of the country.

3. At the outset, I would like to congratulate all the young men and women who have received Degrees this evening and I wish them a very happy and prosperous future. I would also like to congratulate the members of the Faculty, who have made it possible for﻿ these young people to obtain their degrees. The knowledge that you have imbibed at the University is only the beginning and the foundation for your future career. On this, you will have to build up the expertise required for the career that you choose for yourself. Remember, the process of learning in life never stops.

4. I realise that I have been invited here, not to put forth any views or give any advice in the academic field. You have enough experts for the purpose in the University and outside. I felt that my address should be more defence oriented. I am certain that nobody will deny that the subject of Defence is of vital importance to any country. Therefore, the bias of my address will be towards Defence; and I am sure that this is what you would want me to do.

5. As you are no doubt aware, our country has been invaded several times, subjugated and ruled by alien conquerors. The main reasons for this were lack of unity, character, weakness in military capabilities, particularly, not keeping abreast with latest developments and technology and weak leadership. We had secured our freedom, not by a violent revolution, but by nonviolence and a civilised approach. It entailed à great deal of sacrifice, in particular by some of our great leaders like Mahatma﻿ Gandhi and Jawaharlal Nehru. It is for us and the future generations to ensure that the independence and security of this great country are never again endangered. I am sure that you are also aware that after attaining Independence, we have had to fight four major wars that were thrust upon us. In these, it has been our proud privilege, that is, that of the Armed Forces, to make every sacrifice necessary for the successful defence of the country. We are a Nation wedded to the concept of Panchsheel', the five principles of peaceful co-existence; and would like to resolve any problems that we have with any country by peaceful methods and avoid resort to force. However, the international situation in general and the situation on our borders. in particular, is such that the threat to the Nation appears to be on the increase. Internally also, we are faced with several problems-economic, sociological and maintenance of law and order. The roles of the Armed Forces are to defend the country against external aggression and to provide aid to the civil authorities when called upon to do so. I know that the people place great reliance on the Armed Forces to do their duty towards the country. I wish to assure everybody that we shall live upto the confidence reposed in us by the Nation. We are ensuring that a high degree of combat effectiveness and﻿ operational preparedness are maintained at all times. We realise only too well that there is no 'Runners Up'in a war and that when it comes, we have got to win it. I wish to reiterate that we shall consider no sacrifice too great for upholding the honour and integrity of our Motherland.

6. Clausewitz, a great military thinker and writer, said "War is a continuation of policy by other means." When nations fail to solve international disputes by diplomatic means, recourse is taken to the use of Armed Forces to obtain the solution. Modern war is complex and total, involving every branch of national life. All the resources of a Nation have to be geared up and all walks of life are involved, in the preparation for and the prosecution of war. A Nation at war is a team composed of the Government, the Army, the Navy, the Air Force, the Para Military Forces, the Civil Services, the farmer, the industrial worker and the numerous others who play their seemingly smallest part in the life of the country. Experience of the past wars in the world has shown that the strength of a Nation is based on certain important factors,

(a) The strength of the Armed Forces,not only in terms of numbers but also in terms of equipment, training, motivation and above all, leadership.

(b) National will and determination to﻿ see the war through to a successful conclusion, in other words, national morale.

(c) Political stability, unity, character and discipline.

(d) Economic stability and maximum possible self-sufficiency.

(e) A high standard of science and technology.

7. I would like to say a few words on each of these factors.

(a) Strength of the Armed Forces. The strength of the Armed Forces is determined by the commitments of the forces, by what is intended to be achieved, that is, war aims and objectives, and the strength of the adversaries. In our case, this is a matter that is constantly receiving the attention of the Chiefs of Staff and the Government. The importance of the man behind the gun cannot be over-stressed. Training of the Armed Forces to a high standard and providing them with effective leadership is very important.

(b) National Morale. National morale cannot be built up over night. A war involves several sacrifices, not only during the war itself but during peace time as well. People must be prepared to lose their near and dear﻿ ones, property, put up with all types of discomforts and dangers, and yet, sustain the war effort. A belief in the basic principles and fundamental objectives of the Nation, righteousness of the cause and determination never to be subjugated, helps. People must be prepared to completely subordinate their interests to those of the Nation. In peace time, the Armed Forces have to be maintained at the requisite level to ensure that war is deterred if possible ; and that

if deterrence fails, we win it.

(c) Political Stability. I mentioned lack of unity as one of the main reasons for the several successful invasions of our country in the past. I hardly need emphasise that "Unity is Strength”. Political stability ensures the effective development and progress of the Nation. The need for character and discipline hardly require any elucidation, if a Nation is to move forward and be strong.

(d) Economic Stability. Economic stability and political stability are interdependent. Self sufficiency in food and other essential requirements of the people, must be achieved. Judicious allocation of national resources to developmental programmes is﻿ essential. Production must be such that imports are restricted to the minimum essential. Exports should reach such a level that the foreign exchange position is sound.

(e) Science and Technology. Science andTechnology play a very significant part in the development and defence effort of a Nation. In this connection, the need for original thinking and research, and indigenous production of our numerous requirements, hardly needs any stress. Obviously, we cannot always be assured of continued supplies of our requirements from abroad, as it became evident several times. New weapons and new equipment, which may turn the tide of the war, will have to be thought of and produced, sometimes during the war itself. All these require a high level of Science and Technology in the country.

8. You would have noticed by now how every citizen is affected, whether it is a question of preventing war in peace time by developing effective deterrence capability, or successfully waging a war, as and when it breaks out. In many countries, national service, whereby every able bodied citizen within the specified age group is required to serve in the Armed Forces, facilitates awareness of the defence requirements of the Nation. In our country, our Armed Forces are completely voluntary in nature. Perhaps national service in a modified manner could be introduced to a limited extent. Irrespective of this, the need for people taking interest in the defence of the country and contributing their mite, cannot be overemphasised. In this connection, I may mention that unfortunately, people see the Armed Forces mainly on ceremonials, during sports or at the most while in aid of civil power. Due to various reasons such as security, they do not get an opportunity to see the Armed Forces during war or even during training for war. Management of defence at various levels is not an easy affair; but requires considerable intellect, organisational ability, knowledge of contemporary warfare and leadership qualities of a high order. If any of you are joining the Armed Forces, I have no doubt that you will realise this very soon.

9. Even if you do not join the Armed Forces, and irrespective of the walk of life that you choose for yourselves, as I said, many of you will be having something or the other to do with the defence effort of the Nation. Whether you are a civil servant, a manager of an industry, an engineer, a doctor, a farmer or whatever you may be, you may well be involved with defence. You add to﻿ the strength of the Nation by just doing your job well, no matter what it is.

10. Many of you would have learnt the famous prayer from our scriptures

" From untruth O Lord lead me to truth.
From darkness lead me to light.
From death lead me to immortality".

The real aim of education is enlightenment. It may also bring immortality, if the enlightenment is geared towards the general good of the society. Education is not merely study of particular subjects, such as, literature or mathematics or sciences; but there is much more to it.' I feel that you would have fully benefitted by your education, if you have imbibed certain essential qualities that go to make you a good citizen, which in my opinion, are-

(a) Patriotic spirit, which means, that you will be prepared to make any sacrifice for the honour and freedom of the Nation.

(b) The belief that, irrespective of the State, religion, class or community that you belong to, you always consider yourself to be an Indian.

(c) Service before self; in other words,you are prepared to subordinate your interests to those of the community or the organisation.

(d) Pursuit of excellence, that is, never to be satisfied with sub-standard﻿ effort, either on your part or on the part of those who are under you. Nothing is impossible, provided you pursue your aims with determination and tenacity. Give off your best and then leave the rest to God, as enjoined in our scriptures. Whatever you want to achieve, do so in a correct and disciplined manner, in other words, do not forget constitutional methods and gentlemanly qualities.

11. I trust that my friends in the Faculty, would agree that education in the Country which does not include the objectives that I have mentioned, cannot be considered to be real and complete education. I may mention, with all the humility at my command, that in the Army, we are constantly striving to foster these qualities; and I consider, that whatever success we achieve, is largely due to these.

12. We Indians, are generally a very critical lot of people. Perhaps this is a good thing, to keep everyone on his toes. However, I would like to say that before you criticize others, ask yourself whether you have given off your best to the Country. Have you done anything that has an adverse impact on the Nation ? Here, I would like to quote a famous US President--"Ask not﻿ what your country can do for you; ask what you can do for your country."

13. Finally, I thank you once again for inviting me over to this important function. I wish you all the very best and may God be with you.

JAI HIND﻿

ADDRESS BY Dr. BALRAM JAKHAR
on Saturday, 22nd Jan. 1983
Mr. Chancellor, Mr. Vice-Chancellor, Members of the Senate, Ladies and Gentlemen

I feel honoured to be here to deliver the Convocation address and to share my thoughts with you. This University has had the distinction of giving eminent scholars and educationists who have brought name and fame to the country. The glorious record and healthy traditions of dedicated service established by this great seat of learning, during nearly six and a half decades of its existence, makes the honour of participating in its Convocation, all the more greater.

Let me, at the outset, offer my warm felicitations to all the young scholars who have been awarded the various degrees today. It is my earnest hope that in keeping with the fine traditions of this University, the young men and women who are leaving its portals' today, will always use their knowledge for the betterment of the poor and weaker sections of the society and humanity as a whole.

My young friends, you are now stepping out into a wider field. While some of you may decide to continue with your higher academic pursuits, others may look for means of livelihood to settle down in life. In the prevailing milieu and the general socioeconomic conditions you have to develop a﻿ sense of adjustment in life because hope and despair are inseparable and unless we learn to live with the 'circumstances, our lives become miserable. Therefore, I would like you to face the complexities of life with supreme confidence and fortitude. When you tackle your problems with sincerity of purpose and perseverence, anything that you desire in life will not be unattainable. Every success should spur you on to attain greater heights and every failure should, likewise, fill you with renewed zeal and vigour to eventually reach your goal.

I have no intention on this occasion to burden you with any sermons. I would only like to share with you my thinking on some of the problems which are exercising the minds of the people today.

All of us are privileged to belong to a land with a rich and glorious past Our country is renowned for its inimitable feature of unity in diversity. We have here an infinite variety of religious faiths, cultural practices and social customs, of languages, food, dress and behaviour. As one travels from one end of the country to another and sees India in its manifold manifestations, all these differences fall into their proper place, revealing their essentially trivial nature and the country's inherent integrated pattern. Many are the common ideal and objectives which we share and amidst an apparent sea﻿ of diversity, there is a common bond which unifies us and that is, our heritage of being Indian.

After a long and consistent struggle under the leadership of our great leaders like Lokmanya Tilak, Shri Gopal Krishan Gokhale, Mahatama Gandhi and Pandit Jawahar Lal Nehru we achieved our independence from foreign rule nearly threeand-a-half decades ago. These great souls assiduously worked for the unity of our nation and infused in us a sense of brotherhood, fellowship and patriotism. It was only through a rare sense of unity shown by our people during these long years of struggle that we achieved independence.

Young friends, you are fortunate enough to have been born in an independent country. Could you imagine the plight of those who suffered the pangs of slavery? Just think of the great heroes like Shaheed-e-Azam, Bhagat Singh, Shri Madan Lal Dhingra, Shri Ashfaq Uļla Khan, Shri Udham Singh and Shri Chander Shekhar Azad who sacrificed their lives for the motherland. What was the spirit behind all this? Selfiess dedication to a national cause. That missing link has to be revived to make the nation stronger and stronger.

During our existence as a free nation, we have had to pass through times of trials, tribulations and turmoil and face difficulties﻿ of one kind or the other. We have had to cope with challenging situations such as those resulting from external aggression, natural calamities, domestic social and economic changes and enormous developmental tasks. If we have successfully met these challenges and surmounted our difficulties, it is only because of the unity and steadfastness displayed by our people, in moments of difficulty and grave crisis. These challenges and difficulties notwithstanding, India has made phenomenal progress in many directions, but the problems of growing popula-. tion, resultant unemployment, consequent poverty, malnutrition and hunger still defy solution and greatly hamper our progress and prosperity. When the population grows faster than the development of resources, it, is obvious that the minimum needs of the vast majority remain unfulfilled. The provisional results of the latest census operations have placed India's population at a staggering figure of 683 million which shows that during the last three decades about 322 million people have been added to our population. This has naturally affected every sector of our economy, more so the rural sector, where more than 75 per cent of our people live. Viewed in the eontext of the large additional requirements of food, clothing, housing and educational facilities, employment, etc., which the grow﻿ing numbers require, the effects of the significant economic development registered as a result of the implementation of the successive five year plans gets vastly neutralised and eventually have very little impact on the economy of the country. In the overall context of the country's development efforts, the highest priority is, therefore, to be accorded to the creation of an awareness among the people and securing their cooperation in making the population control programme a success. We cannot afford to be slow and sluggish in this matter of great concern. The voluntary organisations and the student community can play a very effective role in this direction and I expect my young friends to address themselves to this vital task by educating the people about the enormity of harm we are doing for posterity.

Although I cannot claim to be an expert, yet I feel that education system needs to be overhauled. Greater importance and emphasis need to be given to the quality of education that is imparted by our educational institutions and the extent to which it helps in turning out young men and women with a greater sense of self fulfilment and dedication to national goals. There has been a phenomenal growth in the number of educational institutions and the rate of literacy has also recorded an upward trend but this﻿ is not enough to meet our requirements. Our educational system has to be clearly and consciously oriented to the national ethos and to the needs of our country's growth process. Without attempting to imitate blindly the experiments of the Western countries, our educational planners and administrators would do well to ensure that our educational institutions produce scholars and integrated personalities who are fairly well-rooted in India's composite culture and at the same time keep their windows open to allow fresh breeze to flow in freely from all directions. The whole philosophy of education should emphasize the training of independent and self-contained individuals capable of facing the problems and realities of life. This alone will fulfil the professed aims of education viz., producing good citizens with high character, scholarship, dedication and selfless service to the community, men imbued with wisdom, patriotism, self-confidence, high ideals and discipline,

Education, as you know, is the foundation of developing society but there appears to be total chaos. The sanctity of examinations seems to be over due to mass copying and leakage of question papers with impurity. Established values are fast eroding. The educationists must give a serious thought to this aspect. Further, I feel that instead of creating a classless society, the present day﻿ education is creating different sets of people. The students who get education in public and convent schools--the privilege of the rich-- and those who get education in the Municipal and village schools, stand on different footing. The common student, thus, cannot catch up with the standards of public and convent schools. How can it be? The children who are getting sub-standard education in ordinary schools, when required to compete with their counterparts coming out from public and convent schools stand nowhere. Therefore, it is the duty of every good Government either to (a) provide facilities available in convent and public schools in ordinary schools or (b) take over all the convent and public schools for giving equal opportunities to the students to receive education there. But, for obvious reasons, these alternatives do not appear to be practicable. Therefore, the only reasonable solution can be that job availability in the administrative services and other spheres should be made proportionate according to the number of students coming out from convent/public schools and Government schools. A percentage could be fixed for each category and their merit and selection should be independent of each other. The students qualifying from convent/public schools could be absorbed in the number of vacancies set apart for them and the remaining vacancies﻿ could straight away go to the students coming from ordinary schools.

In short, all available resources would have to be mobilized to rejuvenate our educational system for the benefit of the masses rather than for the elite sections of our society.

In order to bring about a real socioeconomic transformation, I for one would like to advise our student community to strive to change the old order with its array of social and economic injustices, with its meaningless prejudices and superstitions, with its social stratification that hurts and obstructs development of our vast majority.

The vital question before all of us today is what kind of India are we to bequeath to posterity-a strong, harmonious, self-confident or a faltering and weak India ? The answer is obvious but the task is onerous. The future of the nation is in the hands of our educated youth. You are our torchbearers and masters of tomorrow. It is for you to give serious thought as to how best you can contribute to serve the people and promote national outlook. It is my fervent prayer and hope that whatever your calling or station in life, you will always keep in mind your responsibilities as the citizens of this great country and with patriotic effort, fulfil your obligations for building a selfreliant, modern and progressive India.

Thank you.﻿

ADDRESS BY R. VENKATARAMAN
on Thursday, 16th Feb. 1984
Mr. Chancellor, Mr. Vice-Chancellor, Ladies and
Gentlemen and Graduates of the year

I feel privileged at your invitation to deliver the. Convocation Address at this University which has a glorious record of service extending over six decades and which has won renown as a great seat of learning. Mysore is a "city beautiful” and it symbolises the emerging India. As a princely State, it was a pioneer in irrigation, industrial development and power generation and after independence, Karnataka has made rapid progress in agriculture, defence and sophisticated industries and scientific and technological research. Farsighted statesmen like Visvesvarayya and Mirza Ismail had laid solid foundations for growth and their endeavours are in full blossom today.

At the outset, I would like to congratulate all the graduates who have received their degrees and wish them a happy and prosperous future. It is my earnest hope that in keeping with the fine traditions of this University, the youngmen and women who are leaving its portals today, will strive to serve the Nation to the best of their ability informed by a spirit of dedication. The aim of University education is to make better men out of men and better citizens out of﻿ the common people. It behoves you, therefore, to think and act with responsibility, diligence and dignity. Many of you will seek employment in industries or Government. Many more will be self-employed in productive sectors of our economy. In whatever walk of life you may be engaged in, I trust you will not lose sight of the perspective, the pursuit of excellence. By conscious application of skill and disciplined pursuit of goals, you will not only be serving your personal interest but also the national cause of productivity and prosperity.

Scientific inventions followed by Industrial Revolution had transformed medieval societies into prosperous nations. Unfortunately, Industrial Revolution bypassed the countries of Asia and Africa which were under colonial domination during those critical days and practically left them in a medieval state. It is only after the transfer of power that the newly emerging nations took to the path of scientific, technological and industrial development starting with a handicap of over two centuries. This, however, need not deter faster growth of developing countries. Fortunately, Science is impersonal. It is not moved by heed or appeal. It does not treat laboratories of developing countries any better or worse than a rich laboratory. If developing countries acquire capability to﻿ absorb current technology and embark on innovation and improvement on the technology acquired, they can even march ahead of developed countries. It is indeed a waste of time, effort and money to attempt to rediscover scientific and technological developments known to the world. It is far wiser to acquire current technology and concentrate effort on innovative work on it, so that a •steady stream of self-reliance is built up. Mere acquisition of every improvement in technology, without indigenous effort at upgrading it, will only result in abject dependence on import which will bleed the country white. The Technology Policy Statement of the Government of India clearly declares that science and technology is the basis of economic progress; it recognises that we have a strong agricultural and industrial base and a scientific man-power 'impressive in quality, numbers and range of skills. Given clearcut objectives and necessary support, our science also has shown its capacity to solve problems. The Technology Policy Statement categorically asserts that "Our future depends on our ability to resist the imposition of technology which is obsolete or unrelated to our specific requirements and policies which tie us to systems which serve the purposes of others rather than our own."

It is the habit of nature to conceal its riches and yield its graces only to those﻿ who arduously labour for its denouement. It is impossible to predict with any amount of certainty what discoveries or inventions in Science are going to be in the current decade. Nobody predicted the invention of the transister or laser or xerox process a few decades back. Until Science discovered the minerals, ores were no more than filthy clay or rubble. Man has turned many a waste into wealth by sheer intelligence and endeavour. It is said that not a grain of sand lies in the beach but infinite knowledge knows how to utilise it. Humanity is marching towards attainment of that. infinite knowledge and India cannot retreat from the march, if she wishes to increase the national wealth and improve the standard of life of the people. The Kothari Commission on Education pointed out that Universities have to provide the right kind of leadership in all walks of life, to identify gifted youth and help them develop that potential fully. It is the duty of our Universities to produce among the thousands of graduates a handful of gifted youth as envisaged by the Commission on Education. While our Universities and colleges mass produce average quality graduates, they do not go all out to seek talent and develop it. In fact, a genius with talent in one specialisation may not even qualify for a degree in our Universities because he does not make the grade in the other compulsory subjects. There is too much rigidity in the curricula that one is denied opportunity to study a combination of subjects of one's choice. There is no reason why a student should not be allowed to study a combination of subjects, such as, literature, psychology, electronics and computer technology. Such options are available in many western Universities and I do not think that any of those graduates are worse off for it. I understand that a few institutions in India have introduced this concept and I hope it will become more and more widespread.

Indeed we are living through historic times. We have transformed a backward benighted agricultural India that it was prior to independence, into a modern tenth industrialised nation in the world. Thanks to the vision and foresight of Shri Jawaharlal Nehru, heavy industries like steel, coal, aluminium and copper were started on a massive scale through the successive Five Year Plans. Crude oil production will touch 26 million tons in 1983-84 while installed capacity for power generation will reach 42,000 MW at the end of this Plan. The manufacture of engineering goods, fertilisers, chemicals and pharmaceuticals and consumer durables followed as a corollary to the establishment of basic industries and the development of infrastructure. Thus, industrial economy has strikingly diversified ; manufacturing﻿ capabilities extend over a wide range of products and have acquired adaptability for designs, structurals and machine tools. I can state with confidence that the industrial economy has reached the take off stage.

I have somewhat laboured this point to impress on you that we have every reason to congratulate ourselves on our growth and development. It has become the fashion among seeming intellectuals to denigrate ourselves and destroy the self confidence so necessary for adventure. While I will not be euphoric on our progress, I cannot accept the ill-informed criticism that detracts the past achievements and undermines future national effort. Viewed in the proper perspective, our achievements should spur us towards higher goals and not lull us into complacency. I should like to recall the famous lines of Robert Browning.

"That a man's reach should exceed his grasp or else what is a Heaven for."

National progress will be meaningful only to the extent that it improves the standard of living of the weaker sections of the society. If scientific and technological developments are not translated into schemes for the relief of the vulnerable sections of society, these very developments will soon get discredited. A deprived people will turn into a desperate people and the peaceful﻿ evolution of society will then become a casualty. Thus, confining the fruits of development to certain regions or certain classes constitutes a threat to society. We have. managed to inject scientific agricultural methods in a rigidly traditional area and to introduce mechanised small scale units in the place of traditional cottage industries. We have made massive investments through successive Five Year Plans but all these have not mitigated the gigantic problem of unemployment and under-employment. Nor have they made noticeable impact on the volume of persons below the poverty line. One of the reasons, for this sorry state of affairs is the unbridled growth of population. From about 320 million people three decades ago, the population of India has increased to around 700 million today. Besides, the rate of growth of population among the vulnerable sections of society is disproportionately larger than in the middle and affluent classes, thereby accentuating the increase of people below the poverty line. There is an urgent. need, therefore, among the educated people not only to practice population control but create a climate for its acceptance among those amidst whom they live.

I had stated earlier that one of the aims of a University is to make better citizens out of the common people. Virtues like tolerance, discipline, punctuality and law abidance﻿ cannot be developed overnight but must be cultivated from a very early age in the schools and colleges. True democracy rests on voluntary observance of the laws of the land and not on enforcement thereof by force. Indeed the history of civilisation is nothing more than the history of human endeavour to tame the primeval instincts of man and make him live in peace and harmony with his fellow men. If University education teaches one patriotism to sacrifice everything for the freedom and honour of the motherland, humanism to regard every person, irrespective of religion, caste or creed as a brother, discipline to perform one's duty to one's own satisfaction, it would have rendered service to its alumni.

What distinguishes the youth from the old is the outlook on life. It is the habit of the old to look at the setting Sun and bemoan the day that had passed while the youth looks at the rising Sun, ever hoping, ever believing that the brighter day is before it. It is with this confidence I want you all graduates to start on your career with my best wishes for your success.﻿

ADPRESS BY B. SHANKARANANDA
on Friday, 21st Mar. 1986
ಕುಲಾಧಿಪತಿಗಳೆ, ಕುಲಪತಿಗಳೆ, ಈ ವಿಶ್ವವಿದ್ಯಾನಿಲಯದ ಪ್ರಾಧ್ಯಾಪಕ ವರ್ಗದವರೆ, ನವಪದವೀಧರರೆ, ವಿದ್ಯಾರ್ಥಿಗಳೆ, ಬಂಧುಗಳೆ, ಭಗಿನಿಯರೆ,

ಈ ದಿನ ನಮ್ಮೆಲ್ಲರಿಗೂ ಹರ್ಷದ ದಿನ, ವಿಶ್ವವಿದ್ಯಾನಿಲಯಕ್ಕೆ ಒಂದು ಹಬ್ಬದ ದಿನ. ಪದವೀಧರರಿಗೆ, ಸಾಹಸದಿಂದ ಸಾಗರ ದಾಟಿ, ದಡ ಸೇರಿದ ಆತ್ಮ ಸಮಾಧಾನದ ದಿನ, ಇಂತಹ ಈ ಸಮಾರಂಭದಲ್ಲಿ ತಮ್ಮೆಲ್ಲರೊಡನೆ ಬೆರೆಯಲು ಅವಕಾಶ ಮಾಡಿಕೊಟ್ಟ ನಿಮ್ಮ ಕುಲಪತಿಗಳಿಗೆ ನಾನು ತುಂಬಾ ಆಭಾರಿ,

ಈ ವಿಶ್ವವಿದ್ಯಾನಿಲಯವನ್ನು ಬೆಳಸಿ, ಬೆಳಗಿಸಿದ, ಬೆಳಸುತ್ತಿರುವ ಹಿಂದಿನ ಹಾಗೂ ಈಗಿನ ಕುಲಪತಿಗಳಿಗೂ, ಪ್ರಾಧ್ಯಾಪಕ ವರ್ಗಕ್ಕೂ ಹಾಗೂ ಈ ಬೆಳವಣಿಗೆಗಳಿಗೆ ಕಾರಣವಾದ ಉಳಿದ ಎಲ್ಲರಿಗೂ ನಾನು ತುಂಬು ಹೃದಯ ದಿಂದ ಅಭಿನಂದಿಸುತ್ತೇನೆ. ಅದರಲ್ಲಿಯೂ ಈ ವರ್ಷ ಪದವಿಗಳನ್ನು ಪಡೆದು ಹರ್ಷದಿಂದ ಹೊರ ಬರುತ್ತಿರುವ ಎಲ್ಲ ಪದವೀಧರರಿಗೂ ನನ್ನ ಹಾರ್ದಿಕ ಶುಭಾಶಯಗಳು; ಹಾಗೂ ತಮ್ಮತಮ್ಮ ವಿಷಯಗಳಲ್ಲಿ ಪ್ರಶಸ್ತಿಗಳನ್ನು ಪಡೆದ ಎಲ್ಲರಿಗೂ ನನ್ನ ಅಭಿನಂದನೆಗಳು. ಅವರೆಲ್ಲರ ಭವಿಷ್ಯ ತುಂಬ ಉಜ್ವಲ ವಾಗಲೆಂದು ನಾನು ಹಾರೈಸುತ್ತೇನೆ.

ಮೈಸೂರು ಮಹಾ ನಗರ, ಕನ್ನಡ ನಾಡಿನ ಕಣ್ಮಣಿ, ಸಂಸ್ಕೃತಿಯ ಸಾಗರ. ಅದಕ್ಕಾಗಿ ನನಗೆ ಅತ್ಯಂತ ಆದರ, ಈ ಮಹಾನಗರ ಕನ್ನಡ ಸಂಸ್ಕೃತಿಯ ತವರು ಮನೆ. ಇದು ಒಂದು ಪರಿಶುದ್ಧ, ಪವಿತ್ರ ಸಂಸ್ಕೃತಿಯ ಕ್ಷೇತ್ರವಾಗಿಯೇ ಉಳಿಯಬೇಕೆಂಬುದು ನನ್ನ ಹಿರಿಯ ಆಸೆ,﻿ ಆಧುನಿಕ ಔದ್ಯೋಗೀಕರಣದ ಹೊಗೆ ತುಂಬಿಕೊಂಡು ಬೂದಿ ಹರಡಿಕೊಂಡು, ಇದರ ಪರಿಸರವನ್ನು ಹಾಳು ಮಾಡದಂತೆ ನೋಡಿಕೊಳ್ಳುವ ಎಚ್ಚರಿಕೆಯನ್ನು ನಾವೆಲ್ಲರೂ ವಹಿಸಬೇಕು. ಆರ್ಥಿಕ, ಶೈಕ್ಷಣಿಕ ಹಾಗೂ ಸಾಮಾಜಿಕ ಕ್ಷೇತ್ರದಲ್ಲಿ ಈ ನಗರದ ನೈರ್ಮಲ್ಯ ನಿರಂತರ ಉಳಿಯಲೆಂದು ಹಾರೈಸುತ್ತೇನೆ.

ದೇಶದಲ್ಲಿ ಈಗ ನೂರಕ್ಕೂ ಮೇಲ್ಪಟ್ಟು ವಿಶ್ವವಿದ್ಯಾನಿಲಯಗಳು, ಸುಮಾರು ಐದು ಸಾವಿರಕ್ಕೂ ಮೇಲ್ಪಟ್ಟು ಕಾಲೇಜುಗಳು ಇವೆ. ಇಂದು 'ನಮ್ಮಲ್ಲಿ ಅತಿ ಹೆಚ್ಚಿನ ಸಂಖ್ಯೆಯಲ್ಲಿ ವಿಜ್ಞಾನಿಗಳು ತಂತ್ರಜ್ಞರು ಇದ್ದಾರೆ. ಇದು ನಿಜವಾಗಿಯೂ ಹೆಮ್ಮೆಯ ವಿಷಯ. ಹೀಗಿದ್ದರೂ ನಮ್ಮಲ್ಲಿ ಮೂರು ದಶಲಕ್ಷ ಜನ ಇನ್ನೂವರೆಗೆ ನಿರಕ್ಷರಿಗಳಾಗಿರುವುದನ್ನು ನಾವು ಕಾಣುತ್ತಿದ್ದೇವೆ. ಅವರೆಲ್ಲರೂ ನಮ್ಮ ಜನತೆಯ ದುರ್ಬಲ ವರ್ಗಗಳಿಗೆ ಸೇರಿದವರು. ಸಾಮಾಜಿಕ ಹಾಗೂ ಆರ್ಥಿಕ ಅನಿವಾರಗಳಿಂದಾಗಿ ಶಿಕ್ಷಣಾವಾಕಾಶಗಳ ಲಾಭವನ್ನು ಪಡೆಯಲು ಅವರು ಅಸಮರ್ಥರಾಗಿದ್ದಾರೆ. ಮಕ್ಕಳೆಂಬುವರೆಲ್ಲರೂ ತಂದೆ ತಾಯಿಗಳೊಂದಿಗೆ ಹೊರಗಡೆ ದುಡಿದು ಕುಟುಂಬದ ಆದಾಯಕ್ಕೆ ಸಲ್ಲಿಸ ಬೇಕಾಗಿದೆ. ಸರ್ಕಾರವು, ಸಮಾಜವು, ಈ ಸಂಗತಿಯನ್ನು ಗಮನಿಸಿ, ಇಂತಹ ಸೌಲಭ್ಯವನ್ನು ನಿರ್ಗತಿಕ ವರ್ಗಗಳವರಿಗೂ, ಶಿಕ್ಷಣ ಪಡೆಯಬೇಕಾದ ಮೂಲ ಭೂತ ಅನುಭೋಗದಿಂದ ವಂಚಿತರಾಗಿರತಕ್ಕಂತಹವರಿಗೂ ಕಲ್ಪಿಸಿಕೊಡಬೇಕು.

ಯಾವಾಗಲೂ ಹೊಸಹೊಸ ಶಾಲೆಗಳನ್ನು ತೆರೆಯುವ ಬೇಡಿಕೆಗಳು ದಿನೇದಿನೇ ಬೆಳೆಯುತ್ತಿವೆ. ಆದರೆ, ನಮ್ಮ ಆರ್ಥಿಕ ಮೂಲಗಳು ಬಹಳಷ್ಟು ಷರಾಜಿತವಾಗಿರುವುದು ಅಷ್ಟೇ ನಿಜ. ಅಂತಹದರಲ್ಲಿಯೂ, ಸ್ಥಳೀಯ ಜನತೆಗೆ ಶಿಕ್ಷಣ ಸೌಲಭ್ಯ ಇಲ್ಲದೆಡೆಯಲ್ಲಿಯೇ ಇಂತಹ ಸಂಸ್ಥೆಗಳನ್ನು ಆರಂಭಿಸಲು ಎಡೆ ಮಾಡಿಕೊಡುವ ಕ್ರಮ ಪ್ರಾಪ್ತವಾಗಿದೆ. ದುರ್ಬಲ ವರ್ಗದ ಮಕ್ಕಳು ಇತ್ತೀಚೆಗೆತಾನೆ ಶಿಕ್ಷಣಕ್ಕೆ ಕರೆದುಕೊಂಡಿರುವುದರಿಂದ ಹಾಗೂ ಮೊದಲ ತಲೆಮಾರಿನ ಗಳಿಕೆಯವರಾಗಿರುವುದರಿಂದ, ಈ ವರ್ಗಗಳಲ್ಲಿ ಪ್ರಗತಿ ಅಷ್ಟೊಂದು ಕಂಡು ಬರದಿದ್ದರೂ ಶಿಕ್ಷಕರಾದವರು ಅವರಿಗೆ ವಿಶೇಷ ಲಕ್ಷ ಪೂರೈಸಿ ನೆರವು ನೀಡಬೇಕು. ಶಿಕ್ಷಕರ ಯೋಗ್ಯತೆಯನ್ನು ಅವರು ತಮ್ಮ ಅಧ್ಯಾಪನದ﻿ ಅವಧಿಯಲ್ಲಿ ಎಷ್ಟು ಜನ ಹಿಂದುಳಿದ ಮಕ್ಕಳನ್ನು ಮುನ್ನಡೆಸುವುದರಲ್ಲಿ ಯಶಸ್ವಿಯಾಗಿದ್ದಾರೆ ಎಂಬುದರ ಮೇಲೆಯೇ ನಿರ್ಧರಿಸಬೇಕು.

ಹೆಚ್ಚು ಹೆಚ್ಚು ಶಿಕ್ಷಣ ಸಂಸ್ಥೆಗಳ ನಿರ್ವಹಣೆಯನ್ನು ಸರ್ಕಾರ ಕೈ ಗೊಂಡಂತೆ, ಈ ದಿಶೆಯಲ್ಲಿ ನಮ್ಮ ಸಾಮಾಜಿಕ ಹೊಣೆಗಾರಿಕೆ ಹೆಚ್ಚ ಬೇಕಾದುದೂ ಅತ್ಯಗತ್ಯ. ವಿದ್ಯಾ ಸಂಸ್ಥೆಗಳನ್ನು ಸಮಾಜದ ಅವಿಭಾಜ್ಯ ಅಂಗವಾಗಿ ನೋಡಬೇಕೇ ವಿನಾ ಪ್ರತ್ಯೇಕತೆಯ ಭಾವದಿಂದಲ್ಲ. ಸಾಧ್ಯವಾದಷ್ಟೂ ಸಂಸ್ಕೃತಿಯ ದೃಷ್ಟಿಯನ್ನು ಬೆಳೆಸಿಕೊಂಡು ವಿದ್ಯಾಸಂಸ್ಥೆಗಳಲ್ಲಿ ಜನತೆಯ ಪಾಲುಗಾರಿಕೆಗೆ ಎಡೆ ಮಾಡಿ, ಶಿಕ್ಷಣವನ್ನು ಉದ್ದೇಶಪೂರ್ಣವಾಗಿಸಬಹುದು. ಹೊಣೆಯರಿತವರಾದ ಶಿಕ್ಷಕರು ಅಶಿಕ್ಷಿತರನ್ನು ಗೌರವಯೋಗ್ಯರಾಗುವಂತೆ ಮಾಡಬಹುದು. ಹಾಗೂ ಅನ್ನೋನ್ಯ, ಸೌಹಾರ್ದ ಸಾಧಿಸಬಹುದು. ಶಾಲೆ ಎಂಬುದು ಜನತೆಯ ಸಾಮಾಜಿಕ ಹಾಗೂ ಸಾಂಸ್ಕೃತಿಕ ಅಭಿವೃದ್ದಿಯ. ಚಟುವಟಿಕೆಯ ಕೇಂದ್ರವಾಗಬೇಕು, ಅಲ್ಲಿ ಊರಿನ ಜನ ತಮ್ಮ ಸಾಮಾಜಿಕ ಹಾಗೂ ಸಾಂಸ್ಕೃತಿಕ ಕಾರ್ಯಕ್ರಮಗಳಿಗೆ ಆಗಾಗ್ಗೆ ನೆರವಾಗಬೇಕು. ಶಾಲೆಗೆ ಅಗತ್ಯವಾದ ಸಾಮಗ್ರಿಗಳನ್ನು ಒದಗಿಸಲು ತಯಾರಿರಬೇಕು. ಹೀಗೆ ಹಲವು ಬಗೆಯಲ್ಲಿ ವಿದ್ಯಾಸಂಸ್ಥೆ ಹಾಗೂ ಜನತೆ ತತ್ಸಂಬಂಧಿಗಳಾಗಿ ಬೆಳೆಯಬೇಕು.

ಇಂದು ಈ ವಿಶ್ವವಿದ್ಯಾನಿಲಯದಿಂದ ಹೊರ ಬೀಳುವ ಪದವೀಧರರು ಉದೋಗ ಶೋಧನೆಗೆ ಹೊರಡುವವರೆ ಆಗಿದ್ದಾರೆ, ಎನ್ನುವ ಅರಿವು ನನಗಿದೆ. ನಿರುದ್ಯೋಗವು ಭೂತಾಕಾರವಾಗಿ ಈಗಾಗಲೇ ನಿಮ್ಮ ಮನದ ಎದುರಿಗೆ ನಿಂತಿರ ಬೇಕು. ಅನೇಕ ಜನ ಬಡ ಪಾಲಕರು ತಮ್ಮ ಬದುಕಿನ ಅಗತ್ಯಗಳನ್ನು ತ್ಯಾಗಮಾಡಿ, ತಮ್ಮ ಮಕ್ಕಳನ್ನು ವಿಶ್ವವಿದ್ಯಾನಿಲಯಕ್ಕೆ ಕಳುಹಿಸಿಕೊಟ್ಟಿದ್ದಾರೆ. ಅವರೆಲ್ಲರಿಗೂ ಒಂದೊಂದೇ ಆಸೆ ! ತಮ್ಮ ಮಕ್ಕಳು ಬೇಗನೆ ಒಂದು ಲಾಭ ದಾಯಕ ನೌಕರಿಗೆ ಹಚ್ಚಿಕೊಳ್ಳಬೇಕು ! ಆದರೆ, ಅವರಲ್ಲಿ ಹಲವರಿಗೆ ಭ್ರಮ ನಿರಸನವೂ ಹತಾಶೆಯೂ ಕಾದಿದೆ !

ಇಂದಿನ ಕಾಲಕ್ಕೆ ತಕ್ಕಂತೆ, ಮನುಷ್ಯರ ಶಕ್ತಿ ಹಾಗೂ ಶೈಕ್ಷಣಿಕ ಅವಕಾಶಗಳಿಗೆ ಸಂಬಂಧಿಸಿದಂತೆ ಸೂಕ್ತ ಯೋಜನೆಗಳು ಅವಶ್ಯ. ಸ್ವಯಂ﻿ ಉದ್ಯೋಗ ಸಾಮರ್ಥ, ಸನ್ನಡತೆಗಳು ಉಂಟಾಗುವಂತೆ ಇಂದಿನ ಶಿಕ್ಷಣ ವಿಧಾನಕ್ಕೆ ಹೊಸ ತಿರುವು ನೀಡಬೇಕಾಗಿದೆ. ಸರ್ಕಾರದ ಆಡಳಿತ ವರ್ಗ, ಅದರಂತೆ ಪ್ರಾಧ್ಯಾಪಕ ವರ್ಗವೂ ಯೋಗ್ಯ ಉದ್ಯೋಗಾವಕಾಶಗಳನ್ನು ಒದಗಿಸುವ ಬಗ್ಗೆ ಗಮನಿಸಬೇಕಾಗಿದೆ. ಉದ್ಯೋಗದ ಅವಕಾಶಗಳಿಗೆ ಅತ್ಯಗತ್ಯ ವಾದ ಅರ್ಹತೆಯ ಮಟ್ಟವನ್ನೂ, ಒದಗಿಸಬೇಕಾದ ವೈಜ್ಞಾನಿಕ-ಪ್ರಾಯೋಗಿಕ ವಿಧಾನಗಳನ್ನೂ, ಬೋಧನೆಗಳ ಹಾಗೂ ಬೋಧಕರ ತರಬೇತಿ ಕ್ರಮಗಳನ್ನೂ ಯೋಜಿಸಬೇಕಾಗುತ್ತದೆ.

ಭಾರತೀಯ ಜನಸಂಖ್ಯೆಯಲ್ಲಿ ಅರ್ಧಕ್ಕಿಂತ ಮೇಲಾಗಿ ಮಹಿಳೆಯರಿದ್ದಾರೆ. ಯತ್ರ ನಾರೀ ಪೂಜ್ಯತೇ ರಮಂತೇ ತತ್ರ ದೇವಾಃ " ಎಂಬುದು ಭಾರತೀಯ ಸಂಸ್ಕೃತಿ, ಸ್ತ್ರೀ ಶಿಕ್ಷಣದ ಪ್ರಗತಿ ಸಾಧಿಸದೆ ಸಮಾಜ ಸುಧಾರಣೆ ಆಗಲಾರದು. ಮಹಿಳಾ ಉದ್ದಾರದ ಕಾರ್ಯ ಶಿಕ್ಷಣದ ಪ್ರಗತಿ ಪಥದಲ್ಲಿ ಮಾತ್ರವೆ ಸಾಗಬೇಕು. ಈಗಿರುವ 70 ಕೋಟಿ ಜನ ಸಂಖ್ಯೆ ಇನ್ನೂ ಬೆಳೆಯುತ್ತಾ ಹೋಗಿ ಅದು ಹೊರಲಾರದ ಭಾರವಾದರೆ ಭಾರತದ ಭವಿಷ್ಯ ತುಂಬಾ ನಿರಾಶಾದಾಯಕ ವಾದುದಾಗುತ್ತದೆ. ಶಿಕ್ಷಿತ ಮಹಿಳೆಯರು ಈ ಭಾರವನ್ನು ಬಹು ಪಾಲು ಭಾಗ ಕಡಿಮೆ ಮಾಡಿ, ಭಾರತೋದ್ದಾರಕ್ಕೆ ಸಕ್ರಿಯ ಸಹಾಯ ಮಾಡುವುದು ಒಳ್ಳೆಯದು.

ನಾವೀಗ ನಮ್ಮ ಶಿಕ್ಷಣ ಪದ್ಧತಿಯನ್ನು ಮೂಲಭೂತವಾಗಿ ಮಾರ್ಪಾಡು ಮಾಡುವ ದಾರಿಯಲ್ಲಿ ಇದ್ದೇವೆ. ಬ್ರಿಟಿಷರು ಬೆಳೆಸಿಬಿಟ್ಟ ಪದ್ಧತಿಯನ್ನು ಬೇಕಾದ ಹಾಗೆ, ತಿದ್ದಿ, ಬಳಸುತ್ತಾ ಬಂದಿದ್ದೇವೆ. ಆದರೆ, ಈಗ ವಿಜ್ಞಾನದ ಮುನ್ನಡೆಯಿಂದಾಗಿ, ಹಾಗೂ ಸ್ವದೇಶೀಯ ಜಾಯಮಾನಕ್ಕೆ ಇದು ಸಂಪೂರ್ಣ ವಾಗಿ ಸರಿ ಹೋಗದಿರುವುದರಿಂದಾಗಿ ನಮ್ಮೆಲ್ಲರ ಆಶೆ ಆಕಾಂಕ್ಷೆಗಳನ್ನೂ ಈಡೇರಿಸಲು ಈ ಶಿಕ್ಷಣ ಕ್ರಮವನ್ನು ಬದಲಾವಣೆಗೊಳಿಸಬೇಕಾಗಿದೆ. ಸ್ವಾವಲಂಬಿಗಳಾಗಬೇಕಾಗಿದ್ದ ನಮ್ಮ ವಿದ್ಯಾವಂತರು, ಪದವೀಧರರು, ಪರಾವಲಂಬಿ ಆಗುವ ಸ್ಥಿತಿ ಬೆಳೆಯುತ್ತಿದೆ, ವಿದ್ಯಾಭ್ಯಾಸ ಕೇವಲ ಸರ್ಕಾರಿ ನೌಕರಿಗೆ ರಹದಾರಿ ಎಂಬ ಭಾವನೆ, ಸ್ವಾವಲಂಬನ ದಾರಿಯಲ್ಲಿ ಸಾಗಿರುವ﻿ ಭಾರತದ ಭವಿಷ್ಯಕ್ಕೆ ಸರಿಯೆ ? ಪದವಿಗೂ ನೌಕರಿಗೂ ಇರುವ ಕೊಂಡಿಯನ್ನು ಉಳಿಸಬೇಕೆ, ಕಳಚಬೇಕೆ ? ಇಲ್ಲವೇ ಸಡಿಲಿಸಬೇಕೆ ? ಹಾಗಾದರೆ, ಪದವಿಗಳ ಅಗತ್ಯವೇನು ? ಈ ಪದವೀ ಸಮಾರಂಭಗಳ ಆವಶ್ಯಕತೆ ಏನು ? ಎಂಬ ಮೂಥಿ ಸಮಸ್ಯೆಗಳು, ಶಿಕ್ಷಣತಜ್ಞರು ಸಮಾಜ ಪರಿವರ್ತಕರು ಹಾಗೂ ಸರ್ಕಾರವೂ ಬಿಡಿಸಬೇಕಾದ ಪ್ರಶ್ನೆ.

ಪ್ರಾಥಮಿಕ ಶಿಕ್ಷಣದಿಂದಲೇ ವೃತ್ತಿ ಶಿಕ್ಷಣ ನೀಡಬೇಕಾದುದು ಅತ್ಯಂತ ಆವಶ್ಯಕ. ಆದರೆ ಅವರವರಿಗೆ ಅವರವರ ವೃತ್ತಿಶಿಕ್ಷಣವನ್ನು ನೀಡುವ ಮೂಲಕವಾಗಿ ಆಯಾ ವೃತ್ತಿಪರರನ್ನು ಆಯಾ ವೃತ್ತಿಗಳಲ್ಲಿಯೇ ಆಳವಾಗಿ ಬೇರು ಬಿಡಿಸಿದಂತಾದೀತು, ಎನ್ನುವ ಭಯವೂ ಪ್ರಾಥಮಿಕ ಮಟ್ಟದ ವೃತ್ತಿ ಶಿಕ್ಷಣದ ಬಗೆಗೆ ಕೆಲವರಲ್ಲಿದ್ದರೆ ತಪ್ಪಲ್ಲ. ವೃತ್ತಿಗಳಮೇಲೆ ಜಾತಿಗಳು ಹುಟ್ಟಿ ಕೊಂಡ ಈ ನಾಡಿನಲ್ಲಿ ಜಾತಿಯ ಸಂಕೋಲೆಯಿಂದ ಮುಕ್ತರಾಗಿ ಹೊರಬರಲು ಹೇಗೆ ಸಾಧ್ಯ? ಉದಾರ ಶಿಕ್ಷಣವನ್ನು ಸಾಮಾನ್ಯವಾಗಿ ಎಲ್ಲ ವೃತ್ತಿಯವರಿಗೂ ಎಲ್ಲ ವರ್ಗದವರಿಗೂ ಕಡ್ಡಾಯವಾಗಿ ನೀಡಲೇಬೇಕು. ಅವರವರ ಜಾತಿಗಳಲ್ಲಿ ಮುಳುಗಿಸದಂತಹ ವೃತ್ತಿ ಶಿಕ್ಷಣವನ್ನು ಉತ್ಪಾದಕವಾಗುವಂತೆ ಜಾಗ್ರತೆವಹಿಸಿ, ನೀಡಿ, ಯಾರೂ ಜಾತಿಯ ಕೆಸರಿನಲ್ಲಿ ಬೀಳದಂತೆ ನೋಡಿಕೊಳ್ಳಬೇಕು.

ವಿಶ್ವವಿದ್ಯಾನಿಲಯದ ಓದು ಇನ್ನೂ ನೂರಕ್ಕೆ ಒಬ್ಬರಿಗೆ ಮಾತ್ರ ಲಭಿಸುವಂತಹ ಮಹಾ ಯೋಗವಾಗಿದೆ. ರಾಷ್ಟ್ರದ ಜನಸಂಖ್ಯೆಯ ಅರ್ಧಕ್ಕಿಂತಲೂ ಹೆಚ್ಚು ಜನರಿಗೆ ಅಕ್ಷರಜ್ಞಾನವೂ ಎಟುಕದ ಕೈಲಾಸವಾಗಿದೆ. ಈ ಎಲ್ಲರಿಗೂ ಓದು ಬರಹ ನೀಡುವ ಬಗೆ ಹೇಗೆ ? ಗಂಗೆ, ಯಮುನೆ, ಕೃಷ್ಣ, ಕಾವೇರಿಯರು ಹರಿದು, ಹರಸಿದ ಈ ನಾಡಿನಲ್ಲಿಯೂ ಬರಗಾಲ ಇರುವಂತೆ, ನೂರಾರು ವಿಶ್ವವಿದ್ಯಾನಿಲಯಗಳು ಇನ್ನೂ ಕೋಟ್ಯಂತರ ಜನ ನಿರಕ್ಷೆರರಾಗಿಯೇ ಉಳಿದಿದ್ದಾರೆ. ನದಿನದಿಗಳನ್ನೆಲ್ಲ ಕೂಡಿಸಿ, ನಾಡನ್ನೆಲ್ಲ ಜಲಸಂಪನ್ನವಾಗಿ ಬೆಳಸಿ, ಪೈರುಪಟ್ಟೆ ಯಿಂದಾಗಿ ಫಲವತ್ತಾಗಿ ಮಾಡುವ ಒಂದು ಮಹಾಸ್ವಪ್ನವು ನನಗೆ ಇದೆ. ಅದರಂತೆ, ವಿಶ್ವವಿದ್ಯಾನಿಲಯಗಳಲ್ಲೆಲ್ಲಾ ಓದಿ ಹೊರಬಂದ ವಿದ್ಯಾವಂತರು﻿ ನಿರಕ್ಷರರಿಗೆ ಓದು ಬರಹ ನೀಡುವ ಮಹಾ ಸಾಹಸಕ್ಕೆ ತೊಡಗಬೇಕಾಗಿದೆ. ರಾಷ್ಟ್ರವು ರೂಪಿಸಿಕೊಂಡಿರುವ ಈಗಿನ ಶಿಕ್ಷಣ ನೀತಿಯಲ್ಲಿ ಪ್ರಾಥಮಿಕ ಶಿಕ್ಷಣಕ್ಕೆ ಪ್ರಾಧಾನ್ಯ ಇದೆ. ಎಲ್ಲರಿಗೂ ಆರೋಗ್ಯದ ಅರಿವನ್ನೂ, ಅಕ್ಷರ ಜ್ಞಾನವನ್ನೂ ನೀಡುವ ಹೊಣೆ ರಾಷ್ಟ್ರದ್ದಾಗಿದೆ. ಹಳೆಯ ಜಾಡಿನಲ್ಲಿ ನಡೆದು ಬಂದ ಮನಸ್ಸಿಗೆ ಈ ಹೊಸ ಉದಾರ ದೃಷ್ಟಿಯು ವಿಶ್ವಾಮಿತ್ರನ ನವಸೃಷ್ಟಿ ಎಂದೆನಿಸಬಹುದು,

ಸಾಮಾಜಿಕ ಸಮತೆ, ಸಮಭಾವ ಹಾಗೂ ಆರ್ಥಿಕ ಅಭಿವೃದ್ಧಿ ಇವು ದೇಶದ ಪ್ರಗತಿಯ ಅಡಿಪಾಯಗಳು, ಇವಕ್ಕೆ ಶಿಕ್ಷಣವೇ ವಜ್ರವೇದಿಕೆ. ಇದಕ್ಕೆ ಮುಂಬಲ ಬೆಂಬಲವಾಗಿ ಕಾಠ್ಯಕ್ರಮವನ್ನು ರೂಪಿಸಿ ಮುಂದೆ ಹೋಗುವ ಮನಃಪರಿವರ್ತನೆಯು ಸಮಾಜದಲ್ಲಿ ಸಾಧ್ಯವಾದರೆ, ಸರ್ವೊದಯದ ದಾರಿ ಸುಗಮವಾಗುವುದು. ಅರ್ಹರಿಗೆ ಮಾತ್ರ ಉನ್ನತ ವ್ಯಾಸಂಗ ಎಂಬುದು ಸರಿಯೆನಿಸಿದರೂ, ಅರ್ಹರು ಯಾರು ಎಂಬ ಪ್ರಶ್ನೆ ಏಳುತ್ತದೆ. ಮೇಲು ನೋಟಕ್ಕೆ ಸರಿಯೆನ್ನಿಸುವ ಅರ್ಹತಾ ಸಿದ್ಧಾಂತವನ್ನು ಕಟ್ಟುನಿಟ್ಟಾಗಿ ಒಪ್ಪಿದ್ದರೆ, ಈಗ ನಾಡಿನಲ್ಲಿ ಪ್ರತಿಭಾವಂತರೆನ್ನಿಸಿಕೊಂಡಿರುವ ಎಷ್ಟೋಜನ ಅಶಿಕ್ಷಿತರಾಗಿಯೆ ಉಳಿದಿರಬೇಕಾಗಿದ್ದಿತು. ಏಕಲವ್ಯನಿಗೆ ಧನುರ್ವಿದ್ಯೆಯನ್ನು ನೀಡಲು ಒಪ್ಪದ ವರಿದ್ದ ಈ ನಾಡಿನಲ್ಲಿ ಉನ್ನತ ವಿದ್ಯೆಗೆ ಅರ್ಹರು ಯಾರು ಎಂದು ತೀರ್ಮಾನಿಸುವುದು ಹೇಗೆ ?

ತಂತ್ರಜ್ಞಾನ ಹಾಗೂ ಮುದ್ರಣಯಂತ್ರವನ್ನು ನೀಡಿ ಅಕ್ಷರ ಕ್ರಾಂತಿಗೆ ಎಡೆ ಮಾಡಿದ ವಿಜ್ಞಾನ ಉಳ್ಳವರ ಜ್ಞಾನವನ್ನು ಬಯಸುವವರ ಬಳಿಗೆ ಹರಿಸಿ ಸಾಮಾಜಿಕ ಕ್ರಾಂತಿಗೆ ನಾಂದಿ ಹಾಡಿದೆ. ಆಕಾಶವಾಣಿ, ದೂರದರ್ಶನ ಇತ್ಯಾದಿಗಳು, ಸಾಮಾಜಿಕ ಕ್ರಾಂತಿಯ ಗತಿಯನ್ನು ಇನ್ನಷ್ಟು ವೇಗಗೊಳಿಸಿವೆ. ಈ ಸಮಗ್ರ ತಾಂತ್ರಿಕ ಜ್ಞಾನವು ಪ್ರಗತಿಯ ಸಾಧನಕ್ಕೆ ಅಮೂಲ್ಯವಾಗಿದೆ. ಇನ್ನು ಕೇವಲ 10-15 ವರ್ಷಗಳಲ್ಲಿ 20ನೆಯ ಶತಮಾನವನ್ನು ದಾಟಿ, ಬರುವ ಶತಮಾನದ ಬಾಗಿಲನ್ನು ತೆರೆದು ಭಾರತದ ಭವಿಷ್ಯವನ್ನು ಕಟ್ಟಲು ಹೊರ ಬಂದಿದ್ದೇವೆ. ಇದಕ್ಕೆ ನಾವೆಲ್ಲರೂ ಭಾರತದ ಭವಿಷ್ಯದ ಭದ್ರ ಬುನಾದಿಯನ್ನು ಕಟ್ಟುವ ಅಮೋಘ ಆದರ್ಶವನ್ನು ಮುಂದಿಟ್ಟುಕೊಂಡು﻿ ಸಾಗಬೇಕಾಗಿದೆ. ನವೋದಿತ ಯುವ ಪದವೀಧರರಾದ ನೀವು ರಾಷ್ಟ್ರ ಕಟ್ಟುವ ಮಹತ್ಕಾರದಲ್ಲಿ ಸಮಭಾಗಿಗಳಾಗಬೇಕು ಎಂದು ನಿಮಗೆ ನಾನು ಆಹ್ವಾನಿಸುತ್ತೇನೆ. ಅನೇಕರ ಬೆವರು ನಮ್ಮ ಉನ್ನತಿಯ ಹಿಂದೆ ಕಾಣದಂತಿದೆ ಎಂಬುದನ್ನೂ ಮರೆಯಬಾರದು. ಆ ಬೆವರನ್ನು ಕೊಂಚಮಟ್ಟಿಗಾದರೂ ಒರೆಸುವ ಪುಣ್ಯ ಕಾವ್ಯಕ್ಕೆ ನೀವು ದೀಕ್ಷೆ ತೊಡಬೇಕಾಗಿದೆ. ಈ ಕ್ಷಣದಲ್ಲಿ ನಾನು, ಸ್ವಾಮಿ ವಿವೇಕಾನಂದರ ಸಿಂಹವಾಣಿಯನ್ನು ಸ್ಮರಿಸುತ್ತೇನೆ :

“I call him a traitor who, having been educated, nursed in luxury by the hearts' blood of the downtrodden millions of toiling poor, never even takes a thought for them.” ಕಟುವಾಗಿದ್ದರೂ ಅತ್ಯಂತ ಹಿತಕಾರಿಯಾದ ಈ ಸಂಜೀವಿನಿಯಂತಿರುವ ಈ ಮಹಾಪುರುಷನ ಈ ಮಂತ್ರವಾದ ಮಾತು ಸದಾ ನಮ್ಮ ಸ್ಮರಣೆ ಯಲ್ಲಿರಲಿ.

ಶಿಕ್ಷಣ ರಂಗದಲ್ಲಿ ಸ್ವತಂತ್ರ ಭಾರತ ಅಭಿಮಾನದ ಪ್ರಗತಿ ಸಾಧಿಸಿದೆ. ಭಾರತೀಯ ಶಿಕ್ಷಣತಜ್ಞರು ಜಗತ್ತಿನ ಅನೇಕ ವಿದ್ಯಾ ಸಂಸ್ಥೆಗಳಲ್ಲಿ ಗಣ್ಯಸ್ಥಾನ ಪಡೆದಿದ್ದಾರೆ. ಆದನ್ನೂ ಕೆಲವು ಸಮಯ ನಮ್ಮ ಭವಿಷ್ಯದ ಬೆಳಕಿಗೆ ಆಶಾ ದಾಯಕವಾಗಬೇಕಾದ ವಿದ್ಯಾಮಂದಿರಗಳ ನಿರಾಶೆಯ ನೆರಳನ್ನೂ ಚೆಲ್ಲುತ್ತಿವೆ. ಅಧ್ಯಾಪಕವರ್ಗ ಹಾಗೂ ವಿದ್ಯಾರ್ಥಿವೃಂದಗಳು ಮರ್ಯಾದೆಯ ಮೇರೆದಪ್ಪಿ ಅನ್ಯ ಪ್ರಚೋದನೆಗೆ ಒಳಪಟ್ಟು, ವಿದ್ಯಾಮಂದಿರಗಳ ಪವಿತ್ರ ವಾತಾವರಣವನ್ನು ಕದಡಿಸುವ ಅನೇಕ ಪ್ರಸಂಗಗಳು ಅನುಭವಕ್ಕೆ ಬಂದಿವೆ. ದೇಶದಲ್ಲಿ ನವೋದಯ ಮೂಡಿಸಿ ನವ ಸಾಮಾಜಿಕ ಸಂಸ್ಕರಣ ನಡೆಸಿ ಜನ ಜೀವನದ ಪ್ರವಾಹವನ್ನು ಪ್ರಗತಿಯ ಪಾತ್ರದಲ್ಲಿ ಸಾಗಿಸುವ ಪವಿತ್ರ ಕಾವ್ಯದಲ್ಲೀಗ ವಿದ್ಯಾಮಂದಿರಗಳು ತೊಡಗಬೇಕಾಗಿದೆ. ಹಿಂಸೆ, ಭ್ರಷ್ಟಾಚಾರ ಜಾತೀಯತೆಯನ್ನು ಮೆಟ್ಟಿಕ್ಕಿ, ತ್ಯಾಗ, ಸೃಜನಶೀಲತೆ, ಲೋಕಬಂಧುತ್ವವನ್ನು ಬೆಳೆಸಿ, ಅತ್ಯುನ್ನತ ಜೀವನ ಮೌಲ್ಯಗಳನ್ನು ಎತ್ತಿ ಹಿಡಿದು, ಜಗತ್ತಿಗೆ ತೋರಿಸುವ ಸತ್ಪಯತ್ನವೀಗ ವಿಶ್ವವಿದ್ಯಾನಿಲಯಗಳಲ್ಲಿ ನಡೆಯಬೇಕಾಗಿದೆ. ಜನಜೀವನದಲ್ಲಿ ಹೊಸ ಚೈತನ್ಯದ ಬೆಳಕನ್ನು ಹಾಗೂ ಉಜ್ವಲ ಆತ್ಮಶಕ್ತಿಗಳನ್ನು ತುಂಬಿ ಅಜ್ಞಾನದ ತಮೋ ರಾಶಿಯನ್ನು ಹೊಡೆದೋಡಿಸು﻿ವುದು ವಿದ್ಯೆಯ ಹಾಗೂ ವಿದ್ಯಾರ್ಜನೆಯ ಉದ್ದೇಶವಾಗಿರಬೇಕು. ಧಾರ್ಮಿಕ, ಆರ್ಥಿಕ, ಸಾಮಾಜಿಕ ರಂಗಗಳಲ್ಲಿ ಆದರ್ಶ ತುಂಬಿ ಪ್ರಗತಿ ಸಾಧಿಸಿ, ಹೊಸ ಸಮಾಜವನ್ನು ಸಂಘಟಿಸುವುದಕ್ಕೆ ಸಹಾಯಮಾಡುವುದು ನಮ್ಮೆಲ್ಲರ ಕರ್ತವ್ಯ. ಜನತೆಯಲ್ಲಿ ಸ್ನೇಹಬಾಂಧವ್ಯ, ಸಮಾನತೆ, ಐಕ್ಯ, ಸತ್ಯ, ಅಹಿಂಸೆ, ಸದಾಚಾರಗಳು ಬೆಳೆಯಬೇಕೆಂಬುದೇ ಶಿಕ್ಷಣದ ಮೂಲ ಸಂದೇಶ. ನಿಮ್ಮಲ್ಲಿ ಆತ್ಮ ನಿರೀಕ್ಷಣೆ, ಅಂತಃಶುದ್ದಿ, ಸರಳತೆ, ಸದಾಚಾರ, ವಿನಯ ಮೂಡಿ ನಿಮ್ಮ ಬಾಳಿನಲ್ಲಿ ನಿಸ್ಪೃಹ ಭಾವ, ನಿಷ್ಠೆ, ಆತ್ಮವಿಶ್ವಾಸ ಬೆಳೆದು ದೀನದಲಿತರ ಬಗೆಗೆ ದಯೆ, ಕರುಣೆ, ಅನುಕಂಪಗಳು ಚಿಗುರಿ ನಿಮ್ಮನ್ನು ಸತ್ಕಾರ್ಯದಲ್ಲಿ ತೊಡಗಿಸಲಿ. ಆ ದಿಶೆಯಲ್ಲಿ ನಿಮಗೆ ಚೇತನ ತುಂಬಿಬರಲಿ, ದಾರಿದ್ರ, ಜಾಡ್ಯದ ಜಟಿಲ ಸಮಸ್ಯೆಗೊಳಗಾದ ಜನತೆಯನ್ನು ಉದ್ಧರಿಸಿ, ಸಚೇತನ ಸಮಾಜದ ಸಂಘಟನೆಯ ಮಹತ್ಕಾರ ನಿಮ್ಮಿಂದ ನಡೆಯಲಿ. ಸರ್ವಜ್ಞ ಹೇಳಿದ : “ ನಡೆವುದೊಂದೇ ನೆಲವು, ಕುಡಿವುದೊಂದೇ ಜಲವು. ಸುಡುವ ಒಂದೇ ಇರುತಿರಲು ಕುಲಗೋತ್ರ ನಡುವೆ ಎತ್ತಣದು.” ಎಂಬ ಜಾತ್ಯತೀತದ ಮೂಲ ಮಂತ್ರವನ್ನು ಎತ್ತಿ ಹಿಡಿದು, ರಾಷ್ಟ್ರದ ಐಕ್ಯತೆಯನ್ನು ಕಾಪಾಡಿ. ವಿಶ್ವಶಾಂತಿಗೆ ದಾರಿ ದೀಪ ತೋರಿಸಿದ ಮಹಾತ್ಮಗಾಂಧೀಜಿ ಹಾಗೂ 'ಇಂದಿರಾಜಿ ಅವರ ಬಲಿದಾನದ ಆದರ್ಶವನ್ನು, “ವಸುಧೈವ ಕುಟುಂಬಕಂ ” ಎಂಬ ಉದಾತ್ತ ಗುರಿಯನ್ನು, ಮನದಲ್ಲಿಟ್ಟುಕೊಂಡು ಮುಂದೆ ಸಾಗೋಣ.

ನಾನು ಇನ್ನೊಮ್ಮೆ ನಿಮ್ಮೆಲ್ಲರಿಗೂ ನನ್ನ ಶುಭೇಚ್ಛೆಗಳನ್ನು ಸಲ್ಲಿಸಿ, ನಿಮ್ಮ ಭಾವೀ ಜೀವನವು ಸುಖಮಯವಾಗಲೆಂದು ಹಾರೈಸುತ್ತೇನೆ.

ಜೈ ಹಿ೦ದ್﻿

Saturday, 14th Mar. 1987 CONVOCATION ADDRESS BY
Mr. K. R. NARAYANAN,UNION MINISTER OF STATE FOR SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY,
ATOMIC ENERGY, SPACE, ELECTRONICS AND OCEAN DEVELOPMENT

Mr. Chancellor, Mr. Pro-Chancellor, Mr. Vice-Chancellor, Members of the Faculty, Graduates of the Year, Ladies and Gentlemen,

I have great pleasure to participate in this sixtyseventh Convocation of the University of Mysore. You have conferred on me a great honour by inviting me to deliver the Convocation Address. May I thank you for this gesture. May I also, at the outset, extend my hearty congratulations and best wishes to the students who have taken their degrees today, especially those who have received their prizes and medals and are standing tip-toe with expectation at the threshold of a new and challenging stage of life. I have no doubt that it was a great experience for you to have been educated in this University, which has such a high reputation for academic excellence and which is situated in the garden city of Karnataka with its natural beauty, its treasures of sandalwood and gold, its graces of traditional arts and culture, and its modern set-up of science, technology and industry symbolising a fine synthesis of old and new India.

Mr. Chancellor, India, as we all know, is a land where the human mind has soared to incredible heights of thought and philosophy and plumbed the unfathomable depths of the mind and soul of man. It is here in this﻿ land that perhaps the first fundamental questions were asked of the origin and the nature of the universe and of the predicament of mankind. The tradition of the persuit of knowledge was therefore long established, and learning was held in high respect and rewarded be it in gurukulas, ashramas, viswavidyalayas or in exceptional individuals. However, knowledge in this elevated form was the preserve of a creative minority at the uppermost layer of society though a few from below often managed to slip to the top through the meshes of the social network. To the vast majority of the people who remained outside the privileged sphere, religious and philosophical concepts, and knowledge in general, were purveyed in drastically, though beautifully simplified forms through mythologies, rituals and popular literature that captured the emotions and imagination of the masses. It was a magnificent feat of popularisation and communication on a grand scale which could arouse the envy of modern informatics with all its electronic equipment and gadgetry. The fact, however, remains that there was in this golden age of ours a yawning gap in knowledge or in education, to use modern parlance, between a small minority on the top and the immense majority below and all around. Even in respect of the basic instrument of education and communication, viz., language, a gap existed in the sense that Sanskrit with all its literary and philosophical treasures was not the tongue of the common people.

This situation prevailed almost throughout history as far as the all-India level was concerned, though the upper class language changed from Sanskrit to Persian and then to English. During the long period of British rule a new chasm came into being between the English educated﻿ and the rest of the people with the modernised sections of the semi-feudal society and the new industrial bourgeoisie and intelligentsia at the head of the social and administrative power-structure and the masses. Although there was a greater degree of social mobility in this system, basically the wide gap between the educated and the custodians of knowledge on the one hand, and the illiterate masses on the other remained almost super-imposed on the caste, social hierarchies and inequalities of the older order. Universities and educational establishments of the modern kind were in fact, though not in law and theory, institutions standing quite apart from the generality of the people, notwithstanding the filtration process associated with the new education. Even to-day the alienation of the educated from the people is an alarming phenomenon inspite of the tidal wave of the freedom movement that swept the country, the advent of popular democracy, and the intermittent assaults of socialistic ideas and demands on the system. What Rabindranath Tagore said of the educated classes in India, that they were like, a second storey added to an old family house with the architect forgetting to construct a staircase in-between, seems to be still essentially true of the social scene in India.

I have inflicted upon yon these rather breezy generalizations in order to highlight the current position of the university in our society and its role in the context of the developmental tasks facing the nation. It is true that today our universities and educational institutions are swelling enormously with numbers with over 3.5 million students in the universities and about 130 million in the school system, straining national resources and lowering standards of education. Yet the fact is that only 38 per﻿cent of the people are literate with a much smaller per centage managing to get inside the portals of higher institutions of learning. If our universities have been called ivory towers, they are crowded ivory towers, alienated from the masses, their relevance to the problems of the people being remote and their involvement in the vital developmental process almost insignificant.

How can we make the universities and the academic and student community actors and participants in the process of development? The University is a place of independent thinking, where young minds open up and evolve in an atmosphere of freedom and amidst the clash of opinions and ideas. There is thus a conflict between this inherent objective of a University, and the attempt to narrow it down and to harness it to some specific practical national tasks, bringing to bear upon it pressures of society and the machinery of the State. Is there an irreconcilable contradiction between the traditional idea of the University and the demands on it being increasingly made by society today? I do not think so. As Professor A. N. Whitehead said "In the process of learning there should be present, in some sense or another, a subordinate activity of application. In fact, the applications are part of knowledge. For, the very meaning of things is wrapped up in relationships beyond themselves. Thus, unapplied knowledge is knowledge shorn of its meaning".

The current conditions in our country offer exciting opportunities for such subordinate but vital activity of applications of knowledge in the process of learning itself, establishing some sort of healthy balance in the University system between education, research and social service. First of all, it should be possible to introduce in the study of individual disciplines a new direction which emphasizes and brings out in practical terms their relevance to developmental problems, especially in the study of social sciences, economics, agriculture, architecture, engineering, urban development, environment, health sciences, managerial, physical and earth sciences. We need a problem-oriented rather than a narrowly subject-oriented education, in our schools and universities. To acquire knowledge without a central purpose and any sort of subordinate application would be to gather knowledge devoid of meaning and relevance.

We are all aware that the Gandhian system of education had emphasised the joy and excitement of doing things while learning and carrying out service to the people as an integral part of education. Though not in the Gandhian way we had from time to time made halting and haphazard attempts in taking up some of the service aspects of education. In 1969.70 we started pilot projects in 37 Universities enrolling 40,000 student-volunteers in order to expose youth to social problems and to stimulate them to do service under the National Service Scheme. That and similar efforts never got off the ground. That must have been partly because in society as a whole there did not exist the spirit of service and the values associated with it. As a people we have been notoriously averse to manual work except those traditionally condemned to labour, an attitude engendered by the caste system. That was essentially a projection of the general attitude of our society which Swami Vivekananda decried when he made his famous remarks about the obsessive pursuit of personal purity by the Indian. “Our religion", he said, is in the kitchen,﻿ our God in the cooking pot; touch me not. I am holy". This traditional attitude was paradoxically fortified by modern bourgeois-bureaucratic values imbibed by the intelligentsia which placed a higher value on sedentary Government service than active work in agriculture, industry or business. Fortunately industrialisation and technological changes are gradually breaking down such false and regressive value systems and attitudes. But we need a thorough-going peaceful, cultural revolution in our country that would completely breakdown narrow domestic walls, dead habits and debilitating distinctions and prejudices so that dignity of labour and mobility of labour are brought about on large scale opening up work of all kinds and opportunities for our young people, enabling their talents and genius to blossom rather than being kept in constricted compartments.

In this context, may I recount a Japanese story. There was a young man who was bitten with curiosity with regard to the ultimate secret of life on earth. He was told of a Buddhist sage who could reveal the secret to him. The young man went in search of him and on reaching the home of the sage he impatiently asked him what the secret of life was. The sage said, 'Young man you have come a long way, have a bath first. After the bath, he posed the question again to the sage who advised him to rest a little and then have lunch. The lunch over, the young man put the question again and awaited with bated breath for the truth about the secret of life. The answer the sage gave was, 'Let us wash the dishes'. I hope I am not pouring cold water on the bursting enthusiasm of our young people by telling this story. Because, I believe, life is as much a matter of high idealism and hitching your﻿ wagon to a star as washing dishes and doing things by your own hands. In fact, one can often 'reach the unreachable stars' only if one is prepared to wash the dishes on earth. I can tell you that many Indians who went to Europe and America and became affluent and great did so after passing through a spell of dish-washing experience. Even a great hero like Ho Chi Minh of Vietnam did that once.

I should like now to deal with another aspect of the alienation of our Universities from society--that is lack of effective relationship between the University and Industry. We are today passing through a major industrial and technological revolution. The future jobs for our young people are in the sector of industry, technology, commerce and in the rapidly developing services sector, apart from opportunities in the vast agricultural and rural sector. To day, there is hardly any nexus between the university and the industry and even science and technology are developed in the specialised institutes and laboratories rather than in the more natural habitat of the University system. Universities can become relevant to national development when they are the main centres for the study and promotion of science and technology. For bringing about this crucial change the Government and Society have as much responsibility as universities themselves. In the famous SILICON VALLEY in the West Coast of the United States of America the genesis of the great electronics revolution centered around one university---the University of Stanford. It was from its research facilities and its faculty and students and the technological parks established around it that the electronics industry developed out of the intellectual and productive inter-action and collaboration﻿ between industries and the universities. In the mainly brain-based electronic industry of the future the university has an important role to play which would eventually bring about innumerable new jobs for the students who come out of our educational institutions.

A study team appointed by the Department of Electronics of the Ministry of Science and Technology has estimated that the total annual additional requirements of trained man power in the electronics sector would be 1,25,282 by the end of the 7th Five Year Plan. This volume of new employment created refers only to direct employment in the electronic and computer sector and not the indirect employment that would be generated in the economy as a whole. It is necessary for the universities to begin, seriously and systematically, research and development work in collaboration with our growing industrial sector and also to train students in these new branches of science and technology. The Government has launched a new programme for encouraging and helping our educational institutions in establishing training courses for electronics, and they are planning to set up National Institutes of Informatics Technology (NIIT) in four regions of the country. Of course, apart from all these, Government is also planning to give a vocational and technological bent to our education as envisaged in the new educational policy. It is our aim to make our schools and colleges and higher institutes of learning to turn out young people who are eminently employable and who would be forerunners in the development race to the 21st century that Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi has initiated.

Though we have taken it as an axiom, I must nevertheless emphasis here the over-riding importance of﻿ education in national development not only of higher education but primary and secondary education and also mass education. Eradication of illiteracy is central to this, because, without the majority of our population literate, neither the benefits of development nor the door of the 21st century will be open to us. That is why Prime Minister has declared eradication of illiteracy as an emergency programme called a technological mission to be carried out within a 15 year period. I should like to point out here the experience of Japan in this context. The success of Japan in industrialisation is often misunderstood in India as a result of imitative genius. According to a historian, "Any attempt to explain Japan's exceptional success in national development must give a high degree of credit to the educational system which took in its modern guise just a 100 years ago".

The 1872 Education Code of Japan pronounced that “There shall in future be no community with an illiterate family, nor a family with an illiterate person". In the post-war period Japan took another major decision that educational planning should constitute the main aspect of economic planning. This is a priority that we can well follow in India.

Jawaharlal Nehru once said: "A University stands for humanism, for tolerance, for reason, for progress, for the adventure of ideas, and for the search of truth. It stands for the onward march of the human race towards our higher objectives. If the Universities discharge their duties adequately, then it is well with the nations and the people. But if the temple of learning itself becomes a home of narrow bigotry and petty objectives, how then will the nation progress or a person grow in stature?".﻿

In India today, it has become imperative for us to riase above narrow bigotry and petty objectives. National vision and national integration have been inherent in our culture and civilization. But, they have become today indispensable for the progress of the whole of India as well as of each and every part of it. The compulsion of development and our predicament in the world have made unity of India and inter-dependance of India and of the Indian people a reality and a necessity. Youth who constitute the majority of our population today are no longer just the leaders of tomorrow but of today. They have already inherited India with all its difficult problems and exciting opportunities and prospects. They have today the privilege of being part of the great adventure of uplifting millions of our people from poverty, malnutrition and ignorance, building a strong united progressive India, and contributing to the peace and prosperity of the world. These are great tasks and to shoulder them you have to prepare yourselves for the responsibility and leadership that is devolving upon you. It is an inevitable and indispensable responsibility. But as Justice Holmes put it "The inevitable comes to pass through efforts". The University is a forum for efforts, for joyous creative efforts in order to shape your own future and the future of the nation. May I wish you all success in these noble efforts.

JAI HIND﻿

ADDRESS BY Justice E.S. VENKATARAMIAH on Tuesday, 1st Mar. 1988
Hon'ble Chancellor, Hon'ble Vice-Chancellor,
Graduates of the Year, Brothers and Sisters,

University of Mysore is my Alma Mater. On completion of my studies in 1943 at Maharaja's College which was the chief unit of this university, I joined the University of Bombay as a student. After a lapse of about 44 years, an opportunity has been provided to me to participate in the Convocation of the University, of Mysore. I acknowledge my gratitude to the authorities of the University for this.

On this occasion, I offer my humble salutations to the members of the teaching community of this university who taught me. I sincerely feel that it is only because of their good wishes that I have been successful in my life. Those who teach us to read and write in our childhood and those who in our youth impart the right education required for us to achieve our subsequent objectives are as important as our parents. The upanishad dictum "Acharya Devo Bhava" proclaims so. I always remember the help rendered to me by my teachers. This reminiscence alone is my precious armour.

About 44 years ago, I had also participated, like the new graduates who have assembled here today, in a function at Jaganmohan Palace where degrees. were awarded. I received two gold medals from the then Chancellor, His Highness the Maharaja of Mysore.

There is a vast difference between those times and now. Then the degree classes were conducted only in four colleges in the University of Mysore. All those who had qualified for the award of the degree could assemble in the auditorium of the Jaganmohan Palace and receive their degrees. It was possible to announce the names of all the graduates and to introduce them to the Chancellor as well. At present﻿ this is impossible. The situation now is that hundreds of colleges have been established and thousands of students receive their degrees. This is due to the increase in population and the relative increase in student strength. Therefore, earlier conventions have to be given up. Yet, I would like to offer on this occasion my good wishes to all those who are receiving their degrees today, in person or in absentia. I wish them a purposeful life as worthy citizens of our nation.

The path of life is multifaceted. Those who receive their degrees today would acquire various positions and honours in future, shoulder responsibilities of their own and meet the challenge of their personal lives and also further the interest of the nation. Hence it is customary to say a word or two by way of advice to them on this occasion. Therefore, kindly permit me to speak a few words.

It is 40 years since India attained freedom. What have we achieved ? What are we going to achieve in future ? Now is the proper time to think over the issue. By 1857 A.D., British power was deep-rooted in India. The Sipoy Mutiny which took place in that year was the first and really momentous call of our freedom struggle. Though deceitful tactics adopted by the British divided the Indian people into different groups and made them subservient to their rule, the British thirst for power and the imperialist ideology did not have the thrust required to contain nationalism and the desire for freedom.

The Indian National Congress was established subsequently. The spirited call for freedom that was heard everywhere was the joint result of the enthusiasm of the nationalists who were influenced by the Congress, and the wildfire generated by the division of Bengal. The First World War (1914-1918) intensified the nationalistic fervour of Indians. The sagacity, eloquence and the spirit of sacrifice of Gopalkrishna Gokhale, Balagangadhara Tilak, Lala﻿ Lajpat Roy, Bipinchandra Pal and later by Mahatma Gandhi when he assumed leadership further strengthened the freedom movement in India. By then the influence of Mahatma Gandhi had reached its peak. Thousands of people sacrificed their lives for freedom, they fell victims to bullets and blood flowed in the streets. Farmers, merchants, students, teachers, lawyers, doctors, a few Government officers, in short, people from all walks of life sacrificed everything to attain political freedom and rid our land of the British. They went to jail, became invalid, discontinued their studies, lost their home and property. Ultimately India became free on the 15th of August, 1947. But the subcontinent was also divided into two. We are grateful for ever to every individual who made sacrifices in the cause of our political freedom. Let us pay homage to all of them on this occasion.

Until 1947, there was a single goal set for the Indians, that of political freedom. This was due to the nationalism and patriotic spirit of the people. This goal and the cause succeeded in freeing us from political slavery and made India one among the free nations of the world. This is an important stage in our history. We could now proceed to examine what happened subsequently.

On 26th January 1950, i.e., within two years eleven months and eighteen days after freedom 'we drafted the constitution and established the Indian Republic, More than five hundred princely states which were in existence till then were incorporated into the Indian Nation. Within a few years the French and the Portuguese colonies of India also became part of the Indian Nation India became one integrated whole. Under the leadership of Jawaharlal Nehru and of Vallabhbhai Patel the Indian republic marched ahead

The aims and objectives of Indian constitution are depicted in its preamble. We, the people of India﻿ having solemnly resolved to constitute India into a sovereign socialist secular democratic republic and to secure for all its citizens justice, social, economical and political; liberty of thought and expression and freedom to profess and practise any religion, faith and worship; equality of status and of opportunity and to promote in the people fraternal feelings which would reaffirm the dignity of the individual and the unity and integrity of the nation, have adopted and enacted this constitution of India.

India is one nation. In the constitution it is stated at various places that the integrity of the country should be safeguarded by those who are at the helm of affairs. It is the duty of every citizen to protect the freedom of India. According to the constitution every Indian is merely a citizen of India and not a member of this sect or that. In short, we are all Indians. Moreover, the fundamental rights of the people of India and the directive principles of state policy are clearly stated in the constitution. It shall be the duty of every citizen of India to respect the national flag and the national anthem; to cherish and follow the noble ideals which inspired our struggle for freedom; to uphold and protect the sovereignty, unity and integrity of India, to render service when called upon to do so in order to defend the country against external aggression, to promote harmony and the spirit of brotherhood among the people of India transcending religious, linguistic regional or communal differences; to renounce practices not consistent with the dignity of woman; to value, preserve and consolidate the rich heritage of our composite culture and its values; to protect the environment, inclusive of forests, lakes, rivers and wild life and to have compassion for all living creatures; to develop the scientific temper, humanism, the rationalistic outlook, the spirit of inquiry and social reform; to safeguard public property and to abjure violence, to strive towards the highest levels﻿ of achievement in personal and public spheres. India is a federal state though it is not clearly stated so in the Indian constitution. It is the largest republic state consisting of a Union Government, 25 State Governments and 7 Union Territories and with a population of 800 million people. A number of laws are necessary to rule the country in accordance with the constitution. Those who rule must also have proper tactfulness. The constitution should not be a prison house for an obsolete system of life ; it should reflect our aspirations and be a lamp that lights the road ahead. The constitution cannot afford to be the printed ultimate which cannot be changed. It should be alive and must have the potency to inspire. It ought to become an excellent means for fulfilling the people's aspirations.

Four main pillars are needed for India to march forward as a good, welfare state retaining its sovereignty and integrity. First of all every region of India should be an indivisible part of the nation. Secondly, a high premium must be placed on social justice.

Thirdly, peace should prevail all over the country, Fourthly, cordiality and an unshakable faith in the welfare of the people, rather than selfishness, be cultivated. These are the four pillars. Their realization ought to be the aim of every Indian citizen.

Prior to the attainment of political freedom patriotism was the only driving force behind Indians. For about seven or eight years after independence the sacrifices made by the freedom fighters were still fresh in the people's memory. "We are all one, the whole of India is ours"-the hearts of the people were filled with this feeling. As years passed, this feeling gradually lost its intensity. Love of one's caste, religion, language and region gained in strength and the separatist attitude which is now conspicuous here and there, began to manifest itself. People﻿ started forgetting the value of freedom. The examples set in the political field by Mahatma Gandhi, Nehru, Patel and Rajaji were erased and a decline set in. Now if you take any newspaper in the early morning what do you read ?
