Murder in the name of politics, robbery, assault on woman, bribery, political immorality, bund loss to public property, irregularities in universities--an assortment of corruptions fills the major part of the newspaper. If this trend is not stopped, India will fall into irretrievable depths in the near future. All will be lost, if a moral revolution does not take place now. This moral revolution can be effected only by the youth of today. For such a revolution to materialise certain timely strategies have to be adopted. First of all every young man should have a feeling that he is Indian first; he should set aside his inclinations towards caste, religion, language and region.

Let me now reveal a secret no politician or government official who has benefited in the name of caste has ever helped the ordinary man in his caste ! If he has faith in the constitution and in laws, he .cannot help people of any particular community. He has to view all citizens uniformly. If he is inclined by nature to abuse power and to act against the constitution he would still help only his relatives, friends and those who have given him money. He would not help the other members of his community. The common people who are not able to understand this simple fact continue to fall into the traps set by the casteists. If you find here and there a few people who have progressed, it is on account of their own strength and not because of a minister or an officer belonging to their caste. But today's illusory context is such as to make an individual in Mysore district derive greater pleasure when someone in Bidar district who belongs to his caste but is not known to him gets a job, than when a neighbour intimately known to him but belonging to another caste gets the same﻿ job. If the neighbour concerned gets the job he feels infinitely jealous. Is this not real misfortune ? Is this not a symptom of inhumanity ? Take the election scene. Law says that nobody shall be elected through propaganda based on caste and religion But consider the candidates chosen by the political parties. In the constituencies where members of a certain caste or religion outnumber others, individuals of that caste or religion are selected as candidates.

Consider the surveys that appear in newspaper as election previews. They base their predictions of possible, winners on consideration of caste and religion of the constituency. Do we really conduct our political affairs keeping at a distance caste and religion ? I do not know when we would come out of this delusion. But our practice is even now violative of the constitution and the laws. A few might speculate about the candidates who are likely to secure higher marks in the University examinations in several places in the same way. Often the speculation does not depend on the merit of the student. These examples had to be cited to describe the mishaps that occur on account of caste, religion etc. Such is the toxic effect of caste and religion that whether it is the mariage pandal, rail or bus travel, universities or legislature-everywhere we hear only caste and religion being mentioned. It is difficult to say when we can get rid of this plague. I pray to my young brethern to root out the evil.

We have lagged far behind in providing social justice to all-particularly to the poor. How long would it be possible for 70 percent of Indians to endure poverty? They continue to be plagued by hunger, illiteracy and ill-health. Many have no clothes to wear, no homes to stay in. The situation in the villages is agonising. Those who migrate to the cities live in slums like wretched vermin. What is the remedy that would remove the anguish caused by poverty ?﻿

A meeting of Man and Nature (Purusha and Prakruti) is needed. I am not expounding Sankhya Vada, but am suggesting a way out of our present economic crisis.

We have abundant natural resources; our manpower is immense. But our people lack the capacity to utilise the natural resources. Take the example of Japan, Taiwan and Singapore. Though they do not have extraordinary natural resources, in a short span of 40 years they have harnessed their manpower to the utmost effect and are now in a position to hold out a threat to the U.S.A. in the economic sphere. But our position is diametrically opposed to theirs.

First of all, efforts have to be made immediately in India to build 25 new cities where about 50 million people could live comfortably. The practice of adding new extensions to the existing cities has to be dropped. Existing cities have lost the capacity to accommodate suitably those who migrate from the villages. You might have read in the newspapers recently the steps taken by Japan to reduce the pressure of population on Tokyo city. We have to follow that example. Instead of taking the Telugu-Ganga water to Madras by expending 500 crore rupees, it is better to build a new capital in Tiruchirapalli district on the banks of the Kavery by spending 500 crore rupees, as the late M. G Ramachandran used to say.

Instead of supplying the Kavery water to Bangalore with an expenditure of 250 crore rupees, it is possible to build a new city on the banks of the Tungabhadra by spending 250 crore rupees. To prevent people from living on the pavements of Bombay, a new capital for Maharashtra may be built on the banks of the Godavari. The headquarters of all public institutions need not be located in Delhi. They could be shifted to cities newly built. Hundreds of mills situated in the city of Bombay should be shifted to and distributed in the various districts. Until the process of shifting is over the labourers﻿ should continue to receive their pay. I have heard from informed circles that it is possible. I have also heard that it should be possible to build good houses for the labourers in the new locations. By the sale of lands where the mills are now situated, huge amounts of money may be collected. If Calcutta is to survive, another city has to be built which can reduce the pressure of population on Calcutta. Such programmes, if undertaken, would provide jobs to lakhs of people, people would get good houses to live in. In the big cities we have to pay now a price of Rs. 1,000/- to Rs. 10,000/- for a square yard of land. Is this not shameful? Why should we allow the landlords in the cities to make unwarranted profit ? The rent-control law is of no avail, for only tenancy cases are increasing in number. Public welfare will be achieved only when new houses are constructed. However, politicians do not think along these lines. They do not like to leave big cities. How can those living in big government bungalows be aware of the difficulties the common people have to face ?

The existing highways have to be broadened. Efforts should be made to build new roadways. Railway lines have to be extended. Many benefits will flow from these. Thousands of petitions have been filed in the Supreme Court, demanding job opportunities. Most of these cases have been decided and appropriate orders have been passed. Everyone who is capable of work has got to eat. Therefore food-grains have to be supplied to him. If he is without work the nation will lose the benefit of his capacity to work. Manpower is a gradually wasting asset. If a person does not work for a day the thing he could have produced or the service he could have rendered on that day is lost to the nation. To that extent there is a reduction in the Gross National Product in India.

If all are provided with jobs, a large number of crimes that now take place would not happen. A man﻿ without a job falls a prey to evil inclinations. It is our duty to provide everyone with work in this country. If all are engaged in work the purchasing power of the people, especially of the poorer people, will increase. The derand for materials and services will also increase, and to fulfil the demand we have to appoint more and more people. New job avenues will open up and there will be greater opportunity for all people to be employed. This is a question of 'cycles' in the world of economy. Secondly when a person begins to work and earn, he develops greater interest in society, government and peace. His responsibility to the nation and answerability would increase. Bunds, destruction of public property, unrest and violence would decrease. As the standard of living goes up the families become smaller. The tendency to beget more children would be checked. •

Because of the increase in population, the cultivable land available to man is gradually decreasing. Therefore it is necessary to develop more industries. The industries should be established in rural areas. Then the migration of the villagers to the cities would naturally decrease. If the economic change outlined above is to take place, people should become large-hearted, love for and faith in each other should come into being, peace and cordiality should prevail. This would be possible only through the development of human resources. There should be a rise in the level of intelligence and capacity for action. To achieve these, proper education is needed. The universities have to play an extremely important role here, and in particular,, the teachers have a major role to play. In recent days, the situation in the universities has become pathetic. I have a request to make to all of you. Kindly do not misunderstand what I say-I am talking about the universities in general. For any reason, do not promote to the next class a student who does not learn what he has been taught for if you did two offences would have been committed. First, the future of the student has been spoiled, you have deprived him of a fortune--the opportunity to learn; his mind stagnates, he would eventually be a worthless person in society. Secondly, he turns out to be burden on society. The average intelligence of the society would decrease. Now we do not find individual like C.V. Raman or Ramanujam. The students coming out of a number of universities: do not pass in all India examinations like I.A.S. Advertisements state that the students of certain universities need not apply. There are a number of reasons for this state of affairs. Malpractices in examinations, students' indifferent attendance, internal feud of the teachers, growing interest in bunds and strikes etc., and the discrimination teachers show towards students. If a boy is his favourite, let the teacher teach him well. But no favour should be shown when it comes to marking. Such instances, many more similar instances, have been brought to light through the cases heard before the court.

In universities, one expects greater discipline, a higher sense of dedication, of involvement and devotion both to teaching and learning. There should be a downward trend in litigation concerning university affairs. Intervention, in student affairs and university administration by political parties and politicians should be minimized.

The laboratories of our colleges should be genuine laboratories, not mere showpieces. Attempts have to be made to create greater interest in the sciences among students. A majority of the students who score more than 70 percent of marks join medical and engineering colleges. The best are not inclined to study pure sciences. Hence talented students do not come forward to undertake research in universities. The Government should be more concerned about this issue. Students of exceptional talent have to be attracted to the study of pure sciences by awarding if necessary every student a﻿ fellowship of a thousand rupees a month. In a state like Karnataka, steps should be taken to ensure that at least 500 meritorious students study pure sciences every year in the universities. An expenditure of even 5 to 6 crores of rupees on this score would not be a bad proposition. I request the Government and the universities to build strong science departments so that the returns may be adequate.

To cultivate the sense that we are all Indians, and to promote our environment in all its purity, it is important to teach nationalism and environmental protection to the children from the first standard in the primary school on to the tenth for at least one hour in a week. Inclination towards and a sense of cleanliness, rural sanitation and conservation of nature should be inculcated upon the children. If all these are firmly rooted in the young minds, the burden of the university at a later stage would be lessened.

Earlier, I have pointed out a meeting of Man and Nature should take place. If the nation has to progress through a combination of natural resources and human effort, in addition to the programmes outlined above many others have to be taken up in the initiation of which I request all of you to be involved.

No animal would voluntarily walk into the mouth of a sleeping lion. You have to wake up and work hard for the uplift of your self and of the nation. Do not forget the dictim: "Work is God." I wish all the best to the new graduates who are entering the vast arena of life on the completion of their student career. It is my wish that they would tone up our public life.

"JAI HIND"

(English version of speech delivered in Kannada by Justice Sri E. S. Venkataramiah).﻿

CONVOCATION ADDRESS BY Smt. MARGARET ALVA,
MINISTER OF STATE IN THE MINISTRY OF
HUMAN RESOURCE DEVELOPMENT, GOVERNMENT OF INDIA.

Hon'ble Chancellor, Hon'ble Vice-Chancellor, Graduates of the Year, Brothers and Sisters,

1 deem it a privilege to be invited to this great seat of learning to deliver the Convocation Address. It is my Alma Mater which has produced many outstanding personalities over the seventy-three years of its existence. I am specially grateful for the honour bestowed on me today by conferring on me the degree of " Doctor of Literature” a distinction which I know, I do not deserve, but which I humbly accept. Not many universities in the country can boast of a woman Vice-Chancellor. Dr. Selvie Das stands out as an example of a successful educationist and bold administrator, who has overcome many hurdles to reach this position. To have on a platform like this, two women, speaks much for the dynamism and new thinking of the University.

We are graduates, you and I, of this great University. That is a privilege, but it carries great responsibilities. You go out into the main stream of life as young people to whom is handed the heritage﻿ of the past — with all that is precious in it and, with all its blemishes. It is for you to preserve what is good and to make good what is not, and to bring to the future the special touch of your generation. You come to this high responsibility as graduates in a nation where university education is still a luxury. In all you do, it is essential to remember, that you carry that proud label of being a graduate of this University. I feel deeply honoured to share it with you.

Ours is a land in which contraction thrive and opposites co-exist. We see in its daily life many centuries telescoped into one, with many patterns of culture, each as ancient as the other, contesting for survival. There are so many demands, ever-growing, on a resource pool that always seems inadequate. Literacy percentages rise, but the actual numbers of illiterates go up : development takes place, but poverty in quantum terms increases; thousands throng the universities, but they come out less equipped to earn a living. Population pressure mounts and the disciplines of self-regulation crumble before the onslaught of the impatient, the frustrated, and the angry. We talk about bridging the many gulfs between our people, and of the need to be egalitarian in outlook and policy, while our systems, rules and regulations, and value systems, increase disparities. We create for the young, dreams of affluence which can neither be fulfilled nor are worthy of fulfilment. So many of the practices of a feudal-colonial past that should have little relevance when we are seeking a social﻿ transformation based on equality, encroach upon the present, destroying our capacity to cope with the challenge of change.

Each solution generates a new set of problems. The growing aspirations of the people create a new quality of pressure on policy making. It is a situation in which the idea of a humane society, of

good government' based on fairness and justice, to • be achieved through collective political wisdom, have gradually gone out of focus. Unless the consciousness of history is made the prime mover of the developmental process, we must of necessity end up creating tyrannical structures in the name of a mythical future that is never realised. For today's crisis.' is rooted in a process that has made the human being ( the citizen') the beneficiary of impersonal forces-means of production, economic institutions, technology, the state-rather than their creator.

What is the solution ? Is it possible for us to create a political philosophy sufficiently dynamic and yet able to guarantee the stability of our democracy? The only way to go about this enormous task is to state categorically, that every theory and plan, will be tested on the basis of what it is likely to do for the mass of our people. This was Mahatma Gandhi's 'talisman'. Indian democracy demands a growth model which ensures substantial changes in the basic living condition of the mass of our people within their life-time. If it cannot be done in a democracy they will seek other ways. We need today to turn to the﻿ people who have bitherto been made the objects of all projects of history-making. This involves not just a new rhetoric but a new commitment on the part of the thinking strata, a new strategy of intervention, in the social process. And while considering the critical question of a new economic balance for our democratic transition, we must keep in mind the fact that the answer has to be found within the context of the Indian experience, at the base of the economic structure: in the lives of the peasant, the craftsman, the worker, the student, the woman, the unemployed, the homeless, the hungry and the exploited.

Pandit Nehru had pointed out “...We have to promote industrialisation on a large and balanced scale, so as to add to the wealth of the country, and thus to the national dividend which can be equitably distributed.... But production by itself is not enough: for this may lead to an even greater concentration of wealth in a few hands. which, in the context of today, produces instability and conflict. Therefore, fair and equitable distribution is essential..."

Speaking purely from the economics aspect, the top 20 per cent of our society today accounts for 52 per cent of the national income, while the bottom 40 per cent gets a mere 5 per cent. Even a 2 per cent shift in income from the top 20 per cent to the bottom 40 per cent will mean a growth of 40 por cent for the poorest in our society. We need to consider the implications of this for industrial growth and to the improvements in the living standards of﻿ the impoverished. Greater equity and even some redistribution in income therefore, has to assume a high place in our priorities.

I believe it is possible to achieve the necessary corrections in our policies and implementation strategies, through democratic peaceful processes, if we begin to stir ourselves out of the old grooves. The economics of democracy in a developing society must be understood more creatively. No longer can we rest content with injecting radicalism into the content of planning. Our planning process must become a major weapon in the structural transformation of India. People's participation both in planning and implementing programmes for themselves must be ensured. Political and economic leadership must combine to attack the problem of poverty and despair.

No society is stagnant, no society stands still. Therefore, unless the legal' system adapts itself to the changing needs of the people, it will not assure its viability in the challenging conditions of our age. What is needed is adjustment between the framing and implementation of laws on the one hand, and the aspirations of the people on the other. What we need. is an adequate theory of change and intervention... and this is precisely a time and a moment when the basic idea which is inherent in the constitution, namely, of building a humane, socially compassionate and politically just and equitable 'order' needs reworking-in the changed context. We have to ensure that the legal processes do guarantee﻿ the freedom and rights which we think are important to human relationships in society. We have to ensure that those who may be afraid or have been made to fear, find justice through the processes of law.

Inaugurating the International Youth Year in 1985 our youthful Prime Minister said, “We must evaluate what we have achieved. We must identify the mistakes we have made, because it is only then that we can correct them and move ahead." We have to learn from the past and plan for the future. We have to combine the wisdom and spirituality of the ancient with the material, scientific and technological advance of the modern. It is only thus that we can grow into a peaceful, dynamic and progressive society. You have a vital role to play in the making of this new society. No country can progress if its young run away from responsibility. Be prepared for sacrifices--for hardship-for sweat and toil.

You have acquired. many skills here. You have acquired knowledge and scholarship. You have acquired technique and discipline. You have acquired intellectual and moral values. All these are part of the talents you will use for creating this new society.

Tagore had said :

“ The great human societies are the creation not of profiteers but of dreamers":

I say to you today-have a dream. Let it be a dream of personal betterment, of human betterment. Let it be a dream for your home, your village, your﻿ town; let it be a dream for India. Let your dream be a liberating force ; let it be a force for freedom ; let your dream' not be a solace for failure. but a spur to achievement. And may you make that dream come true......

JAI HIND﻿

CONVOCATION ADDRESS BY Dr. VS ARUNACHALAM,
SCIENTIFIC ADVISER TO THE DEFENCE MINISTER AND SECRETARY,
DEPARTMENT OF DEFENCE RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT, MINISTRY OF DEFENCE.

Mr. Chancellor, Mr. Pro-Chancellor, Mr. Vice-Chancellor, Respected teachers of the university, graduates of the year, distinguished guests, ladies and gentlemen,

I am conscious of the honour the Mysore University has done me by its invitation to address its Seventieth Convocation. First, of course, is the very privilege of this invitation. For hasn't this address in the past been delivered by many eminent sons of our country? For, Mysore University has a long and rich tradition of learning and scholorship. Scholars thronged to this seat of learning with a chosen few serving the institution at one time or another in its history and enriching it by their intellectual might. There were the greats like our former President late Sarvepalli Radhakrishnan, or our Kuvempu, the philosopher Prof. Yamunacharya and the physicist Pancharatnam. They all taught at this temple of learning,﻿ building and strengthening the rich tradition of scholorship the University is famous for. This invitation is also a source of personal pride for me: for, I was a student of this University some thirty five years ago studying science in a local college. Then, like all young men I wasn't also sure of what I wanted to be. Sometimes I would dream of becoming a writer or a journalist; but most often, it was science for me. The very environment of Mysore as I remembered was ideal for a student. The city is proud of its University, and she in turn, forms the cultural core and I do not remember an instance when the University was looked upon with anything except with pride and affection by the citizens of this city. I still cherish this period of my life often reliving the past many times over.

Today, University education has started appearing as a contradiction in our perception of education needed for this country. This fear, I suspect, has arisen because of distortions in the very social fabric of our society. For, our country holds the unenviable record of having the largest number of illiterates among its people. Even primary education is not available to them and they have been denied or they have denied themselves opportunities for being, counted as a literate. India, it is said, lives in her villages, but alas, her schools do not live there. The statistics on village schools, the existing facilities, and the number of available teachers can make very discouraging reading. It may even appear that with the existing facilities we have no hopes of ever catching up with the stated national objective of providing everyone with at least a primary education. Alongside with this debilitating deficiency, we also boast of over one hundred fifty universities graduating a few lakhs of students annually. The spectrum of subjects and disciplines our universities cover is impressive: you only﻿ have to name a subject, which may be just unfolding or even be esoteric to be told that we have at least two universities teaching it and some may well have research programmes going! Many developed countries cannot boast of such accomplishments. Thus we have two societies in education intertwined uncomfortably with each other forming an India with a large uneducated populace as also with highly trained, technologically sophisticated, and knowledge-rich people. There are not many countries in the world with such strong and stark contrasts.

Therefore, there is a desire in all of us to find ways and means for eliminating these contradictions. There are those who believe that primary education can only be pulled up by the creation and availability of economic opportunities to all the people, and they, in turn, will automatically opt for educating the young when economic deprivation is reduced. This belief, with some justification, is based on our cultural heritage and people's intrinsic desire to educate themselves, and therefore given opportunity and environment, literacy will automatically go up. On the otherhand, there are also those who believe that education has become elitist in our country, and universities and institutes have mushroomed taking away disproportionate amount of our resources at the expense of primary education. The only way it appears of clearing this imbalance is to abandon the support given to higher education at least for the time being, till the needs of the primary education are met. There is also an accompanying social concern about the desirability of producing so many graduates without much specialisation, who then look to the government for employment. This, then, is the problem. How are we going to meet the needs of the society for﻿ educating all without distorting the requirements for highly skilled and educated manpower?

In this debate, may I hasten to make my position very clear. I am all for the university education for as many as can get in, for it constitutes the country's resource for an alround development. Sometimes, I fear that this strength is not so fully understood or appreciated. India is unique among the developing countries, the so-called Third World, in that she does not have to depend on others for her engineers, doctors, economists, scientists and administrators. Our universities have provided this core for generations making India run like a well-oiled machine. This is a unique phenomenon among the developing nations, for our country could transform herself without even a small dislocation when the foreign rulers left our shores. This infrastructure determined that political freedom is accompanied by other capabilities which made our country truly independent. This unfortunately is not the case with many countries which followed us on the Independence Road. Many are still not really free, toyed between dependence of one form or another, while we have been our own masters in the true sense of the term. Our non-alignment, our independence in matters related to defence, and our scientific independence to harness the power of the atom or outer space for the common weal, would not have been possible without the availability of the educated manpower.

Perhaps they could have accomplished more. But the problems were gigantic, and the demands were many When I look at many of the unmet challenges, I remember our achievements and become conscious of our limitations including the environment we inherited. Years of colonial﻿ subjucation have drained from us the strength to create new structures for addressing the problems of our society. Part of the difficulty arises from the historical truth of our missing the Industrial Revolution. When the Western society was revolutionising its social structure by harnessing the full power of the technologies unleashed by the Industrial Revolution, we were still living in a pre-industrial age crippled by a debilitating class and caste-structure. The Industrial Revolution in the West broke all barriers by the very capability of its technology which freed the serfs from rural oppression providing them opportunities and living in new industrial towns that grew almost overnight; in colonial India, we missed it all. We had universities and colleges producing graduates, but not many industries to employ them. The rural poverty and the stratified social structure therefore continued unabated. Thus when our graduates came out of the universities, they had to make do with an environment which did not need their knowledge. If anything, by its strangeness the very university education introduced distortions of its own: the so-called white collar workers who considered any physical work beneath their dignity filling our institutions with people who would merely continue the tradition of command and control at various levels without contributing meaningfully to any activity. Thus university education has become synonymous with a white collar job and a passport to being a respected member of the society. This is not to decry the contributions of the countless many who helped to transform the society and brought in a breath of fresh air in every field. One has only to look at all our freedom fighters to see that how many of them were graduates of universities; in fact, many of them were lawyers from the Mahatma to Rajaji. There were engineering geniuses like Dr. Visveswarayya, or scientists﻿ like C.V. Raman or mathematicians like Srinivasa Ramanujan. They all helped to shape the India of today. Therefore, to decry our higher education as elitist is to ignore these contributions. Without these we would not be where we are today.

What is wrong with our education, then? The only immediate answer I can submit is that we associate a university degree as a passport to a job. Instead of considering education as a must for human development, we consider it as a mere career requirement. Unfortunately, most of the graduates in India are from liberal arts and they, for want of any specialisation, end up as mere cogs in the wheel of the country's bureaucratic machinery and stratified structure, merely lengthening the decision-making chain. W it takes only one person to mind a bus in the West, we need at least two and sometimes even more! We must therefore make education more meaningful and relevant.

There have been many attempts in the past to modify the structure including the setting up of new educational institutions. The setting up of Shantiniketan or even the Women's University in Bombay are such examples. We have to build more such institutions, specially now. For a start we must actively discourage a large number of graduates entering into post-graduate education unless they are keen to take up a professional career based on such studies. A large production of M.As or M.Scs without high standards of scholarship and concommitant availability of employment opportunities make a mockery of our very education process. This problem has become more acute with the mushrooming of more universities and the availability of correspondence courses even for the post-graduate education.﻿

How do we make the university education more relevant and also suited to the nation's requirements? First, of course, is the basic need for a liberal education for every university student. Today our courses have become very narrow, with a narrower specialisation. The arts student is totally ignorant of science and mathematics and even about the recent happenings in science and technology. Often, he or she gapes with ignorance, and wonders when some science spectaculars are announced very similar in feelings to that of a common man who hasn't had the benefit of education at all. There are similar parallels with graduates in science and engineering having no rudimentary knowledge of economics or even of social sciences. These must be corrected, for it is too early for a student to decide which is going to be his or her chosen field. Opportunities must therefore be provided for broad-based courses. This may even reduce the hurried rush we have for engineering and medical colleges. We must also provide opportunities for training in areas relevant to our needs and appropriate to our society. Our undergraduates, for instance, do not have opportunities for vocational training. Many have not experienced the thrill of making things work. It may be repairing of pump-sets in our fields or of radios in villages, or even of cleaning the environment for making water potable. Today, we still depend on uneducated or untrained 'professionals' for any work involving manual labour. I fear this may well be the continuation of our caste system where manual labour was relegated to the lower castes. We must change this, and change it fast, if we have to transform our society into an industrial and enlightened one.

I have earlier mentioned about the commitment to provide education at least upto the primary level for every child in the country. This mission itself is so gigantic that we do not have adequate resources even to provide for this modest requirement. There are not enough teachers or schools or even books and other student aids. The only option therefore is to adopt unconventional approaches using some of the advanced technologies that are available in other areas. The Electronics Revolution, more appropriately the Microchip Revolution, has radically altered the entire field of Information Processing. We have television and more easily available radios for a wide-spread and effective communication across the entire country. If we look for interactive communication where both parties can talk and discuss, we can then look into the various channels of telecommunication. Communication is no more the mere laying of cables and connecting of telephones. It can be small satellite terminals that link up the entire nation, or may even be battery-operated two-way radio sets or computers which can be charged by sunlight. These facilities can really take schools to every village if we are only ready to modify the available technologies to meet our national and regional requirements. I fear that we have an in-built resistance that makes us use the recent inventionas only in high technology areas. This may be due to the original push for the invention which may, in the first place, have come from the Defence or Space technological requirements. But Japan's successes in recent years have come from this flexibility of using technologies in appropriate places without worrying about their original or intended applications. Even some toys and games produced in that country have electronic microprocessors! The wide electromagentic spectrum invites the society with its rich possibilities.

I am also detecting a resistance in our country to go in for such technologies for solving our old but still crippling﻿ social problems. The conventional route is well-known and can therefore be adopted without much effort. More important is the manpower we section to these areas. It is not well-equipped to look into these options as we lose our bright youngsters to foreign shores and other remunerative professions which seem to carry social recognition and benefits. In common with the rest of the developing world, we have some lopsided distribution among the specialisation the students choose. Innovative and far-reaching options are therefore not discussed, and we continue the same old rut as though the fate has willed us that way. This gets expressed in variety of self-justifying statements. We abandon computer as a teaching medium because it is considered costly or inferior to a blackboard, forgetting its potential to teach a large group of children and at the same time meeting individual requirements. We must resist this temptation, and instead must seek ways and means of making these modern equipment cheap, easily available and more adaptable to Indian conditions. This may well be our only option to fulfill many of our long standing commitments to the very society we live in. It is said that those who forget the past are condemned to relive it. We must therefore remember our history of not going in for paper or for printing, choosing instead to live with dried and fragile palm leaves. We thus missed the age of enlightenment which engulfed Europe few centuries back. The computer of today may well be the paper and printing of yesterday.

I have been talking so much defending the university education that I almost seem to have forgotten its products who are graduating today! I most warmly offer my congratulations to them and wish them well for the coming years when they will be exposed to the real world. It may﻿ be a little too early to worry about the world outside just when you have completed your examinations well and passed them successfully. Even preparing for the examination itself trains our mind fully. First, of course, is the need to understand the issues well and assimilate the essentials so that they can be stated when asked for. Hard work is needed as also an intellectual and physical discipline that allows one to sit and study. I believe preparing for an examination is not dissimilar to an army general preparing for war with all strategies considered and some options worked out in detail. There is also the moral issue involved in this preparation. Many of us believe that it is immoral to use wrong methods for passing the examinations and we look down on those with contempt who practise those methods. By trying to bypass, they short-circuit the entire system throwing away the confidence people have on these structures.

Real life is not unlike college and examination. We must work hard, practise discipline in every aspect of life and ensure that wrong doings are discouraged and not allowed to continue. Every one of us has a responsibility to keep our environment clean, earn our living by honest means and eschew violence in every walk of life. In a sense, this message is not new. All our Puranas talk about this as also the more recent teachings of the Father of the Nation. A disciplined nation can only be built by self-disciplined people. What better place to start this exercise than from the very cradle of learning -- schools and colleges.

There is also another concem about our young men and women that I want to share with you. This is our attitude to things other than work. Most of us give up physical exercise and games so soon early in our life. We tend to﻿ avoid all forms of physical activity preferring instead to practise only those not involving any physical effort, or exertion. We may have the highest mountain in the world, but only foreigners walk on them. Our beaches are many and sunny and we do not swim there. The Indian flora and fauna are exquisite and rich, and only now we are waking up to their beauty and charm. These are deficiencies which get reflected in our life. We do poorly in sports and in athletic events. We may complain of lack of infrastructure and facilities, but they do not get built up in isolation. An awareness to the beauty of the world we live in and happiness in achieving success through physical labour should be important to every one. I also note with concem the increase in diseases amongst us due to the sedantary life we all seem to practise. While we have wiped out the dreaded diseases of the past by better hygiene and potent medicines, we are replacing it with diseases of sloth. Our ancestors knew of the problems and of Yoga that makes us realise the full physical and spiritual potential in all of us. I would like to ask the graduates of today to analyse these issues as well. For, the university in which you have been privileged to study has as its very motto - NAHI GYNANENA SADRESAM. The spirit of human being is unquenchable and is at its best when there are challenges and opportunities to meet them.

May I, once again, thank the University for the kind invitation and congratulate all the new graduates of today. For, the future belongs to them.

JAI HIND﻿

Hon'ble Chancellor, Madame Vice-Chancellor, Hon'ble members of the
Syndicate, Senate and cademic council, Distinguished guests,
Graduates of the year, Ladies and Gentlemen,

I feel greatly honoured for being invited to be your. Chief Guest and deliver the Convocation address this year, the Platinum Jubilee year of the University of Mysore, whose motto, is implicit in its name Manasa Gangotri, that of a great seat of learning from where knowledge should flow across the entire country. I extend my hearty congratulations to all the successful graduates, who by their dint of hardwork and dedication have been able to overcome life's first hurdle. To those, who have not succeeded in this goal, I, offer my best wishes and hope that they will turn this temporary set back into a fresh challenge to face their future life with purpose and determination.

The University of Mysore, since its establishment in 1916 has been guided by a galaxy of eminent men and distinguished scholars, who as Vice-Chancellors shaped this unique temple "of light, of liberty and of learning', firmly convinced in the words of Rashtra Kavi Kuvempu :
ವಿಶ್ವವಿದ್ಯಾಲಯಗಳು ಅಣೆಕಟ್ಟುಗಳಂತಲ್ಲ : ಕಾಗದದ, ಉಕ್ಕಿನ ಅಥವಾ ಹೆಂಚಿನ ಕಾರ್ಖಾನೆಗಳಂತಲ್ಲ; ಅವುಗಳಿಂದ ಹೊರಬೀಳುವ ವಸ್ತುಗಳು ಸಜೀವವಾದುವು, ಸಚೇತನವಾದವು : ಒಂದೊಂದೂ ತನ್ನ ವಿಶಿಷ್ಟತೆಯಿಂದ ನಿರುಪಮವಾದುದು ;﻿

My young friends, you are entering a new phase of life, full of challenges and excitement in an era which is aptly termed as space age, characterised by stupendous scientific advancements and extraordinary technological achievements. You are the privileged torch bearers on whose shoulders, lies the responsibility of leading this nation, to the next century in less than a decade. Even the most spectacular scientific discoveries and technological developments of this century will look like a far off melting away mist compared to those which you will experience in your life time. I sincerely hope your education has adequately prepared you to meaningfully participate in the excitement and challenge of the future overcoming the plethora of problems you have inherited, with courage and determination.

The World you are Inheriting

You have inherited a world full of inequities and disparities - a part of the developing world sustaining 80% of underprivileged global population, with less than 20% of world's resources, constantly plagued with problems of malnutrition, hunger, illiteracy, inadequate health care and an abysymally low standard of living. The very regions and countries which were once the seat of great civilizations, have now become overpopulated, highly polluted and﻿ industrially backward, unable to provide even minimal sustenance to their peoples.

In our own country, the tragic picture of prevalence of chaos and scarcity, of unrest and terrorism, of large scale unemployment and wastage of valuable manpower, must be rightly raising severe anxieties in your minds as to your future. In spite of spectacular progress. made in some selected areas of science and technology such as space, atomic energy and agriculture, the overall impact of science and technology on the common man has been marginal. The phenomenal growth in the number of universities and institutions of higher learning with over 180 universities, 7000 colleges and six million students, has not made a significant impact in reducing the rate of illiteracy in the country. While the green revolution has enabled the country to increase its food production from 55 to 172 million tons in the last four decades, the available per capita food has remained practically unchanged, leaving a large body of nation's population barely at survival level, just adequate to hold their body and soul together.

Large scale deforestation resulting in severe erosion and degradation of soil, increase of wasteland and sedimentation of river beds and lakes have become a cause of recurrent floods and drought with untold misery to human lives and livestock. The available land resources in the country has﻿ shrunk to a mere 0.17 ha/capita, which can barely support the present food requirements of the country, let alone meeting the targeted annual requirement of 230 m ton by the year 2000. In spite of the country being blessed with a large amount of rain, indiscriminate wastage of water resources and grossly inadequate conservation practices have led to water shortage, denying even drinking water to thousands of villages. In summary a substantially large part of our countrymen still live well below the poverty line, unemployment of even educated is on the increase, the industrial growth has been unable to initiate a revolution and the educational system has remained stagnant, unable to produce innovators, scientists and technologists who can strike new pathways.

How did this happen?

How did our country, with a long and glorious tradition of science beginning with the ancient times of great teachers like Aryabhata, Varahamihira and Bhaskara, a country which rightly claims credit for discovering "zero", a country which boasts of having the third largest stock of scientific manpower in the world, degenerate into the "present state of affairs? The answer partly lies in the rigid application of religious dogmas and social attitudes which have crippled the very spirit of scientific enquiry,﻿ and chained our society to the relics of the past, unable to adjust itself to the challenges of the technological future. As Sir M. Visvesvaraya put it "The religious and fatalistic philosophy has been used to foster our genius for standing still." We have been consistently preached that there is richness in poverty" and contentment is the true path for attaining nirvana, forgetting that it is only the unemployed who knows that such richness and contentment cannot fill his empty stomach. Even the fact that the basic ethical, social and religious norms cannot be blindly applied but need to be constantly adjusted to make it relevant to any evolving society has been totally forgotten.

If centuries of colonial exploitation and religion have played havoc, the socio-political atmosphere in the last few decades have virtually crippled the country, using every means - language, caste, creed, colour, religion, - to divide the country, seeding distrust and unrest between man and man and neighbour and neighbour. Rampant corruption, nepotism, unrest, selfishness, violence bred by the socio-political system have brought the nation to a grinding halt. None of us even doubted for a moment the integrity, honesty, sincerity and patriotism of our great freedom fighters like Pandit Nehru, who brought independence to this country, The present socio-political situation has﻿ degenerated to a point, where we are unable to accept the presence of honesty, even if it exists at some places. The paramount need of the country today, is to produce a new generation of statesmen, who will bring back to our vocabulary the words - duty, pride, honesty, sincerity, dedication and honour without such a suggestion being greeted with sarcasm or scorn. The need of the hour is "to take care of the stomach of the living than the glory of the departed in the form of monuments.”

What needs to be done ?

Notwithstanding the seemingly insurmountable problems the nation is faced with, I do not subscribe to the doomsday syndrome. The affairs of the nation can certainly be put into a new order provided we, as a nation, demonstrate the political will and work towards the progress of the nation with complete sincerity and dedication to enable our nation to occupy its rightful place of pride in the community of nations. The existing state of scarcity and social structure of inequity can certainly be abolished by the judicious use of appropriate science and technology, based on sound scientific and economic evaluation. On close examination, we would often find that the adoption of the most sophisticated technology may enable us to take a quantum jump to achieve rapid﻿ transformation of a dormant society. For such rapid transformation to occur the society as a whole must imbibe true scientific spirit and steadfastly work towards its assimilation into its culture fabric. We have to reaffirm our faith in what Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, the great architect of modern India firmly believed that "science alone can solve the • problems of hunger and poverty, insanitation and illiteracy, of superstition and deadening customs and tradition, of vast resources running to waste, of a rich country inhabited by starving people".

The remarkable achievements in science and technology, in particular, the release of energy from the atom, remarkable growth in electronics and materials, the emerging biotechnology revolution and the spectacular developments in space, offer a new beacon of hope to all developing societies. New technologies are becoming available for tapping abundant sources of energy such as solar, nuclear, wind, tidal and geothermal resources in nature. The rapia developments in genetic engineering and biotechnology hold the best promise to initiate yet another green revolution. The vast and unlimited benefits from space technology which already extend over communication, meteorology, TV transmission, education, agriculture, industrial growth, resource management, environmental protection, disaster mitigation, flood and﻿ drought management, health and entertainment, virtually touching every facet of human endeavour, needs to be increasingly exploited. Space by virtue of its ability to provide instantaneous access to even remotest corners of the nation, has already shrunk time and distance by initiating a communication revolution in the country. Space imageries have 'enabled us to dilineate underground acquifier potential, monitor soil health and identify the extent and type of wasteland at village level, half of which amounting to almost 25 m. ha can be reclaimed for productive agricultural use. Continuous weather watch, flood and cyclone monitoring and disaster warning systems are now regularly used to save thousands of lives, just as repetitive monitoring of vegetation health from space provides the necessary advance warning of drought to take appropriate remedial measures.

The crisis of continuous global warming and resulting irreversible climatic changes predicted for the coming decades, which is threatening the very survival of human and biotic species on this planet, can and will have to be averted by the worldwide implementation of appropriate environment friendly. strategies. Wide acceptance of the revised Montreal Protocol, which aims at controlling the increasing anthropogenic activities pumping various harmful gases into the atmosphere﻿ and affecting the entire green house equilibrium,' is undoubtedly a step in the positive direction. The new tools being provided by Science and Technology can lead to ecologically sustainable integrated development at micro level to ensure that this world will continue to be habitable for future generations.

I am convinced that scientists will discover alternate energy sources, find ecologically sound agricultural technologies and develop new varieties of seeds and genetic strains to enable hüman kind to survive even with limited land and water resources. Establishment of space platforms and even space habitats eventually leading to manufacture in space and exploitation of other planetary resources are already within our sight. Worldwide communication revolution, already initiated will bring the world closer with the help of large computer networks and artificial intelligence. I believe, within your own life time, you will be able to solve the great mystery of the origin of the universe, the unifying principle governing its evolution over the past billions of years and man's own position in the universe.The Role of Universities in the Changing Scenario

A fast changing technological scenario demands continual upgradation and change﻿ of our educational system, to make it more purposeful and relevant to suit the changing requirements of a society and to ensure its organic, self-reliant and holistic growth. Unless our universities are able to inculcate the interdisciplinary character in both basic and applied sciences, the universities will only produce a large breed of followers but not a generation of excellent innovators, who can participate fully in the "march of science, which is probably. mankind's greatest enterprise". Continuous adoptation of new system of disciplines is very essential to enable the graduates coming out of the universities to understand and appreciate the cybernatic relationship embodied in scientific and social systems.

The present university education and its examination system which has been reduced to imparting a collection of catalogued information needs a drastic reform aimed at provoking a logical thought process and the development of creative and innovative genius of the human mind. Innovative changes are produced only through new ideas and not by money and it is only such ideas that have the power of transformation. Only when the new generation realises that education is a continuing process which instead of ending, begins at the university level, it will be able to effectively deal with the rapid technological obsolescence and the﻿ nation will produce creators of jobs rather than mere seekers of jobs. We have to realise, to quote Alvin Toffler, "The technology of tomorrow requires not millions of highly lettered men, ready to work in unison at endlessly repeated 'jobs, not men who take orders in unblinking fashion, but men who can make critical judgements, who can weave their way through novel environments, who are quick to spot new relationships in the rapidly changing reality.”

Prevailing education system even in the industrially advanced countries has been seriously questioned as to its adequacy to meet the demands of the fast growing technology in a competitive world. Our own educational system with its age old rigid tradition, requires a fundamental change in its outlook, if graduates of the present day are to play their rightful role in the society. Even worse, is the ingress of politics into our educational system, which if left unchecked, will surely result in even our best institutions to degenerate and cease to be temples of excellence. Mediocrity in educational institutions can only end up multiplying mediocrity.

Excellence in institutions of higher learning can only be sustained when they are encouraged to carry out high quality research and development with the top quality scientists and engineers. While the financial allocation for scientific research and develop﻿ment, which at present is around 1% of the GNP of the country, needs to be atleast doubled, forging a closer interaction between academic institutions and industries, to work together in partnership, is essential to make the Indian industries' vibrant, dynamic and forward looking. Very few Indian industries, today support any significant research and development, unlike in developed nations where almost 50% of the funds required for research and development are supported by industries. We need policy controls which facilitate establishment of a new atmosphere of excellence and not licensing controls which have only promoted kit culture and made Indian industries look for quick returns by continuously relying on outside know-how.

While the essentiality of education for the liberation of human beings is well recognised, unless eradication of illiteracy is tackled on a war footing and not by mere slogan adoption, over 30% of our population will continue to remain illiterate even by the turn of this century. Clearly the answer lies not in simple linear expansion of educational facilities, but by widespread use of innovative, result-oriented technologies. New concepts involving dedicated "GRAMSAT" satellites specifically tailored to provide audio-visual education to the vast rural masses in health, hygiene, family planning, better agricultural practices and environment, are probably the answer for realising the dream of eradication of illiteracy within the next decade. If only our universities show an initiative, they can now play a positive lead role by adopting the new technologies to provide both continuing education to the new generation of graduates and in eradicating illiteracy in rural areas to enable the nation, as a whole to achieve a smooth transition into the next century.

Conclusion :

My young friends, you belong to the generation of the 21st century and it is in your hands to usher a new era of hope and abundance. What you need is new spirit of hope and confidence, as expressed by the great poet Kuvempu
ನಮಗಿಂದಿಗೆ ಬೇಕಾದುದು ಉದ್ದಾರದ, ಆಸಕ್ತಿ, ವಂತಿವಂತನೆ, ಓ ಮಾನವ, ಕಟಿ ಬಂಧನಗೈ, ನಿಲ್ಲು! ಯಂಗದೊಟ್ಟಿಗೆ ಜಗದೊಟ್ಟಿಗೆ ನಿನ್ನೊಳೊನ್ ನೀಂ reo!

I hope that the insight and light you have gained here will provide you with sufficient perception to tread safely into the unknown. Let the past be only a part of your history but not an example to blindly emulate. Look at the future with wide open mind and accept the technical challenges as they come. I believe there is a mystery cycle in human events. To some generations much is given, of other generations, like my own, much is expected; but it is your generation, with the﻿ responsibility of taking the country to the next century, which has rendezvous with destiny. I am convinced that you can achieve this goal, if you can substitute the inferiority complex developed through centuries with courage, hope, scientific rational and dedication. As Sir C. V. Raman said, "what is needed in India today is the destruction of the defeatist spirit. We need a spirit of victory, a spirit that will carry us on to our right place under the sun. A spirit which will recognise that we as inheritors of proud civilization are entitled for a rightful place on this planet. If that indomitable spirit were to arise, nothing can hold us from achieving our rightful destiny".

My young friends, I wish all of you a bright future and pray that you may be bestowed with necessary strength, courage and wisdom to face life with all its uncertainties, but full of challenges.﻿

CONVOCATION ADDRESS BY Dr MANMOHAN SINGH,
HỌN'BLE UNION MINISTER FOR FINANCE, GOVERNMENT OF INDIA, NEW DELHI.

Mr. Chancellor, Mr. Pro-Chancellor, Mr. Vice-Chancellor, Distinguished Guests, Learned Faculty', Alumni and Graduands:

I deem it a great privilege to deliver this convocation address to your University, a renowned seat of learning nestling in one of our most beautiful cities. On the occasion of your Platinum Jubilee, I join all of you in paying my homage to the late Sir M. Visves varayya, former Dewan . of Mysore, and to His Highness Nalvadi Krishnaraj Wodeyar who started and nourished this great University. Some of India's most illustrious sons have been associated with this University. I refer in particular to Dr. S. Radhakrishnan, Sardar K. M. Panikkar and Shri R. K. Narayan. The University has completed 75 years of outstanding service to the nation. I pray that its next 75 years will be even more productive and creative.

I remember my own convocation day as one of great elation-I then thought that it was the greatest day of my life. I have lived through stirring times, and my memory begins to blur. But the combination of achievement and hope that graduation represents﻿ makes the Convocation Day a landmark in all our lives.

What awaits you is not all roses. I would be surprised if mest of you did not leave the University with a nostalgia for the past and a certain fear of the future. If it were in my power at this moment to grant you a gift, I would make you a present of self-confidence.

The world you will enter is a different one from the one I walked into when I graduated. There was one aspect of the world of my youth that I treasure, an aspect I would greatly like to see restored : that somehow the society in which I lived and worked was more united, more naturally, unselfconsciously Indian than the one that is emerging today.

That all-permeating Indianness is still strong. My principal civil servants, for instance, come from four corners of India. One comes from Tamil Nadu, another from Kerala, one from Punjab and another from Gujarat ; and they have all sérved India in their own ways. The India in which I grew up, earned my livelihood, brought up my children--this India has meant much to me. I have regarded all of it as my home, and I could not have been at home anywhere else.

But in some important respects, that India is being questioned, challenged. My own home state is rent by strife over its Indianness, a strife that fills me with great sadness. Competitive politics has raised caste and communal tensions to a dangerous level in several parts of our country. There is more parochiality﻿ in the governments. Politics is ceasing to be a vehicle of purposeful social change. Even industry finds its cosmopolitan character under threat of erosion. This is what I find most disturbing, even more for you than for myself. You have the future of this country in your hands; I would urge you to work to restore its Indianness, its instinctive unity.

There is another important respect which requires urgent national attention. I refer to the visible signs of erosion of national self-confidence and to the need for strong corrective action.

The sense of confident nationhood was the most palpable characteristics of the era of my youth. Our leaders - Gandhiji. Nehru, Patel-had this confidence in great abundance ;' they had no doubts about the potential of this nation. or about its ability to look after itself. They were, infact alergic dependence and its consequences--to sycophancy on the one hand and truculence on the other. The one thing they tried to impart to the country was selfconfidence and self-respect. Their influence is still strong and their example would continue to inspire us to look the world in the face. But it must be admitted that cf late there has been a weakening of this feeling of self-confidence. A feeling has grown that somehow we Indians are inferior to other nations, that we cannot compete against other countries in the global markets, that therefore we must build strong protective walls to insulate oui economy from outside competition. I regard this feeling of lack of self-confidence﻿ a major barrier to the realization of India's immense development potential.

The leaders of our national struggle had faith in our nation, and the greatest homage we can pay. them would be if we could restore the nation's belief in itself--not simply restore it, but revivify, rediscover, and redesign it. Let me illustrate what I mean by taking examples from the fields which I know well.

Take, for instance, the area of trade. Industrialists in this country are blessed with many advantages that other countries do not enjoy. Our wage costs are very low.. Our food prices are generally lower than elsewhere. We grow some of the world's best cotton at extremely competitive costs. Our raw materials, whether it is ironore or coal or bauxite or bamboo, are available at throwaway prices.

But even with these advantages, the idea of our industry competing with industry abroad encounters resistance. Our important duties are amongst the highest in the world. We are trying to reduce them. We have reduced the peak duties to 110 per cent in the last budget. With this, the duties on some products have fallen to the same level as the duties on their inputs. This appears to some of our industrialists as unreasonable. They argue that their products must bear a duty that is at least 20 per cent higher than the duty on their components and raw materials. But if they made full use of the cheap labour and raw materials available in this country, it is not﻿ they but their competitors abroad that should need protection.

Excessive protection of industry and import substitution regardless of cost have created a pattern of industrialization which generates few additional jobs. It has sheltered monopolies and accentuated disparities in income and wealth. Protection entails a subsidy given to the producer at the cost of the consumer. Heavy protection granted to industry has constituted massive discrimination against agriculture ; no wonder that the disparities in living standards between rural and urban India have increased over time.

Industries and firms may be protected to correct inequalities in competition. If firms are new or small they may deserve protection until they can compete on equal terms. But they should not become permanent infants. It is important not to equate protection with patriotism and trade with sin. Glorification of autarky can do our country enormous harm. India has a fairly diversified natural resource endowment but it has to be recognized that on a per capita basis we are not well endowed with natural resources. Thus India has to become a major international trading nation if its development potential is to be realized in full measure.

With our manpower, with our natural resources, we can capture considerable, share of markets in the world. We can be the world's leading exporters of tropical goods, textiles, steel and engineering goods. With larger exports we can import materials from elsewhere and become competitive manufacturers of goods﻿ for which we do not have cheap inputs - electronic goods, chemicals, wooden and metal handicrafts. Export activity would generate production and employment in our own country. We would not need to send our workers abroad to work under arduous conditions ; they could make a gainful living in India itself. With a more dynamic economy, the graduates of our institutes of science and technology will not need to migrate to foreign lands in such large numbers. I cannot help feeling that our problems of poverty and unemployment would bocome much more tractable if we paid greater attention to the exploitation of the world market.

Trade also has political implications. Japan and Germany are major world powers today. not because of powerful armies or lethal weapons, but because of their trade with the world. As the world prospers, they will inevitably prosper ; on the other hand, they are so important to the world that the world cannot. let them go down. The world has a stake in a country in proportion to its international trade. Our share in world trade has declined from 3 per cent in 1950 to half a per cent today. The result is that the world's stake in our welfare and prosperity is minimal today.

Our country has been in serious economic trouble in the last two years. We have looked for help from outside. Irrespective of their political colour. irrespective of their nationalist postures at home. finance ministers have travelled abroad in search of support. Yet they got very little. The reason is not that the world is unduly hardhearted towards﻿ us, but that our importance to the world has diminished. Our place in the world is not measured by the size of our population or our arsenal, but by the goods and services we export and import. India sits astride the busiest trade lanes of the world. All the sea and air traffic between the east and the west pases along its seaways and airways. But little of it originates or ends in India. It is my hope that this trade will not simply pass us by, and that we shall take our rightful share of it.

But the world outside cannot be forced to take our goods and services; it must be coaxed to do so. We have to produce the goods the world wants, up to the quality standards that it demands, with the techniques it finds acceptable. This is where we need not only to have knowledge of the world. but to use it in ways it recognises. Our country has imported technologies on a considerable scale. We have sent thousands abroad to be trained. But if we want to learn at home how pepole work and produce abroad, it is also possible to do so by letting people from abroad come and show us; and one way to get a live demonstration is to invite them to set up enterprises in India.

come

The idea of foreign direct investment generates considerable heat in our country. It is evident that there are large corporations in world, and that they can play a role in the foreign policies of their home countries. One should not be unmindful of the possibility that their interests may conflict with our﻿ national interests. But their power should not be exaggerated; nor should our ability to protect our interests be belittled. The East India Company had acquired control of a large part of east-west trade by means of a control of trade routes, ports, centres of production and markets. No multinational corporation of today comes close to acquiring that kind of control. Further, the Government today has more means and more knowledge to regulate the activities of foreign enterprises in the national interest. This is what independence means; this is what independence should be used for- not for cutting ourselves off from the global production system, but to interact with it for our own benefit.

And worldwide, direct investment is not a monopoly of large transnational corporations ; more often, it is small, knowledge-intensive firms that make the most difference. For instance, small Japanese firms driven out of production by rising wages have gone to Malaysia and made it the world's biggest exporter of rubber gloves. Italian shoemakers looking for new opportunities have provided the backbone of the highly successful Brazilian shoe exports. Mysore and its surroundings today produce some of the finest silks. The most expensive garment in the world is the Japanese silk kimono. Why should not Japanese pattern-makers come and make kimonos out of Mysore silk?

For trade, technology and investment are not the only things the world can give us ; there is a world full of knowledge outside. There are books, journals﻿ that inform and educate ; and with the advent of electronic communications, new means of knowledge are arising. The creation of knowledge is a global process involving universities, research institutes, industries and inventors.

We too can participate in this process with enormous benefit. For much of this knowledge is available at costs for lower than we would incur to produce it, and the value that can be produced by using that knowledge is vast multiple of the cost of the knowledge. It is shortsighted to try import substitution in knowledge at whatever cost. It can do considerable harm to our technologieal dynamism. It can cut India off from the community of nations where knowledge grows in an ordered framework. The successful absorption, assimilation and adaptation of available knowledge is a critical aspect of development. It is a necessary precursor to the stage where we can ourselves generate new knowledge. India needs a strong research and development base to emerge as a front-ranking nation in the world. We must 'spend more on research and development. Our scientists and technologists ought to be provided with facilities comparable to those available abroad. But R & D must have a proper focus. We ought to pay particular attention to areas which have hitherto been neglected, where we cannot depend on foreigners to generate new knowledge and where new knowledge can make a major contribution to the enhancement of India's development pctential and the improvement of living conditions of our masses. I refer in particular to the need for stronger R & D﻿ efforts in the areas of agriculture, post-harvest technologies, rural development, primary health care, renewable sources of energy and control of environmental degradation.

So how are we to regain our self-confidence, to restore our self-reliance ? Self-reliance should not mean self-defeating withdrawal and futile confrontation, it should mean thinking for oneself. An essential element in restoring the spirit of self-reliance must be to change the policy environment which gave sanctified withdrawal and glorified confrontation, and to open our country again to the winds of change. Self-confidence comes from practice, from successful adaptation to change ; for adaptation, change has to be invited into our country.

This is what we have been engaged in doing in our recent policy initiatives. The intention behind the initiatives is not to betray our nation, nor to weaken its resolve for creative self-réliance. It is to broaden the arena for our productive forces, to bring the best out of them by raising the level of challenge, to make our resources more productive and to distribute the fruits of that productivity more equitably. Whatever the intentions of our policymakers, their ability to help the poor and the weak is fettered today by the generally low levels of incomes, the limited reach of the state and the absorption of its resources in less deserving uses. Stimulating the growth of production, removing the bias in favour of capital-intensity, giving a fairer deal to agriculture, making producers compete for rewards﻿ these things are not foreign devilry but meaning of self-reliance.

But practice is helped by example, and action by resolve. For this leadership our nation will look to you, to young men and women whom it has educated at much cost. I would invite you-I would challenge you-to look at the world with frank and confident eyes, and to translate the lessons it holds into a better life for our people. In this great endeavour you will have my enduring good wishes. May your path be blessed.﻿

CONVOCATION ADDRESS BY PROF. ERIC
R. GILBERTSON, PRESIDENT, SAGINAW VALLEY STATE UNIVERSITY, UNIVERSITY
CENTER, MICHIGAN, U. S. A.

Your Excellency the Governor, Honorable Pro-Chancellor, Honorable Vice-Chancellor, Distinguished Members of the Syndicate and the Senate, Respected Members of the Faculty and honored graduates, ladies and gentlemen, my friends:

I am deeply grateful for the honor of addressing you on this very important day in the life of your University and in the lives of its graduates.

I bring you greetings from the academic community of my University, my State of Michigan and my nation. I know that your invitation to me is also a gesture of respect and friendship to my University, and this too is deeply appreciated and sincerely reciprocated.

There must be something deep in the human instinct that moves pepple, in virtually all the varieties of human cultures, to create ceremonies to mark the important moments and changes in our lives-births, religious commitments, weddings, funerals,﻿ celebrations of achievement. The American humorist, H. L. Mencken, called this "the immemorial tendency of mankind to concoct rituals.” And so it is with convocations like this one and like all those graduation ceremonies which occur in our sister educational institutions throughout all the continents of the world.

But we know-especially those of us closely associated with institutions so deeply grounded in tradition, like universities that our traditions, rituals and ceremonies truly are important. They give us a sense of identity and continuity across the years and the generations; they serve to remind us of the importance of events and accomplishments; they reaffirm and give dignity to important values in our cultures, values at the core of the university's reason for being-such as the imperative of courage and integrity in the search for truth, the duty of each generation to transmit the best of its knowledge and wisdom and culture to the next, the dignity of personal and intellectual achievement.

And so, for now and for these few moments, it is altogether right and proper that we pause to note the passing of time and the important changes taking place in your lives and in the life of this distinguished University by coming together﻿ in this ceremony-officials, teachers, students, friends and relatives we hold most dear-to honor our acadèmic traditions, to celebrate your academic achievement, to share our hope for the future...and for however brief a time, to reflect upon what meaning we might ascribe to these things.

In my country at such ceremonies it is customary for a representative of one generation to address the graduates from the next, purporting to offer perspective or wisdom hard earned through the trials and errors of his or her generation's experience. Hope endures, even in the face of all historical evidence to the contrary, that the speaker on such an auspicious occasion will say something that leaves' a lasting impression, something that reveals some profound truth or instills some lofty thought.

But, alas, with due humility, I also know that those of you about to graduate are likely to be preoccupied at this inoment with other thoughts of family and friends, of plans and perhaps even of your own celebrations. But I know that you leave your studies here with a sense of gratitude for opportunity that has been yours. You have been well taught and you learned well, and on behalf of the generations before you I offer sincere congratulations. And together we pray for your happiness and the fulfillment of your promise as individuals and as a generation.

THE UNIVERSITY ... OUR CHOSEN
INSTRUMENT OF HOPE

At some American universities, new graduates are solemnly welcomed "to the company of educated men and women.” That strikes me as a bit pretentious and conceited, for we find educated people in all stations of life, from a wide variety of backgrounds and with a wide variety of intelligences. Academic institutions surely have no monopoly on the production of truly educated people.

We also know, poignantly, that mere graduation from a university - however distinguished-does not ensure that a person is truly educated. And, in some ways, to be truly educated means only that we are more fully aware of our own ignorance.

The Father of this great nation, Mahatma Gandhi, had only a limited faith in universities--once even declaring that he was "an enemy of higher education as it is given in this country," primarily because of what he saw then as universities too eager to mimic foreign cultures while neglecting things genuinely Indian,

All our universities have critics today who find fault in what we teach and how we teach it, and in our occasional arrogance. Universities need critics, and those of us who﻿ know universities best are usually among those critics-though we are loving critics, for we also know best our universities' great strengths, their great potential for good. Universities are, flaws and all, still the chosen instruments of my society and yours for the fullest development of precious human talent.
