Universities are, flaws and all, still the chosen instruments of my society and yours for the improvement of life and the discovery of truth.

Such is the secular faith of my society and of yours-a faith in the value of education.

Thomas Jefferson—the author of my country's Declaration of Independence and its third president-first and best expressed these thoughts for Americans: That open opportunity for individuals to better themselves through education was indispensable not just for economic prosperity but also for the survival of democracy. Only through such open opportunity could a nation ensure that the natural aristocracy of the talented” might emerge to defeat the "artificial" aristocracy of privilege and wealth. This is an idea and an ideal that was and is vital to social and political democracy.

And India's educational policy of 1913 and the platinum jubilee anniversary of your distinguished University both stand as moving﻿ testimony to your State's and your Nation's commitment to this same principle--the importance of opportunity for your people.

Those of us who serve these universities, these chosen instruments, also have a special responsibility. We know that institutions like ours are fragile-even as truth is fragile. They exist by public sufferance and with public support even as they are determinedly free to criticize the conventional wisdom, the status quo and the powerful interests. Yet they remain the most precious assets of our societies-worthy of our care, our fierce defense, our deep affection.

We who have enjoyed the benefits of the university are still among a privileged few. Therefore, this moment, this ceremony, should inspire us to pause and consider what this means to be educated-what special gifts and what special responsibilities does this privilege confer or impose ?

TO BE EDUCATED ... UNDERSTANDING
CHANGE AND WHAT IS CHANGELESS

Education at its best prepares people for change. And in this, our time, changetechnological change, demographic change, political and diplomatic and economic change-is relentless and pervasive and ever accelerating. We ignore the tides of change only at our great peril.﻿

Still, there is much about life in our World that is relatively unchanging-we may call this the "human condition." Whatever the chosen professions of you graduates-medicine, law, the sciences, education, whatever--you will likely spend far more of your time and energy and agony puzzling over the vexing mysteries of your fellow humans than you will over matters in your technical expertise. You will wonder what makes them do the things they do, why they cannot or will not change or why they change too quickly, how reason or emotion collide in personal and political or organizational busincss. And even as individuals struggle to understand and deal with one another, whole nations and huge social organisms likewise worry and scheme in life's larger and more dangerous arenas.

Beyond mankind's fascination with the natural and physical universe, man's principal fascination is still with man himself. And so it has been since the authors of our classicswhether Kalidasa's "Shakuntala" or Homer's e The Illiad "--and the authors of our sacred texts—whether the Vedas or the Koran or the Bible all tried to explain the common aspects of our common humanity. And it is that common and relatively unchanging humanity that makes these classics and sacred texts still so relevant to our understanding of ourselves and one another today.﻿

The themes of our art and literature are the themes of everyman's life : love, hope, wonder, disappointment, the passing of time, our universally human conflicts between passion and reason, between' ethics and ambition, between the illusion of immortality and the fear of death. These things are at the essence of what it means to be human; these are the things we share best through our arts and literature. And sharing these things brings us together across the barriers of language and geography and generations. Sharing these things reminds us we are not alone in this life.

Education, at its best, has taught us to understand and prepare for change, but also to understand things that are timeless and enduring.

TO BE EDUCATED ... DISCERNING
DIFFERENCES BUT UNDERSTANDING
ALL WE SHARE

Education, at its best, does teach us to make critical distinctions between things and ideas-distinctions that may be camouflaged at a superficial level. There are critical differences between facts and ideas and systems of government and culture and faith. To be educated surely means to have the sophisticated capacity to discern and understand sometimes subtle but nonetheless critical differences.﻿

But at least equally important, education should also teach us to see and understand our similarities, our sameness as humans on this small planet. We share so much ... and we are not alone.

I remember first developing a keen interest in and affection for India as a small boy. One of my favorite television programs was about an Indian boy-I only wish I could now remember his name. But I do clearly remember that he was portrayed as having a pet elephant and living in a land of fierce lions and majestic Bengal tigers. His world seemed so different from mine, so dangerous and so exotic-yet somehow I could share his dreams, his sense of danger, his hurt feelings, his love for family and friends. I felt that I knew him well ... he was my. friend.

Later, having had the opportunity to know and make personal friends from India, I learned that they had likewise been entertained with images of American youths—and they imagined that we all lived as cowboys in the "Wild West," that our lives were like those fictional characters portrayed by John Wayne and later Clint Eastwood.

How little we really knew of one another's lives and cultures—but still how well we seemed to understand the very﻿ human experiences and feelings that we shared in common.

Here today I am struck not by the differences between our nations and our peoples--as large and real as these truly are-but rather by the similarities.

Political values

We share many of the same political values. The Indian Constitution and the Constitution of the United States contain so many similar or even identical words and phrases expressing so many common values—"We the People” both cherish freedom of speech and expression, freedom to assemble peaceably, the rights to life and liberty and the procedures established by law, the freedom to profess and practice religious beliefs, equality before the law. Your Constitution's commitment to "justice” and the "dignity of the individual” are also reflected in our nation's precious "Declaration of Independence.”

The fabric of our political values are almost as if cut from the same bolt of cloth.

Search for place in New World Order

Each of our nations is at this point in history searching for a new diplomatic and military role in what some are calling es the New World Order”-though the term﻿ chaos" may be a more accurate descriptor than "order." It is a World no longer dominated by a cruel American-Soviet competition for influence and hegemony, a World in which other nations were unfairly forced to choose between friendship with one or the other. But today it is also a World more' unstable and in many ways even more dangerous.

It is a World less threatened by the fear of massive nuclear holocaust, but a World in which man's inhumanity to man is no less painful or lethal-witness the recent tragedies in Kuwait, in Somalia, in Bosnia.

And each of our nations is struggling, under new leadership, with economic dilemmas. Yours is how to harness a superb technological capability with an ample labor force to improve the lives of your people. Ours is how to discipline and reinvigorate what was once the World's most productive economy in order to succeed in peaceful competition with new economic powers in a united Europe and a Japan-dominated Pacific Rim.

And both our nations are struggling, under new leadership, to determine whether these democracies--ours the oldest and yours the largest in the World-can be disciplined to constrain military spending, to reduce public debt and to repair the maldistribution of its wealth.

Faith and a secular state

We share a belief in the importance of a secular state, but still we are both a religious people. And we share a faiththough called by different names and expressed in different rituals, our shared faith is that human lives do have meaning, that the divine virtues of love and humility and forgiveness can redeem our human flaws, that shorn of our petty differences and disagreements we are indeed all brothers and sisters. The teachings of the Vedas and the Ramayana, the teachings of Moses and Jesus, of the prophet Mohammed and the Buddha, all affirm these great lessons and these great hopes.

There are those in both of our societies who_in the name of religious faith, whether Christianity or Islam or Hinduism-would use the power of the State to impose their beliefs or to limit the rights of those who do not agree with their specific dogmas. And there are other societies and nations where such an unholy alliance of religion and government have done violence to that most basic of human rights the freedom of conscience. They show us the dangers of such an alliance.﻿

But as our Constitutions make clear, the founding fathers of both our countries well understood these dangers. Both had seen, painfully, how religion could be appropriated to misuse the powers of government. Both were also men and women of faith themselves—but people who also understood that true religious faith must be freely accepted and expressed, that true religious faith should not, could not, be imposed by force of government.

Forsaken ideals and their price

Finally, and even while relations between India ,and the United States have in recent history been sometimes close and sometimes strained, we share many common aspects of our histories. Our nations each emerged through a heroic struggle from the oppressions of colonialism-whether the tyrannies of King George or the tyrannies of the East India Company and the British raj. India was born in non-violent revolution, even as America was born in rebelion, and both nations made great sacrifices for their freedom

Each of our, nations is founded upon noble ideals, but each has also failed these ideals-as with the shame of racism in the United States and the shame of religious intolerance in India.﻿

And both our nations still pay dearly for those sins-we pay with lives and with hatred.

Perhaps we have yet to learn what the authors of the American Declaration of Independence said--that "All men are created equal." And perhaps we have yet to learn the lesson from Mahatma Gandhi, who once said that the Harijans too are the children of God.

TO BE EDUCATED ... TO AFFIRM HOPE

But to be educated means also to recognize that while we as societies and as individuals--are the products of our history, we need not necessarily remain the prisoners of that history. The idea and the ideals of education, and institutions like ours, stand for the fundamental proposition that people can learn, people can understand, people can be changed, freed from their worst traits and instincts: And in so doing people can become not just more competent but more compassionate, not just more prosperous but more kind, not just more powerful but more humane.

To be educated to believe in and to care about education-means to affirm such hope.

This was the hope of Abraham Lincoln who, nearing the end of my nation's tragic Civil War and nearing the end of his life,﻿ implored us with these great words : "With malice toward none, with charity toward all, with firmness in the right as God gives us to see that right, let us ... do all which may achieve and cherish a just and lasting peace among ourselves and with all nations.”

It may be easy for cynics, who witness history's repeated tragedies, to dismiss such hopes, as impractical or 'naive. And it is true--mankind has, throughout his history, practiced greed, revenge, hatred. But education must still give us hope-hope that we need not be prisoners of our passions, prisoners of our history.

Lincoln's hopes survived the horrors of slavery, the horrors of bloody battles at places like Antietam and Gettysburg.

This was, of course, also the hope of Mahatma Gandhi-that, to use Biblical phrases as he sometimes did, the lion would someday lie down with the lamb, that swords would be beaten into plowshares, that the meek would inherit the Earth. This was a hope that did not die at Chauri Chaura; it could not be killed, even by General Dyer at Amritsar.

And this was the hope of Gandhi's disciple, Martin Luther King, Jr., who thirty years ago spoke eloquently of his dream of a just and a decent society based on principles of fairness and the love of brotherhood.﻿

King's dream endured the indignities of segregated schools and brutal beatings, the squalid jail cells of Selma, Alabama.

And the hopes of Mahatma Gandhi and Lincoln and King-powerful ideas that move us still today-all were not extinguished when they were taken from us at Ford's Theater or in the garderr at Birla House or at a motel in Memphis, Tennessee. As Nehru said of Gandhi, theirs "was no ordinary light.'

Their lessons for us are as old as time and as young as the birth of the human spirit in each new child-they speak of the horrors of hate and the power of love ... and of hope.

I am told that the Hindus have a legend concerning a mythical bird, called Bherunda. As I understand the story, the bird has a single body but two necks, two heads, and two separate consciousnesses. After an eternity together, these two heads come to hate each other. Both swallow pebbles and poison to injure the other but, of course, the whole bird dies a painful death. It is brought back to life through the mercy of Lord Krishna and thus reminds us that hatred harms nou only the object of that hatred, but, perhaps even more, the one who hates.

And hatred feeds upon itself, it builds. The Czech writer and statesman, Vaclav Havel, once observed that " Collective hatred﻿ shared, spread and deepened by people capable of hatred, has a special magnetic attraction and therefore has the power to attract countless other people..... We must struggle energetically against all forms of collective hatred not only on principal, because evil must always be dealt with, but in our own interests.”

This is the lesson today for Sarajevo and for Beirut and Mogadishu. And this is the lesson today for the streets of Los Angeles and of Ayodhya.

We find ourselves together here todayat this point in time and space and circumstance-as recipients of the most precious privilege our societies offer, the privilege of a university education. As educated people we must also join together. in hope-the hope of Mahatma Gandhi and Lincoln and King for peaceful and caring societies, the hope of our generations and yours for a World free from aggression and nuclear terror, the hope of the founders of your University and mine and universities everywhere that the education you received will enable you to live life more fully and well.

And I join today in the hope of your teachers here, and of their colleague teachers everywhere, that you, the educated, will practice your professions and live your lives﻿ so as to give hope to others-respecting the dignity of their persons and the sanctity of their souls, the bonds that tie us together as brothers and sisters of this human family.

Thank you.
